The competitive world has caused technologies to improve rapidly in the 21st century .
One of the advancements in technology would be surveillance technology .
The concerns for safety and security have increased the extent of use of the surveillance systems .
Despite the proper usage of surveillance technology , there is a widespread abuse of the technology by some criminal organizations .
Hence , the potential for abuse increases .
Surveillance technology has been used as a tool for illegitimate activities which in turn threatens public safety and security .
This issue has become a main topic in public discussion .
Thus , due to the risk of misuse of surveillance technology , I fully concur that the use of surveillance technology should be banned .
First and foremost , surveillance technology such as Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) has been used as a tool for hackers and identity thieves to commit " 'contactless' "crime against victims without their consent (Lewan , 2009) .
RFID chip is largely used in some official identification documents such as driver's license and passport in America .
Once the RFID number is intercepted , it is possible for the criminals to track the movements of their targets without their knowledge .
Additionally , it has been concluded that the use of RFID has no benefit on the achievement of national security , but it resulted in an increment in risk of personal privacy and security (Lewan , 2009) .
Hence , the use of RFID should be discontinued .
In conclusion , surveillance technology should be banned as it has been misused by people for illegal activities .
The misuse of surveillance technology not only invades users' privacy but also increases the risk to personal and national security .
There are many types of genetic testing , such as late-onset disorders and newborn screening .
Genetic testing allows early detection of diseases , which  may be useful to mankind .
However , genetic testing has brought about issues if such genetic results are revealed and abused .
Thus , I agree that the individual requesting genetic testing should have the final say in whether to reveal the results of such testing .
First , we will discuss  the relationship between employees and their employer's organisation .
There is tension between employees and employers regarding genetic testing .
(Stephen , 2003) .
If genetic testing indicates susceptibility  of an employee to diseases , there is a  chance  that the employer will dismiss the employee .
This is supported by the fact that most people with disabilities or diseases are discriminated against .
Most companies are not willing to employ them as they may be seen to be inefficient because of their disabilities .
Thus , genetic results should not be revealed to protect people from losing their jobs .
Opponents to this position may argue that such results should be revealed to protect the employer from an employee who is vulnerable  to illness .
(Stephen , 2003) .
However , the primary basis of employment should be work performance and efficiency , rather than on genetic testing .
(Kankowski & Capron ,1991) .
Hence , individuals should have the final say to protect them from  that may harm them .
(Stephen , 2003) .
Next , a further difficulty issue involves revealing of genetic results to insurance companies .
(Stephen , 2003) .
Applicants will be at a disadvantage when applying for insurance .
For example , if genetic results are revealed , the cost of the insurance will be expensive such that it may not be worth it .
Critics of this position claim that insurers will also be at a disadvantage if such results are not revealed to them .
(Stephen , 2003) .
I must admit that the insurer will be at a disadvantage if the situation is switched .
However , the cost of insurance should be on the current medical status of the applicant and should not be on the results of the genetic testing .
Genetic testing is a test performed to allow genetic diagnosis of inherited diseases .
Not only so , genetic testing (fingerprinting) is also used to determine the child's paternity .
[1] Genetic testing does have many advantages in today's society .
In the society today , many have debated whether we really have the right to have the final say whether to reveal the results of the testing as many will think that it will lead to many ethical and social issues .
Or is it that it is a must to reveal it due to reality and we , individuals do not have the final say to reveal our testing to the public .
In my  opinion , in the high technology society we are living in , we do not have the final say in revealing of our genetic results to the public .
Companies do have the right to know the genetic testing results of an individual who is applying for the job offered by them .
For companies that offer jobs that require physical strength , it will be necessary to obtain the genetic testing of the individual .
For example , if one have inherited genetic disease like muscle dystrophy , it will be dangerous for them to work in the construction site .
Accidents might occur and it may also result in death .
Although many have debated that this is discrimination as companies may not employ those who has inherited diseases , but companies do have the right to choose employees with concern for their profits and the safety of others .
Individuals that may inherit genetic diseases should not choosejobs that are beyond their reach .
Hence companies instead of the individuals have the right to know the genetic testing of the individual .
A spouse does have the right to know the family disease of their partner .
If a couple is planning to have a child , it is best for them to go through genetic counseling if the parents are carriers of genetic disease [2] .
It will be unfair if the one kept the truth from their spouse .
The spouse does have the right to know whether the child will suffer from the genetic diseases .
This is a basic respect towards your partner in a marriage .
It is a must to declare it  and thus individuals do not have the final say in revealing of their genetic results to the third party .
The education sector  does have the right to know the genetic testing of their  students .
Those with genetic diseases like mental retardation and Down syndrome are asked to be enrolled in schools like MINDS and bright sparks .
Some may debate that this is a form of discrimination and violates the human rights of these children .
However , according to the American Association for mental retardation AAMR [3] , revealing of genetic testing results is not a form of discrimination but it is to be fair to those children with these genetic diseases as the children will be enrolled into the school that provides a better environment for them to study in .
It is a must to provide the school with the genetic testing result .
Hence individuals do not have the final say in revealing of their genetic results to the public .
All in all , in my  opinion , in the high technology society we are living in , we do not have the final say in revealing of our genetic results to the public .
It may not be a disadvantage and can even benefit many people based on the points mentioned above .
Thus individuals requesting  genetic testing do not have the final say in whether to reveal the results of such testing .
With rapid technological advancement , myriad forms of surveillance technology have surfaced and people are using it both intensively and extensively .
From forms as high level as satellite surveillance to the common Radio Frequency Identification Device (RFID) , surveillance technology has served us well .
However , due to the improper exploitation of it , surveillance technology has become more  detrimental than beneficial .
Intrusion of privacy and upsetting of the various balances in society are concerns people are increasingly worried about .
Hence , with so much discomfort people are experiencing with surveillance technology , it should be banned .
Due to the immense usage of surveillance technology , the society has become relatively transparent .
On the intangible aspects , information of individuals can be easily retrieved with the ease of data mining (Easton , 2006) .
With high speed connections and data transfer rate nowadays , an enormous bulk of data can be moved around in a very short period .
Classified information like credit card , banking and medical records can get into the wrong hands , producing many repercussions .
(Easton , 2006) Identity theft is flagrant and many more will suffer from financial losses .
Moreover , as RFID technology becomes increasingly popular with the retailers , privacy of consumers is again compromised .
(Hariton , 2006)The tags are usually not "killed" and this allows consumers' movement to be tracked and habits to be observed .
(Hariton , 2006) This thorough understanding of consumers has certainly gone overboard .
Last but not least , biometric surveillance has given checkpoints the capability to monitor people down to the skin .
(Monahan , 2006) Evolved surveillance here is so revealing that people appear literally naked on screens .
Furthermore , surveillance technology has created many  and upsets in the balance of our society .
Society will see the rise of discriminations since the entire background of an individual can be easily traced .
Dates cancelled , different standards in pricing of insurance premiums and harassment of political dissidents are just a few to mention .
(Easton , 2006) Next , surveillance technology also widens the gap between the rich and the poor .
The rich can afford to encrypt and protect their data while engaging in better surveillance over the less well off .
Moreover , by selling information (Easton , 2006) , the rich will get richer .
With regards to RFID , usage mentioned earlier  will reduce the variety of products available in stores because retailers will only consider the better selling items .
Society will witness a smorgasbord of changes in the various balances and the birth of more deviants such as stalkers .
Therefore , with all the worrisome disadvantages  surveillance technology will bring , we ought to ban it .
It makes privacy lose its meaning and is unhealthy for our society .
Consequences will be disastrous if we do not put an end to it .
With the revelation of human's DNA structure by Watson and Crick in 1953 , it shows that there will be a totally new science and engineering related subject being brought to the world , which is genetic engineering .
By utilizing the sophisticated technology tools , together with the perseverance of researchers , many genetics related approaches have been made possible .
One of the noted breakthroughs is genetic testing .
However , the advent of genetic testing does not bring unanimous consent from the public .
There are uproars regarding the moral and ethical issues which cloud the topic of genetic testing from time to time .
Some think that the individual requesting genetic testing should have the final say in disclosure of the results .
In fact , individuals requesting genetic testing should not have the final say as they would possibly make wrong decisions .
First of all , if the individuals get diagnosed with hereditary genetic disease , they will probably be overwhelmed by guilt or anxiety , thereby making a wrong decision , which is nondisclosure of their results within families .
It is primarily caused by the desire of protecting family members from troubling information .
Conversely , siblings of the subjects should be told immediately as they may carry the same genetic disease as the subjects' .
Some diseases are treatable in the presymptomatic stage .
Therefore , the siblings must know it so that treatment could be administered as soon as possible .
The general practitioner , who is the one they are consulting and also experienced in handling this kind of case , definitely has the final say to make a more rational decision for them .
After that , parents who request genetic testing for their children must provide the genetic information of their children to school authorities for the enrollment .
This aims to divide the group of children according to their learning skill and to ensure that every single child is provided with the most appropriate education .
Individuals requesting genetic testing usually decide not to disseminate their genetic information as discrimination may be put forth to their lives .
In fact , there is one of the federal laws that has been applied to genetics nondiscrimination which is Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act of 2008 (GINA) .
Besides forbidding the employers making adverse employment decisions , GINA also prohibits insurance companies reducing their coverage and pricing on the basis of information derived from genetic tests .
Thus , there is no fear of revealing the genetic results .
On the other hand , individuals are responsible to inform employers about their genetic conditions so that a better and safer working environment could be provided .
Finally , it has been said that individuals should have the final say on not disclosing their genetic information for research purposes .
Indeed , research teams should have a direct access to the genetic results so that the further genetic sequence on DNA could be unmasked in a faster pace .
As a result , individuals must provide their genetic information .
Ultimately , individuals requesting genetic testing should not have the final say in disclosure of their results .
This is because individual  is less capable of making a suitable decision .
It may end up with not only affecting one's life , but also influencing a few generations .
Hence , by having a requirement to reveal the genetic results , rational decisions will often be made to the benefit of the individual as a group discussion always comes up with fruitful conclusion .
Genetic testing will bring about many consequences .
First , by doing genetic testing , people may be able to discover about their genetic disease early .

In addition , the result may be emssing and can affect their prestige .
For exampmana man has mutation in his gene and the takes the genetic testing one day and finds out the truth about his condition .ave the final say to reveal the result or hold it (Wertz , 2001) .
However , in the reality , the result of genetic testing is so important and could give impact to all his fmay be present may comprise information about hereditary disease .

Therefore , the final say should not be in individual but the whole family .
Genetic testing has become a common practice in the modern society .
Its general purpose is to check if one has the potential to develop certain genetic diseases .
However , this has brought about many debates on  ethical issues in  society .
Some argued that individuals who have requested the genetic testing should have the final say about revealing their test results so as to preserve individual's rights .
However , this will have a  negative impact on  society .
Thus , they should not have the final say .
Employers are able to help their workers by making it compulsory for the latter to reveal their genetic test results . .
Some may say that it is a kind of discrimination against employees who have certain genetic traits .
However , one must be reminded that there are many occupations that required the employees to work in  hazardous environments  and their welfare can be protected through the revelation of genetic test results .
For example , people with the thalassemia gene will be at  risk if they were exposed to lead (The Markkula Center for Applied Ethics) .
By getting employees to reveal their genetic test results , employers can determine if the job applicant is suitable for the job and therefore assign them to a job environment that will not have any exposure to lead .
This benefits both the employees and the companies .
On the other hand , it will be disastrous if a soldier who has the genetic traits of Dissociative identity disorder (DID) were to be deployed in the field .
In another example , a colour-blind pilot has caused the crash of a FedEx plane in Florida , USA .
This can be prevented if he were to undergo genetic testing and the results were revealed to the company . .
Thus ,  individuals should not be given the final say about revealing their genetic test results .
Giving the insurance companies the final say about revealing genetic test results can prove to be beneficial  .
Many may think that insurance companies used the test results as  excuses to deny them from claiming or even buying certain medical policies .
These are just myths because proponents of the federal legislation would outlaw the acts (Harmon AA .
) .However , insurance companies have the rights to judge if the declarations of the clients are truthful by comparing them with the test results .
This is to prevent abuse of policies .
Moreover , many insurance companies used the test results to encourage the clients to buy certain policies that can maximize their benefits .
Clients should not have the final say if they want to enjoy the coverage of the insurance policies .
In conclusion , individuals should not have the final say about revealing their genetic test results since it will be more beneficial to the society .
By revealing the results will benefit the majority  .
After September 11 2001 , surveillance became important as it is one of the tools to prevent terrorism .
This then brings about the debates on whether surveillance technology should be banned  This is because surveillance could provide security , and it could also invade our privacy and disturb the society .
In my view , surveillance technology should be banned as the disadvantages clearly outweigh the advantages .
Surveillance technology should be banned as it invades our privacy .
Surveillance technology could be used to track people's movements , lifestyles and habits unknowingly (Hariton , Lawford and Palihapitiya , 2006) .
Furthermore , this information is not only available to the owner of surveillance technology , it  might also be available to affiliated people or people who bought the information (Easton , 2006) .
Hence , our privacy is being invaded as our very personal information is being known by a lot of people .
In addition , surveillance technology disturbs the society .
The economy gap between the rich and the poor will be wider (Monahan , 2006) as the rich is able to purchase information and use it to their advantage , This enables the rich to make more money than the poor .
Hence , surveillance technology should be banned .
Some might argue that surveillance technology should not be banned as it provides security .
With surveillance technology , terrorists could be more easily identified  .
Surveillance technology also prevents people from committing crime as they know they are being watched (Easton , 2006) .
However , this might not be true .
In fact , it might bring additional work to the security force as they now have to take care of minor issue captured by the surveillance technology (Monahan , 2006)  , and this may cause them to overlook the real threat to our security .
Hence , surveillance technology should be banned .
In conclusion , surveillance technology should be banned as it invades our privacy and disturbs the society 
The past two decades have brought about huge technological advances in the areas of nano-engineering and information systems .
With the help of  modern technology , humans are able to create increasingly efficient devices which are able to store relevant personal information or to trace one's location .
The use of sophisticated personnel tracking devices has long been an ethical quagmire , with people holding polarizing views debating if  surveillance technology can be  allowed to track people .
Proponents for the use of tracking devices on humans assert that patients can be easily identified in cases of emergency with their medical profiles easily accessible , since information is stored in a database that can be accessed via the internet (Lewan , 2007) .
Administrative procedures are greatly reduced , and the patient's vital records , for example drug allergies are readily retrievable .
Patients will be able to receive immediate and proper medical attention , which in certain cases can be a matter of life and death .
Moreover , tracking devices are able to assist law enforcement personnel to monitor suspects closely (Michael , K & Rose , G , 2007) .
Unknowing crime suspects can be monitored closely by the police over a period of time .
This allows discovery of new evidences through observation of the suspects; and to  prove if one is innocent or guilty .
Some arguments brought forward by opponents states that tagged identities could be easily duplicated by identity thefts (Lewan , 2009) .
This argument is flawed , as there is no concrete evidence showing the existence of such crimes .
The argument also blatantly ignored the fact that there are additional measures being taken to preventing such crimes .
Opponents also claim that the government will be able to use such devices to monitor , instil fear , and ultimately control the users (Lewan , 2009) .
This assertion is a fallacy , as it is based solely on foresight , and is cynical and biased .
In conclusion , tracking devices should be allowed in tracking people , as it is able to change human lives for the better , and it may even prevent or reduce crime rates .
Nowadays , advances in technology have made tracking people no longer an uphill task .
Due to this , many surveillance technologies have been created in order to make the tracking job efficient .
A controversy on the benefits of the surveillance technology and the effects of the surveillance technology has been aroused .
Nonetheless , the use of it has brought along significant benefits and therefore it should not be banned .
There are two main benefits that the use of surveillance technology has brought  .
Firstly , it helps to tag "high-risk" patients (Todd Lewan , 2007) .
A microchip is implanted into the arm of patients who had heart diseases , diabetics or Alzheimer's disease .
For the Alzheimer's patients , it helps to track them in order to ensure their safety .
By using this technology , the location of the patient can be easily detect by a reader and immediate action can be taken if the patient is in risk .
This system really benefits the Alzheimer's patient who are often lost due to their degrading memories .
Another benefit is to use GPS (global positioning systems) tracking device to track criminals (Michael K , Rose GL , 2007) .
The GPS tracking device helps in the investigation of crimes .
This system can trace the position of an individual globally as it helps to trace the track of criminals .
This helps to smooth and speed up the process of investigation of crimes by the police .
Besides , GPS is also widely used to monitor the action of the terrorists .
Terrorists are under the tracking of the system as when they arebeing traced .
Immediate actions will be taken by the authorities .
This technology fights terrorism to make the world a safer place . .
In conclusion , the use of surveillance technology to track people should not be banned .
It benefits not only the individual but the whole world .
There are two major advantages of using surveillance technology to track people .
Law enforcement agencies are able to identify terrorists and put a stop to their plans .
Recent happenings show that a number of terrorist plots have ceased because of  surveillance technology (Michael & Rose , 2007 , p . 8) .
It consequently helps to prevent major catastrophes ,  which involve the loss of human lives (Michael & Rose , 2007 , p .8) .
Other than that , the technology also helps in reducing crime rates all around the world .
It is especially useful in stamping out "transnational crimes such as drug and people trafficking , money laundering , and the smuggling of things" (Michael & Rose , 2007 , p .8) .
Besides that , surveillance technology also enables the tracking of criminals who are on the run  , and  even kidnappers .
Once being tagged , the lawbreakers' positions can be monitored and crimes can be solved within a short period of time .
Critics argue that such surveillance technology is able to track an individual on a regular basis , thus there is a compromise of one's privacy (Michael & Rose , 2007 , p . 2) .
Similarly , the United States has been criticized for promoting the use of human tracking technologies after the 9/11 event (Michael & Rose , 2007 , p . 8) , as it indicates the beginning of an Orwellian era as claimed by many privacy advocates (Lewan , 2007 , para .
7) .
However , this unfounded argument is not adequate to outlaw the use of human tracking technology .
Jacques Ellul noted that "to be sure of apprehending criminals , it is necessary that everyone be supervised" (Lyon , as cited in Michael & Rose , 2007 , p . 20) .
Safety of mankind is not worth being sacrificed just for the sake of their privacy .
A balance should be reached between the two extremes - the banning of human tracking technology and privacy being stripped away from innocent citizens .
In conclusion , the use of surveillance technology to track people should not be banned as it helps to prevent terrorism and crimes .
Consequently , an agreement should be reached between the privacy advocates and law enforcement agencies on the degree of control in surveillance .
This is because  innocent citizens have the rights to live in secured environment without facing erosions of their human rights and privacy .
Easy access by third parties such as insurance companies or healthcare professionals to an individual's genetic information may cause invasion of privacy and discrimination .
Although medical personnel are entrusted with the ethics of genetic testing , commercialization and easy access to certain genetic testing may lead to compromising situations for members of the public (Bioethics Advisory Committee , 2005) .
For instance , genetic information that falls into the hands of insurers and employers without the consent of individuals will be used to prejudice against the tested individual .
Society might treat the person differently or even deny basic rights to equal job opportunities , income , education , mental well-being , housing status , health , and medical treatment .
Racial discrimination still exists today in various parts of the world despite government efforts to eradicate it .
Who can say what will happen if a patient's genetic information falls into the wrong hands ?
Besides that , disclosure of genetic information to close relatives without informed consent may also cause internal family problems .
Often , prediction based on genetic information is uncertain , especially by those who are not well informed about the nature of a disease .
This misunderstanding not only creates unnecessary psychological , economic as well as social burdens on the carrier of a known genetic risk , but may also affect family ties . . A couple with a positively tested disease has to sacrifice their dream of having children if they do not wish to pass on their defective genes to their offspring .
As such , the couple suffers in silence , having to face the social stigma of not having children and having their dreams of building their families shattered .
Moreover , the in-laws , usually the more traditional type , may be dissatisfied with the daughter-in-law for not  being able to produce a 'perfect' offspring , or being unable to produce any offspring at all , to sustain the future generation of a family .
In conclusion , the patient of genetic testing should have the final say in  revealing the results  .
Until proper steps such as enactment and reinforcement of laws are taken by the governments , genetic information of individuals should be kept private and confidential to avoid exploitation by unscrupulous parties and also to avoid the disintegration of family relations .
The release of genetic information of a patient has wide and lifelong implications on his or her life , and therefore this vital decision should be made after careful thought .
Genetic testing includes special techniques to examine the information carried by DNA which are held in the sequence of pieces of DNA called genes .
DNA is taken from a person's blood , body fluids or tissues .
By analysing an individual's specific genes , some diseases such as cystic fibrosis and sickle cell anemia may be detected .
An individual can prevent some diseases or get the appropriate treatment for the diseases after getting the results of genetic testing .
However , if the result of the test can be easily assessed by a third party , a lot of problems will occur .
Therefore , the patient should have the right to decide whether he or she wants to reveal the results of the genetic tests .
The privacy and confidentiality of a person will be affected by revealing his or her undesirable genetic testing results .
The issues of privacy and confidentiality may affect the individual , the family and the group to which the individual belongs .
If the result is being publicized , third party may stigmatize the other individuals in different group , with potentially discriminatory consequences .
Misconstruing the results of genetic testing will affect  an individual's self identity and sense of self-worth .
Besides , the individuals will feel embarrassed of their potential weakness if they get undesirable genetic testing results .
They will have no confidence while socializing with other people and this is due to their low self-esteem after getting the result  .
Hence , they may underestimate  their own ability in certain field .
This issue will strongly affect the relationship between employees and employers .
Generally , all of these genetic results will be revealed to the employer and if the employer knows that some of the employees  are prone to certain diseases , it is likely that the employees will be fired .
This is because people with disabilities are often being discriminated against .
These people have to look for other alternatives to earn a living .
Once the results are revealed , employees will have difficulties finding other jobs .
Hence , results should not be revealed to protect employees from environments that might harm them .
Another difficulty involves the disclosure of genetic information to insurance companies .
Applicants for insurance will be under increased pressure to undergo genetic tests and those prone to diseases are less likely to be eligible to buy insurance .
In conclusion , genetic testing results are a matter that should be kept private for the benefits of the patient and should only be released under certain extreme circumstances . .
Genetics plays a role in every disease .
Genetic testing informs individuals and families of their genetic status; this knowledge may enable them to take adaptive measures against a genetic disease (Jacobs , & Deatrick , 1999) , if the disease is treatable .
However , as technology advances , exploitation of genetic testing increases , resulting in the breach of human rights of privacy .
Removing individual's control over the results will in turn lead to freely accessible genetic information , which may cause social problems and family dilemma .
Firstly , every human's gene is unique and personal .
The sharing of personal genetic result is akin to being exposed to public scrutiny . .
It is undeniable that one is morally obliged to inform the relatives of the patients about the genetic test results .
However , one has the rights to confidentiality and decision on what information to reveal and how to disclose it .
Moreover , relatives , being the recipients of the bad news should have their choice whether to remain ignorant  .
Therefore , one has the rights to one's genetic privacy .
Secondly , being able to access one's genetic information will reveal the list of diseases one is susceptible to , and the one who possesses the information may have an ulterior interest .
This can in turn cause social issues like genetic discrimination in the terms of employment and insurance (Bereano , 2000) .
For example , potential employers may want their interviewees screened to determine if they carry the ideal genes for the job .
; insurance companies may deny or increase their premium for carriers of certain genetic disorder (Bereano , 2000) .
Thirdly , family members generally inherit the same set of genetic codes from their parents , and may be susceptible to similar diseases (Jacobs , & Deatrick , 1999) .
However , one would not be able to determine their preparedness for such information .
It may cause not only unnecessary distress and anxiety to relatives , but will also unravel family secrets; namely adoptions and parentage (Doukas , & Berg , 2001) .
Thus , it is still up to the discretion of individuals to go for genetic testing if they are at high risk .
Therefore , individuals who have requested for genetic testing should have the final say in whether to reveal the results of such testing .
Genetic testing has made it possible to identify individuals who are at risk of having a disease , and to test the probability of them passing on a disease to their offspring .
There is an ongoing debate in whether these individuals should have the final say in whether or not to reveal the results .
This is because these results will affect not only the individual , but also his family , offspring , the future generations and even the society .
Thus , individuals should not have the final say in the disclosure of genetic testing results .
First of all , it will benefit and protect the individual's family members and offspring .
Research has shown that individuals tend to keep risk information to themselves (Forrest , 2000) .
But the disease could be due to hereditary genes .
The individual's family , offspring , and offspring of the family members might also inherit the disease .
If individuals did not reveal the results , family members and offspring will not know they have a risk of inheriting the disease .
When symptoms of this disease appear , their chances of full recovery will decrease .
Secondly , individuals can receive better family support and further harm can be prevented .
If individuals do not have the final say in revealing genetic test results , their family members will know their condition , and they can be more sensitive to the individual's feelings , such as giving them better support and encouragement .
Also , people diagnosed with chronic diseases are more prone to getting depression (IMH) .
Bottling up emotions will worsen the condition , and in severe cases , will lead to suicide (IMH) .
This will do more harm than good to the individuals .
Thirdly , revealing of results will benefit the future generations and the individual .
It will benefit the future generations as scientists will be able to find new or more effective cures and treatments for the disease .
It will also benefit the individual as governments will be able to come up with anti-discrimination acts to protect their rights .
Governments may also educate the public so as to minimize genetic discrimination , and build infrastructures and prepare  medical teams to provide them with proper care .
Thus , individuals should not have the final say , as it will benefit the individual , their family , and the society .
In modern times , there is an increase in the types of threat that can affect a nation's security .
People need to collect intelligence about a situation before they can act against it; and this has led to the increasing employment of surveillance technology .
The use of surveillance technology has raised concerns over the intrusion of personal privacy (Sim , 2006) .
However , since surveillance technology can help to identify problems , a solution or preventive measure can be formulated to prevent these problems from occurring , and this in turn lead to the protection  of people's health and the country's socio-economic stability .
Hence , the use of such surveillance technology  to track people should not be banned .
Firstly , the use of biometric surveillance in the form of a biometric passport will make it more difficult for terrorists to travel in and out of different countries , due to increasing passport security and border surveillance .
Furthermore , this information which is kept in a central repository can easily be updated and shared among other government agencies by wireless internet , making biometric surveillance timely and accurate (Sim , 2006) .
This method is highly efficient compared to traditional passport controls and surveillance methods .
Not being able to track terrorist movements could allow terrorists to enter a country and possibly carry out a terrorist attack; and it also makes it easier for them to escape .
Another possibility of using surveillance technology is during disease outbreaks , such as the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) outbreak in 2002 .
An electronic card embedded with a Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) chip was used to monitor the movements of patients , healthcare workers , and visitors within a hospital (Defense Science and Technology Agency , 2003) .
This system resulted in an increased efficiency of the contact tracing process and quarantine procedures when a patient was confirmed with SARS .
Contact tracing and quarantine procedures would normally take two days with the previous method; and it was also more taxing on manpower (Defense Science and Technology Agency , 2003) .
Thus , if the previous method was used , more people would be at risk of contracting the virus as it would take more time to identify and quarantine an infected person .
Some people would not support the use of surveillance technology as it is an intrusion to their privacy  .
There is a fear  that personal information could be stolen and used against their interests .
However , citizens should understand that surveillance technology was developed as a tool to help society; but it is the exploitation of people with criminal intent , or more often , the use of surveillance technology without careful consideration that makes surveillance technology harmful (Sim , 2006) .
Perhaps a better solution is for the government to introduce a privacy act to ensure security and prevent the misuse of personal information (Sim , 2006) .
Over the years , there has been an increase in the use of surveillance technology .
This has brought about a wild debate on the banning of the use of surveillance technology to track the movement of people .
While most propositions agree to ban the use of surveillance technology , they have in fact overlooked the actual and potential benefits of the surveillance technology .
These benefits include disease surveillance and private surveillance on family members .
Thus , the use of surveillance technology should not be completely banned .
Surveillance technology can be used to control the outspread of acute diseases .
Firstly , the use of electronic cards allows hospitals to track the time and movement of people within the hospital .
This has helped to accelerate the tracing of contacts and implementation of quarantine procedures .
(DSTA , 2003) .
Next , those who were under home quarantine during the SARS period were instructed to install a camera in their isolation zone to make sure that they are always visible and contactable , to prevent further spread of the disease .
Also , the use of infrared fever sensing system in Changi airport and along borders allows mass surveillance of body temperature , which can detect and isolate feverish passengers (Basu , 2003) .
The SARS outbreak in 2002 clearly demonstrated how the surveillance of patients , suspects , healthcare workers , and the general public led to the eventual containment of the outbreak and prevented it from escalating into a pandemic .
Surveillance technology could also be used to ensure the safety of our family members .
Through the use of the permission-based location tracking service , which is provided by our local telecommunication provider , SingTel , the location of our loved ones can be detected readily by this new surveillance technology (Daily Singapore News , 2008) .
This is very useful for families with young juveniles and aging parents because their location could be tracked easily if they are lost in the crowd and thus this may prevent  them from any possible harm they may encounter .
Over the years , drastic advancement in genetic testing allows the detection of defective genes associated with many hereditary diseases .
This impact of genetic testing posed on the individual and their family has brought up many debates on the ethical , social and family issues .
Some suggest that revealing of genetic results could benefit family members as they could seek appropriate medical treatment if tested positive (Jacobs & Deatrick 1999 .
However , negative implications such as violation of privacy , long- termed psychological and sociological effects inflicted on the  , outweigh the  .
Therefore individuals should have the final say in whether to reveal their genetic results or not .
Firstly , an individual should not be robbed of his basic right to privacy .
Although , it cannot be denied that it is ethical to inform family members about their risk of hereditary  ,  one does not have any obligation to reveal their genetic status since this information could be exploited and misused by othersthus threatening their welfare (Jacobs & Deatrick 1999) .
Thus , they should have the right to decide either to disclose their genetic information or not and also to what extent  they want to publicize it .
Secondly , revelation of one's genetic status subjects the individual to many social issues related to genetic discrimination (Bereano , 2000 .
For instance , insurance companies would reduce healthcare coverage , increase health premiums or terminate the health insurance policies for individuals with potential genetic risk (Bereano , 2000 .
Furthermore , discrimination imposed by employers and colleagues could influence an individual's self- esteem and psychological well-being .
Lastly , family dilemma could arise due to the tension caused by the unfavorable psychological influences of genetic testing (Doukas & Berg , 2001) .
Since every individual has a different level of acceptance , disclosure of genetic results could cause them to experience unnecessary emotional distress (Doukas & Berg , 2001) .
Hence , an individual should decide rationally whether to disclose their genetic results if it inflicts harm and misery to their family .
In conclusion , individuals should have the privacy to determine whether to reveal their genetic results or not since it not only inflicts emotional distress on their family but also subjects them to social discrimination .
Advancement and breakthrough in technology has now made tracking individuals using surveillance technology a reality today .
This has sparked many controversial debates on ethical and moral issues on using such technology .
Some have highlighted that usage of such technology infringes on individuals' personal privacy .
On the other hand , surveillance technology can also protect the well-being of people .
Since the advantages of surveillance technology far outweighs the disadvantages , it should not be banned .
Surveillance technology can be applied to private surveillance .
Private surveillance of individuals restricts their movements and helps to prevent the spread of a pandemic in the country .
This was especially seen during the SARS crisis back in 2003 .
( , 2003) .
Probationers are also tagged  for better control on their whereabouts .
Furthermore , loved ones can also be tracked , with Singtel's Location Tracking Service ( , 2008) .
Arguments presented for the ban on the use of surveillance technology to track individuals are totally flawed .
For instance , the existence of surveillance technology in the virtual world helps to curb crimes against copyrights , piracy and bank frauds .
Copyright protection such as the TurnItIn Online Programme , is designed to detect unreferenced copying or plagiarism in individual's work .
In addition , illegal file distribution , sale and download are acts that tantamount to promoting piracy .
Individuals can be sued by the relevant distribution companies and authorities .
Moreover , surveillance technology helps protect against bank frauds and illegal activities , such as hacking into personal Internet banking accounts .
DBS Bank has in place security surveillance systems that regularly "monitor and detect any potential form of illegitimate activities" ( , 2007) .
As  genetic testing is making rapid progress on providing information on the hidden DNAs which might cause diseases , the techniques have also aroused a large amount of heated debates on the ethical and moral issues surrounding the control of final say of the testing .
In terms of individual rights of privacy and long-term social influence , the one requesting genetic testing should have the final say in whether to reveal the results of such testing .
First of all , the individual has the right to determine whether or not it is necessary to make the genetic testing results public .
According to the definition released by Bereano (2009) in his article Does Genetic Research Threaten Our Civil Liberties , the right of privacy "involves notions of the dignity and integrity of the individual" .
The individual who received the genetic testing should determine for himself or herself how and to what extent the relevant information is communicated to the public .
Although it cannot be denied that the other family members to some extent also have the right to know whether they share the same suspected genes as the tested , they can choose to test their genes by themselves , rather than to depend on other people's testing results .
If one's privacy cannot be protected so that the result might be made use of on any purpose , the human rights are endangered and hence this decision should be made by the individual requesting the genetic testing .
Secondly , social problems such as genetic discrimination tend to be implemented .
For instance ,  insurance companies can require the testing result before signing for a contact with a client who may be potential carriers of diseases .
Despite taking the risks of catching a disease , the client should  own the right to buy the insurance .
Nevertheless , insurance companies judge clients on the testing result and either refuse the healthcare coverage or even transfer this suspect diagnosis to the next generation" (Lynch & Lynch , 1996) .
This kind of problem will be wide-spreading .
Thus the individual should have the right to decide whether to reveal the result  , considering his own benefits .
To conclude , the one who requests genetic testing should have the final right to determine whether this result should be made public or not .
Surveillance technology was first introduced in the seventies where video tape surveillance became the global norm to watch human behaviours in a small area .
Over the years , advances in science and technology has empowered surveillance technology by introducing many forms and magnifying the scope of surveillance .
This has brought about many controversies on the ethical , health and social issues surrounding the notion of mass surveillance .
While supporters argue that surveillance technology brings benefits to the human race , the harms it causes when it is excessively misused outweigh the benefits .
Thus , due to the implications of surveillance technology , it should be banned .
Firstly , the use of surveillance technology invades our privacy .
Privacy is a  fundamental fundamental human right and we have the right to lead our lives without public surveillance .
In Britain , there are 4 .2 million CCTV cameras on the streets , about one for every 14 citizen ( , 2006) .
Mass surveillance has infringed our rights to lead a personal life as all our  actions and behaviours are being watched and tracked .
Therefore , surveillance technology should be banned as our basic right is being infringed upon .
Lastly , surveillance technology , such as RFID , might cause health problems in human implants .
Research shows that that implanted RFID tags are associated with tumors in rodents , mostly sarcomas (Foster & Jaeger , 2008) .
This result is alarming as it suggests  the possibility of a similar effect in humans (Foster & Jaeger , 2008) .
Surveillance technology has advanced rapidly over the years and is commonly seen in many places , from leisure places to workplaces and even to our lifts and homes .
This monitoring of other people's behaviour , activities , or information has brought about many debates on ethical issue , security issues as well as individual's health issues .
Though some suggest that surveillance technology benefits us  the negative implications outweigh the benefits .
Therefore , surveillance technology should be banned .
Firstly , the use of surveillance technology has dehumanized and violated our most basic right which is privacy .
This is because surveillance technology such as closed-circuit television (CCTV) allows others to watch and track our daily activities .
We have lost our rights in leading a personal life and have to live in  constant fear that our every movement is being monitored .
Furthermore , unethical companies could easily obtain our personal information through social network and use it to manipulate us .
When we lose our privacy , we become vulnerable psychologically and easily manipulated by others .
Therefore , it is ethically wrong to invade other people's privacy and there is a need to ban surveillance technology to protect our own rights .
Lastly , surveillance technology such as implantable radiofrequency identification technology (RFID) brings about potential health hazards .
Today , the use of RFID offers important health benefits such as convenient access to patient's contact information and medical history .
However , it has also been testified that RFID brings about other health complications such as infections , especially in elderly and weak individuals .
Therefore , surveillance technology should be banned as it may do more harm than benefits .
In conclusion , surveillance technology should be banned as it is not only ethically wrong but also poses threat to our security and health instead of protecting us .
Genetic testing has been in  forefront science research area in this 21st century .
With this unparallel knowledge of truth , came the issues of an individual's ethical rights on whether the person should have the final say in revealing his own results .

An individual should not have the final say in revealing his genetic testing result .

"It is widely recognised that one of their roles is to inform  may be at risk and patients are encouraged to discuss this risk with their relatives" (Forrest , 2000) .
