Early detection of cancer will not only keep it under control but also keep  loved ones safe .
Family planning with genetic testing can help married couples to prepare themselves mentally and emotionally if the probability of them having a genetic defective child is high .
Secondly , it is a political issue .
People have grown fearful of genetic testing due to the negative results for life insurances .
The government has to intervene by implementing policies that will help to prevent discrimination .
It is important to  the public to change their mindsets towards genetic discrimination .
Joly , Knoppers , and Godard (2003) found that  Thirdly , it is from the psychological point of view .
Individuals will tend to keep the results from their family as they are afraid that they might be a burden and will cause tensions within the family but understanding the situation will give them better emotional support .
"Don't bottle things up .
Try to talk to someone close to you .
It helps to have a good cry and talk things through"  , 2009) .
In conclusion , individuals should not have the final say in revealing their genetic test results for the benefit of the people around them .
With the revelation of the results , trust can be generated and relationship between them and their loved ones will become closer .
Surveillance technology has advanced rapidly , and it has dominated our lives .
This has brought about many debates on the ethical , security and health issues surrounding the use of surveillance technology .
While some suggest that the use of this technology brings benefits to both the country and the world , it in fact not only affects the country's safety but also the citizens' privacy in the country .
Thus , due to the negative implications that outweigh the benefits of using surveillance technology , it should be banned .
There are three factors that arise from the use of surveillance technology .
Firstly , surveillance technology dehumainzes citizens' basic right to privacy .
Under this technology , citizens are being watched .
This results in the loss of personal space and people live in fear as they tend to be very cautious in their every movements .
An article said that in US , "there is evidence that President Bush's executive order authorizing eavesdropping on phone conversations of U .S . citizens , monitoring email and gaining access to private computers while failing to follow the law requiring court- ordered warrants may amount to criminal activity ."
(Flocco , 2005) .
US citizens involved in the process have to be very careful with their daily lifestyles .
, In Britain , there are 4 .2 million CCTV cameras on the streets , about one for every 14 citizens ( ,2006) .
This is ethically wrong as , in general , humans have their basic right to privacy .
Too much intrusion of privacy could also lead to  psychological factors of one's mental status .
Hence , surveillance technology should be banned because it is ethically wrong to invade other people's privacy and it is an obligation to respect other people's privacy .
Secondly , it lowers the level of security of a country when terrorists are able to hack into their system and take control of the country's well-being .
As we know it today , the use of surveillance technology is globally used as a mass communication .
It is also  used as a safety to watch over one's power grid just like what US is doing now .
"According to officials , cyberspies from China and Russia have hacked into the US electricity grid and hidden software that could be used to disrupt power supplies ."
( , 2009) .
This imposes a high risk to the US in a time of war or even crisis due to the disruption of network by these cyberspies .
Thus , it is ironically contradicting the purpose of having a surveillance technology to secure us which in fact is back-fired .
Finally , critics have argued that by implanting a biochip (eg .
Radio Frequency Identification , RFID) into a dementia person , it eases the hospital authority to locate the  patient's whereabouts .
However , there is often a health issue that is involved in this implantation which causes complications to patients' health .
In late 2007 , an anti-chip activist  an important point that for more than one decade it has been known that implanted RFID tags are associated with tumors in rodents , mostly sarcomas (Blanchard et al .
1999; Elcock et al .
2001; Tillmann et al .
1997) .
This causes a controversy about possible carcinogenic effects; a substance or agent that tends to produce cancer () , that may occur in the implantation of chips on humans .
Thus , this affects patients by adding a new disease to them when they are already ill .
In conclusion , the use of surveillance technology should be banned as it brings negative implications not only to the citizens but also the world and thus poses a high risk of insecurity to the world .
Surveillance dated back all the way to ancient times .
In the past there was no real technological advancement , hence Surveillance limited to mainly watching over live stocks and prisoners .
As the world advances so does technology .
surveillance nowadays covers a wide spectrum of life from the wellbeing of a child left alone in the room to national security to prevent events such as terrorism and political instability .
As there is always a consent threat to the equilibrium of peace , surveillance technology has played a huge part in society to help enforce law and order and should not be banned .
Due to the broad spectrum of various surveillances technology  , I would address only a few that is of  .
Namely national security and disaster security .
National security as the name  , means security measures taken by the various governments to ensure that its country is a safe place for its citizens .
Some of the devices that have been set up and used are for example biometric passports .
It allows the immigration officers to have an idea of the background of the tourist or citizen that is entering the country .
This helps in preventing terrorism as appropriate measures can be taken to stop terrorists from entering the country .
In 2001 , the capture of terrorist members prevented a bomb explosion at Yishun train station in Singapore .
Critics may cite the flaws of the system in the case of Mas Selmat a member of the regional Islamic group called the Jemaah Islamiyah (JI) , who successfully escaped to Malaysia .
This however does not mean that the system of surveillance should be  .
This is where flaws of the systems are examined to come up with a more fool-proof system where such a terrorist cannot make use of the loop holes of the system to escape .
Pandemics and epidemics have been prevalent since  ancient times like in the 18th century where small pox caused massive deaths .
Today with the recent spread of SARS , H1N5 (bird flu) and the latest H1N1 (swine flu) , having surveillance technology helps us to  battle these disasters .
In 2003 when SARS spread causing thousands of deaths all across the world , the temperature radiation surveillance technology was invented to help identity those possible infected people from those who were not , and to separate those who are likely to be infected from the healthy population .
home tracking devices  implemented especially for those who were quarantined for the 10 days duration to ensure that they did not break the rules and venture out of their homes into the community .
Critics of tracking devices have lobbied for tracking devices to be banned as they have  been said to invade privacy .
However in this  , although the tracking device ia an invasion to a person's privacy , it serves a good cause to ensure the safety of the general population . 
Over the years , genetic testing has become more available to the public .
An individual can request and afford to undergo genetic testing to find out whether or not his body houses a defective gene .
When the results of the test are given to the individual , the question of whether the results should be revealed or not arises .
Although the individual may feel that he should have the final say on the revelation of the results , in fact , having the physicians decide whether the results should be revealed would be much more beneficial to the society and the individual himself .
Therefore , the individual should not have the final say on whether the results of such testing should be revealed .
Firstly , the physician is in a better position to decide if the results should be revealed .
This is due to the physician being more knowledgeable about the results , especially if a defective gene is detected in the individual .
The individual is unlikely to reveal their results to their family , potential and current employers , insurance companies for fear of discrimination from them ( 2007) .
However , by doing so , he is actually putting his family at risk as they will not know whether they too carry the defective gene which would put them at a higher risk of developing the disease associated with the gene () .
Furthermore , the physician would not be able to determine if the defective gene is hereditary and whether the other family members have that gene or not .
Secondly , for his own reasons , such as family disputes , the individual may choose not to act responsibly and withhold the results from family members .
In such cases , the physician would have the right to reveal the results to the family of the individual , especially if the test results indicate that the defective gene is present , there is the possibility that others in the family have the gene as well .
Also , with regards to the problem of discrimination , which is the underlying factor for the individual not wanting to reveal the results , there are laws in place in many countries that states that it is against the law to discriminate against people who have tested positive for a particular defective gene .
The physicians also have their medical code of conduct that states information about the patient which is confidential unless it poses threat to others ( 2008) .
Genetic testing has made possible the determination of genetic diseases .
However , the release of genetic testing results has brought about a controversy .
If family members havesimilar   genetic background , individuals may feel the need to disclose their results .
However , being likely to face discrimination from society , individuals should also have the choice to conceal the information from others .
This freedom of choice provides respect for their basic human rights .
Thus , individual consent should be obtained before the release of genetic testing results .
Firstly , the disclosure of a positive test result for a certain genetic disease may cause an individual to be susceptible to discrimination .
He may be treated less favourably than others due to his genetic disability .
For example , employers may prefer to employ individuals who are not predisposed to genetic diseases  , 2005) .
Health insurance companies may also avoid clients with genetic disorders ( , 2005) .
Thus , the discriminatory treatment an individual may be subjected to makes it essential that their consent be obtained in advance .
It may be argued that the legalization of the Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act (GINA) may solve the problem of discrimination ( 2008) .
However , limitations in this policy may still subject individuals to discrimination due to the exclusion of those applying for life insurance , disability insurance or military benefits  , 2008) .
Thus , the ability of GINA to solve the problem of discrimination may be limited .
The failure to gain an individual's approval to release the results denies him of his basic human rights , which is "the right to determine for oneself how and to what extent information about oneself is communicated to others ."
( .
By releasing the results without an individual's consent will subject the individual to a violation of his human rights .
Thus , it is important that each individual's approval is obtained before any circulation of the genetic testing results .
As a type of surveillance technology , RFID (Radio Frequency Identification) is drawing increased attention and has caused many conflicts with regard to privacy , security and health issues .
Advocators suggest that using RFID to conduct social control and tracking of suspects could benefit the whole society .
However , RFID in fact is not as ideal as they thought .
On the contrary , it not only leads to an invasion of privacy and identity theft but also poses health risks .
Hence , the use of RFID to track people should be banned .
Using RFID to track people raises many issues .
Firstly , the abuse of RFID invades privacy .
It is hard to guarantee that every tracking is innocent and conducted in proper ways and .
For example , overzealous employers and criminally intent people could take advantage of the RFID readers to track employees and victims' movement (Jean 2007) .
In this case , victims may lose their privacy even without awareness .
Secondly , because a RFID embedded card can easily   be skimmed and cloned , to some extent , it is a loophole for identity theft .
by using the cloned card , anyone could pass into a restricted area through the secure and locked entrance (Jones 2008) .
Hence , using a RFID equipped card to track and control entrance is not secure and effective at all .
Thirdly , implantable RFID chips have connections with health issues .
Research showed that "implanted RFID chips caused cancer in mice and rats and may cause cancer in cats , dogs , and humans" (Jean 2007) .
Additionally , "although an RFID chip in particular may not cause cancer , the inflammation caused by surgical implantation of a foreign object can increase the instance of tumor development" (Jean 2007) .
sacrificing the health of people when conducting tracking is therefore unacceptable
However , RFID advocators may argue for the purpose of alleviating the fear of privacy invasion .
For instance , the reader needs to be within about ten feet of the chip in order to extract data , so it may not handle long-range tracking (Jean 2007) .
However , it is still highly undetectable if the reader is installed inside doors or walls .
Furthermore , within such distance , RFID readers could still function (Jean 2007) .
Hence , people are still under the risk of being tracked and losing privacy without knowledge .
Genetic testing is a test whereby the individual is tested for any deficiency in the genes that could indicate the presence of future diseases .
But once the result is out and the person has some defective genes , different issues starts to surface .
The person might be subjugated to discrimination and not even the Genetic Information Non-discrimination Act (GINA) would be able to solve the problem .
Furthermore , the individual has the right to decide on whether the result should be disclosed or not .
Hence , I strongly agree that the person should have the final say on whether to reveal the genetic testing result so as to avoid these problems .
Firstly , the person would face discrimination by society if the results are declared openly without his consent The person would be unable to purchase insurance since they would cost the insurance company more money than the company had bargained for (Henry T .  2005 , ) Moreover , employers would not want to hire them as the employee's health problem would have an undesirable effect on the company's productivity , such as , costing the company more money on the employees' frequent sick leaves and medical reimbursements (Henry T . 2005) .
In addition , the person will be ostracized by the community due to the community lacking the knowledge of genetic diseases (WHO , 2009)
Secondly , critics at the other end of the table may argue that there is the Genetic Information Non-discrimination Act (GINA) in the US that was passed down by the former US president , Mr . Bush on 21 May 2008 which states that 'the genetic carriers would be protect against discrimination when it comes to work and health insurance' (Kaiser Family Foundation , 2008) .
However , these laws generally fail to offer comprehensive protection to all people at risk for genetic discrimination .
Tera Eerkes , founder of personal genetic testing company  states that 'this measure does not prevent genetic discrimination against people when they are applying for life insurance , or long term care and disability insurance' .
Moreover , the insurance companies will be forced to hike up the cost of their premiums and might result in healthy individuals being quoted the same rate as the genetic risk group (David , L .V .
2008 , ) .
Thirdly , the individual should not be denied of his rights in the decision on whether the result should be disclosed or not , or else , problems might occur .
The European Convention on Human Rights states that "Everyone has the right to respect for his private and family life , his home and his correspondence ."
(Patrick , N . ,1993) .
If an individual is denied of his right to decide on the disclosure of his test result , probably no one will dare go for testing since they know that they do not possess the right to decide whether the result stays secret .
This will result in dire consequences , for example; there will not be proper family planning since genetic disorder is not taken into consideration , which might result in continued breeding of undesirable genetic traits in one's offspring .
In conclusion , the person who went for genetic testing should have the final say on whether to reveal the genetic testing result so that he will not be discriminated against or even denied of his basic human rights .
Recently , Radio Frequency Identification technology , also known as "RFID" has been a hot topic for discussion .
In the past , it was used to track equipmentequipment and data and this did not create much controversy with regard to the issue of privacy .
However , as technology improved RFID is now more frequently used to track people .
While some argue that the use of RFID to track people is unfavourable , it in fact not only ensures one's security and safety but also saves time and cuts cost for an industry .
Thus , due to the immense benefits of RFID , it should not be banned .
There are two important benefits of RFID .
Firstly , RFID is used in hospitals to keep a close watch on people for their own safety .
(Getz , 2009) .
This reduces the need to hire full-time nurses to accompany the Alzheimer's patients wherever they go .
When these patients wander around and get lost in an unfamiliar place , we are able to track their whereabouts and know where they are immediately .
Secondly , RFID is used to monitor employees' movements .
(Getz , 2009) .
This is especially useful in hospitals during emergency to track the whereabouts of doctors .
In life and death situation , doctors that are in the vicinity of the operation theatre can be called in for help instantly , hence saving time .
Arguments put forth to ban RFID are faulty .
For instance , it has been argued that the excessive use of RFID tags result in deterioration of personal privacy .
(Ward , 2006) .
However , for the group of people who requires constant attention , safety outweighs privacy issues .
Furthermore , RFID tags can be snapped in half to prevent the transmission of data when it is no longer in use .
Thus , this will not threaten individual's privacy .
Finally , there has been greater concern about RFID not only tracking the data of the patient , but also tracking the patient's actual whereabouts .
(Getz , 2009) .
On the contrary , this is a minor issue as only those with access to hospital's database can interpret the information .
Otherwise , this information is purposeless .
Advances in technology have made mass surveillance possible , even to track humans .
However , this has stirred up much controversy due to the privacy , security and health issues surrounding its use .
Supporters claim that surveillance technology can increase efficiency and effectiveness in tracking criminals and potential terrorists , and decreasing crime rates or track runaway or Alzheimer patients in hospitals to provide better care for every patient (Jean , 2007) .
In fact , it causes more security than health threats thus using it to track people should be banned to ensure their safety .
Threats discussed here would be with reference to Radio Frequency Identification Device (RFID) .
The main argument to support the banning is the risk of identity theft .
RFID tags and cards can be easily hacked and cloned and used immediately to get past what we presumed to be secured (Jones , 2008) .
If one had their pocket picked , he would know and can take measures to prevent it .
However , if one's personal information had been stolen without one's knowledge , one is completely vulnerable .
It is against the law to steal another persons identification card but not the information by "skimming" (Jones , 2008) .
The problem is worsened by the fact that these RFID tags and cards carry unlimited information and there are no regulations to include these virtual crimes .
RFID has enabled potential criminals to commit crimes more easily than ever with technology that is so readily available and surprisingly inexpensive .
The rapid advances in medical technology present genetic testing that is used , to identify specific genes responsible for a significant disease in an individual (Centre for Genetic Education , n .d .) .
The perception of whether an individual should have the final say to reveal the results of genetic tests has lead to an ethical dilemma in  society and amongst individuals , particularly in family-relationships .
Since , the advantages of revealing the results of genetic tests outweigh the disadvantages in most situations ,  an individual should therefore not have the absolute authority to reveal their test results .
There are two main benefits of not having the absolute authority to revealing the results of genetic tests .
Firstly , physicians are able to carry out studies on the gene occurrence in the family , by using the samples of family members .
This would benefit both the individuals and the relatives on their own health and well-being .
It also provides understanding of specific gene occurrences to others (Centre for Genetic Education , n .d .) .
Secondly , the awareness of deleterious genes in individuals that could lead to disease , like HIV , ensures their responsibility within the community .
The organization involved in genetic care has the authority to disclose the genetic information to appropriate people if harmful genes could lead to serious disease .
If an infected individual does not  reveal it then  little effort is made for diagnosis and treatments (Minkoff and Ecker , 2008) .
This would cause harm to others , like the spread of HIV to the uninfected sexual partner and the future generations .
In addition , moral support from sexual partner would be a key determinant factor in motivating infected individuals to seek help .
Radio-frequency identification , more often known as RFID in short , is one of the most pervasive technologies developed since the late 1940s .
Today , enterprises found the use of RFID chips in a wide variety of places including hospital , transportation system , corporations , schools , and worryingly , human beings (Andrea Jean , 2007) .
In this paper , I would like to discuss some problems in the use of RFID chip on human beings .
Human implant is experimented and studied deeply in many countries .
However , this has  proved to have huge problems unfortunately .
Volunteers participated in a controlled experiment on skimming  proved that a hacker is able to skim and clone an access card in a split second and using the card to get entrance to a "secure and locked" entrance (Jones , 2008) .
This absurd result brings into question  the security use of the human implant .
One area which benefits greatly from RFID technology is the health sector .
Firstly , due to RFID , the safety and security of the patients are ensured .
RFID is used to track patients' locations in order to make sure they are safe .
This is especially true for elderly patients with Alzheimer's disease .
Patients suffering from Alzheimer's have the tendency to wander .
Hence , RFID will be able to lookout for these patients and ensure they do not go missing , making them safe (Getz , 2009) .
Also , RFID technology can prevent newborns from being kidnapped .
With RFID , the locations of newborns can be monitored .
Thus , if there are to be unauthorized movements , immediate action can be taken (Getz , 2009) .
With the newborns' safety being ensured , their parents will not have to worry constantly when they are not able to take care of their infants around the clock .
Thus , RFID technology is able to protect the patients and ensure a safe and secure environment in hospitals .
The completion of Human Genome Project has contributed significantly to the rapid development of genetic tests , a valuable tool that aids in diagnosis and prevention of genetic diseases .
However , due to the nature of the information generated , there have been many debates over who should hold the final decisions to the disclosure of genetic test results .
While some propose that giving individuals the authority to decide curbs arising ethical implications like discrimination , this in fact stops physicians from preventing illnesses and saving more lives .
Thus , the final decision should not be made by the individuals tested .
An important reason why patients should not be empowered to make the final decision is that it prevents doctors from tending to potential patients who could be at high risk of developing a disease if disclosure is not made .
Due to the need to maintain confidentiality of results , doctors will be compelled to watch patients with the defective gene fall ill when appropriate intervention can be done to avert  harm .
This  has gone against their 'proper medical and ethical practices' (Minkoff & Ecker , 2008) of preventing harm or avoiding serious jeopardisation of the health of others ) .
Considering  these competing obligations faced by physicians , the genetic care and counselling organisations have devised guidelines which accept disclosure to relatives without the consent of those tested when there is going to be a high degree and immediacy of risk faced by them (Minkoff & Ecker , 2008) .
In the event in which the patient tests positive for a particular terminal illness , and refuses to receive the results , should the physician then respect his/her wishes although it violates the physician's ethics of putting patient's safety first ?
[2] Physicians trained to deal with the emotional burdens of a positive test result , are capable of properly counselling the patient of the implications of not knowing the test result and also providing the needed medical treatment for the long run .
[1] As the medical professionals would know what medical treatment the patient would need , and also understand the encumbrance such knowledge would bring , it is best that the medical professionals decide whether or not to reveal the test results .
Technology has made our life so convenient that we have overlooked the {repercussions that comes with it .
An example would be the use of surveillance in this case radio frequency identification (RFID) technology in our everyday life without considering the health risks , consumer privacy rights and also its vulnerability to information thefts .
With that the usage of RFID should be banned so as to safeguard the general public .
Firstly the health issue poses a big threat to the usage of RFID as these chips are used in close vicinity to our body .
Patients who wish to keep their medical information might choose to have the chip implanted right under their skin .
The safety of using these chips is still uncertain even its exact position as the chips "(could) migrate under the skin and become difficult to extract" (Bacheldor 2007) .
Another concerning issue is that the "RFID tags may electromagnetically interfere with electrosurgical devices" (Bacheldor 2007) with particular attention at magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans .
Instead of aiding the patients to recuperate , the tags might in turn cause further deterioration to the patient's health .
Secondly , consumers might be ignorant to the fact that the products they purchased could be tagged so as to provide companies with the sales data and for market research .
Customers could also be tracked with the products anywhere so long as there is a right reader that could read the frequency (Free 2007) Consumer privacy will no longer be existent as consumers lose freedom of choice and also consistently losing personal information to marketeers .
Lastly as another information-carrying device , the RFID is also vulnerable to cyber criminals out to steal information about the users .
The attempts on hacking and spoofing the RFID tags had already been successful and so long as the frequency is replicated , the hacker would have access to the functions the RFID tag was made for (Halamka , Juels , Stubblefeild and Westhues 2006) .
The user might lose his password for access to areas or monetary items and also his identity .
The possibility that the RFID technology would prove to be more of a hindrance than a convenience is evident .
Therefore it should be banned in order to protect us from such vulnerabilities that the RFID would cause ,
Surveillance technology such as Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) makes use of technical means to track individuals .
This has brought about many controversial issues regarding the privacy and health concerns surrounding the use of RFID .
While some argue that the adoption of RFID is a violation of human privacy , it  indeed helps to protect the safety of families  ,the public and to identify patients .
Hence , the use of RFID should not be banned due to the uses it brings about .
There are three important uses of RFID in tracking people .
Firstly , RFID protects the safety of loved ones by tracking the movements of kin in cases when they got lost or were kidnapped .
With the help of A RFID tag worn by senile elderly ,  the police can identify the missing elderly and then contact their family members .
In addition , RFID tags help to  assist the police to locate the hostage and kidnappers .
Secondly , RFID ensures the safety of the public by monitoring suspicious people who might pose a danger to  society so as to prevent them from causing harm to the public .
RFID is useful in combating crime .
Thirdly , RDIF improves the speed of patient identification in hospitals .
Upon admission to hospital , each patient is given a RFID wristband which reveals the patient name , patient identification number and patient medication record (Antonio , n .d .) .
This is to prevent misidentification of patients from happening .
Admittedly , the use of RFID presents some privacy and health issues .
Nevertheless , the current legislation is sufficient to deal with the development of RFID so as to prevent user privacy from being invaded .
For instance , the setting up of RFID Security Alliance (RFIDSA) provides assistance in RFID privacy issues .
Furthermore , the RFID tag does not bring health problems to  users .
An example is European council proposal on the limitation of the exposure of electromagnetic fields to the public (Council , 1999) .
In conclusion , the use of RFID should not be totally banned but it could be restricted in some cases .
RFID serves as a tracking device and an identification system in safeguarding the safety of loved ones  , the public and for identifying patients .
Human genetics has made tremendous leaps over the past years , and consequently made a significant impact on many people's lives .
As such , the growth of genetic testing technology has initiated considerable debate over the privacy and confidentiality of genetic information .
In any case , it can be advocated that the individual should have the final say in whether to reveal the results of genetic testing or not .
This is due to the legislation polices that have been implemented for genetic testing 
Firstly , genetic information is not like any other medical information .
Basically , it is far more confidential as it may contain more  individual personal health issues  such as determining whether one carries any defective genes .
Hence , it is rightful to say that genetic information should be kept confidential and should only be revealed by the individual .
In accordance with federal law inthe United States  ,  medical information should be kept confidential and genetic professionals or doctors do not have the right to disclose any information without seeking the consent of the patient .
Though , they may assist  patients by informing them of the likelihood of their relatives contracting the same diseases , the final decision ultimately still depends on the individual .
On the other hand , critics may argue that genetic professionals can interpret the genetic testing results more accurately than  patients .
Thus , they can explain the implications of the results more precisely to  family members .
However , only  patients will understand their family members' different behavioural patterns .
This means that they are more suited to revealing the results by using a more desirable method .
As a result , they may help reduce the psychological stress on family members .
In conclusion , the decision of whether revealing the results of genetic testing should lie only with the individual and not other third parties involved .
Any disclosure of results by third parties will be considered a breach of the genetic privacy and confidentiality law and may cause unnecessary moral implications .
Genetic testing is generally used to test for any diseases that arise due to gene mutation .
Genetic testing has become more ubiquitous in recent years .
Issues that revolve around genetic testing are no longer limited to whether the individual should go for a genetic test but include the concerns of privacy and confidentiality .
I advocate the idea that  patients should have the final say to decide whether to disclose the test results to relatives and families .
First , the law and human rights declaration recognizes the right to privacy of  individuals .
A law , under any circumstances , is justified and objective .
The law , by no means , states that moral implications have to be considered by the individual .
In serious cases of diseases which are infectious , even though the doctor thinks that the family has a right to be informed of the risk , he cannot breach the confidentiality agreement between him and the patient .
Under the European Convention , article eight states clearly that "everyone has the right to respect for his private and family life ."
(Abrumsky ,L . , Berry , C . , Carltan ,L . , Chandler ,J . , Dimaricius ,J . , Ennals ,P .
et al . , 2009) Unless there is mutual agreement on both sides , the final say should lie with the patients .
Secondly , the final say should lie with the patient as he knows what is best for his family members .
The patients knows the different behavioral patterns of his family members and will know the best way to approach them regarding their genetic condition .
He can also decide not to tell his family members if he thinks that they might not be able to cope with the news emotionally .
In this way , the family members of the patient are protected from  emotional harm like stress and anxiety .
A doctor cannot determine how the family members will react to the news and hence should not have the final say in the disclosure of genetic test results .
In conclusion , the final say in the disclosure of genetic test results should lie with the patient according to the legal jurisdiction and to the fact that the patients understand the different personalities of their families and will have their best interests in mind .
The advancement of Science and Technology has lead to many possibilities , one of which is the ability to predict one's risk of contracting certain diseases , mostly hereditary , via the study of one's genes .
Called genetics testing , the test results , though not definitive , are highly accurate .
Hence this predictive power leads to one of the many controversies- should an individual have the final say in whether to reveal his/her results ?
Because the results could potentially be used to save lives , yet at the same time be misused , the individual requesting the test should not have the final say .
In fact , this authority should go to  medical professionals; basically physicians undertaking the proceedings of the test and  interacting with the patients firsthand .
Firstly , a physician is a profession that is bound by standard protocols and most importantly  physicians possess medical ethics .
As the genetics results also apply to the family and relatives' health risks as well as the patient's own , many lives are concerned and any unjustifiable reason not to disclose should be overwritten .
The American Society of Human Genetics even propose conditions whereby patient autonomy should be disregarded (Bioethics Advisory Committee ,2005) , emphasizing the importance of disclosure of results .
Secondly , there are laws such as the Genetic Information Non-discrimination Act (GINA) or the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act ({HIPAA}[HYPERLINK: http://www .hhs .gov/ocr/hipaa/]) (Norrgand , 2008) , which protect the confidentiality and interests of the patient .
These are laws that  physicians adhere to , which the patient may be unfamiliar with and overlook , despite pre- test counselling .
Thirdly ,  society benefits when sound decisions are made by pragmatic , rather than individualistic , individuals .
Patients can make informed decisions and adopt healthy practices when they face the harsh truth of the results; something the patient may not anticipate at first hence must be brought to picture by the physician (Lee , 2005) .
The opposition may state that leaving the decision to a third party who may be insensitive ,may jeopardize the patient's chances in employment and insurance .
However , there are laws in place (Norrgand , 2008) that will prevent such occurrences .
Moreover , physicians still respect patient autonomy unless certain conditions permit otherwise .
It has also been suggested that the harsh truth of inheriting a genetic risk may create an emotional impact , especially when disclosed despite the patient's reluctance .
However , the physician is present to provide advice and post-test counselling .
Moreover , the mental preparedness of the patient is most likely moulded on the pre-test counselling before genetic testing is carried(Lee , 2005) .
In conclusion , physicians should have the final say in whether to reveal the genetic testing results as they have the know-how on managing the entire situation before and after the patient is subjected to the test .
Genetic testing is an issue that mankind has placed great emphasis on .
After test results are analyzed by physicians , there is a dilema about whether the information should be made known to others or whether itshould be kept confidential by the individual .
Despite the fact that human rights exist ,  physicians actually have a clearer understanding of the results and the ethical and social issues that surface by withholding such information .
Hence , the proposition that genetic test results be made known to others by the medical professionals should hold .
Firstly , genetic testing has led to the ethics of medical professionals being questionable .
There are instances when a patient tested positive for a disease , but refused to know their results (BAC , 2005) .
I must admit that the rights to privacy should hold .
Nevertheless , by not sharing this critical information , it creates more problems for themselves .
This is clearly true as test results indirectly reflect genetic information related to family members as there is a possibility of them inheriting the disease too .
In such a situation , the authority to release the resultst should lie with the healthcare professionals .
Secondly , genetic testing has also been deemed as a social issue .
It has been speculated that discrimination occurs during employment and the application of health insurance when genetic information lands in the hands of  employers and insurance companies (Lee , 2005) .
However , they fail to realise that there have been laws legislated to prevent discrimination of such forms (Lee , 2005) .
As a result , the employers and insurance companies should have the right to request genetic information from their employees or clients directly , or indirectly from medical professionals who have a better interpretation of the genetic test results .
In conclusion , although on the surface there seems to be disturbing issues in sharing genetic information ,  when observed in depth , the information  shared can be  an advantage to the individual as well as those around him .
Eventually , the stand that test results should be made known to others by the medical professionals should hold .
The use of the technology such as radio frequency identification (RFID) in tracking people has been heatedly discussed recently due to privacy and security concerns .
Nevertheless , these concerns are outweighed by its pros due to the benefits it brings in ensuring the loved ones , the public as well as identifying patients .
Hence , I strongly agree that surveillance technology such as RFID should be used to track people .
Firstly , RFID can ensure the safety of loved ones .
In the case of kidnapping , those who had RFID implanted can be easily located by RFID readers .
For elders who suffer from memory loss , RFID can provides their identities once they are found lost their way home .
Secondly , RFID can ensure the safety of public .
By implanting RFID tags on prisoners , their movements can be monitored and their location can be easily spotted should they escape .
It can also be used on ex-convicts to track their movements and prevent them from committing crimes again .
Thirdly , RFID helps to identify patients .
A RFID tag which contains patients' complete medical history can be implanted to enable treatments by doctors according to their conditions .
Furthermore , RFID tags help to prevent wrong prescription of medicine and any delay treatments which will endanger the lives of patients (Antonio , Putten & Gerald) .
Medical advances in technology have made it possible to detect if one has a genetic disease through genetic testing .
Genetic testing can be defined as the analyzing of one's DNA to detect the possible risks of contracting a genetic disease .
This has brought about a lot of debate on the ethical and law issues on whether the individual has the final say in revealing the genetic testing results .
Due to privacy and the effects of emotional stress , the individual should have the final say .
Secondly , there will be emotional stress experienced by relatives , if results are revealed unnecessarily .
For example , letting parents know about the genetic risks may cause them to have a guilty conscience , they may feel responsible for passing a genetic mutation on to their child .
However , there is a common misconception that being tested positive means that they will definitely get sick(Varga ,2008) .
This is not necessarily going to happen as many other factors are needed to occur as well , like non-genetic risks such as smoking(Varga ,2008)  .
Therefore , revealing  results could be redundant if relatives do not have non-genetic risks , and furthermore it could create undesirable emotional stress for the relative .
So , the individual should first observe  any signs of symptoms of the genetic disease the relative may have , such as deformity or behavior problems , before deciding whether or not to tell .
In this case , third parties such as doctors should not reveal the results , as doctors are usually more concerned with alerting the person of the possible chances of contracting the genetic disease , rather than the possible negative impacts this news may bring to the person .
In conclusion , due to the law issues and  possible undesirable emotional stress caused by relatives , the individuals should have the final say in revealing the results , as it is their personal information , and  they understand their relatives better emotionally .
Tracking of an individual's  movement using RFID technology is made possible when it is used in a combination with Global Positioning System technology , as proposed by RFID vendors .
A person's movements can be tracked if the RFID tag is associated with a person .
The RFID tag could be  in an article of clothing or under the skin in some part of the body and it could also serve as an identifier for the person wearing it .
RFID should not be banned as it brings many benefits to our lives .
There are many advantages to using RFID technology to track people's movement .
Firstly , companies/family members could leverage   RFID technology to locate their loved ones/employees if they were missing or working in a dangerous environment .
(Jerry , David , Manuel & Thompson , 2007 p .469) Secondly , in hospital , a positive patient identification system using radio frequency identification , RFID , to identify patients can led to fewer patient misidentifications .
Patient misidentification has been the leading cause of medical errors and medical malpractice , posing a serious risk to patient safety .
(Antonio , Putten & Gerald , n .d) Thirdly , monitoring of RFID tagged convicts in prison can prevent possible prison breaks .
In addition , using RFID to tag offenders that are serving their term in the community can help to enforce  home curfews . 
It is often argued that the implantation of RFID is a violation of privacy .
However in  cases like working in a dangerous environment , safely is prioritized over privacy violation .
Furthermore , the tags can be deactivated to prevent tracking if there's a need .
There are also worries over leaked confidential information through RFID tags .
However , the tags can be encrypted and cleared of information before being discarded .
Finally , there are health concerns over exposure to electromagnetic fields , EMF , from the usage of RFID .
But guidelines of recommended limits of EMF exposure have been adopted internationally to prevent any known negative health effects .
(The Council of the European Union , 1999)
In conclusion , tracking  people's movement using RFID technology should not be banned as its benefits heavily outweigh the downsides it might bring .
Advancements in technology have allowed the invention of new devices that have helped improve lifestyles and  helped bring  convenience into our lives .
Surveillance technology such as the Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) is one example .
It has made tracking people a simpler task .
Hence , it should not be banned due its benefits .
RFID is an essential tool used for tracking  people .
It can be used in various situations .
In hospitals , RFIDs serve as a means for tracking  patients as well as indentifying them .
Instead of having to go through long procedures , one's personal details , medical histories and other information can be obtained through the use of RFIDs .
This reduces time taken to track down these details and hence makes procedures simpler .
It also allows for the tracking of patients when they are lost .
This is especially the case for elderly people suffering from illnesses such as dementia who tend to lose their way .
Hospital staff and family members can thus easily track down the locations of their loved ones with the use of the RFID ({http://www .antonio-aguilar .com/files/papers/hisi_paper .pdf}[HYPERLINK: http://www .antonio-aguilar .com/files/papers/hisi_paper .pdf] , 2009) .
RFIDs are also used in monitoring crimes and in keeping our society safe .
Through the use of RFIDs , escaped convicts can be easily traced .
Locations of ex-convicts can also be known so as to track their daily activities .
It also makes things easier for the police and government agencies to locate them should they engage in a crime .
Hence safety of  society is ensured .
Alternatively , RFIDs are a beneficial tool for convicts as it gives them a chance of entering society again .
This is because the police would be able to track the locations of the convicts and hence would be more willing to allow these convicts out of prison and into society .
(Banks , Hanny , Pachano & Thompson , 2007)
However , there are also downsides to the use of RFIDs .
The main issues concern privacy and health .
The use of such a tracking device would mean that the locations and actions of the person will always be known .
Hence the person might feel that he is always being watched and would not have the freedom to do whatever he wants .
Health is also a concern as the implants of RFID into the body might lead to complications and hence cause health problems .
Nonetheless , these problems can be solved with advancing technology .
Data protection technology has already been put in place to ensure that privacy of individuals is not compromised(http://www .rfidconsultation .eu/ ,2009) .
Restrictions can also be made to prevent leakages .
With regards to health concerns , precautionary measures can be put in place to ensure the safety of the human implants .
Operations can be carried out with extra care to reduce the risk of complications .
In conclusion , RFIDs should not be banned as it can benefit society widely in many ways .
Despite the disadvantages it may pose , these can be offset by appropriate actions put in place .
Hence , society should not totally shun away from the use of RFID to track people but put in place measures to overcome the problems so as to ensure its optimal use .
Today , Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) technology has been used almost worldwide .
Many countries are developing this technology with positive anticipation of its useful applications and benefits .
However , the use of RFID in tracking people has brought about a lot ofcontroversy .
Nevertheless , the use of RFID technologies to track people is essential in today's society as it is effective in locating people .
Therefore , the use of RFID to track people should not be banned .
There are two important reasons why RFID technology to track people should not be banned .
Firstly , its use in hospitals is important as it reduces the chances of misidentification of patients (http://www .antonio- aguilar .com/files/papers/hisi_paper .pdf , 2009) .
Besides , there have been many cases of infections that spread rapidly among the human population .
Thus , it is a challenge for authorities and medical personal to keep track of infected patients .
However , with the use of RFID to track people , this challenge may be overcome as hospitals use a "specially developed Hospital Movement Tracking System (HTMS) to trace the movements of Health care workers , patients and hospital visitors" (Banks , Hanny , Pachano & Thompson , 2007 p .420) .
Secondly , the use of RFID to track people r the safety of workers who are working in hazardous working conditions .
In the event of an accident , rescue operators can locate workers who are RFID tagged and save them as soon as possible (Banks , Hanny , Pachano & Thompson , 2007 p .469) .
Moreover , RFID technologies are durable  and are able to withstand adverse conditions (Banks , Hanny , Pachano & Thompson , 2007 p .469) .
Thus , this can help reduce casualties and assist rescue work to proceed smoothly .
Arguments against the use of RFID to track people could be the long- term health implications to the human body (http://www .rfidconsultation .eu/ , 2009) .
However , the World Health Organization has found out that safe use of RFID will not have any adverse effects on human health health (http://www .rfidconsultation .eu/ , 2009) .
Moreover , others oppose this as it causes invasion of privacy due to leakage of personal information to the third part (Banks , Hanny , Pachano & Thompson , 2007 p .269) .
Nevertheless , there is data protection technology that is already in place to prevent unauthorized individuals from accessingsensitive information .
(http://www .rfidconsultation .eu/ , 2009)
In conclusion , we should not ban RFID technologies to track people as there are many benefits and because of its use as an effective measure to locate individuals during times of emergencies .
In recent years , the aging process has affected many countries as the life expectancy of people has increased .
This is due to countries becoming more affluent , and thus people  better living environment and are also more educated to be conscious of their health .
However , living longer also means the need to depend on others as aging will weaker a person physically and thus results in a person unable to contribute to the society .
In order to ease the aging process such that the elderly can live without being neglected and also in comfort , various policies have been implemented .
To a large extent , these have helped to ease the aging process through investing in healthcare for the elderly , giving financial aids to the elderly and also enhancing the psychological well being of the elderly .
Firstly , Governments are setting aside more funds for healthcare to meet the growing demand of the elderly .
In Singapore , $4 billion was committed over 5 years to expand the healthcare infrastructure which includes redevelopment of older hospitals and also building of 2 new hospitals(Government of Singapore , 2009) .
Healthcare professionals like nurses are also trained to be able to handle more complicated procedures as compared to the past (The straits times , 17 August 2009) .This provides quality healthcare for the elderly in a high standard of living environment .
It may be costly to implement these policies , but it is necessary as in future the aging population is projected to soar .
In Japan , it is expensive to create and own a nurse robot , but it is necessary as in future there will be lack of human resources to take care of the elderly(James Brooke , 5 March 2004) .
Such technology will allow the elderly to be self equipped to take care of themselves , which is vital in the current competitive society where their children will be overloaded with work to take care of them .
Secondly , the financial aids plan policy makers come up with  also manages to ease the aging process .
Governments help to reduce the burden of the elderly by subsidizing healthcare , giving financial aid and also forcing  people to save for retirement .
In Singapore , the elderly are entitled to a subsidy of 75 per cent of the fees charged at polyclinics and even free medical service for frail or disabled elderly(Government of Singapore , 2009) .
However , some may argue that the financial benefits may still be inadequate as the elderly may need long term medical treatment and take longer time to recover .
Also , the elderly may abuse the medical services when they are provided with financial aid .
Thus , to counter these problems there is also the Central Provident Fund (CPF) which consists of compulsory medical savings in Medisave , health insurance in MediShield and government aid in Medifund to make the people save for their own retirement(Government of Singapore , 2009) .
This will lighten the financial burden of the elderly , easing the aging process as they can retire with more security and less worry .
In addition , enhancing the psychological well being of the elderly can make aging less depressing and cultivates a pleasant lifestyle for the elderly , thus making the aging process more enjoyable .
There are policies like revising the retirement age from 65 to 67 in the United States (U .S . Social Security Administration , 1 April 2009) and also from 60 to 65 in Taiwan(The China Post news staff , 19 April 2008) .This allows older age group to continue to contribute to the economy and feel useful .
There are also retraining and upgrading programs , like the Senior Community Service Employment Program initiated by the United States Department of Labor (U .S . Department of Labor , Employment & Training Administration (ETA) , 13 Jan 2009) , to make them be as competent as the young people , making the elderly still feel young at heart .
These will have positive effects on the mental health of the elderly , easing the aging process .
Although it may be difficult to totally change the mindset of the elderly as aging will wear them out , these policies at least allow the elderly to not feel like a burden to the society .
Moreover , these policies will give the older aged group more choices for choosing the kind of lifestyles they want .
If they prefer a relaxing aging process , they can also engage in activities in the community centre which will also enhance their mental well being and ease the aging process .
However , Critics of this position point out that there are also policies that have not helped to ease the aging process .
This is particularly the case for policies that aim to increase birth rate .
By increasing birth rate , there will be more productive population who can generate income to support the future aging population .
For example , the baby bonus scheme in Singapore has been ineffective as the birth rate remains at 1 .28 .
The attractive financial incentives like giving cash gift of up to $4 ,000 each for the 1st and 2nd child and $6 ,000 each for  a 3rd and 4th child and also providing  of 4 months have not been enough to make people want to have more children .
This can be due to the lifestyle of Singaporeans like having long working hours and high standard of living; thus , they prefer not to have any children .
As long as the government considers solutions to these issues like encouraging working from home , the policy may be more effective .
If these policies were successful , they will definitely ease the aging process .
In conclusion , current policies have helped to ease the aging process in many different areas .
In the coming years , more countries will also be facing this problem and thus different types of  policies should be explored to prepare for the future .
That there should be a limit on public spending on the aged so that money could be diverted to other areas of the country's development (Peterson , 2001) is a suggestion that should be implemented in order to combat the rising cost of healthcare for the elderly .
With the rapid growth of the elderly population , for example in a country like Singapore , where the median age is expected to hit 41 years old from the present 36 (Wijaya , 2009) , increasing public spending in healthcare could further strain the government's expenditure as more money needs to be poured in to cater to the growing numbers of elderly in the country .
There are several factors that explain the need to limit public spending on elderly healthcare .
Government needs to focus the spending on more important sectors first like economic development before worrying about healthcare for the elderly .
As Friedland and Summer (2005) suggested , with more economic growth , the country will be able to have more choices and more resources to invest into the elderly healthcare sector .
This move will be beneficiary in the long run as it does not only ensure that the country is progressing economically , it is also securing a brighter future for the healthcare sector as more money could be spent on it  .
In contrast , if the government decides to cut back spending on economic development and rather channel it into the elderly healthcare sector , tougher choices like tax increase have to be made in the future if the economic development is unable to sustain the rise in healthcare spending .
For example , assume that the government has 100 dollars and it has 2 choices of either investing it for 2 times the return or spending it on healthcare .
Assume that the government decides to invest all of the 100 dollars at first and gets 200 dollars in return .
The government can now choose to allocate some money on healthcare , invest the remaining money and as time goes by , not only the government will be earning more profits but the healthcare will be getting a bigger allocation .
However , should the government decide to spend all of the 100 dollars into healthcare , there will be no profits and the government will also suffer from a deficit .
Secondly , public spending on elderly healthcare should only be limited to the elderly who really need it to prevent abuse by other citizens .
If no limits are set , other citizens can abuse the system by using it indiscriminately  , denying the rights of healthcare to truly needy patients .
An example could be seen in the United Kingdom  , where healthcare is fully subsidized by the government .
People would go to the doctor for even the smallest discomfort , causing doctors to waste time on non critical care and forsaking those that need immediate attention (Messerli , 2009) .
This may in turn cause a clogging up of cases where there will be more patients waiting longer for their operation  , reducing the quality of the healthcare sector (Press Association , 2005) .
Besides encouraging abuse , increased spending in healthcare for the elderly will also cause an increase in taxpayers' money to subsidize the cost , placing a heavier burden on the people .
This could probably cause a public outcry as the current economic crisis has yet to fully subside and the government should instead focus on recovering the country's economy first .
Public spending on the elderly should therefore be limited to those with chronic conditions or need immediate attention who cannot afford the cost of healthcare to avoid abuse and increase of taxpayers' money .
Finally , the responsibility of taking care  the elderly should first rest on the children , not the government , if the elderly has any working child .
Some might argue that it is the government's duty to look after the welfare of its citizens , but if the government were to look after all of the elderly without the help of the children , it would certainly cost the government an enormous amount of time and money .
The government needs to first concentrate on more important matters regarding the country  , for example in issues regarding national safety , trade , education , international relations and defense , to ensure that the nation's interests are safeguarded and that the government does act as a nursery home for the old .
Public spending on elderly healthcare must not be raised to compensate for the failure of children to look after their parents .
Children should be taught the importance of filial piety since young to ensure that they do not abandon  their responsibility of taking care of their parents when they are old .
The government could also enact a law to compel children to support their parents if the children are capable and the parents are in need .
An example would be the Maintenance of Parents Act in Singapore , where parents could lawfully demand support from their children in court .
In conclusion , there are many reasons  why  public spending on elderly healthcare should be limited to allow governments to channel the money to other areas of development .
While healthcare for the elderly is still important ,  governments must ensure that other important areas will not get neglected as well .
Ageing population is a serious problem faced by many developed states .
It is mainly caused by the increased number of elderly and the drop in birth rate .
The ageing population is creating many social problems such as healthcare problems , high government expenses and high income taxes , which are causing stress for  young workers and the aged people .
Many states such as the US , the UK , Japan and Singapore start to implement various policies such as increasing child birth rate and introducing plans for the elderly and health care policies to ease the ageing process .
However , most of these policies tend to be ineffective in easing the ageing process because they either have their limitations or fail to solve the social problems behind the ageing process .
This essay is going to examine the limitations and the problems ignored by those current policies .
Health care policies in many developed countries ease the ageing process to a very limited extent , because they create social burden and fail to service minorities most of the time .
For example , the UK has tried to make the nation a welfare state , but this leaves heavy tax burden to the working class and creates low working incentive for the workers .
It shows that medical policies must be planned well to provide health care to people who really need it .
For example , Japan has introduced medical service which allows its citizens to save for their personal medical account so that they can use the money when they fall sick in their old age .
Similarly , Singapore has introduced the same kind of policies called Medi-save and Medi-shield .
However , these policies cannot help those people who have long term diseases because these diseases require a huge amount of money to cure .
Ironically , the World Health Organization has released a report in year 2006 which shows that the number of people who have long term diseases such as heart disease and cancer is increasing sharply .
The data also shows that stressful working life contributes to the poor health of the people .
Moreover , the minorities who and do not have proper job or income do not have a medical care account will not be taken care of by the health service .
They will have nothing to rely on when they fall sick .
Therefore , the health care policy in most developed countries should be improved to help those patients with long term diseases and those who are neglected .
The baby bonus policy also has its limitation in easing the ageing process through increasing the birth rate to support the elderly .
Today ,  two leading states  in the areas of slowing down the ageing population , Japan and Singapore ,  have implemented "Baby Bonus Policy" .
Basically , families that give birth to more than one child will get economic support from the government as they help ease the the ageing process .
This is because  many elderly couples only have one child to support them and this always puts a heavy burden on the child .
Hence , with more children , more economic support could be provided and the old parents could be taken care of better .
However , the "Baby Bonus Policy" does not work well although almost everyone is aware of its benefit .
For example , Singapore's birth rate is 1 .28 , which is the lowest in the world .
This is because firstly , the stressful social environment  forces couples to put their time and effort in their work , so that they are unable to spend time with each other .
Secondly , getting more salary through longer working hours makes life much easier than appealing for limited economic aids by having many children .
Thus , the government fails to notice the two root causes of the evil .
Therefore , baby bonus policy could not increase the birth rate effectively in easing ageing process .
The modern society today is imbued with modern values that lead to the ageing population , thus causing  some government policies to become ineffective in easing the ageing process .
Many states have introduced housing policies , which allow the young couples to live near their parents or which give priority in purchasing houses to those people who have married .
This allows the couples to take care of each other especially when they are old , or to take care of their parents when they are still young .
However , the states fail to realize that people's values towards family are changing today .
The family bonding in most western societies is very weak and the young generation does not really have a sense of filial piety in their minds .
Also , the stressful working market created by capitalism today is taking away so much time and effort from people that they do not havetime with their family , or even cannot think of having a family .
It creates a modern value that allows people of opposite sex to live together without having a family .
So , what if people do not get married ?
What if the idea of family vanishes ?
What if the young no longer care about their parents ?
If all these assumptions occur , the housing policy  will not be relevant at all .
Hence , besides housing policies , the governments should also raise the awareness of having strong family bonding .
In conclusion , most of the current policies in easing the ageing process have their limitations or are ineffective .
The fundamental problem is that the states fail to realize the underlying social problems which contribute to the stressful ageing process .
Hence , in order to ease the ageing process , the policies should be designed to solve the root problems of the evil rather than just focus on the surface of the problems .
Population aging , as stated in the introduction of the report World Population Aging: 1950-2050 (2002)  , is the process by which older individuals become a proportionally larger share of the total population .
It was at first experienced by the developed countries , but is now taking place around the globe .
Why is our world aging ?
This can be explained through two main factors .
Firstly ,  the elderly are leading longer lives .
A special report from Economist .com (2009) states that average life expectancy for the whole world was only 30 years during the 1990s , and that for the rich countries under 50 .
However , the figures have each increased to 67 and 78 , and the increase has no signs of stopping .
The next factor contributing to the aging phenomenon is the declining of birth rates as people tend to have fewer kids than in the previous years .
Therefore , as this phenomenon poses a certain threat to the development of a country , many governments have produced policies and initiatives to ease the aging process .
Nevertheless , the strategies taken do not seem to help ease the aging process .
Between the two significant contributing factors to this phenomenon , declining fertility is likely to hold primary responsibility for the aging global population .
As a result , new policies are now introduced to increase the birth rate .
For instance , the "Stop at two" policy that was once carried out in Singapore is now replaced by "Three , or more if you can afford it" policy , together with other incentives .
Despite these measures , the birth rate of Singapore has not increased significantly (Mui Teng Yap , 2003) .
The "Stop at two" policy had been so successful that couples in Singapore saw that they could have a better standard of living with a smaller family .
Educated women prefer to pursue their careers before getting married; thus , women have a sense of insecurity in losing their job when they have to take maternity leave or when they are about to give birth to their child .
Other than that , educated women do not just want to be successful in their careers , but they also want to be  a good mother .
Therefore , by having a small family , a woman may be able to be more attentive to each and every child , in terms of education , values , and overall well being , so that the children will be able to survive in the competitive world ahead of them .
As we grow older , our body turns weak and so , we tend to face difficulties in conducting normal activities in daily life .
The declining performance of the body limits the ability of the aged to care for themselves .
But , we are now living in a world surrounded by all sorts of advance technology .
It has improved our quality of life in many ways , especially in the field of medical science .
High awareness for healthcare among elderly people allows them to seek professional help such as undergoing kneecap replacement surgery to ease the pain of arthritics .
Their children are also willing to finance the medical bill as there are government policies to cover the spending .
For instance , in Malaysia by paying your parents medical bill , you are able to claim up to RM1000 .
This is a government policy to encourage filial piety .
However , this leads to an implication that the upper class and middle class people who are likely to have easier access to  information will take advantage of this policy .
This , in turn will create a misguided impression that medical fees of the elderly are high , resulting in the debate between the government and policy makers whether to limit healthcare spending on the aged or not .
Thus , the welfare of those who are really in need is also neglected .
Some may argue that the measure of increasing the retirement age should be able to reduce the negative effects of the aging population .
It is true that by letting the elderly people carry on working can increase manpower in labor markets and simultaneously  increase their savings to support themselves during old age .
However , are employers willing to do so ?
Employers tend to hire the inexperienced young people in order to save money .
It is also a common mindset that young people have a higher level of work productivity in contrast to the elderly people .
In some cases , employers have the notion that in order to employ the aged , the setting of the workplace might have to undergo some changes to accommodate to the needs of the elderly .
In short , life today is not similar to that in the past , and challenges lies ahead waiting for us to overcome .
The effects of the aging population may be exaggerated , but we should not lack foresight and neglect them .
Therefore , government and policy makers have to put more effort to ease the aging process as the elderly are still experiencing inadequate protection .
Singapore's population is the second fastest ageing in the world after Japan .
In year 2000 , 7 .2 percent of the population was aged 65 and above .
By 2030 , the figure is expected to increase to 18 .4 percent for those aged 65 and above .
By 2050 , the figure will increase to 35 percent for those aged 60 years and above (Ministry of Community Development , Youth and Sports 2008 , February) .
Ageing population is a challenge for Singapore for the coming years .
Therefore public spending on the aged should not be limited and used to divert to other areas of the country's development .
The development of the country is important .
Money is needed in areas  such as transportation , research and development , infrastructure , investment and defense .
However , Singapore is currently a developed country .
In terms of quality of life , Singapore  tops in Asia and is No .
32 in the world (Mercer Human Resource Consulting Survey in 2008) .
Singapore also scored 22nd in monocle's list of top livable cities in 2008 and ranked top 5 in city infrastructure (Mercer's 2009 Quality of Living survey highlights 28 April 2009)  .
Singapore's Changi airport has accumulated 250 awards and is recognized as one of the best airports in the world .
Therefore the current problem Singapore is facing now is the aged population .
Money should be allocated for the ageing population .
Singapore is currently a developed country .
Currently the investment in the resort worlds in both the Marina Bay and Sentosa will bring in more income to Singapore .
35000 new jobs will be created and expected to bring in an estimated 1 .5 billion annual boost for GDP in the country (May 27 , 2006 Newspaper) .
Hence money is still needed for the country's development in order to maintain its world class standard  .
Although money is important for the growth of Singapore , the current problem of the ageing population must still be addressed .
Citizens are the most valuable asset of a country .
In order for  Singapore to prosper , money is necessary to solve the problem of ageing population .
In order to encourage the elderly people's self-reliance , the government introduced central provident fund in 1955 .
It is a compulsory saving plan for the work force .
Every month both the employer and the employee contribute to the account .
This is to ensure that individuals will be able to take care of themselves when they grow old .
The money can also be used to pay for medical cost incurred  .
Despite the introduction of the central provident fund , the aged population feel that it is insufficient for them to retire .
Having better medical facilities and better standard of living , people live longer now .
In 2008 , the average life expectancy of Singaporeans has increased to 80 from 61 in 1957 (Mon , Apr 14 2008 News Straits Times) .
Hence funds are needed to prepare for the ageing population who live longer now .
Money is needed to encourage the elderly to work longer and pursue lifelong learning .
For example incentives are given to companies like MacDonald who employ retired workers .
Trainings are given at subsidized rate for workers to upgrade themselves and to remain competitive in the workforce .
Children are encouraged to take care of their parents .
For example , housing grants are given to encourage children to stay close to their parents .
The government has increased the housing grants from $30000 to $40000 (HDB Website) .
New condominium units are built with two units on each level to encourage children to stay with their parents .
Even though the government encourages children to take care of their parents , there are still cases where parents sue their children for not taking care of them .
Singapore government has passed the maintenance of parents act to make children look after their parents .
In cases where the elderly do not have any children or do not have any savings left , money is also needed to cater for their daily expenses , housing and medical expenses .
Public spending should not be limited as the population in Singapore is facing an ageing population .
Eventually by 2050 , 35 percent of the population will have reached the age of 60 years and above .
Money are needed to spend on areas like medical centres , new infrastructure and homes for the elderly .
More medical centres is needed to cater for the ageing population which require more healthcare assistance .
For  buildings like shopping malls and HDB flats , the government and developers should spend more money on building elderly friendly infrastructure and upgrading  existing HDB flats to make it more elderly friendly .
Examples include lift upgrading , slopes for wheel chairs and old folk corners .
Despite the fact that ageing population is imposing more cost on the government , their well being must still be taken care of .
If not , when elections come , the government might lose their votes as 35 percent of the population will reach the age of 60 and above by 2050 .
This makes a big difference in the election .
In contrast , although money is needed for areas of the country's development , public spending should not be limited on the aged .
