Often , the handicapped can hardly make a stand in applying for a job if they are to compete with the others because of their physical weaknesses and lack of living skills .
public spending will come in handy to support their living .
Some may argue that the  aged need more money as they are unable to earn income to support their living .
However , the  aged are still be able to be involved in the work field by extending their working lives and accumulating wealth for their later years .
In  contrast , the handicapped can hardly get a job , not to mention that they can accumulate wealth through working .
Therefore public spending should be diverted to other areas to help the needy and unfortunate .
Furthermore , limited public spending on the elderly can encourage the grown-up children to take up their filial responsibility .
If the government reduces public spending on elders , those whose living cost depends on the public spending have to rely on their children for support .
In the past , the elders have worked hard to raise their children and provide the best for their children .
Hence , the grown children should appreciate their upbringing and take good care of them in return .
There may be opposing views which claims that the grown children do not have much money to support the elderly as they have their own families to support .
Nevertheless , the grown children can actually do some adjustments to their monthly expenditure by practicing cost saving to have sufficient money to support their own family and their elder's living cost .
This will increase the willingness of the grown children to take care of their parents and realize their obligation to their parents .
In a nutshell , government should change their mindset and policy in order to meet the modern challenges .
Policy maker should limit public spending on the aged and divert money to other country's development to maintain a balance development of the country .
Or else , the country development would be stagnant and the nation would not have to live in a comfortable life .
If the government helps the senior citizens with public spending by constraining the fiscal cost on other areas of country development , the government would actually put the country in a straggling condition .
Due to poor fertility rates and late marriages , the government is now confronted with the problem of an aging population .
This is a phenomenon with dire consequences , such as having to direct large amounts of money to take care of the elderly .
Examples include a need to build facilities that are elderly-friendly and heavy subsidizing  their medical fees due to their poor health and low income .
Although forking out a lump sum of money for medical fees is inevitable , the government should not neglect the economic growth of the country .
Thus funding for the elderly medical fees should be limited so as to divert funds to other areas which are more necessary for improvement .
We cannot deny the fact that what we have today is a result of the hard work of the elderly in their prime years .
It is only right that the government takes care of them , and spends vast amounts of money on them with no questions asked .
Critics of this approach have argued that if the government continues spending , more tax will be imposed on each working individual and elder dependency will rise .
It would be very stressful for them , having to keep up with both the pace of work and tax expenses .
Furthermore , there are key areas such as tourism , education and technology which will produce significant results if enough resources are channeled to them .
Other than the government spending  , there are other alternatives which can be implemented to remedy the situation .
Firstly , it is through stressing filial obligation and increasing the willingness of tomorrow's grown children , however numerous or productive  , to support their own elderly parents through informal and familial channels .
(Peterson .P , 2001) .
This is a social responsibility for each working individual , and it is often easier to get people to be socially responsible than to increase their tax contributions .
The government should give incentives to children who live near their parents , such as cheaper housing , or give priority to them when allocating flats .
Secondly , it is by requiring people to provide in advance for their own old-age dependency .
They should be encouraged or compelled by law to save and invest more of their income earned while they are active in the work force .
(Paterson ,P . ,2001 2001) .
Minor monthly contributions made during their working years will definitely accumulate to a substantial pool of wealth for their retirement days .
Diverting funds to other more vital areas of improvements has its benefits too .
Firstly , there will be economic growth and country prosperity .
Singapore has strived hard to achieve the status as a tourism hub , and the revenue that could be generated from it alone should never be overlooked .
Therefore , if more funds are diverted to it instead of to the  elderly , there is no doubt that the country will experience tremendous economic growth and be prosperous .
Secondly , the future workforce of the country will be very productive .
A productive workforce is often defined as one which possesses the best qualifications , and education emphasis is the only way to go about it .
Thus , expanding the current budget on education will surely result in a larger and more affluent generation in the future .
Spending on the elderly is necessary , and it could be done on a ration basis .
We've discussed the far-reaching effects of diverting to other more vital areas of improvement and it outweighs any existing issues .
There are also other available alternatives which could be implemented to deal with the medical needs of the elderly , such as stressing filial obligations and introducing retirement schemes .
The limit , however , should be duly considered by the government in line with its current policies .
In a survey conducted by Manpower Incorporated , 40% of global leaders felt that introducing population was to be one of the most crucial problems in the future (AARP Multinational Survey of Opinion Leaders 2006 , March 2007) .
Thus it comes as no surprise that governments around the world have stepped up their efforts to alleviate the effects of global aging .
The social policies adopted have greatly introduced the older population into the workforce and the volunteering sector , thus keeping them actively involved in the community and easing the aging process to a large extent .
Firstly , governments have reduced the dangers of an ageing population by encouraging retirees to participate actively in volunteering (MCYS Media Release No .
03/2008) to increase their mental alertness and at the same time tap on their wisdom to aid the community .
However , critics argue that citizens are unaware of these volunteering opportunities .
Also , they contend that most would be unwilling to volunteer during their 'golden years' , thus wasting the government's efforts to increase volunteering opportunities for the elder population .
This claim is flawed as the government has been stepping up its efforts to increase awareness of elder volunteerism through public campaigns and functions .
Fairs have also been organised to encourage active ageing through volunteerism (MCYS Media Release No .
03/2008) .
As a result , there has been a rising number of senior volunteers over the years .
The Retired and Senior Volunteers Programme (RSVP) is an example of an avenue that provides opportunities for retirees to volunteer and use their skills to help others and also nurture new skills along the way .
To date , it has over 500 , 000 volunteers (Senior corps , electronic reference) , thus proving wrong the notion that people are unaware and uninterested to volunteer in their 'golden years' .
The high membership is testimony to the fact that volunteering will give the elderly spiritual fulfillment in their later years .
Secondly , governments in affected countries have introduced incentives to encourage companies to hire and retrain older workers , thus boosting the workforce and easing the aging process .
This will ensure that the huge older population can contribute effectively to the workforce .
Also , they will be able to accumulate more savings and not be over-reliant on the government for pension benefits .
This policy has been effective as surveys have proved that with the retraining and incentives to hire older workers put in place , employers have been increasingly open about hiring older workers .
According to a survey conducted by Manpower Incorporated in October 2006 , 48% and 43% of employers had strategies to hire and preserve older Singaporean workers respectively , whereas in Japan , 83% of employers had strategies to preserve older workers .
This proves that the governments' strategies to promote the hiring of older workers into the workforce have been effective .
According to  Singapore's Ministerial Committee on Ageing (MCA) , employment of Singapore citizens aged 55 to 64 increased from 53 .7% in 2006 to 56 .2% in 2007 (MCYS Media Release No .
03/2008) .
This shows that the retraining of skills have indeed helped older workers to become more productive leading to the increased willingness of employers to hire them .
Lastly , the Singapore government has been encouraging citizens to retire later to accumulate more savings .
As a result , Singaporean working males aged 60 to 64 increased from 49% in 1996 to 63% in 2006 , while the number of  females increased from 15% to 26% (Ministry of Manpower Press Release , 22/2/07) .
This proves that the government's promotion of a longer working life have effectively influenced the mindset and convinced the older population to contribute to the workforce for a longer period of time .
Fiscal cost that was previously used to distribute pension benefits to retirees could now be diverted to funding retraining programmes and monetary incentives to companies to hire and retrain older workers , thus further boosting the economy .
Facing an ageing population , the Singapore government had done research and development to improve the ageing process .
This is so that we will be able to harness the social possibilities , while at the same time , prepare to tackle challenges arising from the ageing population .
The ageing process brings to mind deteriorating health  which requires lots of medical attention .
To make matters worse , social problems such as disrespectfulness and the lack of filial piety among the younger generations arises .
This would lead to emotional problems , where an elderly feels like the "leftover of society" .
Gerard Ee , chairman of Council for Third Age said , we have to deal with housing , health , financial needs and accessibility before older people can be fully integrated into society .
Singapore has looked into the development of infrastructure to create a barrier free society for the elderly .
The main areas of concerns were the Housing Development Board (HDB) precincts and public transport island wide .
Firstly , the government  launched the Lift Upgrading Programme for the benefit of flat owners without direct access to lifts .
By doing so , elderly can then conveniently leave their HDB homes to access shops and services within the precinct (HDB , 2001) .
Next , new buses are now designed with low floors step-free and wheelchair accessible .
According to the Committee of Aging Issues (CAI) , a barrier free environment is important to allow senior citizens to live independently and move out into the community to participate actively in society (CAI , 2006) .
The newly designed buses complement the elder friendly Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) systems , making Singapore an accessible city for all .
Hence , today's elderly has unobstructed access from homes to public amenities , communal and recreational facilities .
In recognition of what the government has done , people have begun to ask if these improvements could really ease the ageing process .
Now elderly are given more access to the public , but the ultimate choice still lies with them .
What could be hindering the decision is their children's disapproval or even themselves .
This is the case as most people will agree that elderly are not able to take care of themselves outside .
We cannot deny the fact that they require more response time and have certain constraints in physical movements .
A little carelessness on the road could cause accidents , thus creating more burdens to their love ones .
Also , they are usually the victims of crime .
However , the government has been creating awareness on looking out for each other especially the elderly in society .
For example , from young , schools teach civic and moral education to educate us on how to take care of the elderly , to be patient with them , to respect them and even offer help to them .
Television programs such as Crime Watch also increases the knowledge of elderly to be wary of conmen and to prevent crime by not wearing excessive valuables .
The second area of research and development is on dementia .
Researchers found that people who retired later are able to avoid Alzheimer's disease longer than people who retired earlier (The Straits Times , 2009) .
The first way of tackling this issue is to raise the retirement age to 62 years old .
This not only keeps the elderly mind active , it also helps them to cope financially with rising medical costs and brings in self-satisfaction for being able to contribute to the society .
Secondly , CAI emphasizes  having strong family ties across generations to ensure that the family continues to be the first line of support .
This is essential to the elderly so they will not feel so helpless and unwanted .
Lastly , the Government has also encouraged activities and interactions by setting up elderly corners at void decks with facilities such as chess tables .
The aim is to prevent the elderly from shutting themselves out of the society , resulting in mind-robbing Alzheimer's disease .
In conclusion , the current research and development approaches adopted by the Singapore Government are helpful to a large extent in easing the ageing process .
With the development of infrastructure and medical field as mentioned above , these problems are better handled .
The elderly can now move around independently and conveniently , decreasing the burden on working adults .
The aging population has been an ongoing problem in  countries over the world .
It is not much of a difference in Singapore as the Strait Times (2009) stated that there has been an increase in the aging population to about 300 ,000 people who are over the age of 65 today and this figure is expected to increase to 900 ,000 by 2030 .
This shows that more attention is required for the aging population  to prepare it to embrace these elderly in the near future .
Hence , the public spending on the aged should not be limited and  be spent on other areas of the country's development as the money is needed for the healthcare and financial needs needsr the aged .
As one gets older , one is more vulnerable to illness which explains the need of spending on the healthcare industry .
In the CIA factbook (2009) , the life expectancy for Singapore is 81 .98 years , which is ranked fourth in the world .
This means that the aged would live longer and drain their family's and their own savings as the hospital fees are costly and thus more subsidies are required (Friedland & Summer , 2005 , p .g .17) .
Moreover , money is also needed to provide the prevention and screenings programmes for the elderly and to educate them about the benefits of having a healthy lifestyle and ways to stay healthy .
These screenings can also help to identify potential health problems that they might have and get them to seek treatment before it worsens and disrupts their daily activities .
Hence , spending on elderly healthcare is necessary as it helps to educate the elderly on the importance of a healthy lifestyle while reducing the burden on the elderly and their family for the costly healthcare services .
Moreover , there is a high chance that the elderly may use up their retirement savings on healthcare and daily necessities despite the implementation of Central Provident Fund (CPF) to lessen their burden .
Dr Ng (2007) stated that CPF members would also use up their CPF account in time due to the higher standard of living in the future .
In addition , based on Statistic Singapore (2008) , the old age support ratio has decreased from 11 .8 in 1990 to 8 .4 in 2008 .
This shows that there are fewer young working adults to support the elderly .
It also signifies that the elderly has to either prolong retirement or increase their saving in order to support themselves after retirement .
Therefore , retraining is needed for the elderly as through  retraining , they can upgrade their skills and adapt to the demanding working environment to save  for the future and contribute to the economy .
Hence , spending on pension and retraining for the elderly is essential and should not be limited as it aids them in being financially independent after retirement .
On the other hand , money is also needed in the other areas of development like education .
Education plays an important part in the country's development and growth as it helps in nurturing the young who are the country's future .
Thus , the expenditure on education is also important instead of focusing on the aging population .
Nevertheless , the Ministry of Finance (2009) had stated that they are planning to provide quality education by setting aside $4 .4 billion for basic education for the young and $3 .5 billion for the higher educational institutions like the polytechnics and universities .
This is in the hope of improving the education sector and nurture the young better for the future of Singapore .
Moreover , the Ministry of Education (2009) had also stated that the budget for education had increased by 5 .5% .
Hence , this shows that despite the increase in the spending for the aged , it does not mean that the other areas of development will be neglected as each development plays an important part in the growth of the country .
In conclusion , spending on the aged should not be limited due to costly healthcare expenses and limited retirement saving for the future .
These expenditures can help to improve the lifestyle of elderly and being healthy the elderly will be able to prolong their retirement which in turn helps in improving the economy .
Hence , not only the country but its people will also benefit from the economic growth .
27 .3% of Singapore's GDP (Gross Domestic Product) is attributed to the manufacturing sector (Nah , March 2006) .
The manufacturing industry in Singapore is one of the important growth engines of the economy .
A large amount of money is diverted to the R&D (Research & Development) sector to give Singapore a competitive edge over its competitors .
But this has resulted in uproars from the people and they claim that more resources should be diverted into the welfare schemes for the aged instead .
So , who is defined as the aged ?
Currently there is no fixed age group where the aged is clearly defined .
Regardless of how the aged is defined , no human is able to survive without money in this current world .
Therefore in order for the aged to be better off , the Singapore economy has to be constantly growing and this can be achieved by diverting more resources into our R&D sector so the local products will be greatly differentiated and value added .
There is a common misconception that most welfare states end up being in debt and the people have a higher tendency to be over-reliant .
However there are no statistics to show that higher government expenditure on the social welfare leads to lower growth and lower productivity .
Well known welfare states such as Germany and Denmark do not necessarily do better or worse  economically than countries which have limited social expenditure such as Japan .
Denmark's welfare expenditure contributes to 37 .9% of the nation's GDP and the GDP per capita (PPPUS$) is $37 ,265 whereas Japan's welfare expenditure contributes to 16 .9% of the nation's GDP and its GDP per capita (PPPUS$) is $38 ,559 (Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development [OECD] 2001) .
From these statistics , we can conclude that it is also possible for Singapore to learn from these success stories and increase welfare expenditure while achieving economic growth at the same time .
Singapore is different from the welfare states in Europe such as Germany and Denmark .
Singapore is practicing the open market policy and thus is more susceptible to external factors .
A recent example would be when the United States's economy fell during the credit crisis , Singapore was badly impacted by the recession .
One of the major growth engines in the Singapore's economy is the manufacturing sector .
Unlike China which has abundance in labour , Singapore on the other hand has little natural resources and is unable to compete with China on a large scale .
(Singapore , a small country with limited resources can outperform others by) distinguishing our manufacturing goods by investing more money to invent cutting edge technology , to increase efficiency , to make our products unique and competitive in the market .
In order to finance the current schemes in Singapore , the economy has to be growing first so that it could support its schemes .
Currently Government Health Expenditure has been limited at 0 .9% from 2005 to 2007(Ministry of Health [MOH] , 2001) .
Since Government Health Expenditure is capped at a percentage of GDP regardless of boom or bust in the economy , therefore the amount of money diverted to Health Expenditure in a bullish economy is higher than when it is during a bearish economy .
As the saying goes "Give a man a fish and you feed him for a day .
Teach a man to fish and you feed him for a lifetime" This is especially true for the senior citizens whose skills are outdated in the current society but have an able body to earn an income for themselves .
Instead of diverting resources to finance the welfare schemes , the government should instead divert resources into retraining and integrating the senior citizens back into the work force .
Senior citizens possess a large amount of experience which is valuable to the younger generation now , thus they are more of an asset than a liability .
"For every working adult in Singapore , He/She has to support 8 .4 elderly residents aged 65 years and above (Ministry of Community Development , Youth and Sports [MCYS] 2008) .
Therefore to ease the burden on the younger generation who has to support the post baby boomers as they approach their retirement years , it would be a win-win situation if we integrate senior citizens back into the work force .
As countries differ both ideologically and geographically , there is no one solution that solves the current situation of an aging population .
Thus with different government's goals , the solution will be adjusted to suit the country .
But in Singapore's context , Singapore does not have any natural resources and (we) dependent on innovation and creativity to gain an advantage over its competitors .
In order to finance these welfare programs , we need to divert resources to other areas in order to have continuous growth in Singapore .
However government intervention alone is insufficient to finance the welfare schemes alone .
Thus it has included private charity organization such as National Council of Social Service (NCSS) to attend to the needs of the aged and the needy together with the help of the government .
Most importantly is the care and concern from the family which is vital to the well being of the elderly .
The BCA has acknowledged the aging problems in Singapore and released a series of Home improvement designs to cater to the needs of an aging population in Singapore .
Those designs include the manoeuvring space for wheel chair bound elderly , visuals and vibration door bells for elderly with hearing impairment and additional safety features like emergency bells in toilets .
All these features will enhance the life of the elderly as they can perform daily duties with ease .
These also allow the elderly to be independent as they no longer need to rely on others' help in their daily life .
Bus service provider SBS transit took the lead to introduce the elderly and handicap friendly buses in 2007 .
The low floor and zero stepped bus is an initiative by the SBS to ease the travelling journey for the elderly .
"This means that the elderly and other less mobile passengers will be able to board and alight easily .
This is especially important given Singapore's ageing population ."
(SBS Transit , 2007) .
It is an important innovation by  transport company , as it showcases its determination to improve the local transport facilities to facilitate the transportation for the ones with special needs .
Land Transport Authority (LTA) did their part by introducing the new elderly- friendly traffic system in March 2009 .
Making use of the new Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) technology , "Traffic lights will open their eyes to keep a look out for elderly pedestrians" (LTA , 2009) .
With the new technology , traffic lights will detect any/an elderly that's still crossing the roads and adjust the timing accordingly .
With this system in place , fewer traffic accidents involving slower moving elderly are expected , as it allows the elderly to finish crossing before the drivers are signalled to go .
Preliminary rounds of test involving 30 elderly pedestrians show that the new system is welcomed by the elderly .
Local technology company ALCOM recently came up with the elderly friendly GSM mobile phone during the COMEX 2009 .
The simple mobile phone captures the essential needs of the elderly in a simple package .
It has big key pads , easy call and hang up buttons , basic SMS functions and Phonebook memory .
It provides additional functions like quick dial buttons for them to gain quick access to those they contact very often .
The SOS button behind the phone will provide instant access to their family members in times of emergency .
The launch of this mobile phone has made communicating easier and inevitably eased the process of communication for elderly .
Despite numerous efforts to ease the process of ageing , government agencies seem to forget  the basic survival requirements for the elderly .
Most of the above technologies come with a price , and not having enough cash for the elderly is effectively cutting off all their access to the aids provided for them .
"By 2013 , those with less than the Minimum Sum of $120 ,000 and the Medisave Required Amount of $25 ,000 (currently $11 ,500) , will not be able to withdraw any CPF money" (Leong , 2007) .
With the increase of minimum sum to $120 ,000 in 2013 , many lower income workers will not meet the requirements as their CPF savings are used to finance their home loan and children's tertiary education .
Together with the increase of unemployment rates in Singapore , it presents a worrying trend of its citizens entering the retirement age of their life .
Understanding the needs of its citizens , Housing Development Board (HDB) introduced the "Lease Buyback Scheme" in March 2009 (HDB Info Web , 2009) .
The scheme aims to allow lower income families to cash out part of their money locked in the HDB flat and still be able to retain the flat for stay .
Current Research and Developments like the Home improvement designs from BCA , elderly - friendly buses from SBS transit , RFID traffic lights from LTA and GSM phones from ALCOM all hope to achieve the ultimate target of an easier life for the elderly .
Together with the government's policies to improve financial independence of the elderly , their life will definitely be greatly enhanced by the new innovations .
In this economy driven society , taking too much of the public's resources to support the elderly does not bode well for the future of the country .
Therefore , placing a cap on  public spending to support the aged should be implemented .
By limiting the resources used on the aged , other developments of the country can be better financed in order to drive the country forward .
The public spending used for the elderly such as healthcare , pension and welfare programs can be diverted into development sectors instead .
For example , the education for our youths , the nurturing of the country's youth is more important as these are the people who will eventually be the ones to carry the responsibility of maintaining the economic state of the country and to ensure a brighter future for her people .
A total budget of $8 ,701 million has been voted to MOE in FY2009 (Singapore Budget , 2009) , most of which goes into the subsidising of school fees for local students .
This ensures that Singapore youngsters get a chance at education regardless of their financial status .
By exposing every possible citizen to education , Singapore then , will she be able to continue in development .
Singapore being a resource scarce country , the only resource we can make use of is our people .
Therefore funds should go into the upbringing of the people who are able to drive the country forward in the future .
Another development sector to which Singapore directs most of its funds is to our defenses .
In the 2009 government budget , the defense sector alone accounted for 11 .4 billion Singapore dollars , which is equivalent to more than a quarter of the country's' spending (Singapore budget , 2009) .
With the recent increase in terrorism , it is important that such a huge amount goes into protecting the people of Singapore .
Some may argue that , as much as youths are our country's future , we cannot neglect the fact that these are the elders that have paved a path for the next generation to come .
Their contribution to the society should at least be recognized and to a certain extent rewarded  .
Some may argue that the incentives given by the government now are more than enough; however ,  the number of elderly people with no homes is still alarming till date .
If the government were doing enough , no elderly should be seen sleeping on chairs in parks .
They should  be instead living comfortably in their homes enjoying the fruits of their labor .
Thus limiting the funds in this sector would mean restrictions placed around how much can be done to help these people .
On the other hand , as mentioned , in this economy driven world , it would be impractical to focus our finances on the people who are no longer efficient in what they used to do .
The country will simply be burdened by placing more funds into rewarding or simply sustaining the elderly .
They should have had savings in either the form of cash or CPF to sustain them , alongside with subsides from the government to help loosen the dependency on others for help .
The rewarding of the elderly does not push the country forward , whereas it is the upbringing of our youth that will ensure a future for our country .
There is too much human factor involved when it comes to whether elders should get more funds to help them cope in their latter days , which should not be part of any equation when other development sectors can benefit instead .
In sum , the limitation of public spending on the elderly and diverting it to other developments would serve well in driving the country forward .
On one hand it is only moral that they are well taken care because of the fact that they are the ones who contributed to the society before a new generation took over , while on the other hand  allocating more public spending to them would hinder the growth of the country as a whole .
Trading the future for the past is simply not a practical choice .
Singapore has one of the fastest aging populations in the world , with people over 65 years old estimated by 2030 to make up 23% of the population , making Singapore the country with the second highest percentage of this age group in Asia just behind Japan (Asia Times , 2009) .
With the growing number of the aged in Singapore , the government should establish its bottom line for financing public healthcare for the elderly .
However , the government should also plan and allocate its expenditures on other areas appropriately in order to fuel the country's development .
A country cannot afford to spend too much on the elderly because of practical realities .
Some people think that the government has a moral obligation to do all that it can to support the elderly .
The high standard of living in many developed countries causes greater difficulties for working adults to support their parents' medical expenses and still take care of their children's needs .
In addition , rising medical cost makes it more imperative for the elderly to receive help in order to support their medical needs in the future .
However , this is not a practicable solution .
Other than the elderly , there are also other groups of people equally in need of the government support to help them .
People like the handicapped , intellectually disabled and single mothers also experience great difficulty in living in Singapore where cost of living is relatively high .
The government should spread out its public spending to the various groups of people in need instead of just focusing on the elderly .
The government's moral obligation should not be supporting the elderly only .
Technology is an important area of development that will benefit everyone in the country .
Increasing public spending on technology would lead to an increased activity in Research and Development (R&D) and new advancement in technology .
Certain new innovations brought about by the rise of R&D activities would in turn help the needy people improve their living standards .
Some examples are the invention of a robot that is able to do household chores and the modification of public buses that can accommodate the elderly and the handicapped .
Advancement in technology will also attract more investors and business opportunities to the country that will contribute to the country's economic growth .
Investing in technology would not just benefit the needy people but also the people as a whole in the country .
Military spending is crucial in maintaining an 'insurance policy' with no buffer zone against potential aggressors .
In 2009 , more than a quarter of the country's expenditure , or $11 .4 billion , had been directed to defence - an increase of 5 .6 per cent over the previous year's budget (Singapore Budget , 2009) .
This has shown the importance the government places on the Singapore defence .
Singapore sees terrorism as one of the biggest threats to its security and economy .
Attacks in recent years in the United States and neighbouring countries such as Indonesia have prompted it to increase its vigilance against similar risks .
With the threat of terrorism intensifying , Singapore should never let its guard down but invest more on its defence in order to be more vigilant .
Military spending should be  one of the top priorities of the government as it concerns the safety and security of everybody in Singapore .
In summation , it is important that the government continue to provide financial assistance for the elderly due to the increasing number of senior citizens .
However , this public spending should not be done at the expense of other expenditures that concern the country as a whole such as technology and defence .
Investing in technology and defence will eventually benefit everyone in Singapore including the elderly and other people in need in terms of better living condition and greater security .
Singapore government should continue to be cautious about how it allocates its expenditure such that it will bring the utmost profit to the country .
The 'greying of society' has become a serious issue for several developing and developed countries  today .
There are several aspects of this issue that prove to be a cause for concern and public spending is seen as one of the ways to curb the problems .
However , failure to efficiently plan public spending can have disastrous effects on the society and the nation at large especially in the current phase of global economic crisis .
For example , in Singapore , the economy has been projected to shrink by 6 .4 to 9 .6%  Therefore to ensure effective public spending , funds should be channelled to several other economic and social aspects of the country's development by limiting spending on the aged .
To begin with , the current global economic climate is not helping matters much .
Therefore , firstly , money should be diverted to the economic sector , for the  stimulation of the domestic economy .
For example , the $20 .5 billion resilience package announced by the government of Singapore is intended to save jobs by helping valuable companies survive the recession , prepare for the near future , increase the competitiveness of the country and prevent a further slump in the economy (The Online Citizen , 2009) .
assistance schemes such as the 'GST' offsets , rebates , service and conservancy charge rebates serve to act as a stimulus for the country in the hope that the people will spend more to keep the economy afloat .
In the face of such a situation , spending on the aged is of least priority .
The second way in which money can be diverted into the economy is through spending on infrastructure .
Banking , communication and transportation are just some examples of infrastructure that a country needs to invest in to stay ahead in the age of globalisation .
Such investments will provide stability to the country in the long-run as it increases the confidence of potential investors .
Investments in communication and transportation make the country more 'accessible' , hence promoting both local and overseas investments .
However , on the other hand , critics argue that the economic growth alone does not dictate a country's development .
They claim that spending on the aged is as important .
According to Peter G . Peterson (2001) , "demographic changes such as the increasing population of the aged will have a serious consequence on healthcare issues in developed countries" and he also goes on to advocate ways to spend on healthcare .
But if this spending can be alternatively channelled into other sectors of the country's development , such as infrastructure and domestic economy as mentioned above , the country will achieve long-term success and stability .
Hence , the demographics of a country alone does not determine its destiny .
Therefore , public spending should be spent on a country's economic development .
Another way in which money can be well spent on the country's development would be to spend on societal needs such as education and general healthcare .
As the saying goes , "knowledge is power" and rightly so .
Singapore was able to pull itself out of the rut from a third world country to a first world country in one generation due to its focus on well utilised human resource .
And the main contributor was education .
Public spending on education accounts for 19 .3% of the total budget and is second in terms of priority in spending only to defence (Singapore Budget , 2006) .
A well educated society will always be at an advantage and this will act as a catalyst for further growth in several other sectors in Singapore's economy .
Hence , a knowledge based economy will propel the nation into societal development .
The flipside to this issue is that , sectors such as healthcare play an important role in a country's societal development too .
Public spending on aged healthcare accounts for the bulk of the spending which is precisely why it should be limited .
Children of the aged should be given more responsibility for shouldering the financial needs of their parents rather than the government .
This allows money to be spent on more pertinent sectors such as education which has been a traditional source of growth for Singapore .
Hence , public spending on the economy and other aspects of society outweigh spending on the aged as money can be better utilized elsewhere for a country's development .
A failure in proper public spending would therefore cripple the country and its development .
The issue of a graying population was highlighted in Mehta and Wee (2004) , who reported that one out of four Singaporeans will be 60 years and above by 2030 .
(p .105) .
In other words , there will be a significant portion of the nation's populace being senior citizens in the near future .
To facilitate the aging process , the Singapore government has since build on existing policies as well as developed new ones that are pertinent to the current society .
First and foremost , as Ministry of Community Development , Youth and Sports has announced , a law was revised in 1996 for aged parents to seek maintenance from their children , who are capable of supporting them and yet unwilling to do so .
In this aspect , the government is entirely supportive of children fulfilling their filial obligations .
The law advocates that adult children  care for their aged parents instead of leaving them alone by themselves to integrate with the society and find their means of survival .
This was further supported by Peterson (2001) who has also brought up the concept of children's responsibility in maintaining elderly parents .
(p .6) .
Secondly , the Central Provident Fund (CPF) was cleverly devised as a social safety net for every Singaporean adult and his or her family members who are reliant on them .
Every month , a portion of the individual's income goes into the CPF .
The total sum will then be released to the individual on monthly basis once he or she is above 60 years old and is no longer working until the sum is exhausted .
This will then aid the retirement process .
In fact in Mehta and Wee (2004) , when a minimum amount of money is used to buy a life annuity from an official insurance company or bank , the retiree will obtain a flat monthly income for life even if he or she outlives the balance in the annuity account .
(p .96) .
A MediShield scheme is also part of CPF where money can be utilized for part of the hospital bills and costly medical expenses .
In spite of the CPF being in favour for retirees or to alleviate medical expenses incurred , not everyone in the Singapore population would stand to gain from it .
In the society , there is still a fraction who remain jobless or whose jobs do not provide a steady contribution to the CPF .
This means that upon retirement , there will be those who are not entitled to receive a fixed amount monthly or be subsidized partially for their healthcare expenditure .
As age increases , chronic illnesses inevitably rise alongside and the burden of medical cost may simply be too much for one to bear .
To make matters worse , treatment of illnesses goes beyond long hospital stays; it stretches on after discharge and includes the need for rehabilitation , medication and so on .
Unfortunately , amidst the other expenditures such as housing rentals and utilities bills , families usually opt to decline treatment or even ignore their chronically ill parents .
In fact , there are even cases where adult children abandon their parents in nursing homes to fend for themselves .
On the other side of the coin , as in Mehta and Wee (2004) , the PAP government has promised that no Singaporean will be deprived of basic hospital care even if he or she is incapable of paying for it .
(p .99) .
Thus , a MediFund scheme which is not part of CPF and is non-contributory was devised .
The fund comes from  the government budgetary surpluses .
Additionally , the government has also provided a sum of $30 million for National Council of Social Services (NCSS) and those under its umbrella to execute a range of social services .
These finances will definitely relieve the burdens shouldered by individuals without the CPF .
Social workers are also planted in the society who can direct families to appropriate helplines for instance , the rent and utilities assistance scheme (RUAS) whenever the need arises .
Therefore , in any area where individuals require assistance , be it medical affairs or retirement issues , there is always a policy or two which one can turn to for alleviation of one's current situation .
Indeed , the government has come up with numerous policies and measures to help smooth the process of aging .
A fast aging population is an issue that most countries including Singapore cannot avoid .
Several problems which relate to the issue include health , financial and welfare problems of the elderly have come under the concern of the government .
Solutions such as having different subsidy frameworks for community hospitals to help patients to cope with the expensive bills (Ministry of Health [MOH] , 2009) and monthly Transport allowance for the elderly who visit day-care centres (Lin , 2008) were implemented to ease the tension that fast aging has brought to the low-income elderly .
A decrease in the labour force due to retiring workers and the need to provide the elderly with a place to stay are the issues that the Singapore government is working on now .
Fast ageing in Singapore has certainly affected its labour market as the  retirement rate increases .
A research report done by the Ministry of Manpower Singapore in year 1999 showed that in year 2020 proportion of the elderly will be increased to 32% compared to 16% in 1998 (Ministry of Manpower [MOM] , 1999) .
This implies that there will be a labour shortage of experienced workers who are able to contribute to the labour force after they have retired .
For example , new workers who are hired to fill the vacancy of the retired workers often lack experience and knowledge .
As a result , the workers might not be able to complete the task due to their minimum knowledge and skills; therefore , , the functioning of the company will be affected (MOM , 1999) .
One of the solutions to minimize the impact of labour shortage could be to re-employ the retired workers and allow them to guide the new workers on the job as well as share their working experience that will benefit the new workers .
Providing shelter to the single or low-income elderly is one of the priorities in the housing estate development program .
Single or low-income elderly could choose to rent a flat from the Housing Development Board (HDB) or downgrade their current flat to a smaller one as this will allow the elderly to have extra cash for them to spend after their retirement .
HDB will also be building more compact and affordable 30-year lease studio apartments to cater to the demand for the elderly  aged 55 and above (Tan , 2009) .
Besides that , more HDB rental flats will also be upgraded with more Elderly-Friendly Facilities .
These include having lifts on every floor , installing features like support handbars in the toilets and along common corridors to assist in the mobility of the elderly and installing an alert alarm system in the house when the elderly residents need  any emergency help (Housing & Development Board [HDB] , 2005) .
No matter how many hardware facilities are installed to improve the living environment of the elderly , they still feel empty and lonely especially if they have no family .
According to a health related article published by Changi General Hospital , the elderly tend to be at a much higher risk of depression and suicide than the young as they are facing several changes in their life such as illnesses , loss of family members , life partners and friends as well as financial issues which include loss of income after retirement (Changi General Hospital [CG] , n .d .) .
Therefore , several voluntary programs have been implemented to serve as a helping hand to the elderly .
Programs include The Befriender Service , provided by Lions Befrienders who work closely with Central Singapore ComCare Local Networks (CLN) to ease the loneliness , isolation and boredom of the single elderly and the homebound and also provide services such as advice and assistance to the elderly (Central Singapore ComCare Local Networks , n .d .) .
Coping with fast ageing among Singaporeans is a slow and tough process which requires both the government and its citizens to work closely together .
Either encouraging retired workers to return to the work force or providing a decent shelter for the low income elderly will definitely send a positive message to the elderly that they are not being abandoned and they are still recognised by the society .
Programs such as visiting the elderly or providing assistance to the elderly will also increase their confidence to engage the society again .
In the near future , the tax burden on each  working adult will increase due to the  aging population .
It may not seem like a major issue in Singapore from the public's eyes , but it will not be so in the near future .
The old age dependency ratio will increase from one elder adult relying on 10 working adults in 2000 to 3 working adults in 2030 .
(Fu & Hughes , 2009 , p .g .124) . 
Singapore has a population of 4 .8 million and 8 .7% percent of them are aged .
The aged are part of the society; we should also take into consideration their needs (Singstat , 2008 , p .g .1) .
With limitations to  . . .(what ?
) , it will create more social problems and repercussions that result in higher costs that far exceed the amount of money that was transferred to other developments .
Due to the decrease in healthcare aid for elderly , lack of community hospitals and nursing homes , social problems will be generated .
The outcome would be homeless elderly turning into beggars and outbreak of diseases as healthcare becomes unaffordable for them to maintain and hygiene becomes an issue .
Investors and tourists would be deterred from entering Singapore as this does not reflect the branding of Singapore to be clean , green and having a stable economy .
The government might end up paying more for the aftermath just 
The spending on the aged should be treated as a social and economic development which prepares healthcare facilities for the society as a whole and boosts healthcare spending by the tourists .
Investing in healthcare facilities and medical insurance for the elderly will result in a high profile , risk free , user friendly , low cost and safe healthcare solution that does not just benefit the elderly but the society as a whole (Munshi , 2007 , p .g .1) .
In times of recession , the spending on the aged would have a direct relation to employment as there will be more labour required to take care of the elderly .
This employment can help to spur economic growth and help in recession .
Singapore is seen as a medical hub due to its excellent geographical location and provision of top notch healthcare services .
Thus , the spending in a way brings in medical tourism revenues for healthcare services and tourism for the medical travellers (Yin , 2009 , p .g .1) .
Treatments that take up to years may result in migration of the family of the sick; this eventually snowballs to a few million dollars of revenue for the tourism industry .
On the other hand , public spending on the aged should be limited and chanelled to the less well-off section of the society .
With consumer price index (CPI) for low income groups rising to 7 .5% in June 2008 and developments in globalization , vast income inequalities are created in Singapore (Singstat , 2008 , p .g .1) .
The Department of Statistics (2008) reported that 14 .8% of households here earned $2 ,000 or less a month in 2008 , which explains the need for more money to be pumped into the social safety net .
However , there are initiatives such as Comcare Fund , which assists the less privileged group in Singapore .
The Comcare Fund's budget is $63 .7 million in 2008 and this amount is estimated to be $168 million in this financial year (MCYS , 2008 , pg .1) .
MCYS would also adjust the budget according to situations such as setting aside $1million to help the needy cope with inflation (Majid , 2008 , p .g1) Hence , the Government has provided an effective social safety net that provides assistance yet at the same time promotes self-reliance among the needy .
It also portrays an image that the Government is concerned with other developments in Singapore other than the aged .
To sum up , the spending on the aged should not be limited as it spurs economic growth and prepares the healthcare industry to combat this pressing issue .
In the future , the effects of aging population would have a much greater impact on Singapore and all resources assigned to the developments should be prioritized based on expediency .
The policies and investments on the aged for today is the preparation by the Government to mould a better future for tomorrow .
Upgrading of housing by the HDB , particularly for the households with elderly residents , has helped to ease the aging process .
Facilities within the blocks were enhanced significantly to aid  the day-to-day movement of the elderly (Housing and Development Board , 2008) .
These include installing lifts at every floor as well as support hand rails in the toilets .
In order to allow the elderly to receive immediate help in times of emergency , alert alarm systems are fitted in every flat .
These changes have made the lives of the elderly more convenient leading to a greater sense of security instilled in them .
A Voluntary Welfare Organization  (VWO) , which is located below the block , will operate a Seniors Activity Centre to provide support services for the elderly living in the block (Housing and Development Board , 2008) .
It creates a cohesive community where the elderly can integrate themselves into the society through participating in various social activities .
Consequently , some of the social and emotional problems that the elderly faced have been resolved .
In addition , encouraging later retirement has proved to ease the ageing process .
Working reduces the elderly's reliance on their children as well as the society in terms of economic and social needs (Peterson , 2001) .
As work keeps them occupied , they do not feel the need for their children's companionship .
On top of that , working provides the elderly a source of income , enabling  them to remain financially independent , hence reducing the financial dependency on the children .
The Government has been cooperating with employers and unions as part of the Tripartite Committee on Employability of Older Workers to enact re-employment legislation by 1 January 2012 so that employees can continue to work beyond the current statutory retirement age of 62 , up to 65 (Adding Life to Years !
Happy , Healthy , Active Seniors , 2009) .
Even before this re-employment legislation has taken effect , more than 700 unionized companies have committed to re-employ around 5 ,000 workers above the age of 62 .
In fact , working not only allows the elderly to spend their time meaningfully; it  can also help to increase their self-esteem and find their own identity in the society (Adding Life to Years !
Happy , Healthy , Active Seniors , 2009) .
This helps them realize that they still have a foothold in the society as they can still contribute to the nation and economic growth , thereby helping them to lead an enriching and fulfilling life .
However , critics have argued that the elderly might not possess the essential skills that are relevant and required in the workforce today (Seah , 2007) .
This is because the society is constantly changing , hence the skills possessed by the older generation becomes obsolete and no longer applicable today .
Moreover , it has been argued that they may face difficulty coping with the fast-paced society and technologically advanced workforce of today (Seah , 2007) .
However , there are retraining programs available for the elderly to upgrade their skills in order to keep them updated and constructive in the workforce .
For an instance , a $600 million Skills Programme for Upgrading and Resilience (SPUR) was launched by the government in November 2008 to retrain and upgrade both the employed and unemployed to prepare them for the newer and better jobs .
(Adding Life to Years !
Happy , Healthy , Active Seniors , 2009) .
Allowing the older generation to stay longer in the workforce not only promotes economic growth of the country , but also keeps them physically active , mentally alert , resilient and socially connected to the society .
An aging population is an unavoidable issue today that needs to be addressed urgently .
It is therefore important to make sure that policies implemented are useful in helping to ease the aging process .
With the current policies such as upgrading of their residences' facilities and longer working lives , the aging process has been eased to a large extent .
According to Singapore Department of Statistics , the average life expectancy for a boy and a girl born in 2006 is 78 .0 years and 82 .8 years respectively .
As compared to 2003 , it shows an increase of 1 .4 years and 1 .2 years correspondingly (Singapore Department of Statistics , 2008) .
Increasing life expectancy has inevitably led to the growth of an aging population .
Aging is a complex and continuous process that begins with birth and ends with death .
Every person will experience the effect of aging process when they age .
In order to help ease the aging process , efforts have been made in the research developments and policies implementation to meet the physical and financial needs of each individual .
It is crucial to meet the physical needs of the people so as to ease their aging process .
As people become old , their physical health will deteriorate .
Moreover , their body immune system usually weakens .
Hence ,  to minimise the physical problems and vulnerabilities of the people .
One such effort is to make commuting more convenient for the aged and wheelchair-bound through the introduction of Wheelchair Accessible Buses .
With low-floor and steps-free design , these new transit buses have made boarding and alighting more manageable for the aged and disabled (Ministry for Community Development , Youth and Sports  , 2006) .
Furthermore , the Lift Upgrading Programme has also aided the elderly by having lifts landing on every floor (Channelnewsasia , 2009) .
These developments have created a living environment that is more barrier-free for our seniors and people with disabilities .
As such , they can fully participate in their everyday activities .
In addition , much has been done to provide the essential financial assistance for the elderly .
Their inability to pay for expensive medical treatments has revealed the need to provide healthcare support for them .
For example , Prime Minister Mr Lee Hsien Loong introduced a step-down care policy during the 2009 National Day speech .
This is to link up acute hospitals , such as Tan Tock Seng Hospital , with community hospitals , such as St Andrew's Community Hospital , to provide skilled and suitable healthcare especially for the aged (The straits Times , 2009) .
When patients are sick , they will go to acute hospitals for treatment and recuperate at the community hospital .
This way , proper healthcare at a reduced medical cost is made available for them .
Another example is the introduction of Medisave .
It is a national medical saving policy designed to help Singaporeans build up sufficient savings to meet their hospitalisation expenses .
(Central Provident Fund , 2009) .
Hence , healthcare needs can be met without increasing the financial burden faced by the people .
Meanwhile , critics have pointed out that the current policies and research improvements have only helped to minimise problems on a superficial level but have not fully met the emotional needs of the individuals when they grow old .
When one ages , he may be less optimistic and feel disconnected from the society .
Hence , emotional support is an important psychological factor in helping them to forget the negative aspects of their lives (Clark , 2005) .
However , we cannot deny the recent efforts that had been made to help to satisfy such needs .
For instance ,  has moved from seniority-based to performance-based wage structure .
Senior workers , with their rich working experience may be able to contribute greatly to the organisation and are encouraged to be re-hired .
This wage structure ensures employability and job security for the elderly workers and it prevents them from feeling detached from the society (National University of Singapore , 2009) .
In addition , under the Central Provident Fund's Housing Grant Scheme , the government provides a grant of $10 ,000 to $40 ,000 for families buying flats near their parents' residences (Committee on Aging Issues , 2006) .
This allows the elderly to be close to their children and some may even undertake the responsibilities of taking care of their grandchildren .
This helps them to feel valued and thereby , aids in the re-discovery of their identity as a senior citizen .
Over the years , an aging population has become an impediment at hand as many countries have been experiencing it , especially in Singapore where statistics have shown that 11 .3% of the population will be aged fifty-five years and above in 2015 (Hateley & Tan , 2003 , p . 10) .
The younger generation is more career-oriented , which has resulted in later marriages and also lower birthrates .
This burgeoning trend ultimately leads to an aging population and the Singapore government has come up with several policies and development in different fields such as enhancing and inventing elderly-related products to cater to the elderly needs .
In light of the many policies and development that have been devised by the Singapore government to address elderly concerns , the aging process will be eased as most of their problems have been addressed .
Some would argue that policies implemented by the Singapore government might not be fully utilized as some companies find it troublesome to comply with it to employ older workers due to several factors .
Critics have claimed that some companies refrain from hiring seniors to avoid spending more time , money and effort in retraining them (Tay , 2003 , p . 82) .
However , this is not a plausible reason to deter the companies from hiring the elderly as the government has improvised a scheme known as the ADVANTAGE fund to encourage more companies to shift towards automation that facilitate the older populace and to re-employ the elderly by giving out incentives and subsides for retraining programmes of the elderly (Lim , 2007) .
For example , Sheng Siong Supermarket , who hires senior workers , was able to buy machinery that helps to expedite the production process from one month to ten to fifteen days and increase their productivity by using the government subsides (Chia , 2009) .
Therefore , social policies , such as the ADVANTAGE scheme , are effective in helping the elderly to work in a less physically-demanding environment and stay productive .
It is mandatory for everyone in Singapore to have a Central Provident Fund (CPF) account .
This initiative by the government helps to ensure that all elderly will have a means of income that will provide for them through their golden years .
Recent adjustments made to the CPF on 3 September 2009 have played a significant role in reducing the working-age population's tax burden and also in increasing the elderly's CPF .
For instance , the interest rate of the CPF for savings in the Special , Medisave and Retirement Accounts (SMRA) will be maintained at 4% floor rate instead of the current 3 .40% for the next two years (Central Provident Fund Board [CPF] , 2009) .
This eases the economic aspect of an aging population as the elderly can benefit from a higher interest rate and therefore alleviate the  .
With an increasingly aging population , many innovative companies have invented several elderly-related products such as hearing aids and automatic wheelchairs to support their large demand for health-care products .
The government has also developed property such as studio apartments with barrier-free access for the elderly .
All these helped to lessen the elderly's problems of hearing , seeing or moving properly .
For example , two students from Temasek Polytechnic have developed a wheelchair that automatically engages the safety gear whenever it slides backwards .
This helps to ease the difficulty for those who are incapable of engaging the conventional brakes or holding on to the wheels manually (Temasek Polytechnic [TP] , 2009) .
Such innovations ease the problem that the physically restricted are encountering in the process of aging .
In conclusion , it is true that the current research and development or policies have helped to ease the aging process due to the proper and effective planning adopted by the Singapore government .
Issues such as the reluctance of companies to hire older workers are ameliorated due to the ADVANTAGE scheme whereby subsides encourage them to re-employ the aged .
The changes made to the interest rate of the CPF for savings in the SMRA will provide a social safety net for the elderly , while the increase in elderly- related products and studio apartments further eases the physical restrictions of an elderly .
However , these policies and development can help to ease the aging process only if people abandon their social stigma on the elderly populace .
It is extremely difficult for societies to find ways to care for the needy during economic downturns when funding becomes limited (Friedland & Summer , 2005 , p . 16) .
And in countries like Singapore and Japan , which face an aging population , the dilemma is even greater .
With more children not being able to or refusing to provide for their parents , the government definitely has to play a bigger role .
The country's finances will be exhausted as more elderly ask for financial help from the government to cover  their medical fees and basic needs .
However , this burden can be lessened if the elderly mindset is changed .
In order to change their mindset , the public spending on the aged should be limited in the future , and in turn the money used for other areas of the country's development like Education , Retraining and Healthcare .
In Singapore , it is true that government aid is important to the current generation of elderly , as the majority of them did not have or did not have enough CPF savings to last through their retirement .
The current generation of elderly is most probably the first batch to learn about the CPF in 1955 , and being a young scheme then , there is a high chance that they were unable to fully benefit from it .
The situation is even worse when the elderly are faced with illness .
Sick elderly who are single are not able to work to provide for themselves , thus leaving them with no income to pay for their high medical fees .
Moreover , even though married elderly have children , the high cost of living is also putting a challenge on the children's finances , which makes it hard for them to provide for their parents .
Therefore , the elderly have to rely on the government .
But all these shall change in 20 years time; the  elderly then shall be equipped with sufficient money in their CPF to provide for themselves .
In order to lessen the country's financial burden , the elderly have to change their mindset .
The time has changed and the elderly should too .
First , they should change their overly dependent mindset; they should not expect the government or their children to provide for them in their golden years .
The reason is that  the standard of living is rising and adult children find it difficult to provide for their parents , especially those stricken with illness .
Sociologists think that this is the cause of the growing trend for children to abandon their elderly parents in nursing homes (Popatlal , 2009 , para .
3-6) .
Next , the elderly should change their mindset that they are too old to work , when in actual fact working slows down the aging of their brains .
The government will not be able to provide much as the population continues to age , and there will not be as many people in the workforce as birth rates continue to drop .
if the elderly do not continue to work , it will put a huge strain on the country's finances .
how do we go about  changing the elderly's mindset ?
The answer is to invest more money inareas like Education , Retraining and Healthcare .
The best way to influence  a person's thinking is to do it while one is young , and the ideal of being independent can be taught during one's Education .
Furthermore ,  a higher education level  provides better job prospects , which in turn benefits individual financial prospect .
Education also equips one with better knowledge and planning skills , like the importance of health and financial planning for their golden years (Lim , 2009) .
As for Retraining , it enables both adults and elderly to improve their skills to continue working .
Lastly , Healthcare aspects like Community activities and Health awareness campaigns lead to a healthier lifestyle .
People of all ages can take lessons to maintain their health and make friends , which will provide them with a healthy mind and body .
In conclusion , the elderly have to change their mindset about being old and dependent .
The elderly should continue to work as they possess experience that should be passed on to the younger generation .
And to ensure the elderly to- be are prepared , it is important to inculcate them with a healthy mindset through promoting education , retraining and community activities .
Nothing beats aging with a healthy body and mind; the golden years should be spent enjoyably .
As Singapore has been faced with an aging population  since 1990s , there has been a shortage of skilled workers and a declining birth rate .
In order for Singapore to sustain its economic development and improve the quality of life of its people , it cannot afford to spend too much on the elderly .
In a globalizing world , Singapore must stay competitive in order to be successful .
This can be achieved by managing resources efficiently in areas such as investing in foreign talents and education which are vital to its future growth .
Some critics argued that senior citizens are assets to the society since most of them possess valuable skills , knowledge and work experience .
In addition , the government is supporting the elderly by increasing its health budget such as building new hospitals in old HDB towns (Khoo Teck Puat Hospital and Jurong General Hospital) (Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong , national day rally speech) .
Other initiatives were also implemented such as the re-training effort for the elderly in theworkforce .
Increasing healthcare budget would be an initiative which might be seen as a necessity by the government .
However , there are other areas which are vital for consideration since they are important to Singapore's future development .
As Singapore is facing a decline in its birth rate and transiting into the knowledge based economy , attracting foreign talents could be vital to its growth .
Foreign talents would bring in specialized skills and valuable ideas to Singapore .
For example , in the area of research and development (R & D) Singapore needs to develop her own  talent pool and technologies to create new and better products; thus we need foreign talent like accomplished researchers who can lead us into the innovation of new products with their experience and knowledge .
As a result , this could increase business and job opportunities for citizens in Singapore .
In addition , with more foreign talents bringing in different cultures around the world , Singapore would be seen as a more cosmopolitan country .
As a whole , foreign talents can help Singapore gain a competitive edge in the globalizing world .
Educating the young in their early age is essential to the country's development and growth .
This would be so as education encourages critical and creative thinking since young .
This would be supported by current schools' curriculum where children are given problem based learning activities where they have to work on their research and ideas .
This in turn trains them to be able to think independently and innovatively which would be vital to the future workforce .
Therefore , investing in the education system would help Singapore in sustaining its growth in the globalizing world .
In conclusion , a country should tap into other areas of resources in order to stay competitive in a globalizing world .
At the same time , there should also be certain amount of public spending on the aged as the senior citizens are still part of the society and they should be taken care of as so that a country can progress and prosper .
Singapore has one of the world's most rapidly aging population and currently this situation has started to put pressure on our economic growth , with increasing emphasis on health care for the elderly .
From the World Health Statistics 2009 , approximately 3 .3% of Singapore's Gross Domestic Product is spent on healthcare in the year 2006 , and this figure is projected to increase even more in the future and is definitely directly related to the fast aging population .
Therefore , public spending on the aged should be limited to prevent over reliance on the government and  more emphasis could be given to other sectors to promote economic growth .
It is true that most of the aged people in Singapore have contributed to the building and development of Singapore up to this stage and it is time for the nation to look after them .
However , the current healthcare structure may lead to an over dependence on the government for their own health .
With the current CPF structure where/ in which part of a Singaporean's monthly wage goes into Medisave and Medishield ,  an 'untouchable' fund that can only be used for hospital and most healthcare bills , Singaporeans may get complacent thinking that they have already saved enough for their medical bills in the future .
But if one is to be diagnosed with a chronic disease or incapacitating illness , the fund in his Medisave might not be enough for the hefty bill over time .
Therefore , instead of investing money in healthcare infrastructures like new hospitals and nursing homes , it would be wiser for the government to help Singaporeans plan out their retirement more strategically .
Other than extending their retirement age , the government might consider collaborating with the insurance companies and help Singaporeans to purchase a basic insurance with their CPF to facilitate illnesses associated with old age .
In this way , not only the reliance on the government will decrease , Singaporeans will be more protected and not be at the mercy of the others when disease strikes .
Therefore , by paying more attention to education and making sure that all if not most Singaporeans can get a proper education , it ensures that most people will be literate enough to get a proper paying job and thus increasing the working adult  to elderly ratio .
The increase  . . . the increase in the ratiowill will without doubt relieve the government of financing  the aged  .
On top of it , a case by case basis might be a more plausible way of giving healthcare subsidy rather than just applying healthcare subsidy to the general elderly as a whole .
This will really improve the allocations of funds to those who really need it from people who still can afford the healthcare in Singapore .
Even though healthcare expenditure is inevitable in any country , money does not solve all the problems and it is still very important to educate the people on the importance of retirement planning .
Therefore instead of channeling public funds into subsidized health care , the money should be put to better use in education or other aspects of the nation's development .    
With the issue of an ageing society escalating in many countries within these few years , governments have been showing an increased concern towards this unprecedented problem of an ageing population with extremely low reproduction rates .
Singapore is definitely not alone in handling this challenge , as in 2005 , both Germany and Japan saw for the first time; their death rates out-number their birth rates .
Currently , there are no clear explanations as to why the phenomenon of low fertility rates has increased in recent years .
Studies , however , suggested that it might be due to the rise in educated citizens and with that , they were taught the importance of family building and hence , would only plan to have a child when they are financially and emotionally ready for one .
This calls for some social policies to be put in place by the governments , to encourage citizens to be more willing to reproduce .
Social policies such as incentives being given out to encourage procreation and increasing the influx of immigrants would help to ease the ageing process to a great extent .
However , they might introduce some new problems and  these will be explored in-depth later .
Recognising the problem of a possible financial burden that might be incurred by families with a new child , the governments of developed nations are providing generous incentives with the birth of each new child , in the hope of encouraging their citizens to reproduce by helping to ease their financial burden .
In Singapore , we have the "Baby Bonus" scheme , which citizens will get to enjoy a cash gift of up to S$4 ,000 each for their first and second child and S$6000 each for their third and fourth child .
(cited from {https://www .babybonus .gov .sg/bbss/html/faq .html}[HYPERLINK: https://www .babybonus .gov .sg/bbss/html/faq .html]  , retrieved on September 10 , 2009) Similarly , the Australia's baby bonus pays their citizens with AUD$5 ,185 per eligible child in 13 fortnightly instalments , as of 1 July 2009 .
(cited from {http://www .fahcsia .gov .au/Guides_Acts/fag/faguide-1/faguide-1 .2/faguide-1 .2 .2 .html}[HYPERLINK: http://www .fahcsia .gov .au/Guides_Acts/fag/faguide-1/faguide-1 .2/faguide-1 .2 .2 .html]  , retrieved on September 10 , 2009) One may argue that this is just a narrow viewpoint .
Nowadays , people are bred on notions of free choice .
They do not like to be bribed into the government's "propaganda" of procreation .
Also , being more educated , they do not see the need for many children , as time and much money is needed to raise the child in the future .
However , this is definitely not true as firstly , it is the citizens' role to procreate , and not the government's .
Hence , it cannot be conveniently stated that such policy is"propaganda" by the government .
Furthermore , there is evidence of an increased replacement rate .
In Australia , its total fertility rates rose from 1 .76 in 2004 to 1 .82 in 2006 .
(as cited in {http://www .melbourneinstitute .com/news/news/media_releases/2009/final-WP-Baby%20Bonus .pdf}[HYPERLINK: http://www .melbourneinstitute .com/news/news/media_releases/2009/final-WP-Baby%20Bonus .pdf]  , retrieved on September 10 , 2009) As for Singapore , we will have to observe the situation carefully for the next few years to see if its policies will nudge it past the subreplacement zone .
Another social policy that governments seem to turn towards  is the encouragement of the inflow of immigrants into our society .
