This is to ensure that the workforce will remain sufficient and efficient , as a shrinking society will only face the threats of declining economic vitality .
Singapore , for instance , welcome talented immigrants to 1"help us reach our goals" .
However , critics argued that though this social policy is feasible to ease the ageing process in Singapore , it does not take into account  the issue of increased competition for jobs in Singapore , due to the high influx of foreign talents .
This might mean that Singaporeans will have to compete for jobs with the foreigners , and might  lose their jobs to them .
In addition , it also does not take into account of the fact that attracting more immigrants might mean a threat to the culture and identity of a country .
For example , in Europe , 2it is estimated that a quarter of her inhabitants will be non-European in origin , character and beliefs , if she continues to depend on importing immigrants to ease her ageing problems .
This reasoning might be flawed as it is inevitable that the locals have to upgrade their skills to ensure high employability in the fast and highly competitive society .
Also , in this increasingly globalised society , it is even more imperative that one keeps one updated , so as not to be outdated , or they will risk losing their jobs to someone more capable , either a local or a foreigner .
It is a fact that we are experiencing an the aging population problem population problem throughout the world , especially in the developed countries such as Singapore .
Due to the fast advancement of medications , we have no article needed longer life spans compared to the past .
Thus , many countries are spending more effort and money on aging population problem .
However , there are many ways to help the elderly to take care of themselves and public spending on the aged should be limited so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
Elder dependency should be reduced by encouraging later retirement , longer working lives , and fewer barriers to elder employment (Peterson , 2001 , p .66) .
By increasing the eligibility age for public pensions , we are forced to retire at a later age and we will be able to accumulate more money as we grow older .
But in order to achieve that , employers should learn the importance and benefits of employing older employees .
Older employees have more working experiences and better knowledge than the younger ones and these are the crucial factors that will contribute to the company growth .
The Government should encourage its citizens to have more children so that that the cost burden of taking care of the elderly is spread over a larger and more affluent future generation (Peterson , 2001 , p .66) .
Some of the children feel that they are having financial problems and they are not capable of taking care of their parents' expenses .
However , their burdens can be reduced if they have other siblings to share the cost of their parents' expenses .
The Government is also increasing its incentives to parents with more children as a mean to increase fertility rate .
The fiscal cost of elder dependency can be further reduced by stressing filial obligation and increasing the willingness of tomorrow's grown children to support their own elderly parents through informal and familiar channels (Peterson , 2001 , p .66) .
This is very important as having more children does not assure that the parents have higher chances of being taken care of taken care of by their children than the parents with fewer children .
Thus , it is necessary to educate the children at  an  early age on filial obligation .
Parents definitely play a critical role by showing a positive role model to their children .
For example , they can show more of their care and concern on their children needs rather than just focusing on their jobs .
Children will be grateful to their parents and increase their willingness to support their parents in future .
Lastly , the fiscal and economic cost of elder dependency can be reduced by requiring people to provide in advance for their own old-age dependency (Peterson , 2001 , p .66) .
This is like a form of long term saving plan where people are compelled by law to save a portion of their monthly income if they start to work .
The amounts that they have saved can only be withdrawn at a certain age and those savings will be a form of support for them when they reach older age and are not capable of working anymore .
This is especially useful for those people who do not have the habit of saving up .
Nevertheless , we also shouldn't completely ignore the aging population .
Although there are plans to reduce elder dependency , there will still be a small percentage of elders that are not capable of taking care themselves .
They may not be physically able to work and at the same time their children have abandoned the task of taking care of them .
In some of the worst situation , elders do not even have any children that they can depend on on .
As such , government can be more lenient to these groups of elders by providing financial care and giving them public pension benefits whenever possible .
Clearly , as many counties are experiencing aging population problems , the importance of solving this problem in the long term period is rather crucial .
The Government can offer many public pensions and financial help to the needy elders , but when will this end ?
Thus , public spending on the aged should be limited and people should be educated from young on the ways to prevent aging population problems rather than to find a solution for it .
Public spending for the elderly , is it insufficient still ?Remove full stop .
In an expenditure overview of this year's budget 2009  , the Ministry of Community Development , Youth and Sports has set aside $42 .1 million to fund the community and residential based care programmes for the elderly  , $15 .1 million for projects under the GO !
( golden opportunities) and Council for Third Age (C3A) , which advocates the elderly to lead healthier and more active lives .
Another $3 .2 million will be set aside to pilot the Wellness Programme to promote active and healthy ageing in the community .
12 constituencies will set up the Wellness Programme in this pilot phase(http://www .singaporebudget .gov .sg)  .Given the countless funds being channeled to them and given that most of the aged nowadays are capable of supporting themselves , the government expenditure on the elderly exceeds what they need .
Whereas the other sectors of the country's development such as education and healthcare , are still underdeveloped .
Therefore , the public spending on the aged should be limited and more funds should be invested in these areas in order to secure the future of the county and maintain its competitiveness in this fast-paced world .
People would argue that more money should be spent by the government on the elderly , given that the elderly are the more disadvantaged group of the society .
Moreover , the government spending is only beneficial towards the active and healthy elderly , with lesser concern towards those who are unwell and not permitted to work .
And as old age is often associated with deteriorating health , the elderly will have trouble coping with the high medical costs .
Based on a text entitles "Doomsday Predictions about Population are Exaggerated" , writers Robert B Friedland and Laura Summer stated that large and long-term healthcare expenses will become a burden to the elderly , especially those who have not been able to save when they were young(Friedland and Summer ,2005) .
This would give an even larger   larger burden to the working adults and taxes will definitely increase .
However , as we all know , the elderly only constitute a smaller part of the society , and the younger ones in the social group must be taken care of the same way or more so than the elderly since they are the determiners of the country's future .
More money should not be invested on the healthcare of the elderly who are unwell and not fit for work since they do not have any other means to spend on with that much money given by the government , except for their medical fees .
Instead , investing more money in education will increase the likeability of the younger people to secure better jobs , and enabling them to provide their elderly parents financial support , no matter in what condition their parents are in .
Based on the statistics obtained from a government statistical website , the  level of education attainment among resident non-students aged 25-39 , despite increasing rapidly in the past few years , is still low at 70 percent in 2008 (www .singstat .gov .sg)  .This means that the government must set aside more money in instilling awareness of the importance of education towards the young .
This can be done by organizing campaigns , and through media such as advertisements and short documentaries .
The Global Campaign for Education for example , has campaigned in many countries in order to instill awareness towards the importance of education .
Therefore , by succeeding in education and securing better jobs , the working adults will ease the burden of the government from having to invest a lot of money on the welfare of the elderly .
Healthcare for the elderly is important in order to enable them to lead better lives .
However , the well-being of the citizens in general is much more important .
As discussed earlier , the younger citizens are the jewels of the country that determines its future .
The country needs healthy and able citizens to ensure the country's progress .
Therefore , more of the government's investments should go to the younger citizens .
Moreover , these younger citizens are the ones who will be responsible for their elderly parents' health and well-being , therefore their health and well-being should be prioritized .Based on a study by theremove full-stop Commonwealth Fund which was released on Wednesday , in the Healthday News/Detroit Free Press reports , which includes 4 ,052 U .S . adults ages 19 or older between September 2003 and January 2004 , about 16 million U .S . residents care for sick or disabled family members , and approximately nine million of those caregivers have medical problems , according to the study .
Three out of five caregivers said they had trouble paying their medical bills (http://www .medicalnewstoday .com) .
This shows that in the course of taking care of their parents , the working adults do not take care of their own health , and what makes it worse is that they are financially in need , as evidenced by their incapability to settle their own healthcare bills .
Therefore as evidenced by these kinds of scenarios , the government should set aside more money on healthcare  ,especially for working adults who are taking care for their elderly parents , since caregivers of the ill and unhealthy should be healthy in the first place .
An ageing population can bring about many serious problems to a developed country .
Lower productivity of an older workforce can lead to a decline in economic growth .
Demand for health care services will increase as elders are prone to illnesses and take a long  time to recover .
Resources will be needed to upgrade the country's infrastructure to cater to the needs of the older population .
By 2030 , 20% of Singapore's population will be 65 years old and above full-stop should come after the in-text citation (MCYS , 2007) Despite the high number of seniors , the birth rate remains low at 1 .29 per female in 2007 .
(Statistic Singapore , 2007) Since the population is unlikely to be able to replace itself in the near future (The Business Times , 2007) , it is important to have policies that help to ease the ageing process by helping the elders to increase their retirement savings so as to lighten their dependency on the younger generation .
In February 2006 , the ministerial Committee on Ageing Issues proposed a polices such as the HDB's rules of housing nucleus families closer to their elders , the Parents' Maintenance act and higher retirement age , to protect the elders and ease old-age dependency .
However , these current government policies have not helped to ease the ageing process .
Most policies are ineffective or attract minimal attention , hence , most of the elderly are still not independent .
The Married Child Priority Scheme (MCPS) introduced by the HDB encourages married children and parents to live near one another .
Married children are given priority if they apply for a flat to stay near or together with their parents .
(MCYS , 2007) no need for 'by' encouraging adult children to stay with their parents can definitely benefit the elderly as the increased interaction can foster care for their parents .
However , even if the married children live with their parents , they may have no time to look after them .
With no need for article rising inflation , both married children have to work to support the increasing expenditureno need for plural form .
A dual career family means that the adult children spend less time at home and that the elder parents are often left alone in the day as their children go to work .
Hence , MCPS does not guarantee more care for the aged parents .
The Maintenance of Parents Act give parents above 60 years old who could not support themselves the legal means to claim maintenance from their children .
(Mathi , 1999) By compelling children to provide support for them , the elderly parents can be assured to retire comfortably with the financial support from their children .
The Act is proposed with the assumption that some children selfishly abandon their parents .
However , the Act overlooked the constraints of the adult children .
Young adult children , especially those who already started a family , find themselves sandwiched between providing care for their elderly parents and their children .
Health care for the elderly can cost up to thousands of dollarsand being  strained financially , adult children simply cannot afford it .
Therefore , the problems go beyond the issue of filial piety , government need to look at each case individually .
Retirement age will rise from 62 to 65 by 2012 to account for the higher life expectancy of its ageing population .
(Inquirer , 2009) The elderly who are healthier and able to work longer can therefore increase their retirement savings by retiring later .
Even so , more have to be done to change the mindsets of the employer .
Many employers often associate old-age with lower productivity .
Older workers find it difficult to compete with the younger applicants who are youthful and demand lesser pay .
Moreover , there is a certain group of elderly who have substantial education attainment such as the older single women .
(Friedland and Summer) This group of elderly will have lower income and more difficulties in finding jobs .
In such instances , the government needs to provide more financial help to this group of elderly who are more vulnerable .
In conclusion , the policies are not effective in helping the elders to ease their old-age dependency .
The government needs to see the real reasons contributing to the different problems faced by the elderly .
Besides introducing policies that help the elderly , people have to also change their attitude towards the aged to engage the elderly into the society and strive together to ease the ageing process .
The ramifications of the aging population have always been a challenge to many developed countries .
The immense social cost arising from ageing population can be attributed to mounting healthcare problem , diminishing of economic productivity and increasing accountability of younger generation towards the elderly .
In view of the accelerated growth of ageing population , the Singapore Government government has been revamping the related policies constantly to mitigate the problem .
With a carefully constructed policy , government agencies get to develop a holistic approach that meets the needs of the elderly .
The diminishing of economic productivity due to the aging population may have an abysmal effect on a country .
Peter G . Peterson has claimed that later retirement could be a sensible method to maintain one nation's productivity and reduce the dependency of elderly .
(Peter G . Peterson , 2001) Singapore's government has adopted this measure and raised the retirement age up to 62 to ensure elderly contribution to the society .
Moreover , such policy emphasizes the principle of self-reliance and reduces the burden and social cost of the community .
The existence of the older workforce not only increases the input of the economy but also enables the elderly to gain some form of steady income .
This will ameliorate the deteriorating effect on a nation's economy due to ageing progression .
However , this policy will remain fruitless without the collaboration between the elderly , employers and the state .
Employers tend to discriminate against elderly frequently as they are deemed to be vulnerable and unproductive .
In order to remove such prejudice , the government provides incentives by reducing the employer's contribution to elderly Central Provident Fund (CPF) .
Initially government will top up the remainder sum for the elderly so that the welfare of elderly will not be jeopardized .
Healthcare is another prevalent problem in a society where the number of elderly is increasing tremendously .
The elderly has a higher possibility of encountering a long-term management of chronic diseases such as diabetes and heart disease .
Therefore it is essential for the government to keep healthcare cost at an affordable rate for this vulnerable group .
Singapore's government heavily subsidizes  medical service and grants some flexibility in the CPF system so that the elderly can utilize part of their saving in the CPF account for hospitalization expenses .
In addition , family responsibility is always is always stressed  stressed such that children are required to contribute to the Medisave account of their elderly member .
The transfer of funds from the Ordinary Account to parents' Retirement Account is also available .
Such policies spread over the cost of ageing progression to family and community and minimize minimize state fiscal fiscal provision .
Moreover , in order to make medical service easily accessible to the needy , polyclinic which is an affordable subsidized one-stop health centre , offer outpatient medical care and pharmacy services .
This facilitates the elderly who are bedridden and confined to wheelchairs .
Despite heavy subsidization on healthcare , the elderly who are destitute without family support may still find medical service prohibitive .
As such , Public Assistance and Medifund have been introduced to assuage this problem whereby rigorous diagnoses are  carried out out and relevant assistance will be given to the needy accordingly .
Lastly , the mental health of elderly is exceptionally vital to enhance their social functioning and to maximize their potential .
The sense of isolation and loneliness among homebound and single elderly might result in mental illness and social problems .
Family bonding and company are paramount in addressing such phenomenon .
Reinforcement of the ethic of filial pity can vicariously develop strong bonds between children and parents .
In line with this ideology , Singapore's government introduced Multi-Tier Family Housing Scheme and CPF Housing Grant to encourage married couple to buy a flat in the same town with their parents .
It is a housing subsidy and family comprising parents and married children staying together in the same household will be given priority for public housing apartment .
Consequently , this can prevent elderly abandonment by children and forms family cohesion among the community so that the aged will not be neglected .
Singapore's government believes that social service should involve the participation of all sectors of society including the community and non-profit organization .
Thus , several programmes have been set up under the joint MCYS-HDB project to improve the quality of life of the aged .
One of it would be the Senior Citizens' Club which helps to enhance family relationship and promote interaction among elderly .
Psychological needs of the elderly cannot be overlooked so that they can be socially integrated into the family and community .
In a nutshell , curbing the enigmas of the ageing population to a large extent , depend on the social policies of a state .
Robert B . Friedland and Laura Summer caution government to carry out wise and forward-thinking planning and therefore the government should adopt pragmatism while formulating social policies related to the ageing population .
(Robert B . Friedland and Laura Summer , 2005) Society should also shift their paradigm and not marginalize the  elderly  to maximize the social functioning of elderly .
One of the strategies from the text , "elder dependency should be reduced by making people work longer" (Peter G . Peterson) can be applied in the Singapore context whereby the retirement age has been raised from 60 to 62 in 1999 .
With longer working lives , people will be able to save more money for old age .
However , longer working lives may have implications on their health , which may lead to an increase in medical expenditure .
Nevertheless , this can be solved by the flexi-work hour program such that the elder group can work shorter hours and not ruin their health .
Moreover , based on a government survey conducted last July , more than 60 per cent of 25 ,000 unemployed older folk who planned to look for work preferred to work part time .
However , only 43 per cent of the employers are willing to offer flexible work to older workers , while 57 per cent are presumably against such arrangements .
Furthermore , figures from the Ministry of Manpower show that the proportion of employees on flexible work arrangements in 2008 was 9 .4 per cent from the public and private sectors .
Hence , I will suggest a development of new models of work which will be required as the workforce ages and employees search for greater flexibility in work organization .
This will encourage the elder group to return to the workforce and achieve a reduction of elder dependency on the government .
In Singapore , education has been a main concern and the government has implemented policies such as compulsory primary school education and subsidies for students from poor families .
Furthermore , in the 2009 Key Budget Initiatives , the government is enhancing school education by "providing better facilities for an all-round education in every school , enhancing both the size and quality of the teaching force and bringing in allied educators into schools to collaborate with teachers in providing better attention for every child ."
(Key Budget Initiatives) With a strong education system base , everyone has a chance to receive high level of education , which will secure them higher paying jobs in the future and also help to stimulate the country's economic growth .
As a result , "the cost burden can be spread over a larger and more affluent future generation" .
(Peter G . Peterson) Nevertheless , one can argue that with a low birth rate , the system established will not be fully utilized .
However , the education  system is important in a country's development for future generations , hence the government can only further revise the baby bonus policy in order to encourage families to have more children .
Another social problem will be elderly parents being abandoned at nursing homes or children living overseas and  no one looking after their parents in Singapore .
However , recent study has found that "seniors here are generally well cared for by their children" .
Moreover , "two in three respondents pay for their senior's medical bills and keep them company" .
(The Straits Times Article) On the other hand , there is also a setback such that there will be another generation of elderly who are not prepared for their own retirement , the reason being that  . . .
The reason being their income will be used to support elderly parents , to cover family expenses and provide for their children .
However , with the CPF scheme in place , there should be savings when they reach retirement age , but I will suggest that research has to be conducted to find out how much people will need to save for their retirement and whether the current CPF contribution rate is sufficient .
Moreover , compulsory insurance scheme can be introduced to ensure more savings .
The government is also "committing to a substantial expansion of the healthcare sector by investing $4 billion to restructure the heath care system to handle the aging population such as the development of community hospitals" .
(Key Budget Initiatives) Patients can then recuperate at these community hospitals which generate savings and increase efficiency on treatment of more acute cases .
In 1950 , there were 205 million persons aged 60 or over throughout the world .
Fifty years later , the number of persons aged of people aged 60 or over increased about three times to 606 million .
Over the first half of the current century , the global population 60 or over is projected to expand by more than three times to reach nearly 2 billion in 2050 .
Aging population includes  any person who is aged 60 and above .
Hence , there is a lot of concern with whether the government is going to spend more money to help the aging population or otherwise .
If the money spent is not planned properly , there may be disastrous consequences .
The aged can still contribute to our society economically and socially , hence there is a need to allocate more money for them .
The aged can still help to develop and push the economy to greater heights since they still have the capability to work .
Public policies are put in place to motivate them to work harder .
One example would be the Central Providence Fund (CPF) in Singapore .
It is a savings account that the working class will put a certain percentage of their monthly salaries into .
This money can be used for themselves or their descendants .
Awards and money incentives are also given to those who have performed outstandingly in their fields of work .
The government should spend more money to come up with new awards as a form of motivation .
They are also the ones who will do all the "dirty" work like collecting garbage and sweeping the floor .
No degree holder will want to exchange their air-conditioned room for standing under the hot scorching sun .
Others may argue that the aged work and learn slower compared to a working adult , however , we must also consider the difference in their salary and job scope .
They may be slower but they do not complain .
No matter how much they earn , be it a little or a lot , they still contribute to the economy .
The aged have a lot of invaluable experiences which cannot be brought in terms of money .
We can still learn a lot from them .
It helps us to plan better , not making the mistakes that they have made in the past , as in the case of World War 2 .
The British thought that the Japanese will not attack through the forest; as a result , we were caught by surprise when they actually came in through the forest .
It is these experiences and mistakes that we learnt from and thus improved ourselves .
The government should spend more money on them for talks and teachings so that they are able to share their experiences with younger generation .
They can also publish self-improvement books .
People may argue that actions speaks louder than words , since all the aged do is to talk , it it definitely sounds  easy .
Yet , it is through this life experiences that we are able to better plan and think of our future .
Hence , I believe that the government should spend more money to subsidize talks for   the elderly .
With aging , the physical and mental parts of the human body will start to deteriorate  .
As a result , there is a need for the government to spend more on elderly healthcare and rehabilitation centres .
Life expectancy across the world is increasing .
People are living longer and tend to fall sick more compared to the past .
What if they do not have enough money to see the doctor ?
Do we let them die on the streets ?
As the standard of living increases , a minor operation will cost at least a whopping $10 000 .
The medicine and the appointments to see the doctors are normally for a lifetime , which would mean more necessary costs .
Some of the elderly may not be eligible for the government policies because they do not fulfil certain requirements .
There are people who believe that the aged should fend for themselves .
However , if we take a closer look , we will see a vicious cycle where the problem will eventually fall back on the children and back to the economy since they will have a keep a portion of their salary for the medical bills .
In conclusion , the government must plan properly to allocate sufficient resources for the aged , yet not forgetting other aspects of the country .
As policies makers decide on how much resources to allocate , they must remember that these policies will be subjected to changes as everything else changes .
Hence , we must be flexible and focus on knowing which direction our country is heading in and plan adequate resources properly .
Nowadays , the aging population is one of the most worrying problems .
The percentage of people who are 65 years old and above in Singapore in 2008 is 8 .67% (1) .
For this reason , the government has been placing much emphasis on spending the budget for the aged .
However , in my opinion , the funding for the senior citizens should be cut back so that we could take full advantage of this amount of money to develop other fields to contribute to the country's growth .
First and foremost , the government ought to invest much time and energy in education .
As a matter of fact , due to the fact that people who are "well equipped" with knowledge get more opportunity to have higher salary and better social status , education ensures a happy hoary age (2) .
The ground for this fact is that because of their hard work during their younger years , they are able to put aside for their future .
Hence , they can cater for themselves without any financial aid from the outside world .
However , according to statistics , though small ,  about 2 .4% of people cannot find a job with an acceptable pay to prepare for their old age .
What is more , the government may open some training programs to offer jobs for those who are about to retire but are unemployed for the time being owing to their lack of education .
Singapore's government seems to make the most of this policy to make more and more people employed despite their shortage of education before .
Data shows that compared with 2007 , there are more than 11 .7 million people of this type having the ability to work on their own .
Moreover , science should be appreciated more .
With more esteem , new technology is possible to be invented to help ease the aged .
From that point , old age is not appalling anymore .
People are more likely to work longer , and it is not necessary for the government to help them .
For example , studies have proved that insomnia in the elderly can be   easily cured by non-drug therapies (3) .
This can be seen as a step forward to what we want to achieve .
Suppose that the science is properly concerned , no one knows whether it might create something which makes people ever young .
This thing , if happens , could be the most marvelous one that has ever happened in the world .
At that time , everybody , irrespective of age , is capable of increasing the productivity of their own country in particular and of the global village in general .
Then , aging population does not exist anymore , and this word would come out of the dictionary .
With the expansion of science , nothing seems hard to imagine and we have the right to hope such world would come into existence into existence .
Last but not least , opponents of this position would argue that senior citizens are also our own citizens , they need care from the government and the strategies above take many times to complete when the senior citizens cannot wait anymore .
However , based on what I have argued above , the government's concern to the aged still exist but should be limited to some extent to take care of the other's areas .
If the government continues to excessively worry about the senior citizens , it will be a good example to rely on the government .
They do not need to worry for their future during their early times because sooner or later they will be provided with help by the government .
This thing must be a disaster to a society .
Furthermore , to place more emphasis on other areas such as education , science , etc .
is considered to be a visionary step to see to our aging population of our near of far future .
And as far as I am concerned , to run a country , we need to take interest in long term more than short term .
In short , "public spending on the aged should be limited so that money can be diverted to the other areas of the country's development" .
Two areas that can be invested in more are education and science , which will make some differences in our aging population so that this problem would no longer be an awesome matter , but one of the proudest ones to be mentioned .
With the continued decline in fertility and the improvement in health in Singaporeans , Singapore faces a greying population (MCYS , 2005) .
In addition , the ageing phenomena are becoming more complex with rapidly changing social-economic-political and technological environments (Mehta , 2004) .
For example , Chow and Chan's study (as cited in Lee , & Mehta , 2004) states that as families become more modernised , the level of the family social support to the old will suffer deterioration .
Without new policies and further research and development in all fields of study , relating to the aged , they will face difficulties in living inheir current environment .
Despite the complex changes in the environment , there are theories on successful aging which could help us in our investigation on  the extent to which the current policies have helped to ease the aging process .
The following theories are role theory and social exchange theory .
The role theory suggests that people play specific roles in their families and communities throughout their life time .
social exchange theory suggests that the degree of interaction of elderly is determined by their ability to engage in social exchange .
We will focus on whether the current policies have made life easier for the elderly on the basis of these theories .
In Singapore , the existing policy on employing the elderly does not do enough to allow senior workers to continue playing their roles in working community .
Companies in Singapore tend to prefer employing younger employees , and when the company is undergoing restructuring , the older workers are usually the ones to be retrenched .
Despite the incentives given out by Singapore government to encourage companies to continue employing the elderly , companies still hesitate to keep them because of possible health problems .
Forcing them to accept less respected job , also mean lower income , to earn for a living as retirement age has increased .
This creates undue stress and negative psychological impact on the aged , at the same time a social stigma on them and also inadequate income .
A survey from MCYS (2005) shows that there is an increased in the proportion of those aged above 55 and above who found their income usually inadequate , 29 .9% of them credit it to low income .
Unlike Japan , the companies tend to treasure the experience of older workers and recognise their loyalty towards the company , allowing them to stay on to managerial position provided that they are competent .
The aged in Japan are very much respected as compared to those in Singapore , hence , aging with more dignity .
Taking a closer look , the success of the policy on employing the elderly is still inconclusive , as it takes years to change the perspective of a society .
At the very least , the elderly is still able to be part of the workforce .
To a large extent , most of the existing policies have helped to ease the aging process .
The HDB housing policy which encourages families to stay closer to their parents allows the elderly to continue their role in helping their children or even an additional role as a grandparent .
The HDB provides additional grants through CPF for families to purchase flats within a certain radius of their parents .
With the close proximity , family members can travel to and fro with ease , helping them in terms of household matters and even taking care of young children .
This allows bonding to increase between them and also increasing the self-worth of the elderly .
In terms of improving the ability of the elderly in engaging social exchange , mobility and places are the important aspect .
The government is creating a more disabled and elderly friendly environment by making improvements in housing estates and public areas .
For example , the transport authority aims to have lift facilities in every mass rapid and light rail transit stations .
In order to encourage active aging , the government is bringing activities closer to housing estates like the RC or CC .
These activities include not only physical activities , and also voluntary activities .
The government also set up the Council for Third Age to further promote active aging (MCYS , 2009) .
Presently , though , social policies are still solely drafted  by the government .
However , Singaporeans can be involved in improving these policies by providing feedbacks through government portals like Reach .
With such initiatives , policies are now more focused on improving the lives of Singaporean as a whole .
Additional healthcare facilities and services are to be provided in line with the aging process .
The escalating figure of aging population will certainly increase the numbers of patients afflicted to intricate diseases such as Ischaemic heart diseases .
With aging population , the likelihood of patients suffering from multiple organ failure will start to increase too .
Nonetheless , the number of hospitalizations due to such medical conditions may amplify as well .
In order to rectify the homeward bound predicament , not only more elder-friendly friendly facilities have to be constructed , but  critical care medical treatment and surgery is  required too .
However , this could prove  to be a major hitch as there is an emerging need for critical care programmes .
Various medical institutions should offer training and preparation to medical professional personnel to equip them with the necessity to counter the upcoming crisis .
The progression of aging could be also alleviated with new and hi- tech medical advancement .
Since the 2003 , Singapore General Hospital has performed numerous robotic surgeries ever since the robotic surgical system , known as Da Vinci Surgical was introduce .
This has significantly augmented the precision of intricate surgeries as well as trimmed down much of the risk faced by the patient during surgical operations .
With the marvel breakthrough of medical advancement , elderly members who are the ones that  health problems are better furnished with finer medication procedures .
However , technology and science cannot replace the need for healing relationships among the medical personnel and patients .
Dr Vivian Balakrishnan , Minister for States and National Development once says that while technology and science continue to alter medical procedures and techniques , health care at its core remains a high-touch profession .
Care is provided by people , not technology , buildings or drugs .
( Dr Vivian Blakrishnan , 2002) Through caring interactions , patients especially the old and needy members can be emotionally and psychologically motivated to fight against the associated sickness .
Thus , healthcare professionals are required to constantly enhance their ability to communicate and care , not just mainly rely on the development of technology and science .
In addition , with the robust production of supplementary healthcare products nowadays , the level of personal healthiness of the elderly can be much maintained .
Taking healthcare products such as natural vitamins and mineral salts is able to build up one's immunity system against viral and bacterial infections .
It is often said that prevention is better than cure .
These supplementary products not only can fortify one's immunity system , but also improve one's mind alertness and body vigor .
Elderly should be taking complementary healthcare products to strengthen their body against diseases as we well as retaining their mental alertness .
At this point one may wonder  whether the manufactured supplementary healthcare products are safe to be consumed as there are cases that the products are proven to be potentially health hazardous .
However , numerous measures have been imposed by authorities such as the Health Sciences Authority to insure that the merchandises are secured to be utilised .
Nonetheless , consumer themselves have to prudent when selecting the varieties of healthcare products .
In conclusion , progress of development in healthcare needs have to always be maintained at a high pace as the tempo of aging progression hastens .
More funds should be provided to increase more research and development in the pharmaceutical and medical sciences fields as well as importing more advance technologies .
This would largely aid in resolving the predicaments of declining personal health system that an aging population will encounter .
Peter G . Peterson concludes that global aging may still impose unsustainable fiscal and economic burden unless the developed countries confront the daunting problem of rising healtcare cost and how to set limits on healthcare .
(Peter G . Peterson , 2001) Yet , insufficient healthcare development spending may degenerate the health standards of the nation and so , in turn reduces productivity even more significantly .
Public spending should therefore be more focused on providing excellent healthcare facilities and services which would benefit and ease the growing health crisis amidst the aging population .
In the recent years , besides many issues such as wars in the Middle East , financial crisis , terrorism , a fast-aging population has become an unprecedented problem which many countries have encountered , especially the developed ones .
This demographic change has lead to several serious consequences which not only challenge the whole society but also the government and policy makers .
Such a problem like this cannot be solved overnight , but needs to have a suitable long-term plan .
Although there are still arguments surrounding old age issues ,  much has been done to ease the aging process , particularly medical advancement and efficient social policies .
To begin with , it is no doubt that when a person becomes older , he will experience health problems , physically and mentally .
Therefore , better healthcare is one of the most important priorities when finding out solutions to help the elderly .
Most developed countries offer the long-term care including nursing home , day cares , home health care and hospice care , and upgrade the facilities as well as infrastructure in the medical sector .
In the Singapore context ,  some hospitals will be built such as Jurong General Hospital opening  in 2015 ,  Khoo Teck Puat Hospital in Yishun  opening in 2010 .
Furthermore , on the understanding that elder people need a longer time to recover , the Ministry of Health has launched a new model to set up a link between mainstream hospitals with community ones where patients can receive relevant care after being discharged from the acute hospitals .
To illustrate this type of healthcare is Tan Tock Seng Hospital with Ren Ci Hospital as well as Changi General Hospital with St Andrew's Community Hospital .
Shortly , with the development in medical aspect , it could be fairly assured that elderly healthcare would be improved .
Secondly , from a social and financial standpoint , the government and policy makers have generated many possible ideas to deal with a graying population .
A question has been brought up in Straits Times lately "Who cares for these when they grow old ?" .
In fact , there are some older people having no child or are single , so it is more difficult for them in their old days .
To deal with this problem , conceived by the Ministry of Community Development , Youth and Sports , The Centre for Enabled Living is the first-top centre for persons needing care .
It is a centre to help the elderly not only with their daily life but also emotional life by providing many helpful services - for example Befriending , Neighbourhood Links and Senior Activity Centres , and so on .
Another solution to reduce elder dependency is The Central Provident Fund (CPF) system , a source of financial support to Singaporeans during retirement .
It is mandatory for every employee and employer to put some money of his income per month into CPF .
Besides , the government also encourages its citizens to work as long as possible and contribute to the CPF to have a good preparation and more financial security in old age .
On the other hand , some people still doubt whether or not the advancement or development has actually helped the aging population .
Although governments raise funds and increase budgets to support the elderly , healthcare costs is still high and some of the treatments which apply new technologies and methods are so expensive that money they save will run out after a few days .
Another point is that some of the policies can only be efficient and useful in developed nations .
Due to the shortage of budget , many other social problems such as poverty , starvation , inflation , etc .
developing or poor countries may not take many actions to help their older people .
Hence , there should be more effort to be done to solve these problems .
All things considered , it can be concluded that current development and policies have helped to ease the aging process in a certain degree .
Solving these problems is not an easy task and can not be achieved in the  short-run either However , with strong effort , many things can be done to help our elderly .
Public spending refers to expenditure by government .
A principal source of revenue or income to pay for public spending is taxation(Tiscali , 2009) .
Some of the other areas in the country's development that require public spending are like social services and benefits , education , infrastructure and development projects like transport , housing and employment (Anonymous , 2009) .
It is important for the government to spend in this area so that the country's economy and social condition will improve .
Many argue that limiting public spending on the elderly would only leave  their families to face with issues on education , housing , social services and transportation .
By cutting expenditure on welfare programs for the elderly , individuals and families are  responsible for a larger share of the cost incurred by the elderly . .
They would need to provide the cost for their own old age dependency , according to Robert B . and Laura S . in  .
Besides , such cost may even be greater than the original cost of running welfare programs for the elderly .
On the contrary , diverting public spending on the other areas of the country's development will expand its economic opportunities and improve its social  conditions .
Such financial and social problems would actually not be faced by the individuals and their .
When there is more expenditure on social services  , education , infrastructure and development  , there is a greater chance for the country to build a better economy . . And with economic growth , the country will become richer and the people will enjoy a higher standard of living .
In fact , public spending on higher education pays off , especially in times of economic crisis or downturn (Aisha , 2009)
For example , the society becomes more educated and affluent as more money is being pumped into the economy to ensure higher education for its people ; and the people will get higher income when they work .
In such a situation , the country becomes richer and there would not be a need to cut down on program benefits or raise taxes .
Therefore , economic growth would ensure the continuation of welfare programs for the elderly in the long run .
The burden on the people to pay for higher taxes in the future would be lessened as the economy serve to benefit the aged .
In addition , limiting public spending on the aged would mean that individuals have to provide the cost for their own old age dependency .
This is  beneficial for the country as people will learn to depend on themselves .
They would be able to able to work betterand attain higher income so as to help support education , housing , social services and rising cost of transportation for themselves .
It would be  useful  when there is an economic downturn and the government is not able to spend on the aged .
"An aging population will push up pension and healthcare costs , forcing major increases in public spending that could slow economic growth in rich and poor countries ."
(Fox , 2009) Clearly , as Singapore experiences the problem of ageing population , it is important to generate economic growth for the country to benefit the aged .
Higher expenditure on areas like infrastructure and education , allows the country to achieve greater economic growth which  in turn will solve the problems of aging population .
With better economic and social condition in the country , people would become richer and affluent .
This would then reduce the worries of individuals and their families about issues pertaining to education , housing , social services and transportation .
In today's society , ageing population is increasingly a problem that many countries such as Singapore , Sweden and Japan , are now facing .
An ageing population brings challenges and opportunities for people to explore .
There is a need to put in place government policies and programmes to meet the emerging needs of an ageing population .
Therefore , I agree to reduce public spending on the aged , so that more resources and funds will be allocated to other areas of development , such as the economy , education , technology and general healthcare within the country .
But , help  for the aged should not be neglected too .
People will learn to be self-reliant when the support given by the government is being limited .
For example , people need to make their own plans to fund for their own health care .
In the case of Singapore , the government implemented policies such as Medisave and Medishield , to "force" her citizens to set aside money and plan for their future finances . .
This will help ease the burden on the government as the people are able to afford their own medical fees through their own savings .
Another scheme that the Singapore government adopted is the Central Provident Fund (CPF) .
Peoplehave to save a part of their salary and could only withdraw and use the savings upon retirement .
Because of such schemes , the government has more resources to focus more on other developments of the country which are equally important to ensure competitiveness in this globalised world .
Therefore , limiting public spending on the aged will reduce the dependency of the aged on the government and ensure continuous developments in other areas of the country .
Even though family members are responsiblefor taking care of their elderly ,  many assume that the government would be responsible for it because of its vast resources .
Some took advantage of the situation and make use of the low-cost medical facilities , as can be seen in the long queues formed at the polyclinics in Singapore . .
This may lead to people who are in urgent need for medical consultation being delayed , which in turn , may cause serious consequences .
Financial help should be given to those who are really in  need , instead of allocating large amount of funds to all the elderly .
Many elderly are still able to work and support themselves , thus they don't need the help of the government .
According to the one article , PM Lee said that "the best way to keep health costs down is by maintaining a healthy lifestyle" (Channel News Asia 2009) .This implies that as long as the elderly keep themselves healthy , lesser burden will be placed on the government .
Therefore , part of the public spending on the aged can be diverted to developing other sectors of the country , so as to ensure that the public spending is well-allocated .
Even though there are schemes to make people save for their old age now , the older generation who have little or no education , are not able to comprehend what these schemes are about and what benefits they will get . .
Therefore they need the aid of the government to help them cope with their medical issues and their daily lives .
More elderly friendly facilities in the neighbourhood of the elderly should be built and good values such as giving up seats to the elderly should be taught to the public to help the elderly to cope  with their daily lives .
For example , in Singapore , there are priority seats for the elderly so that they do not have to stand for long hours .
If money were to be diverted to other area of developments ,  .
Therefore public spending is essential , and it  should not be limited to assisting the developments of other areas  and neglect the major problem of ageing population  .
However , many social problems caused by the elderly are mainly due to the lack of education .
More resources should be allocated to develop the country's education system so as to ensure the continuous supply of good labour and also to educate the public of the importance of self-reliance .
With more people receiving education , they will understand the importance of planning for their future and developing the culture of taking care of themselves and their elderly .
Therefore , funding for the aged should be limited , so as to provide more funds for the development of other areas , such as the education sector . .
In conclusion , for a country to be successful , it not only has to look after the welfare of the elderly , but also to ensure the continuous development of  the economic , the education and technological sectors .
These sectors will in turn ensure the vibrancy of the country , which will lead to long lasting growth .
It is not wise to allocate large public spending on the aged  .
But instead ,  , one may set the sights furtherand tackle the root of the problem , which is to educate the public  to plan for their future finances . .
This will help to develop the country as a whole , as it diversifies the country's development .
The question on whether national economies should be spent on the aged  has long been a controversial one .
Each person has his or her own opinions .
Some people say that the country's budget should focus on healthcare for the elders , as old , retired people find it hard to cope with their problems without any support from the governments .
However , others argue that the money should be used in other areas of the country's development .
Each opinion has its own merits .
In my own opinion , I agree with the latter , for the following reasons: firstly , , the national budget should be spent on the more essential areas of the country's development .
For example , more money should be spent on education than any other areas .
Education has an irrefutably important part of a country's development .
Investing in education , in my opinion , is the key to growth in any country .
With a strongly educated workforce , the national economy would dramatically strengthen .
There are many ways to invest in education .
One of them is to upgrade the facilities and the quality of teaching .
More money should be spent on re-constructing old buildings and building more needed ones (laboratories and libraries ) .
On the other hand , the governments should pay more attention to the quality of teachers  .
Inviting more good professors from overseas to  join our teaching staff may be helpful .
Secondly , the money of the country should also be used to improve health care .
More hospitals with better equipment should be built .
However , it is not just the facilities that need improvement , but also the treatment of patients . .
This has again proved the point that I have made before .
Better education results in better quality of labour .
In fact , this is also a way to solve the problem of the aging   , because the elderly are those who need the support of health care the most .
Last but not least , technological researches and new inventions are also what the government should pay attention to .
The development of technology and its effects has always been one of the most important factors that totally changed the way we have lived  .
More and more inventions are made in order to enhance the quality of our daily lives .
Such improvements indisputably made our lives more enjoyable and our work more effective .
These researches and inventions can cover  .
Technological improvements will improve the educational level of people , the quality of health care , the living standards , etc . . . To some extent , these strategies also indirectly assist the elderly .
Rather , what I try to point out is the elderly could stand to benefit even if the national budget is spent on other fields . .
The most prominent demographic trends in the world today would be the aging of population .
Demographic aging ,  simply means the shift in the age distribution (i .e . , age structure) of a population toward older ages .
An aging population has many social , economic and health implications for a country and this common occurrence is not just a short term issue ; but a long term problem caused by the falling of fertility rates and high mortality .
the aging  of a population has become  a natural process that is happening in most of the developing countries; and Singapore is not being spared too .
In fact , Singapore has one of the fastest aging populations in Asia and therefore , there is A need for the government to develop and implement new public policies to accommodate to this  emerging group of people in the near future .
a need for new public policies would mean a need for greater public spending on the aged .
This is  to cater to the needs of  this newly emerging group whose mean age is 65 years . , and it will would make up nearly one-fifth of our population by 2030 .
Although aging population is of a direct consequence to the drop in fertility rates , it is also the result of high life expectancy and mortality rates .
This has come about due to the improvement in medical technology , public health awareness and sanitation , which in turn showed that many Singaporeans are living in better conditions than they had before .
Currently , there are about 7% of Singapore's population that is over the age of 65; and statistics have shown that this figure would increase to 19% by the year 2030 .
With such a sizeable number of aged in a small country like Singapore , it will definitely have many socio-economic implications ; and thus the government should generate more public polices to care for this group of people in the years to come .
Because this group of people will generally make up a significant number in our population , the government should divert more funds to improve  its healthcare system and also upgrade its infrastructure and facilities to cater to an older population .
In fact , our  government is already preparing Singapore for a new paradigm   , as this can be seen from the funding of projects such as the building of Studio Apartments , which is specially built to cater to the needs of the aged .
These apartments have special facilities that look after the elderly , such as  lifts stopping at every floor and handgrips built around the flat so that it is more convenient and safer for the elderly .
Hence , public spending should not be limited .
In fact , we should  divert more funds to similar projects that will cater to the needs of an older population as they will after all make up a significant number in Singapore , and thus more focus should be placed on them .
In addition ,  more funds should be dedicated to improving the healthcare systems by building more nursing homes and  hospitals for the aged , as old age will usually be an age that is more prone to illnesses and diseases .
Therefore , we will need a large pool of specialised trained nurses and caretakers to look after them .
This can be done through the building of more nursing homes and the encouragement of more people to take up professions relating to this field  .
Therefore , aging population is an issue that we cannot afford to neglect and public policies should cater to this new demographic trend by focusing more on the increasing older population size .
Therefore , more funds should be dedicated to projects which will better prepare Singaporeans for an aging population .
However , although aging population is a serious issue that will affect the productivity and competitiveness of Singapore , we should also note that the aging of a population is happening not only in Singapore but around the world as well .
It is a natural consequence of economic development which extends life spans and lower birth rates .
Hence , government should not over focus on this issue and throw in excessive funds in this area as this will inhibit the growth of other sectors  .
This is because funds can be diverted to other areas of the country's development , such as   and building better infrastructure to support the country's development into a world class city .
Singapore is never a welfare state to begin with; the government has adopted a policy to ensure self-reliance , such as the introduction of the Central Provident Fund (CPF) which makes it compulsory for all Singapore citizens to save for future use .
Hence , it is impossible for our government to provide welfare and pension for everyone .
The Medisave Scheme under Central Provident Fund (CPF) was introduced to make it compulsory for all Singaporeans to set aside 6-8% of their salaries to deposit into their personal account that can be used to pay for hospital fees .
Members of the CPF must keep a minimum of $17 ,000 in their Medisave account to pay for medical expenses .
According to  , the average active member's balance in 1994 was S$73 816 , which  shows how efficient the CPF saving scheme is .
Therefore , with such policy in place , public spending on the aged is already limited in this sense .
Similarly , the government also promotes life long employability which can be seen from the extension of retirement age from 62 to 65 years old .
This is to ensure that the aged can accumulate more wealth before retiring when they are still able to work , thereby reducing the public spending of our government on the aged .
In addition to all these policies , filial piety and greater family support is also emphasized Children are encourage  to take care of their parents when they are old as this will ease the funding of the government for  the elderly .
Instead the government could just focus on the needy elderly who have no children to look after them .
Hence in conclusion , aging population is a natural occurrence due to low birth rates and higher life expectancy .
Therefore ,  the government should not reduce on their public spending on the aged , but should instead increase  .
However , over focusing on this situation may inhibit the growth of our economy as  precious funds can be diverted to other uses , especially  .
One should also recognise the fact that Singapore is not a welfare state in the first place , and the policies were shaped according to the policy of self-reliance  .
Thus in this context , it is possible to justify the point that public spending should not be limited , so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
As Singapore's total fertility rate (TFR) decreases year after year , we are in increasing danger of having an ageing population in the very near future .
As of 2007 , Singapore's TFR is 1 .29 , which is well below the replacement level of 2 .1 .
The old-age support ratio has also decreased to 8 .5 (2007) from 17 .0 (1970) .
This trend suggests that Singapore is confronted with the problem of a rapidly fast aging population .
Singapore's TFR is getting lower and lower every year because more Singaporeans are settling down at a later age .
They are putting more focus on their careers first .
Couples are also giving birth to fewer babies , opting for smaller families to have a higher level of income .
As the aging population in Singapore increases , more and more money have to be allocated to the aging population .
I feel that public spending on the aged should be given more attention and more funds , as in the long-term , the aging population could potentially become a major problem .
Public spending could be focused more on giving incentives for couples to have bigger families .
As Singapore's TFR is very low , the government could do more to encourage couples to give birth .
The government could give higher monetary incentives for families who have more children .
Singapore has a high standard of living , and thus it is expensive to raise a child .
The government could divert more money to the "Baby Bonus Scheme" , though it seems the incentives are not enough at the moment for Singaporean families to want to have a bigger family .
If the incentives worked , there will be more youths in the future .
This will help to ease the financial burden of the elderly .
There would be more people supporting the old and the aged would be better taken care of .
If the TFR is higher , there would also be more people at work in the future , and contributing  to the economy and sustaining its high growth .
This would also mean that the government would not need to worry about spending more money to recruit people for national defense , as there would be enough young people to defend the country in the future .
This is one reason why money can be spent more on other areas for the country's development instead of  on the aged .
Public spending may help to encourage higher birth rates .
In the near future , it is inevitable that Singapore will have an aging population .
To tackle the problem , public spending should be given more to the aged .
The government could set up more schools to train the elderly new skills .
These new skills would allow more opportunities for the elderly to find jobs .
The government could also give more subsidies for the aged .
This will help ease their cost of living as many of them could be unemployed and unable to cope with the higher cost of living .
There should also be more public spending on elderly health care .
As the elderly are prone to more serious illnesses , some would not be able to pay their medical bills .
Smaller number of working people in society would mean that the elderly would be more dependent on fewer people , and these people would be heavily burdened .
The aging population would need more public spending as their dependents would be smaller and heavily burdened .
They would need more subsidies and monetary help to continue to lead a comfortable life .
The government could also spend more money on the health sector in general .
They should concentrate public spending on the health sector , on research and improvement of technology , to promote better and cheaper health care .
This would improve the lives of everyone in general and also help to give cheap and good health care for the elderly .
Public spending for the health care sector would benefit everyone and this could prove to be very effective .
To conclude , I feel that public spending on the aged is very important .
Singapore's population is increasingly becoming an aging population , and it  would be a problem that we cannot ignore .
Good long-term planning is essential to solve this problem of the aged and public spending on the aged is very crucial , and it cannot be neglected .
The government could also spend more money on giving incentives to encourage more families to have more children .
This would be good for the economy in the future , and would also result in more people supporting the elderly .
If this fails , public spending on the aged is the only option and more money should be diverted to it instead of the other areas .
"Over the past two decades , journalists and scholars have periodically commented on how rising public spending for older people is expected to threaten if not erode public commitments to other deserving groups ."
said Paul W . Newacheck (Health Affairs , 2004) .
Public spending is money expended from the government to pay for the country's expenses (Business Dictionary , 2009) .
The money can come from different sources , with the majority coming from taxation .
For instance , the tax policy in Singapore is drawn out based on the notion of guiding desirable behaviour towards different economic and social goals .
Therefore , public spending should emphasize not only the social , but also the economic development of the country .
However , there are many emerging concerns about the ageing society in many developed countries .
Limiting public spending for the aged may in turn bring about social problems , as well as other issues that concerned family responsibilities and dignity .
As the percentage of the aged increases , the percentage of people generating income in the country diminishes .
Without the government to shoulder part of the burden , most immediate families of the elderly will find it financially taxing on their part .
In worse cases , cash-strapped children will be unwilling to take care of them due to the high standards of living and healthcare costs increasing each year .
This problem falls back on society , as abandoned parents will be left to fend for themselves (Megawati Wijaya , 2009) .
A research in Singapore shows that the Geylang East Home for the Aged , a shelter for elderly abandoned by their family , said that its 37-bed home is always full .
In many cases , the families of these abandoned aged just passed their responsibility to another institution .
(Avia Collinder , 2008) Also , I feel that most elderly people have a strong sense of dignity and self worth , considering their lifelong achievements and efforts throughout the years (Nordenfelt L , 2003) .
These people are most probably not going to turn to government's aid even if their own families reject them .
Without the government's initiatives , the elderly people are going to go through a hard time coping in  society .
Nonetheless , it still can be argued that directing public spending to other areas of the country's development can indirectly offset these social problems .
By investing in other areas , we can empower these three groups of people: employers , families and the elderly .
Firstly , this amount of money can be used to help businesses and individuals struggling from the recent economic crisis .
For instance , the government implemented the Job Credit Scheme in Singapore .
This scheme was introduced to preserve jobs during the economic downturn .
Basically , participating employers will receive a cash grant based on the CPF contributions they have made for their existing employees(IRAS , 2009) .
It serves as a winning tool as the employers get to bring their businesses to a higher level , and  existing workers in turn retain their jobs .
In this way , these benefiters can fulfill their basic responsibilities better , such as in taking care of their own families with the higher purchasing power they have .
Secondly , education and learning are important factors contributing to a country's success .
With the society changing constantly , the monetary support which the government can provide is only temporary .
Often , people need to improve themselves to keep up with the demands and needs of their surrounding milieu .
For example , investing on current employees to advance their expertise in the workplace can land them with better promotion prospects and job security .
Equipping the younger generation with relevant skills can also allow them higher chances of securing better jobs of their preferences in the future .
Also , the government can educate these people about their responsibilities by emphasizing the role of the family in caring for the elderly (Megawati Wijaya , 2009) .
With better jobs and increases in income , they can help the families to cope with the high standards of living and spiraling healthcare costs for the aged .
As a result , social stability can be fulfilled while economic growth is being spurred .
Lastly , investments can be made on healthcare to empower the aged to take charge of their own health .
Research studies in New York showed that living a healthy lifestyle is very important to the elderly people in their journey of conquering new physical , emotional and mental challenges (Admin in Aging , 2008) .
The level of physical activity needed to be exerted for beneficial results is attainable by majority of the aged (Gerontology , 2002) .
The government can also hold "Healthy Lifestyle" campaigns to encourage the aged to engage more actively in activities , and promote healthy aging .
On top of that , the involvement of their immediate families in the process will be a bonus in helping them to cope with ageing .
With a blissful mind and a healthy body , these elderly will be less likely to seek emotional and social help from the government .
All in all , limiting public spending on the aged and directing the funds into other areas of development such as businesses , education and healthcare is more rewarding then just focusing on the needy groups .
Although the help is theoretically superficial , it is indirectly helping the society to deal with the ageing society more effectively as compared to  using  monetary support , which is a temporary solution .
This solution is made much easier when we understand the bigger picture .
If we do not pay attention to the long term effects the problem is going to cause , we will risk the possibility of allocating  limited resources for the wrong usage .
It is well-known that there are various areas of a country's development which demand substantial expenditure from public spending .
These areas are urban development , infrastructure projects , biomedical research , edbiz , and so on .
Abundant financial resources are alloted to each of the areas mentioned above , since the development of these areas are essential in national construction and economic growth  .
However , with the aging population increasing in number , more public spending , including pension and health provision ,  is expended on the aged .
More and more elderly people , especially some of those who cannot take care of themselves , empty nesters , other special groups , as well as their families , have a greater demand for pension services; and social services will be needed to provide for old-age pension .
(Wu Li Min , 2009) .
Therefore ,  public spending on the aged should not be limited so that it guarantees the welfare of the aged and protects their rights and benefits .
The aged might have devoted their youth and even their whole life to serving the society; and public spending on the aged is therefore necessary .
In fact , every one of us , regardless of doing mental or physical work , has made a significant contribution towards the development of society .
Hence , as long as a person has sacrificed for the social development of society ,  he should be looked after by the state when he is old , even if he could no longer contribute in his area of work . .
If the public spending on the aged is limited , the burden on the children or younger generation will be much heavier since they will have to bear with more expenses incurred by their parents .
It was claimed that families and individuals will face many issues if welfare programs are cut or restructured (Robert B . Friedland and Laura Summer , 2005) .
A survey in China showed that "living and working pressure makes people powerless to take care of their parents"; and this kind of pressure has become  a great difficulty for young people now (Wang Jun , 2009) .
In today's society , many people of working age , with their own careers and families , have to withstand considerable economic pressure .
Once the elderly reach their old age , they are afflicted with a variety of ailments .
Expensive medical and health care cost  , in addition to the very high daily cost , have indeed caused  serious difficulties .
So ,  when the children have to bear the medical expenses and the cost of everyday lives of their parents , they tend to live beyond their income .
The gap between the rich and the poor in  present society is still apparent .
When  the government subsidies are reduced , retired people from high-income groups may still be comfortable with their finances , but the relatively poor people will face  difficulties in livelihood .
Higher income people tend to have more savings , and so they can enjoy a carefree retirement .
However , people from the low-wage sectors in general do not have much savings , since they are often faced with the problem of having  insufficient money to spend .
In their later years , if they encountered ungrateful children who are unwilling to take care of them ,  Many people today spend money on their own  families , the needs of their children , as well as the pursuit of material comfort   , instead of  spending money on their parents .
At this point , a notion of "Parental Support Law" has been suggested to force the children to be filial to their parents (Huang Yu Shan , 2002) .
However ,  .
If a legal act is required to force people  to support their parents , does it mean that our moral values have deteriorated  ?
Clearly ,  public spending on the aged should be continued to protect the rights and benefits of the aged .
The aged have dedicated so much to the development of a country and they should be thanked .
Reduced public spending will increase the burden of the children and furthermore , poor people will become poorer .
In fact , we all will grow old one day .
According to the Singapore Department of Statistics , the life expectancy of Singaporean has increased noticeably to 78 .0 for male and to 82 .8 for female (as cited from Press Release , Singapore Department of Statistics , 2008) .
Although that is good news  , it also leads to some unpleasant problems for Singapore , such as increasing the financial burden for elderly-care .
From my perspective , economic development is not only the key factor in easing the aging problem  , but also is the key solution to some serious problems caused by this process .
First of all ,  it is commonly believed that a well-funded life which arises from economic success will help people to  purchase sufficient food for their own consumption .
At the same time , there are more facilities  , such as pools for swimming , courts for playing tennis , indoor gyms for various kind of sports .
