With  financial sufficiency , people can live an easy life and  .
For instance , living in air-conditioning buildings helps us  or using  robots reduces death rates in some high-risk jobs .
In the other words , as a result of economic development , we have been enjoying better and healthier lives .
Secondly , economic development also encourages the improvement of services  .
Among  them , the entertainment industry should be mentioned as the most obvious one .
, more and more entertainment parks , visual and virtual products ,  such as films and games come into our life .
For example , a typical citizen in a globalised city , such as Tokyo or London , can now enjoy his or her weekendtime in a hundred destinations for recreation and some of them are known worldwide .
Alternatively , they can stay at home and choose among tens of local and international TV channels to watch or they can surf the internet to visit millions of websites .
Indeed , it is no doubt that  .
What is more , a prosperous economy can also foster further technological invention , medical innovation as well as educational improvement , which all are considered to be important factors in alleviating the aging process .
Once government sufficiently finances medical research , more diseases can be cured or prevented more effectively .
In the same pattern , once the educational level is raised , people can be more aware of how to take care of themselves , as  well as to live long and healthily .
Lastly , the rapid development of a nation's economy not only makes the process of aging slow down but also partially solves its annoying consequences .
Among  its consequences , Peter G . Peterson in the article "A Gray World" raised his concern on the huge expenses for elderly caring services (Peter G . Peterson , 2001) .
In my opinion , economic factors should be the most important solution .
As discussed above , financial sufficiency can urge the improvement of the other factors .
Accordingly , people enjoy  better health and live longer  .
This enables them to stay at work for a longer time .
Since they are also healthy , they can contribute to society as long as they intend to .
In addition , financial factors are also incentives for life long working , as they can support their current lives and save more for the rest of their lives if they had decided to keep working .
There is a citation from Frank Field , British chairman of the all-party committee: "If you look at life expectancy in 1948 , when the state pension was introduced , and take that as a reasonable length of time to receive a pension , you would have a retirement age of 74 today ."
(British Broadcasting Corporation , 2002) .
Looking at this issue from another angle , some may argue that economic factor can  worsen the aging process and its consequences .
In fact , the development of the eonomy itself cannot wholly solve the problems , and one needs to examine more complex solutions in terms of  social , political and economical factors .
However , economic issue should be the first to be considered in any topic relating to the aging process .
In conclusion , today's developed countries have been increasingly confronted with the aging process and its consequences .
,  contribute to easing this process but economic factor  .
, a prosperous economy not only lengthens the of the general population  , but also allow people to live more healthily and lighten their social burden  on elderly care .
While the population is shifting towards a greying one , many would start to worry about the ease of aging in the current society , especially amidst a time of financial crisis and difficulty .
Current research and development such as medical advancement and barrier free housing estates are examples that have helped ease the aging process .
However , more emphasis should be placed on the development of social policy that will help to alleviate and address concerns such as the lack of financial support and social care , which affects the elderly more directly .
Meanwhile , there are already policies in place , such as the Central Provident Fund (CPF) , Lease Buy Back Scheme (LBS) and housing grants for married children staying near parents , which are all structured to aid the aged in terms of financial and healthcare issues .
The Central Provident Fund is a savings account for all workers in Singapore for them to set aside a sum of 33 percent of their wages for retirement purposes  .
This sum of money will serve as a source of income when one cannot work in the future due to old age .
On top of that , a subset of the CPF called the Medisave account , will serve as a backup sum to pay for any medical bills should the need arises .
Therefore , they would not have to strain their pockets to pay for their health care when they have already stopped working .
At this juncture , one may wonder how the Medisave account could be sufficient when medical fees these days are so steep .
Treatment for common illnesses , such as stroke would have already chalked up thousands  and things could be a lot more worse , should there be more than one illness to treat .
However , this could be solved by purchasing Medishield or third party healthcare insurance using the Medisave itself .
The insurance will serve to cover most of the medical expenses , if not all .
In the event that an individual is not being able to pay the minimum amount , they can apply for the Medifund , which is an endowment plan funded by the nation's economic growth , targeted to help those who still cannot afford to pay the bills despite already being heavily subsidised .
With these in place , the aged will be well taken care of and given a peace of mind in monetary ; and they could live in a more comfortable environment during old age .
For those elderly who have funds that are locked in the form of housing assets , there is a solution for them too .
Just recently , on March 2009 , the government introduced the Lease Buy Back Scheme (LBS) for elderly to sell off the tail end thirty years lease of their flats in return for a life-long monthly retirement income .
These elderly will stand to enjoy a supplement to their retirement income on top of what they will receive from CPF payout .
Depending on the age group , an amount ranging from $500 to $800 will be issued to them monthly after an upfront sum of $5000 .
Again , we can see how public policy has shaped to help the elderly to acquire a less financially taxing aging process .
Apart from being well taken care of in medical bills , the elderly needs to be looked after in their social well-being too . .
It is in the government's interest that these elderly do receive an appropriate amount of attention and care so that they will not be deprived of company at old age .
This is why the Housing Development Board (HDB) came up with a housing grant of forty thousand dollars to encourage the younger generations to live in flats close  their parents .
The policy will benefit not only the purchaser in terms of cost  , but it will also help to propagate the importance of filial piety in  society .
When  married children are housed near to their parents , they are more likely to visit them frequently due to convenience and simultaneously , the elderly will be taken care of physically as well .
Opponents of this scheme may argue that the opposite may take place instead .
Rather than having the married couple to look after their parents , it might be the couple  exploiting  their parents; such as living off them or   treating them as babysitters for their own children .
Nevertheless , this actually aligns with the government's aim: fostering mutual care between the young and elderly .
By housing them in close vicinity , it actually adds  purpose to the lives of the elderly as well .
"That's why fitness facilities , children's playground and elderly exercise equipment are put together" quoted Mr Mah BT (2008) in a housing speech .
All this contributes to making the aging process a more fruitful and meaningful one .
In the presence of these numerous social policies , many aspects of the aging process have been addressed by the government and this has served to mitigate some of the most common concerns among the elderly .
These policies have benefited the elderly and will continue to provide assistance to them in the future .
Therefore , it is evident that current research and policies have helped to ease the aging process and made retirement a less burdensome one .
The growth of the aging population is increasing at an alarming rate .
From research , in developed nations , people born in the twentieth century can live for 35 years longer than people who are born in the nineties .
The increase in aging population reflects the need for better healthcare and social services .
This is because as people aged , their health will deteriorate and this results in the increase of healthcare and social cost .
To ease this aging process , government and other industries initiated various efforts to reduce spending on healthcare and elderly dependency on the younger generation .
With continual advancement in the medical industry , current research and development in better healthcare services and facilities like building new community hospitals , providing long-term care services and developing electronic health record system (EHR) , can help ease the problems of healthcare cost and elderly dependency .
Therefore , I agree that current research and development in the field of medicine have eased the the aging process .
Firstly , the building of new community hospitals provide intermediate healthcare for the elderly who do not require consultation from the general hospitals .
With such developments , the elderly can save cost and receive appropriate healthcare treatments more conveniently .
However , convenience does not mean it is affordable .
Healthcare cost in Singapore is constantly rising with the advance in technology .
A single hospitalization can cost up to thousand of dollars .
If the elderly do not have enough savings  , they may depend  on the government or their children .
However , Singaporeans enjoy healthcare subsidies .
The amount of subsidies on hospitalization will be determined by means-testing .
This way , the government reduces the financial dependency of the elderly by providing help based on their financial needs .
In addition , there are also other financial subsidies available ,  like the Medisave , Medishield and Medifund to keep healthcare cost affordable for Singaporeans .
Secondly , Long-term care services like home care and rehabilitation can allow patients to recover in surroundings that are more comfortable and with their families around them . .
These Long-term care services involved two board categories: residential healthcare and community healthcare , which are managed by Voluntary Welfare Organizations (VWO) or by private operators .
These are cheaper support alternatives as compared to leaving elderly patients in hospitals .
In cases where the family cannot provide attention to or support for the needs of the elderly , they can seek for community healthcare services that are carried out at home or in a centre .
Such services can help to reduce the elderly's emotional dependency on their children too .
However , some volunteers for the elderly home care or rehabilitation centre may lack  profession skills , as compared to those provided  in hospitals .
The elderly may not be receiving the most appropriate medical help .
Fortunately , the government has already recognized the importance of such services to ease aging process .
In the 2009 budget speech , over $500 million will be spend in the next five years on training staff and improving this long-term care services for elderly Singaporeans .
Thirdly , the development of electronic health record system (EHR) helps to increase efficiency and accuracy of a medical diagnosis .
Many elderly with chronic illnesses may have complex medical backgrounds .
With this system , medical information of the elderly will be stored in the database and it is accessible to medical institutions island wide .
As a result , doctors and their staff can reduce the amount of  in gathering healthcare background information forthe elderly and reduce the amount of complicated paperwork .
There are arguments that the implications of this system would be excessive costs .
Just by setting up the system nation-wide , the government will be spending about SGD$200 million over the next two years .
However , based on research , the usage of the Electronic Health Record system can help to reduce duplication and error in medical prescription  , resulting in a cost reduction of  as much as USD$50 billion per year .
Therefore , we can conclude that  research and development can help to decrease healthcare spending and improve the quality of service efficiently .
Today , as our society is faced with the issue of ageing population , the needs for better healthcare and social services will increase .
Advancement in research and development within the medical industry has helped to ease the effects of aging population .
As a result , better healthcare services and facilities are created and they have effectively reduced healthcare cost and elderly dependency .
With the constant advancement in healthcare system , people can enjoy a longer life with better health without subjecting  the society to the adverse effects of aging .
To a large extent , I strongly agree that medical advancement has helped to ease the aging process .
In the Singapore's context ,  8% of the  population is over the age of 65 and by 2035 , it will increase to 20% .
Hence , medical advancement will prove to be beneficial for the aging population in Singapore .
However , I would like to stress that not the entire aging population can take advantage of  the medical advancement .
As such , a lot of aging population in Singapore will not be able to afford the high fees for advanced medical treatment that includes the use of advance technology in medicine and treatments .
This might also lead to  from part of the population who would choose not to seek any medical help due to  .
Nevertheless , this  problem has alerted the government to offer financial aids to the needy the aging population in Singapore .
The Singapore government has been actively promoting awareness of health care issues among the elderly population in general .
The Ministry of Health (MOH) has recently launched insurance financial plans for elder care .
The names of the insurance plans are called Eldershield and Eldershield Supplements (as cited from Central Provident Fund Board Ask Us , 2009) .
These programs will  provide helping hands for  aging population in Singapore .
This also  all the  aging population in Singapore to sign up these insurance plans  .
The reason for doing this is because the  needy elderly in Singapore will be covered by this insurance plan .
Thus , when they want to use this insurance plan for any emergency use , they can use it anytime .
Premiums for this insurance plan can also be paid from Medisave .
Thus , all the needy aging population in Singapore will be taken care of by the Singapore government .
Therefore , the families of the aging  group can also go to the respective hospitals to seek for financial aids  .
The Singapore government will providesubsidies for all the elderly when they seek for medical treatment .
Thus , with the solutions given by the Singapore government , they will help  the aging population to gain  .
In order to reduce this high medical advancement expenses , The Ministry of Health (MOH) has been reaching out to the senior citizens in Singapore by implementing mobile screening buses for the monthly health check (as cited from Health Promotion Board , 2009) .
Ministry of Health (MOH) has decided to make the efficient and accessible screening more affordable and convenient for all the needy elderly in Singapore .
All the needy elderly would just need to pay less than $10 for their blood test in ahealth check package comprising checks for diabetes and high cholesterol levels .
This also resulted that all the needy aging population in Singapore were given a chance to receive certain  in Singapore .
Not only that , all the residential committees (RC) and community centres in many neighbourhoods were promoting this meaningful and  health program to the needy aging population in Singapore  .
Thus , this will be beneficial to all the aging population in Singapore who could not afford any medical fees .
Last but not least , I strongly agree that medical advancement has eased  the aging process with the help of the Singapore government .
Thus , this also shows that  the aging population in Singapore is being well taken care of by the Singapore government .
With the budget given by the government , the aging population in Singapore will be given an equal entitlement to  medical advancement  to maintain a healthy lifestyle .
It is always a thorny issue when it comes to the allocation of the budget pie for the country's development .
Whether it is for educational , economical , societal or military advancement , it is of paramount importance that policy makers make suitable decisions in the best interests of the country and its people .
In my opinion , channeling too much government funds to taking care of the aged can have detrimental effects on the country's development .
Therefore , I am for the statement that public spending on the aged should be limited .
Uncontrolled government spending on healthcare or infrastructure for the aged could result in other groups of needy people not getting their share of the government's financial aid .
These include the handicapped , juvenile delinquents and low income families .
These less privileged groups of people are also members of the society who require our assistance .
Not attending to their needs may have serious impact on the society .
People from low income families struggling to make ends meet may be desperate and might resort to robbery and burglary to ease their financial burden .
Teenagers who engage in unlawful behaviours that defied established criminal codes or deviate from societal norms may continue with their misbehaviours , such as running away from school or home , or even committing petty crimes , if they failed to receive help from respective government bodies and the community .
These are complex social problems that might significantly impact other members of the society , and hence , the development of the country , if not handled appropriately .
Many may argue that the elderly are also equally , if not , more in need of the funds , especially since they were once economically  .
It is only right that their welfare is being taken care of now that they have lost the ability to take care of themselves .
In addition , some would argue that it is of the country's social obligation that this should be done .
But , like many countries , Singapore does not have a pension system for the retired  aged .
If the responsibility of taking care of the aged fell solely on the government , the huge increase in fiscal budget will not be an amount the existing workforce and taxpayers can meet .
Public funding is also required in the development of our education sector as Singapore continues to establish herself as an education hub .
In Singapore , the importance of education cannot be over emphasized .
Large amount of funds are pumped into the education sector so that the younger generation can receive the best education .
These could be in the form of better school sports and laboratory facilities , more funding for enrichment courses or even upgrading of school compound to accommodate more students .
In addition , funding could also imply subsidies for needy students .
Students under Finance Assistant Scheme (FAS) could be provided with school uniforms , school shoes and basic school materials .
Merit bursaries and scholarships can be awarded to students who excelled in their academic and exhibit positive traits and qualities in other aspects of their life .
Singapore also has a mandatory six years Primary Education for all Singaporean .
Financial aid will be needed to ensure that poor families , who cannot afford to send their children to school , could do so .
The ministry stands by the notion that no deserving student should be deprived of education .
As a former president of the United State of America once said , "Our progress as a nation can be no swifter than our progress in education .
The human mind is our fundamental resource ."
It is clear that education is one of the key aspects for the progress of a nation .
Without sufficient funds from the government , these plans cannot be implemented to their fullest extent .
People often mention that Singapore has only human resource .
Not developing our resources' full potential through education will indeed impede our country's development .
If significant amount of funds is needed in the education sector , there is then a need to limit expenditure on the aged .
Many may then question: why target public spending on the aged ?
Why not cut down on other areas like urban renewal ?
Or even cut back on military spending ?
I believe it is a difficult question to answer directly because the essence of the argument lies in the fact that the government should always spend wisely , where necessary , within the national budget .
I am not arguing for the Government to cut down public spending on the aged so as to spend without consideration on defense or urban renewal .
To limit military spending might weaken the country's first line of defense .
Singapore , being an island represented by a little red dot on the world map requires strong military defense as a form of deterrence against our potential aggressors .
Without sufficient funds , the military loses its ability to procure better and more effective weapons and devices to train and equip soldiers .
This would prove detrimental for a country's survival , especially when a weak army force may attract potential invaders .
In light of these reasons , it would be justifiable if a bigger share of the budget pie is being given to the military .
Similarly in urban renewal , there is a need to refurbish the neighbourhood and upgrade the old estates .
It is difficult to draw the line as to who should be given how much of the government's budget .
But it is important to realize that , channeling funds into the education sector  may bring about more productive future generations who would in turn help to support the  aged in time to come .
In comparison , diverting funds to support the aged would appear to have no returns .
Diverting funds to other areas can be regarded as a better "investment" by policy makers and would aid in the country's development .
In conclusion , the government has to carry out careful planning on public spending .
Channeling excessive budget or limiting any one of the areas is not beneficial to the country's development .
The Government has to make critical decisions , reviewing their decisions regularly , so as to determine which aspects of the country's development should be the main focus at different periods of time .
In the long run , the government must seek to  for the older generation , at the same time less burdensome for the younger generation .
Perhaps government should introduce policies which could add value to the aged workers , in turn increasing their productivity .
The government should try to accommodate the aging issue while limiting public spending on the aged .
With their vast knowledge and rich experience from their many years of contributing to the society , the aged would definitely be an important resource the country could tap on .
In this highly modernized world , most democratic countries depend on their government for support in an array of areas , usually in the form of monetary support .
Such financial singular by the government is termed as public spending .
A principal source of income for public spending comes from taxation .
As widely known , taxation is very limited and thus public spending has to be circumscribed .
Hence the efficient allocation of funds on public spending is deemed important as  it is definitely not able to cover the amount of funds required by the entire society .
Hence , the question as to how much we should spend on an area compared to another emanates .
Public spending are funds that are used on the society and the aged certainly has a share of it as well .
Diverting much of the public spending to different areas of the country's development is certainly abominable as we would be leaving the defenseless aged to fend themselves against the numerous problems that surface while aging .
Hence , we should limit the spending on the elderly , but only to a small extent so as not to create another problem for the elderly which adds on to their already heavy burden .
In a pragmatic view , channeling large amounts of funds to the singular of the country such as research and development and education would in the long run benefit the country's economic growth .
However , it would be morally wrong to leave the elderly who are part of the society alone .
The elderly did contribute much to the country in their younger age and the society should be obliged to look after them when they are older and not cast them aside .
Furthermore , public spending is made for everyone in the society to enjoy and seek help from and we cannot limit the funds for the elderly just because they are not able to produce any returns after enjoying the funds .
Therefore we should not limit public spending to a large extent .
With changing values in the developed countries , people are giving birth to fewer children .
This change in mindset changes the percentage of young against the old .
As a result , the percentage of old is certainly rising rapidly .
With increasing amount of people turning into old age , the portion of the public spending on the aged should not be decreasing instead .
Nonetheless , the focus of a country is to grow and prosper and development in other areas are seemingly more important .
Therefore , the society has to maintain a high standard of living as a developed world and since the elderly form the bulk of the society; we should spend more to help improve their lives so as not to lower our overall standard of living .
Hence we should spend on other developments but not at the expense of forgoing that for the elderly .
Spending on education , research and development and urban renewals are long term projects and need a large amount of funding in order to succeed .

Aging is a big issue , governments from all over the world are pushing forward policies and Research and Developments to stem its economical and social impacts on a country .
Aging is one process most people dread , especially for those without children .
In Singapore , our government has recently implemented a policyknown as Lift Improvement and Facilities Enhancement , which aims to improve the living conditions of single elderly or those who have been abandoned by their families .
Residential areas with high elderly density are set to undergo upgrading to provide more elderly-friendly-facilities .
Installation of lifts on every level and hand bars in the toilets , for instance , can help elderly overcome certain movement difficulties which they encounter in their daily lives .
The setting up of the senior citizens' corner can also act as a platform for interaction among the elderly , especially when travelling out of their house is made easier .
They would be more willing to engage in more social activities , thus becoming more receptive to happenings around them and learn to be more self reliant .
Also , the new alarm system and window grills can also ensure a higher level of security in their area .
This current policy of facility upgrades is very comprehensive as it ensures  convenience , security , entertainment and thus the social well-being of elderly .
One of our current policies to ease the aging process is by encouraging the inclusion of elderly in our workforce .
, allows the elderly to enter the workforce and maintain a spot in the society .
With the elderly working , they can gain an additional source of income for their family and increase the productivity of the society .
However , it is often argued that such policies could actually stifle competition between the current working group and the elderly .
Working adults , who are already putting too much focus on their career rather than on family planning , tend to postpone their child bearing plans even further .
In such a situation , there will be a surge in productivity initially , but we may expect a serious drop in the long run which aggravates the aging problem due to the shrinking population .
But in the case of elderly employment in Singapore , they tend to be given menial jobs , due to their physical and mental handicap as compared to younger workers .
these menial jobs  are unattractive to the career-driven adults in Singapore  are filled  up by these older workers .
According to the Ministry of Manpower , such jobs are usually occupied by people aged 65 and above and there is still a prevailing shortage of manpower .
Therefore , it would be desirable to have the elderly join the workforce as they could serve to aid in the economy with their spending power and even reduce their need for social welfare , which can be highly taxing to an economy .

The aging process is not a pleasant process for humans to go through .
However , the Singapore government had come up with some policies to help make the aging process a more comfortable one .
This is especially important , considering that Singapore had got one of the fastest aging populations in Asia , according to reports by the Ministry of Community Development , Youth and Sports (incorrect in-text citation) .
Some of the developments and policies are the construction of studio apartments specially for the elderly , the upgrading of the Housing Board (HDB) lifts which helps to improve the elders living area , increasing the retirement age to allow the elders to be more self-dependent and implementing more healthcare benefits and subsidies for the elder Singaporeans such as subsidies for community hospital stay .
All these developments and policies have contributed towards easing the aging process in Singapore .
One of the many important points to take note for an aging society is the fact that the elders' physical ability , such as walking and bathing , would tend to deteriorate over time .
Therefore attention needs to be paid , to ensure a safe environment for the elders to live in .
The Singapore government acknowledged this requirement by introducing the studio apartments and the HDB lift-upgrading projects .
In January 09 , HDB stated that they would be building more studio apartments for the elderly .
These studio apartments are equipped with elderly-friendly features such as non- slip toilet tiles , small grab poles , which are to upkeep delete this and replace with 'and' offered at an affordable price .
The upgrading of lifts in the older flatsdelete the highlighted and replace with 'where' the lifts stops at every floor of the HDB flats also helped to ensure barrier-free accessibility for the elders .
However , some problems cropped up for the lift-upgrading projects .
This was mainly . . . due to the fact that not every flat was suitable to undergo lift-upgrading project and money was needed from the elderly in order for the projects to take place .
To minimize these problems , subsidies were given out for the projects .
Overall , all these facilities would help to create a safer environment for the elders to live in .
In order to ease the aging process , the government introduced later retirement and incentives to companies that employed elderly .
These would decrease the elder dependency .
Elders who are working would be able to keep themselves updated with the current trends and developments through interaction with the younger generation .
The experience of the elders would also be passed on .
Longer working lives also meant that elders would continue to play an active role in contributing to the economy and society , thus making them have a sense of fulfilment .
Although increasing the retirement age would give rise to competition for the limited amount of jobs available and increase the unemployment rates , The positive impacts of raising the retirement age still outweigh its' negative impacts as nothing can replace the valuable experience that the elders would bring to the companies and the fact that they would also be able to earn more savings to look after themselves .
During the aging process , it is easier for the elders to fall sick as we can see from the statistics shown by the Hospital Admission Rates by Age and Sex in 2007 .
The government has thus planned healthcare subsidies and benefits for the elderly .
This is important as not every elderly is able to pay for the heavy medical bills .
These healthcare subsidies would help to offload a certain percentage of the community hospital's fees .
There is one problem with this policy in thats there are quite a few criteria that need to be fulfilled before an elderly could enjoy the healthcare subsidies and benefits .
However , these criteria were meant to sieve out the elders who truly needed help as compared to those who were actually able to afford their own medical bills .
The Singapore government has put in place many measures to help ease the aging process .
The construction of the studio apartment , lift-upgrading project , extension of the retirement age and the implementation of healthcare subsidies and medical benefits have all gone a long way to help ease the aging process .
All these developments and policies have helped to ensure that Singapore will be prepared in both the short run and long run against the problems of an aging population .
However as the aging population in Singapore becomes bigger in size , more research and development policies will need to be carried out to slow down the rapid growth of the aging population instead of easing the aging process .
One and a half decades ago , many countries had to support the aging population through ways like subsidies and public spending on health care services and facilities .
This has led to countries diverting some of the government revenues for the elderly .
As time passed , there is an increase in elderly in the society whereby 3 out of 10 people are elderly () .
The society finds it even more taxing to support the elderly in ways like subsidizing on healthcare or even facilities .
This leads to a continuous search for new research and developments/policies which can aid in today's aging population growth .
Emphasizing on the importance of filial obligation , encouraging greater productivity and improving in medical and science research are some of such examples .
Research generally targets the constellation of problems faced by the elderly , such as declining health - growing physically weak and feeble , emotional problems - living life in a shade of negativity , and social problems - feeling foreign and out of place in the society that they have once experienced .
However , the current research and development/policies unfortunately have provided more of a hindrance than an aid for the elderly .
Encouraging greater productivity among the non-elderly can increase the size of the economy and tax base .
This helps facilitate the public spending on the elderly .
For example ,  and attracting more foreign talents .
While these may seem to be plausible policies , they still cause the elderly to feel uneasy in the society .
Firstly , people would be pressured to accomplish more tasks in a given period which can lead to mental problems such as depression .
Elderly parents may end up looking after such working adults instead , imposing a heavier burden onto the elderly and government .
Furthermore , more elderly would be unemployed as they are unable to work as efficiently as the working-age adults which cause their social circle to shrink .
They will feel outcast by the society as they have the mentality that they are useless , and unable to contribute to the society .
There is an improvement delete highlighted and replace with 'in' medical and science research to cure illnesses which are usually associated with old age such as research on heart diseases and the invention of  artificial pancreas to replace any which fails with age .
However , these breakthroughs hardly ease the lives of the elderly .
Firstly , many low and middle income group elderly are unable to enjoy such medicines and healthcare treatments because such treatments tend to be long term care which can be very expensive for them to afford .
In addition , operations/ drugs have side effects which the elderly might not be able to recover from due to their failing health .
As a result , they might end up having more illnesses that can cause health to deteriorate .
Medical cost will be much higher than before .
Policies aimed at improving the employability of older workers may prove to be ineffective , thus creating economical problems apart from the existing social issues .
Retirement age of all Singaporeans was raised from 55 to 62 with effect from 1 January 1999 , as announced by the Ministry of Manpower .
Employers are also allowed to reduce the wages of employees beyond the age of 60 by up to ten percent .
Furthermore , the Central Provident Fund contribution by employers decreases with the age of the workers .
Some would argue that this policy would help older workers retain their job and get employment as the cost to employers is lowered .
However , employers may still not be willing to accept older workers due to their lower productivity .
As workers grow older , their health deteriorates and becomes less agile and thus less productive .
In the event where a company needs to lay off several staff , the older workers would usually be the ones retrenched as they would most likely draw the highest salaries .
Therefore , unemployment amongst elderly would be a common sight , increasing the number of financially dependent elderly .
The Government would have to tap into its budget to support the needy aged , resulting in a heavy burden on the working class .
Thus , these policies are ineffective without first changing the mindset of employers 
Another step taken by the government to help the aged is the provision of incentives for their children to live near them with the Housing Development Board (HDB) policy .
Children are given privileges when applying for a flat near their aged parents such as subsidized rates and priority during purchase .
Yet , along with the well intentions of the government's policy , negative effects may follow and the success of this policy will largely depend on the child's  filial piety  The lower cost of flats no doubt brings about advantages , especially making it more affordable for those from the lower income group .
With the close proximity , the physical needs of the elderly will be better provided for by their children .
The mental needs of the elderly can also be satisfied with the companionship from their family living just a few blocks of flats away .
Savings from the purchase of housing may also be used to supplement the financial needs of the elderly .
However , the policy is not perfect and the privileges enjoyed may also be abused by individuals .
For instance , elderly may be exploited by their children where the homes of these elderly are turned into  dumping grounds for kids .
These highly active grandchildren may become a burden on the aged physically .
Hence , it is dependent on the individuals' filial piety values that determine the success of the HDB policy .
Evidently , the policies aimed at easing the aging process of a country have various aspects to be fulfilled in order for it to be effective .
Governments have to look into the economical and societal impacts an aging population brings along .
Apart from that , they have to satisfy the three different needs; i .e .
the financial , social and emotional needs of the elderly .
If any one of these aspects is compromised , Singapore would risk losing her foothold in this competitive world .
With an expanding aging population , Singapore is faced with a situation where more resources need to be allocated for the well-being of the elderly .
This places an increased strain on the budget .
The issues concerning an aging population are far-reaching and there will be detrimental effects if these issues are simply ignored .
How much should a government spend on the elderly then ?
In the process of taking care of the aged , Singapore will have fewer funds to invest in the other areas that are pivotal to the country's development .
However , deciding on how much the government should contribute is a feat as a society has many needs .
It is the role of the government  to weigh which issues should be focused on in the short and long term .
Public spending on the aged should not be limited as the aging population is not one to be looked down upon , however , the other areas of development should not be neglected .
Scholars argue that it is more worthwhile to spend on other areas of development in a country such as defense , education , tourism and technology .
In Singapore , as well , emphasis is placed on these other areas .
For instance , in a recent Business Times article , it was mentioned that "government spending on Infocomm technology is set to rise 8%"delete full stop .
(2009 , February 19delete close bracket The Business insert clasoe bracket after Times .
Such development is indispensable for a country to survive in a rapidly advancing world .
If the government has to spend on the aged , fewer funds will be channeled into these areas , which is a cause for concern .
It may be a better decision to spend on the young as there are higher odds of return in this investment .
The young are more productive and equipped with updated skills .
The elderly are deemed to be less valuable to the society as they are weak and dependent on others .
An ageing population may cause a low productivity rate as seen by the Annual Growth in Labour Productivity figure; currently at: -7 .8% .
(2008 , {www .singstat .gov .sg}[HYPERLINK: http://www .singstat .gov .sg])
However , a purely pragmatic approach may not always be the best way to tackle the problem .
Singapore can tap on the aging population to assist in the growth of the country .
"Singapore , with its well-established reputation for clinical and medical excellence , is poised to tap on Asia's growing and aging population and entrench itself as a premier regional healthcare hub" inocrrect in text citation .
Although it may be costly to provide healthcare , pensions and other welfare programs , the country's social and economic aspects will deteriorate if an aging population is unattended to .
A country with sick elderly people will hinder the growth of investments as it shows a lack of planning on the government's part .
Singapore has realized this , hence , the efforts to cater to the aging population .
The government has assured that it would "pour in more resources into healthcare" incorrect intext citation The Healthcare system has be restructured to cater to the ageing population .
An aging population may prove costly to the society and economy if the country fails to prepare for the situation .
Public spending on the aged is therefore deemed necessary to avoid such a crisis .
Despite the drawbacks , an aging population is linked closely to the development of Singapore .
The issue is also set to worsen in the future considering the low birth rate .
Nevertheless with proper planning , Singapore is currently handling the situation very well without compromising on the other areas of development .
Furthermore , with an increasing emphasis on filial piety , the government is able to ensure that the aged are taken care of even as they concentrate on defence , education , tourism and even the needy who require aid and are all in all vital to the growth of Singapore as a nation .
Thomas Love Peacock (1786-1866) once said , "The waste of plenty is the resource of scarcity" .
This quotation implies to everyone , including the government to make a wise decision when allocating limited resources in order to reduce further , unnecessary wastage .
There is much concern about the government's decision to allot a huge sum of the national budget on the elderly as it is uncertain on whether the investment on the aged will attribute or be to the country's development .
The best alternative is therefore to make a more sizeable investment by limiting the spending on the aged and divert the budget to other areas of the country's development .
The present paradigm of care for the elderly is a partnership between the government , community and family .
However , children often forgo their responsibilities to care for their parents and often point the thrust to the government because they believe their parents had gotten everything from the government .
Besides , children tend to abuse their parents' privileges allotted by the government by maximizing the usage of those privileges even though it is unnecessary .
For an example , elderly with little ailment often seek the best treatment as they are provided with either free or subsidized treatments .
Thus , those with chronic ailments are unable to seek the proper treatment they are supposed to get .
If the public spending is limited , children will have to send their parents for the appropriate level of  treatment and this will reduce wastage and increase efficiency in quality of care at the same time .
Thus , judging from the explanation , it is convincing to limit the public spending on the elderly .
Government should divert the budget initially allocated for elderly to the Research and Development (R&D) sector instead .
Investment especially in enhancing the medical research will make everyone better off and also indirectly help the elderly in a way .
Since elderly are prone to chronic ailments such as renal disease or heart failure , medical research will be able to produce new drugs and more flexible treatments for them .
This will eventually increase the life span not only for the elderly , but also for the other generations .
Besides , investment in R&D will be able to develop new technologies and new sectors will be introduced to collaborate with the usage of the technologies .
More job opportunities will be provided and everyone will be able to live a higher standard of living .
Thus , diverting the budget from the elderly to R&D will provide mutual advantage for both the elderly and  economic development .
The Government should invest more in the current education of the youth instead of investing the budget in the elderly .
This is mainly because youth are more progressive towards economic development in comparison to the elderly .
Thus , the opportunity cost to invest in the education is lower than to invest on the elderly .
Besides , moral value especially to make the children beholden to their parents can be inculcated by introducing the appropriate modules in their education .
This will help the elderly indirectly as the children are trained to embrace the Eastern value to respect and take care of their parents .
Investment in education will also lead to development in the country as education serves as a platform for further development in all other sectors such as R&D and Health .
Thus , such investment will definitely pay off in the future economic growth .
In view of providing mutual advantage to both elderly and economic development , it is best for the government to revise  its budget allocation so that the right proportion of budget is divided wisely among the ministries in the country .
Elderly should not be granted a lump sum but instead the fund should be diverted to other areas which will lead to future economic growth .
This is because administrating the budget to the elderly is only a one-way benefit but if the budget is allocated to other areas such as Education and R&D , everyone including the elderly can enjoy the advantage .
What is therefore needed is both a wise policy planning and a closer look at how the allocation will influence our future and society as a whole .
Statistics have shown that by 2030 , 20% of the population will be aged 65 and above (AoA 2009) .
This has raised concerns about the issue of our ageing population and how we could allocate our limited resources efficiently .
During the recent years , the increasing competition between the old and other groups in  society for scarce resources has been on the political agenda of many countries  .
How much public spending should the aged receive is a widely debatable topic .
Public spending should be channeled into developing infrastructure that caters to the needs of the aged , subsidies to lighten the financial burden of the medical bills of the aged and also activities to help bridge the elderly and society .
Ideally , there should be no restrictions to how much resource is diverted to the elderly .
However , due to practical reasons , spending needs to be limited .
The changing demography of the population has led to many concerns regarding the large health expenses on the aged .
We tend to need more health care as we age , in addition to this , medical advancement has led to  rising health care cost , these have led to an increased pressure on the nation's budget .
The government cannot afford to bear the huge cost of public spending on the aged , as it would drain  government resources .
If we fail to limit  public spending on the aged , the pressure is likely to have an effect on public spending for other priorities , and also affect economic growth .
In conclusion , public spendings on the elderly should be limited due to the social problems which may arise from the lack of limited resources , the huge cost of the these public spending and the sustainability of the spendings .
We should not shortchange other groups of society and other developments of the nation , for the needs of the elderly .
Nonetheless , we must not fail to help the aged , but we could prioritize the expenditure such that other developments are not shortchanged in this process .
The community should do its part to help the elderly as well , after all the well being of the aged is our responsibility .
Charities such as the Community Chest can help to reach out to the elderly and hence lightening the financial load of the aged .
Individuals should fulfill their filial obligations and take care of their elderly parents or relatives .
Most countries , by now , should be aware about the rise  in the an ageing population and also the heavy expenditure it brings about .
Must a country totally channel its expenditure on this population and forget about the future savings for its younger generation ?
"Public  policies that encourage and facilitate education , basic research , and the application of promising technologies can enhance the well-being of current and future generation of older people"(Robert .B .Friedland and Laura Summer .2005) .
As a result , the writers are trying to show that public spending on the aged should be reduced .
Indeed , some countries , despite facing ageing population , do not make expenditure on the elderly as their first priority , for example Singapore .
Nevertheless , with the good economic growth it is facing , the issue on the aged is taken care of well .
This essay aims to discuss that channeling public expenditure on other factors of development of a country will not only boost the economy but indirectly benefit the elderly too .
Increasing public spending on the education sector will generate significant external benefits for society , especially the aged .
A person who has received an education not only benefits from having more knowledge and skills but has higher productivity and is able to command a relatively higher wage for his contribution in the economy .
As such ,  investing in a good education ,  will benefit a country in the long run .
For example , The Singapore government realized that quality of education was the key to creating a pool of Singaporeans who were well qualified and highly productive and as a result , it has lead to an economic boost .
As such , the government has placed great emphasis on developing our education sector to ensure that the country maintains its global and regional competitiveness .
Also , incentives should be provided to students who wish to proceed to a higher education level , specifically the tertiary level .
One of the reasons mentioned is "typical college graduates earn 73 percent more than a typical high school graduate , and those with advanced degrees earn two to three times as much as a high school graduate" (Baum and Payae , 2005 , p . 9) .
By earning greater wages , they would be able to prepare themselves for their 'golden age' .
However , it has remained a reality that by forcing people to increase their productivity  by having more knowledge and skills is indeed stressful for them .
Also , a boost in the economy , might lead to higher standard of living .
People today are becoming work-oriented and adding to the notion of higher standard of living , they tend to be "afraid" of getting married as they do not want to burden themselves with the expenditures they have to face when having a family .
As a result , it may lead to an increase in the aging population due to a low birthrate .
For example , in Germany , the birthrate has proved a decreasing trend from year 2000 to 2007 .
Still , in order to counter such concerns , the government has provided various incentives like the baby bonus scheme introduced in Singapore which is to promote marriage and also to provide incentives to boost the birthrate .
Also , Peterson (2001) has mentioned that raising more productive children , through good education , the cost burden is spread over a larger and more affluent future generation .
Thus , public spending on the education sector will indirectly benefit the elderly .
Next , public spending on the economic sectorand international trade , will make a country more affluent , hence benefiting the society especially the aged .
Due to globalization , most countries are now involved in international trade .
Free trade allows a wider range of goods and services and most importantly it is cost saving .
This would therefore , enhance the exports of a country .
Also , by having international trade it forces firms in a country to be more competitive (increase competition among firms) .
This leads to greater improvement in technology as firms would invest in the Research and Development (R&D) .
With trade , it forces a country to be a niche in a certain area , for example , The Singapore economy is a knowledge based one . .
Thus , it has a large pool of highly skilled and educated workforce .
As a result , Singapore has strong tripartite ties between research institutes , industry and universities facilitating a fluid exchange of ideas and competencies that assist the fast adoption of innovative creations .
Since Singapore is also technologically inclined , R&D commitments have been on the rise for the past few years .
Thus , adding to the country's GDP .
However , international trade causes countries to be interdependent .
This results in a 'domino effect' if one needs of the countries involved in  trade faces an economic downturn .
An example would be the current economic downturn faced by The United States .
The USA is one of the prominent countries involved in  international trade and as a result of its economic downturn it adversely affected countries like Singapore who practice an open economy .
Despite this , Singapore was not really badly overthrown by USA's economic deficit due to the government's strong policies in handling such a situation .
Indeed , Singapore's niche in R&D has resulted in the advancement in the healthcare sectorproviding better healthcare facilities .
Since the aged are usually the ones in need of healthcare facilities , they greatly benefit from it .
Hence , public expenditure to boost international trade has resulted in the investment of R&D which significantly benefitted the aged in terms of better healthcare services .
Lastly , public spending should be a channel to providing better infrastructure .
The government's objective is to provide a comfortable living condition for its citizen .
In Singapore , the creation of The Circle Line that would be fully operational by 2011 , has increased the accessibility of places in the country .
As a result , people can easily get to their specific destination in a short period of time .
However , with the increasing affluence and standard of living , the people are now able to purchase cars and thus , getting around would not be so much of a hassle .
Still , increasing car ownership in Singapore leads to congestion on the road during peak hours .
Also , with the wide income gap in Singapore , not everyone; lower income earners , could purchase a vehicle .
As a result , some might still choose public transportation over private transport .
Better infrastructure has also made the government improve its transportation system .
Therefore , most public transport these days is designed to benefit those with special needs and the elderly .
Also , with better infrastructure  , more investors are inclined to invest in the country resulting in a boost to the economy .
Hence , not only expenditure on the development of infrastructure indirectly improves  public transport but also boosts a country's economic development .
Therefore , indirectly , the elderly are able to benefit from it .
Clearly , by shifting public expenditures to other development of the country ,  not only boosts a country's development and makes living more comfortable within the country , it also indirectly benefits the elderly too .
Also , public spending in such areas provides long term objectives and goals .
Therefore , it is like killing two birds with one stone .
Aging populations are compelling governments to create or revise policies and development that may affect the life of its citizens At the same time , this sustainable shift in aging population poses challenges to policy makers .
Policy makers are faced with the challenges such as how changes in the ratio of working-age citizens to retirees affect the ability of the public to fund for the aged ?
In what ways can the health system adapt to the needs of the aged who have a higher probability of having chronic diseases ?
Lastly will the implementation of policies result in increase or decrease in public saving and investments ?
I do agree that the above challenges prove that the country is doing research and working on policies that can help to ease the aging process .
No doubt , countries  are working on policies that can help to ease the aging process .
However , for policy makers their main objective is to think of policies and developments which can help the country in expansion or to ensure that it will not hinder economic growth .
In order for a country's expansion , policy makers are working on developments that can provide a valuable "public product" such as education and infrastructure .
The development of the education sector will enable  further generations to be more educated and to possess a higher level of skills .
Next , development on the infrastructure will attract more foreign investors to set up companies in the country .
With development in both education and infrastructure , foreign investors will choose to set up their companies in a country with a pool of talents and with great infrastructure with this it can boost  the country's economy .
Nevertheless working policies and development to assist the aged can help with the The Country's expansion .
This can be achieve by  placing emphasis  in increasing and raising more productive children in  futurer generations as  "by raising more productive children so that the cost burden is spread over a larger and more affluent future generation" (Paterson , 2001) .
Raising and increasing productive children not only can , attract foreign investors to invest in a country with pool of talents and the burden of looking after the aged population is being spread out with prosperous further generations .
As such , a win- win situation can be achieved as we not only ease the aged population but also assist in country expansion .
Next , advancement in technological tools is required to ensure the sustainability of the health care system .
These technological tools are developed to make life of the aged easier , less stressful and even healthier for them to continue living independently .
For example , monitoring systems are currently researched to allow the aged to remain in their homes longer even if they are being treated with chronic diseases , rather than moving them into a nursing home which may incur more costs .
Lastly , research in life science areas has shown ways  prolonging human life and to prevent illness .
A recent research shows that lighter meals may prolong human life by having calories-restricted diets .
Calorie restricted diets can induce a slowdown of the aging process and  increases survival , resistance to diseases , prevents brain deterioration and lastly reduces muscle loss .
additional research states , that oxidative stress may not help prolong life as oxidative stress has links with aging , cancer and other disease .
Researchers have suggests minimum exposure to oxidative conditions actually offer protection from acute doses .
With  research and advancement in life sciences to prolong human life and prevention of illness can help to reduce the fiscal costs on heath care .
In conclusion , research , development and policies that help to ease the aging process is relatively important .
For instance , increasing and raising productive children not only can reduce the t burden  but also  attract foreign investors to invest in the country with a pool of talent .
Secondly , technology advancement will enable the aged to live independently even if they suffer with chronic diseases and their children can spend more time to focus on their work .
Lastly , research in life sciences to prolong life can help to reduce the fiscal costs on heath care and prevent illness .
Therefore , we must pay attention  on current research , development and policies to ease the aging process .
Governments usually face problems caused by an aging population .
Problems such as a shrinking workforce and an increased need in healthcare support have exerted pressure on government spending .
As the national budget is limited , decisions on the allocation of resources have to be made regularly to create a better livelihood for its people which include the young , the working adults and the aged .
Despite the important role played by a government in ensuring the well being of the aged , there should be a balance in maintaining its social presence to prevent the elderly from over relying upon them .
Moreover , in an Asian society like Singapore , it is also the moral obligation of children to perform filial piety towards their parents financially and emotionally .
Therefore , public spending on the aged should be limited so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
Some people argue that welfare of the aged is the full responsibility of the government as they have contributed to the society for many years and it is a way of showing appreciation to them .
This can be achieved by providing the aged full medical support and adequate living allowances .
However , the limitless spending on them will hurt the country's development in areas which are of importance such as education , employment and communication infrastructures .
Moreover , if the government decides to retain its limit of spending on the aged , higher tax burden will eventually be imposed to increase revenue to fund these interventions .
Firstly , education sets the foundation for a country to progress economically as well as socially .
The government should increase expenditure in this area to maximize the potential of each individual  .
Free education can be implemented till they start working .
This will allow the population to contribute productively to the economy in future .
In addition , retirement programs should be emphasized and introduced to the people in their early working days .
Creating such awareness is crucial during this period as it prepares them mentally and financially to the challenges of aging .
Learning is also a lifelong process .
Peterson (2001) said that elder dependency could be reduced through longer working lives which require them to retrain and learn new skills .
In other words , Governments that spend  more on this area will not only find it beneficial to those who are presently  young but also for the future elderly  population .
However , it is futile to have a skilled and knowledgeable workforce without sufficient job opportunities and career advancements .
As a country develops into a knowledge based society , there will be a shift in the employment situation .
More people are less willing to provide labor work in manufacturing sectors with low career advancements .
As a result , job dissatisfaction of the people will lead to a rise in  unemployment .
Thus , creating the desired job opportunities often lies in the role  Governments play to rectify the deficit .
With the excess money diverted from spending on the aged , the government can promote foreign investments through incentives and tax reliefs to create employment for their people .
Alternatively , it can fund small-medium enterprises which encourage entrepreneurship as well as career advancements .
As the world becomes globalized the need to stay connected and informed with one another is necessary for a country to develop economically .
For example , in order to enable efficient trade globally , telecommunication networks have to be maintained and improved to reach out to other parts of the world .
Hence , government spending on infrastructure is important to boost the economy .
A decrease in the spending to fulfill the constant needs of an aging population will not be worthwhile t . Clearly , the trade off for limiting public spending on the aged is rewarding .
Education marks the beginning of the human capital investment which will benefit the country's economy in the long run .
At the same time , unemployment issues can be reduced by creating more relevant job opportunities through foreign investments and entrepreneurship .
In addition , communication infrastructure bridges the link between a country and the world to ensure trade efficiency .
Therefore , it is critical to spend more in these areas to develop the country's economy rather to adhere to the needs of the aging population and bear full financial support .
The dawn of the twenty-first century has not slowed down the technological progress that man has been pursuing for so many decades .
New products and innovations are produced by the day .
These advances in technology have , most importantly , eased the lives of our aged citizens .
With the world consisting of an ever expanding aged population , there has been a greater necessity for simple household appliances that can be used by the aged and the disabled .
In addition , social policies are constantly evolving and changing , with some newly implemented policies greatly easing the aging process of the elderly .
Researches in economics have also resulted in new policies , as will be discussed below .
The policy that resulted from economical research stated that the size of today's economy and tax base could be increased by encouraging the inflow of employable immigrants .
This fact is proving to be false .
For it must be kept in mind that these immigrants will also grow old and require pensions some day .
Furthermore , evidence shows that there is no relationship between immigration and economic growth whatsoever .
This , therefore , does not solve the problem of the present , but worsens future prospects too .
On another note , some social policies may not be beneficial in the long term .
For instance , the policy that advocates late retirement means that the working period of citizens is extended beyond the usual age of 55 and 60 .
Although it aims for the greater good , by providing the elderly with greater self sufficiency , it is more harmful in the long term because the most critical issue here is the health of the elderly  .
They are often unable to withstand high stress of the mind and the body that these work require and fall ill frequently .
The policy of passing laws that make it a must for children to look after their elderly parents is also much speculated over .
I feel that this is not the correct approach to the problem .
Taking care of one's parents is not a straightforward transaction , like paying one's taxes .
Instead it is one which also involves time and constant emotional attention .
This does not ease the problems of the aged or their children who are coping with the rising prices of goods and services and  who must care for their children  .
Hence , the banes of today's new policies .
However , it is unquestionable that technology has contributed on a massive scale in helping the aged .
The SANYO technical review reveals the existence of "systems that remind the elderly person to take their medicine; systems that detect when he/she is in the room , so that electricity costs can be minimised .
There are systems that will assist you in various day to day activities without the presence of another person including washing oneself , dressing up and using theoilet .
Another invention is a telephone that utilises voice speed control technology .
This technology allows the aged person to slow down the speed at which the person on the other side is speaking ."
This is especially useful for the older citizens , for one's senses become less acute with age , and they cannot comprehend what others are saying , at the rate at which they are speaking .
"The medical alert system is another good example .
This system is set up in the aged person's house and consists of a speaker that is able to know where you are in the house , and guides you simply by tracking the signals emanated by the wristlet you wear on your hand ."
In addition , it alerts the health authorities and your closest relatives in the occasion of an emergency .
It is particularly useful for those who are old and who live alone .
The possibilities of technology are endless .
In addition , I am an advocate of the social policy that deems it necessary for all citizens to put aside a small percentage of their monthly salary , during the working period of their lives .
For this seems to be a rather effective policy , with the value-added element of being able to lighten the economic burden supported by the government  .
It consequently does ease the aging process , for the elderly  need not be at the mercy of others to obtain full medical care and other comforts .
Another policy suggests that money be invested in the educational system , so that more productive children are raised , "resulting in a larger and more affluent future generation" (Peter Peterson , 2001) .
I feel that this is the key solution to easing the aging process , for a more productive younger generation means that all costs required to keep the aged healthy and comfortable can be borne by this efficient younger workforce .
Hence , the progress of the world in aspects of technology , economy and social policies have by far proven to be beneficial to the elderly  of today's society .
It has made their life after retirement one of relaxation , with comforts close at hand ,  .
It has made them more independent from others , and ceased to be seen as a burden in the eyes of their children and society .
Progress will always have its hindrances and flaws , but progress is always the correct path to success .
