Obviously , the notion of reimbursing the elderly with financial aid for their contributions to the country is naive .
There are plenty of methods that  can provide  aid the elderly .
Elder dependency should be reduced by encouraging later retirement (Peter Peterson , 2001) .
This is an example of alternatives that can be used to reduce  spending on the elderly .
So reducing  spending on the elderly for the sake of a country's development is a wise act .
While public spending on the aged is vital , it should not comprise  other aspects of a country's growth and development .
As mentioned by Friedland and Summer (2005) , "With little economic growth , society faces fewer choices on how to care for those who are least able to care for themselves .
On the other hand , with sufficient economic growth , there are more choices and fewer persons in need" .
This underlines the importance of economic development in the country to neutralize the implications of an aging population .
Thus , instead of spending excessively on the aged , resources of the country should be diverted to other areas like healthcare , education , and infrastructure , which will in turn benefit the country economically .
Despite the above  , it may be argued that as the elderly  contributed significantly to the country's development in their younger days , in view of their long term hard work , they should be entitled to more benefits than the rest of the population .
Governments should also set aside sufficient funds to assist them in coping with their old age life , be it in terms of financial or social assistance .
For instance , as people age , there is an increased need for more healthcare resources , hence leading to  inevitable spending in healthcare  .
However , for the elderly with low or no income , they may face difficulties and restrictions in seeking appropriate medical treatment due to financial problems .
It is therefore crucial for governments to extend assistance to the elderly in the form of medical subsidies , allowances , rebates and other kinds of financial aid to ensure that the needs of the elderly are met and protected .
In contrast to the above , although public spending on the aged is essential , there is also a need for investment of resources in the educational sector to provide better education for the younger generation .
As the common saying goes , "Children are the future pillar of the nation" .
They should be given every right to receive education under any circumstances .
Resources of the country should be diverted into this aspect to provide scholarships and bursaries for  needy children who are keen to further their studies and allow them to be exposed to better working opportunities in the future .
Not only that , an educated population will also mean a more productive workforce for the country , which will allow them to have an edge over others .
Moreover , as mentioned by Friedland and Summer (2005) , "Public policies that encourage and facilitate education , basic research , and the application of promising technologies can enhance the well-being of current and future generations of older people" .
This further suggests that with education , older people in the future will be more affluent and will have a lesser tendency to rely on the government for their well-being .
In turn , the government will not need to set aside huge resources for the aged , and will be able to divert these resources into other areas of the country's development .
To summarise , governments should also recognize the fact that unlimited spending on the aged will not be viable in the long run as individuals will only grow to be more reliant on the government to provide for them in their old age .
In short , a better suggestion will be for countries to place more emphasis on its economical development , as with economic growth , people are generally more affluent and hence will possess the financial capabilities of providing for themselves in old age .
Even though there will also be a minority who are less capable of doing that , they will only comprise of the few who require assistance from the government .
In today's context , ever changing societies frequently face a plethora of issues .
Likewise , most countries are currently tackling the main  issue of an increasing ageing population .
Since today's silver population of 65 years and above is 15 percent and is estimated to grow phenomenally to around 25 percent by the year 2030 (Centre for Strategic and International Studies 2009) ,  governments are deeply concerned with the implementation of fiscal and welfare policies that would directly impact the aged .
A component of fiscal policy , public spending , should be limited so that self-reliance can be inculcated into the aged through forced savings and so the economy can function better by shifting monetary input to facilitate trade and investments in infrastructure .
Contrary to limiting public spending , critics of human rights have been  advocating that state funding should not be minimized at the expense of growing the economy .
The mindset of respecting those who built the country from scratch resonates with feeling indebted to take care of them when they are old and providing them with the best of health-care .
Thus , in this instance , financing the elderly is an obligation in which public spending should not be cut back just because the aging population is growing at an alarming rate .
Moreover , to a large extent , the government should favour funding programmes and policies for the elderly so their interests are well looked after  .
Although it has always been the case that an appropriate amount of public spending is set aside for the aged ,  it is  of the utmost importance to instill a sense of self-reliance in them , which can be effective through education about saving for retirement throughout their working life .
This plan of accumulating savings by an individual is compelled by law in some countries and at the same time , while the savings can help to enhance one's responsibility for their own life , they can also provide people with financial security after retirement .
In this way , the aged would not be too dependent on family and the state for financial assistance .
Furthermore , when public spending is minimized through self-reliance on the part of individuals to save for their future , the money can instead be put to better use to help those who really need it .
Another point in case is that since the elderly can be self-sufficient to support themselves in old age , public spending in this area is thus limited , and may eventually result in a shift of state funds and capital to boost other sectors of the country's economy .
As such , there may be a huge concentration of growth in the area of trade because when more capital is used to invest in trade , it reaps substantial rewards in the form of revenue and higher growth and stability of the economy will ensue .
Besides  state funds and capital can be used to improve  the infrastructure of the country; e .g .
public transport systems , telecommunications sector , energy and water resource divisions  etc , so that the country may  advance and prosper with the advent of new technologies and infrastructure .
Therefore , when  economic growth is stable , this will lead to avenues of vast opportunities to further develop the country , and also result in fewer elderly in dire needs (Friedland and Summer , 2005) .
As a whole , the notion of public spending can be viewed as akin to a coin which has two sides .
One aspect is that of favouring the elderly to the extent of fulfilling their needs to the best the state can provide because of their esteemed position as 'forefathers' of the country .
Whereas , the other aspect is seen as benefitting the whole community at large since such capital and funds are diverted to improve the economy .
Henceforth , the problems associated with an aging society is one such situation which cannot be dismissed lightly as having a definite solution , as often there are severe repercussions that occur with it .
Even in the face of success , it is important to periodically review the economic and social impact of housing and healthcare policies , as they will remain the key concerns in Singaporeans' lives .
Our public housing policies will have to adapt and respond to the changing needs and aspirations of Singaporeans .
With the rising standard of living , the housing needs in Singapore will change as well .
HDB will also have to do rigorous planning on its housing policies .
As Singapore has limited land  , it will have to think of ways to increase land usability and rejuvenate the old estates .
Pressures to spend on healthcare will also rise with an ageing population .
Public request for subsidies to cover the latest medical treatments , the improvement of service quality , and the reduction of fees for subsidized specialist consultants are becoming more common .
With such pressures , the need to prevent healthcare costs from escalating remains a key challenge .
Policy makers will have to ensure that the best feasible outcome is achieved .
"To a large extent , current research and development or policies have helped to ease the aging process ."
I strongly agree with this statement .
Nowadays , a lot of researches have been carried out and many policies have been implemented in order to ease the aging process .
The three main policies that I will be discussing are filial obligation , later retirement and government subsidies .
Firstly , the main problem of the aging population is that the children do not want to take care of their parents when they are old , because they think that parents are troubles for them , since they are old and unable to contribute .
One of the methods to resolve this problem may be through legislation .
For example , the Singapore government has implemented the Maintenance of Parents Act since 1996 , and a Tribunal for the Maintenance of Parents has been established .
Under this act , parents who are above the age of 60 and are unable to support themselves can claim maintenance from children .
Children who fail to do so may be fined up to $5000 or jailed up to 6 months .
According to the statistics made by a government organization , in the first 3 years after this act was implemented , 400 parents sought for aid under this act .
Some may argue that filial obligation should be voluntary and shall not enforced by law .
But , if the children still fail to support their elderly parents after much education , legislation will be a must in solving this problem .
If children are bound by such filial obligation , they will then take care of their own parents , and hence , the elderly dependency on government subsidies or the public may be reduced .
Secondly , some  senior citizens who do not have any children will have no support at all .
Thus , it is crucial that they have their own jobs , their own income , in order to support themselves .
As a result , later retirement is encouraged by governments from many countries .
After retirement , the elderly always stay at home and have fewer activities .
Eventually , they will become weaker , more forgetful , slower in reaction and less agile .
Not only that , the biggest problem is that they will have no income to support themselves .
Hence , later retirement will be a good option for them .
The reason is that , with a job , the aged can keep themselves busy and do more thinking in order to complete their work .
So , it keeps them healthy .
At the same time , they may have stable income to support themselves .
For example , the Singapore government has extended the retirement age of Singaporeans from 60 to 62 , and at the same time , provides them with trainings and courses , such as the Ling Kwang Home and Seniors@eCitizen , in order to meet the requirements of  employers .
Some may argue that later retirement is too much a burden for the elderly , but it is actually optional for them , depending on their own abilities and desires .
In short , later retirement can help the elderly to accumulate more wealth to support themselves , maintain health and find new purposes of life so that they are less dependent on  others .
Lastly , it is undeniable that , some of the elderly have no children , and they are unable to work , especially those who are too old or uneducated .
Hence , the government and the public will play an important role in order to curb this problem .
For example , the Singapore government has implemented many policies and provided a lot of subsidies to help the elderly .
One of the subsidies is Home Medical and Home Nursing Subsidy provided by the Ministry of Health (MOH) .
MOH targets to fund 50% of the elderly population requiring home care services .
With the subsidy , the elderly can stay in their own houses as they do not have to stay in hospitals .
As a result , the lonely elderly can also stay healthy in a community .
In a nutshell ,  various problems have arisen due to the aging population .
However , rather than to discriminate against and despise the elderly , we should put in more effort in trying to ease the aging process .
The three main methods in solving this problem will be filial obligation , later retirement and government subsidies .
Last but not least , every single person and organization should combine strength together to curb this problem , as quoted in the MOH Philosophy , "An elderly person should stay in community for as long as possible as institutionalization should only be a measure for the last resort ."
The ageing population in Singapore has been growing gradually since the mid 90s .
This increase is due to the larger number of babies born between the baby boomers' years of 1954 to 1964 , and the fall in birth rates subsequently .
Moreover the size of the ageing population is expected to increase more by the year 2030 (by 18 .7%) .
It is therefore  expected that the government spending should likewise increase .
The question is how much the increase should be and whether there should be a limit put in place .
These questions proved to be contentious and controversial and I will be further expanding these ideas through this paper .
Considering that a minority of the elderly population are stuck in the poverty cycle and continues to be weak and dependent on the government financially , we also should not however assume that all the elderly are unable to support themselves financially .
Statistics have shown that it is expected that the predominant of the elderly population by year 2030 will be more affluent since they are given better access to education and other opportunities .
Good health and material needs being granted , the elderly population would be expected to be capable of being responsible for their own financial needs .
In this case , there would not be a need to allocate limitless public spending to the aged .
Minister Mentor Lee mentioned about continued nation building and there being a need for more promotion of local entrepreneurship programmes and education .
He advocates that more of such programmes will help Singaporeans feel more "rooted" and possess a greater sense of belonging , since they will then have a 'stake' in this country .
Furthermore he also mentioned that our country needs to find new sectors such as the life science field to invest upon so as to keep the economy competitive .
When more money is being invested in these entrepreneurship programmes , there should be an increasing pool of business-savvy talents .
Our economy and the population should be expected to benefit from this increase .
The ageing population in Singapore , also known as the "silver industry" will provide a potentially lucrative market of labourers to attract foreign companies and business opportunities .
With the increase of local businesses involving the aged population , there would naturally be new products and services in leisure , retail , asset management , insurance and even healthcare catered to the needs of the elderly .
In other words , there will not be a need for a deliberate public welfare to take care of the needs of the aged population .
With reference to MM Lee's sentiments about venturing into new economic sectors , the money invested serves to seek growth .
However we must also consider whether to either sustain these new fields or deal with their  .
Let us take an example of the stem cell research centres at Jurong Science Park .
In attracting these foreign lucrative industries , the government built new roads and infrastructures to remain competitive globally .
Singaporeans are equipped with the necessary education and skills to become local sources of labourers for the stem cell research centres .
All these intangible costs would require a bigger share of public spending to sustain growth of the foreign industries investments in the long run .
It would be economically rational to place a limit on public spending on the aged population and subsequently channel the excesses to attract more economic investments for the country in the long run .
There are several other notions which are possible to argue in favour of extending a 'limitless' public spending on the aged .
The adequate welfare of the local population would definitely enhance the citizen's quality of life .
By providing limitless welfare to the aged would generally improve the living conditions of some of the less fortunate but that might potentially give room to 'free-riders' who would exploit the welfare system .
It is not a question to reduce or increase public spending upon the aged population , but it is about keeping a healthy balance in public spending efforts .
In conclusion , I believe that spending on the elderly should be limited because the elderly will be increasingly independent in the future , and because new economic challenges which require more government spending would arise .
The benefits of investing on education , new economic fields , and infrastructures would benefit the nation economically in the long run .
I would propose that public spending should be allocated based on the relative contributions each sector is able to make to the country's economic growth .
The key is about seeking a balance .
It is commonly agreed that our society is facing an inclination of growing old .
In Singapore , the proportion of residents aged 65 and above increased from 6 .8% of the resident population in 1998 to 8 .7% in 2008 .
The effect of this aging issue is often being over-emphasized .
In fact , the issue of aging population is normally seen in all developing and developed countries due to the explosion of technologies and enhancement in lifestyle .
It shall be handled with wise policy planning but not putting in as much country wealth to take care of the welfare of the elderly as possible .
In other words , public spending on the aged should be limited to a certain extent as the money can be distributed to other aspects of development .
As a country is moving forward , the aged population tends to be neglected in terms of welfare .
This is why the topic issue is raised , as a result of not forgetting the elderly who contributed much to all the improvements in their younger ages .
Yes , who are we without them ?
However , in conjunction with the positive feedback of modern technologies , the elderly in this era are enjoying a much more comfortable lifestyle compared to decades ago .
They are better educated , healthier and richer due to the economical and sociological changes .
In this case , they have stronger ability to take care of themselves independently .
We shall not be hauled back by the aging issue as the welfare for the elderly is actually better taken care of than before , but we should focus on just taking care of the group of elderly who is really weak .
Government spending is necessary for the welfare of the elderly but the bigger portion of it must be retained for other parts of national development .
On a larger scale , government policies should be made based on the advantage of all but not just the aged community .
Public policies are still needed to be drawn up taking into account of the problems the elderly meet , but not to an unlimited extent that goes for their good at all cost .
It's inevitable there will still be a group of aged people who cannot take care of their own welfare .
It's the responsibility of a caring government to take care of their needs .
As implemented in Singapore , filial obligation is drafted in law , which means that children are compulsory to take care of their parents' elder life .
"It would be agreed that children owe to their parents respect and kindness generally and assistance in case of infirmity or any special need . . ." (Henry Sidgwick 1907) .
For the layer of aged population who is still healthy but has lower income , they might have problems in accumulating wealth .
Extending the retirement age is a great way to let them choose whether to work longer or not .
Although government spending is to be cut down , the healthcare of the elderly should be provided at least for the poor .
Subsidized regular check up and medical fees must be offered to the senior citizens who are not able to pay up the amazingly high medical costs .
Money saved by cutting off unnecessary projects due to the exaggerated aging issue can be divided wisely into fields that can either promote the enhancement of the country or improve the life of all .
This covers government expenditure ranging from education , health , information and communication , environment , transport and many more .
For instance , education is the most important part to invest in , knowing that new generations will be the future work force and take over the power and leadership position .
In Singapore , 743 .4 million dollars was spent in 2007/08 to achieve a high literacy rate of 96% (among residents aged 15 years and over) .
Other than that , economy should be injected a greater amount of fund to ensure low redundancy rate and minimize the loss in economic crisis .
Other requirements that can be achieved include a green environment , an integrated transport system and excellent communication coverage .
In short , government expenditure should be spent on the welfare of elderly , especially those who are in need .
However , due to the high independence of senior citizens nowadays , it's not necessary to provide an all-range policy to all of the aged population as there're still many other aspects that should be taken care of .
This concludes that public spending on the aged population is fairly needed but to an extent that allows more improvement in other fields .
Old age has been always been associated with poor health and loneliness as people reach the final stage of their life .
The aging process is exacerbated when children abandon their parents as they feel that the old ones are a burden to them .
This is evident by anincreasing number of old people being sent to old folks home every year .
In the past , such cases were fewer as abandoning of parents was seen as a social stigma , an unfilial act .
Despite this , current research , development and policies have helped to ease the aging process to a great extent .
Unprecedented advances in technology resulted from extensive research and implementation of different creative policies have made the process of aging more pleasurable .
This could be in the form of less illness associated with old age and more activities available for older ones to participate in .
Firstly , in the medical arena , huge amounts of money have been poured in for research and development .
This is without waste , as many cures have been found .
Previously incurable diseases such as tubercolosis can be eradicated and this leads to an increase in life span and higher quality of life .
People in old age can receive better medical attention .
With a healthier body , the aged can enjoy their later years .
Secondly government policies  have impacted the lives of the aged positively .
One of them is the introduction of subsidies .
Old people tend to have little or no savings .
Hence to be entitled to subsidies greatly increases their welfare .
Furthermore more and more countries are compelled by the law to set aside a certain amount of money for their old age .
In Singapore , a certain portion of working population income is set aside in their Central Provident Fund(CPF) in which the money can only be taken out at age 55 or later .
With more savings the old ones can provide for themselves and have more to spend for themselves instead of relying on the small sums payout by the government .
Another government policy that  benefits the aged is the increment of the retirement age .
This is to encourage more people to work longer and reduce the dependency of old people on the government .
Other than the economic benefits , old people can involve themselves in their work and research has shown that working reduces the risk of getting illness associated with old age such as Alzheimer's disease .
Thirdly , developments in infrastructure have resulted in more community centres built .
There are many activities ongoing in these community centres which are open to anyone interested .
Old people are encouraged to participate in these activites as they not only allow them to fill their time with activities they are passionate about but also expose them to opportunities to mix with a variety of people .
Such activities could include singing competition , karaoke , dancing and mind games .
These activities make the aging process more fulfilling and engaging .
As countries get more developed , their citizens are more affluent and trends and cultures change .
More and more people are forsaking their parents in old folks' homes as they could afford to .
Old people in old folks' homes may have to deal with loneliness and the harsh fact that their own children whom they have brought up , have abandoned them .
The 'loss' of the company of their loved ones may be difficult for them to accept and they may end up not enjoying the rest of their life .
To conclude , advancement in technology , breakthroughs in medical research and various government policies have contributed to the aging process where the aged can have better , quality and pleasurable time completing their last stage of their life .
However  in certain cases  development has caused a weakness in the extended family .
'Aging' is a natural process of human life-cycle , whereby one grows older and gains his wisdom to the fullest before he departs from the Earth .
However , with the increase in this group of 'intellectual' people , our world is turning grayer than before .
According to Gavrilov and Heuveline (2003) , population aging is expected to be among the most prominent global demographic trends of the 21st century .
It is characterized by the decline of the fertility rates as well as the rise of life expectancies worldwide .
As such , this intensifying phenomenon creates a huge economic impact on numerous countries across the globe , presenting challenges on the allocation of fiscal budget to mitigate rising healthcare costs as well as costs in other related areas .
Therefore , given the budget constraint of each country , it is crucial for the government to maximize its resources effectively to have a well-balanced development of other areas .
With the growth of the aging population , public spending on healthcare costs will be exorbitant .
Each working individual will have to contribute more taxes due to the decline of economically-productive people .
Nevertheless , it is important for the government to implement feasible policies to assist the aging population .
Measures to ease the aging process include architecture upgrades and restructuring of healthcare system .
The first measure consists of building innovative features like small bumps on the ground to lead the visually-impaired .
In addition to escalators , lifts are constructed at train stations to allow the wheelchair-bound to traverse between different levels .
The latter consists of building more community hospitals for the elderly as well as extending the services of community hospitals to homes to save costs (Majid , 2009 , para .
3 and 11) .
However , the government should also ascertain the limit of healthcare finances based on an individual's capability .
On the other hand , cutting of elderly welfare finances may increase the financial burden of the family members .
Therefore , it is essential for the government to focus its resources on developing various areas , especially on those that are important to the sovereign interests like defense , education and economy .
A nation's military spending always takes up a substantial proportion of its fiscal budget due to the importance of having a strong defense force to defend itself against aggressors should diplomatic negotiations fail .
For example , the proliferation of nuclear weapons by North Korea has sparked off a regional arm's race , causing neighboring countries like South Korea to purchase more sophisticated weaponry from America .
In addition , since the '911' incident , the world has come to see the threat of terrorism as very real .
Terrorists are able to conduct their operations anywhere around the globe due to their extensive network of terror cells worldwide .
Given the rapid technological advancement today , conflicts between countries can also exist in 'virtual' form like hacking into sensitive websites to disrupt the country's economic activities .
Therefore , it is inevitable for countries to increase more of their military budget to upgrade their defensive capabilities against various sophisticated forms of external threats .
Education is the key to sustain economic livelihood .
A proper educational structure will nurture more knowledgeable and capable people in the future to run the country .
Educated people will also be more inclined to be independent and make financial planning for themselves during their economically-active years .
They will also have better quality of life when they grow older due to their healthy lifestyles .
Therefore , this would incur less healthcare costs as they remain fit and productive in their golden years .
A nation's economy is the main source of country's income as it is an indicator of a country's wealth .
People living in well-developed countries have high standards of living due to their affluence brought about by their stable economy .
As a result , they remain fit and robust despite the rise in their life expectancies .
This also means that less healthcare spending is required to sustain these affluent elderly people .
The lower-income group will also benefit from a well-developed economy as higher economic growth enables a government to provide more healthcare finances to support the elderly .
This would thus reduce the financial burden of this group of people based on their income ceilings .
Despite the volatility of the country's economy due to the global market , it is imperative for a government to implement feasible economic policies to facilitate trade and growth .
Therefore , having a sturdy economy will also incur less financial costs on elderly welfare .
In retrospect , countries around the world face challenges with an increasingly aging population .
Governments need to strike a delicate balance in allocating scarce resources to develop other crucial areas as they are indirectly related to healthcare costs incurred by the aged .
Likewise , they need to forecast future demographic trends and be flexible in changing and implementing new fiscal measures to deal with the graying population .
Aging is , no doubt , one of the most pressing issues that many developed countries are facing today .
Japan and Singapore have been battling an aging society for many years where the birth rates are at depressing levels and better healthcare facilities are available .
Because of this aging process , there is a need for research and development to come out with ideas to counteract it .
Thus , to a large extent , I agree that current research and development is the solution to this aging process .
The process can be eased through economical , social and architectural means .
Firstly , through economical means , elderly people are becoming increasingly part of the working community , working past the retirement age .
Singapore for example has a minimum retirement age of 62 years .
Elderly people can continuously upgrade themselves through job retraining to acquire relevant skills required for the job .
There are subsidies from the government to employers to send workers aged 40 and above to upgrade their skills .
An example is SDF course fee subsidy of up to 90% for workers aged above 40 with 'A' level and below qualifications .
However , critics may argue that employers may hire younger workers due to their lower wages and higher working efficiency as compared to  older workers .
This is not always the case as companies are less likely to waste time and effort to train the newcomers over a period and may not have the satisfied results at the end of the training .
Instead , they may want to retain the more experienced and skilled older workers to maintain a consistent working standard .
As for wages , people aged above 50 will contribute less to their CPF accounts and this includes the employer's CPF contribution .
This will in turn lighten the cost of employing older workers and the company would prefer to hire the more experienced older workers over the less experienced younger workers .
Thus , economically , elderly people will be able to work longer and be more independent by supporting themselves for their retirement .
Secondly , through social policies , there are more and more entertainment activities to keep the elderly  occupied .
To cope with elderly people's increasing loneliness , there are activities that can bond the elders together and engage them in fun-learning and enriching activities according to their interests .
For example , the Wellness Programme in Singapore provides companionship with the other seniors through activities like brisk walking , dancing , gardening or cycling .
However , not all elderly people are willing to participate in such events .
Although there are a lot of activities set up for elderly people , it is optimally up to them to decide whether or not to join the activities .
We cannot force but encourage them to take up the relevant activities that may interest them .
They should also make an effort to keep a healthy lifestyle .
For example , in China , it is common to see many elderly people practising Taiji in the morning in public parks and dancing along the streets at night .
It is thus important to maintain a healthy , yet entertaining lifestyle especially at an old age .
Last but not least , through architectural means , there are many infrastructures and facilities put in place for the convenience of the elderly .
For the safety of the elderly , ramps and slip resistant footpaths are being set up in residential estates .
An example would be at Macpherson Gardens in Singapore where such features are being put in place , creating an elderly-friendly estate .
The flats built in the past in Singapore were not accessible at every floor as the lifts were built in a way where they stopped only at specific levels .
Today , to improve the convenience of the residents , especially the elderly , upgrading works are being carried out at various locations , ensuring that lifts will stop at every level .
All these upgrading works are carried out to ensure that the place is made suitable for the elderly to live in .
Nowadays , our society is highly concerned about the impact of  aging process on our lives .
In order to be a valid candidate for an explanation of the aging process , the changes proposed by the theory must meet the following criteria: (1) they will commonly occur in all or most humans; (2) as an individual ages , these changes will become more pronounced; and (3) the changes will lead to cellular or organ dysfunction that ultimately causes failure of the organ or system (Steven N . Trautwein) .
Although the aging process has raised many problems in our lives , current science research and social policies have helped to solve these problems .
As the life cycle of human beings is  , human life expectancy is heavily dependent on the rate of aging .
However , a lot of money and efforts have been put in by governments ,  companies and scientists worldwide to do  research in aging in order to slow down the aging process and also help to resolve some health problems that are caused by aging .
For example , there are scientists who have created fruit flies that are able to  their normal life spans and thus have made old human cells behave like young cells again .
This research has made it possible to let us live for a longer time ,  leading to a healthier life in our old age .
As a result , degenerative diseases of old age such as arthritis , diabetes and hypertension can be treated and thus help in easing the aging process .
Centuries ago , human longevity was comparably shorter than human longevity today .
This is because  the invention of medicine has helped human beings to sustain a longer life .
As we know , human cells tend to become unable to regenerate when we reach our old age and this will lead to the failure of organs such as kidneys , livers and hearts .
The only way to cure these diseases is to undergo transplantation .
As the growing aging population has increased the need for organs , it is hard to get enough organs needed for the transplantation .
In this case , artificial organs can help to bridge the gap in time until a donor organ is available for transplantation and thus improve the survival of patients while they are waiting for transplantation .
Therefore , we should appreciate the hard work of scientists in the lab and medical center since it has improved  old age  in many aspects .
Other than the medical breakthroughs , social policies for the elderly are also playing important roles to ease the aging process .
For instance , there are social policies such as introducing advanced insurance schemes that encourages young people to start saving more to be financially secure in their old age .
Many countries have made individual retirement funds mandatory and hence successfully increased the number of individuals who are able to support themselves in their old age .
In addition , some social welfare programs , especially those which help to resolve the aging problems , including providing financial help to theneedy elderly , are under way .
These programs protect those underprivileged elderly from starving  or from being homeless .
At the same time , some charitable societies have organized many activities for the elderly to enjoy  whichprevent them from getting psychological illnesses such as depression that could make them feel they are worthless  .
These activities have provided a place for them to socialize with others , make friends , and get exercise as well .
Hence , these social policies have brought a happy , healthy , safe and comfortable life to the elderly .
In conclusion , our society should pay much attention to the aging problems and come up with solutions .
We are unable to reverse  time but on average we can live  a healthier lifestyle and for a compared with our ancestors since current research and policies are practical in solving some  aging problems .
Apart from that , there are also many studies in different fields such as architecture and psychology that are helpful to the elderly .
As  time passes , everybody will eventually become older and so we should prepare for it now .

"To a large extent , current research and development or policies have helped to ease the aging process ."
I agree with the statement .
In recent years , many Asian countries such as Japan , South Korea , Hong Kong and Singapore have been tackling  a long term issue - a burgeoning ageing population , which is a repercussion of rapid economic development , with high quality of health care but a relatively low fertility rate .
An aging population has caused an increase in public spending and decline in Gross Domestic Product (GDP) , owing to a decrease in the people who are highly productive .
In conjunction with this issue , The Council for Third Age (C3A) has been established in Singapore with the aim of promoting active aging .
In fact , the wellness of seniors is very vital .
Surveys show that many elderly individualsare prone to suicide because they can not bear the overwhelming effects of ill health and the feeling of loneliness .
Fortunately , plenty of research studies and policies have helped in easing the aging process .
Prime Minister of Singapore , Lee Hsien Loong , once said , "We are crafting new policies , improving our infrastructure and developing effective programs to enable older citizens to lead full and happy lives ."
An important policy the government has adopted is "Supporting Lifelong Employability" .
According to this strategy , legislation requires employers to offer re-employment to workers for another three years after their official retirement age , not necessarily in the same job or at the same pay .
In addition ,The government is going to retrain  older workers and enhance their skills so that they are ready to  .
For example , in July 2007 , C3M and local university Uni SIM offered courses to senior citizens so as to enable them to earn credits through courses to pursue a degree in future .
However , critics argue that the elderly are inefficient , conservative and out-dated .
They are a burden rather than an asset in the workplace .
Nonetheless , most  older workers are independent , mature and  .
They possess valuable experience to impart to the younger workers and they can the younger workers that are more productive and innovative , but who lack  experience .
This strategy enables senior citizens to stay engaged and contributing in the workforce , have more self-reliance in finance , boost the economic development of Singapore ,  , and thus slow down the aging process .
Furthermore , the introduction of the Central Provident Fund (CPF) , a mandatory saving scheme , is also a policy carried out by the government to ease the aging process .
Under the CPF scheme , employees have to pay into their individual employee accounts during their working years and the savings can be drawn when a person retires to pay for his medical expenses or long- term care .
The policy is quite useful in grappling with the aging issue from the economic view point as it encourages financial planning by individuals during their economically active years and lowers  such as their burden hindering the younger generation's  .
The government can also reduce the privileges allocated to the elderly and the public spending can be used in a more prudent way in the development of the country in other areas .
Maybe from the younger generation's perspective , the policy doesn't make sense as it not only  every month , but it is  .
However , it is a worthwhile practice for citizens to plan for their income and expenditure and  their future .
In addition , the implementation of the "Wellness Program" and policies to create an age-friendly environment also helps in buffering the aging process .
The Wellness Program is a social program designed to encourage active and healthy lifestyles among senior citizens .
It comprises 3 parts- health screening , regular exercise programmes and social activities like brisk walking , dancing , cycling and so on .
Recently ,  realise that  housing estates and public transport   .There is also lift access to all floors of block of flats .
All these create a safe and accessible environment to the elderly .
In effect , the policies are because the welfare of the elderly is well taken care of and they will not be neglected by the community .
Despite the fact that this social policy requires a lot of money , it is crucial because senior citizens are part of our society and as responsible members of society , it is our duty to take care of their welfare when they are  unable to do so themselves .
In conclusion , the aging process is complicated and multifarious , and it affects every one of us .
We may not be able to prevent the aging process from happening but we can try to slow down the process as far as we can .
Current research and development indeed helps a lot in slowing down the process .
The aging problem is serious; it may slow down the economic growth in a country and create long-term stagnation .
Therefore , we must contribute to and support the policies available so as to achieve  on a societal level in the long term .
There have recently been some issues of the ageing population that  people feel strongly about .
Some think that policy makers should reduce the funds for the elderly , and spend more money on other areas of the country's developments .
some critics would argue and object to this  .
However ,  I agree with the first opinion .
Therefore , this essay will talk about the support for the first idea .
Firstly , the portion of public funds spent on ageing population issues should be reduced .
In this way , governments can make people  aware of the necessity of actively working to accumulate more money to support themselves in their retirement .
Moreover , children certainly should look after and take care of their old parents more thoughtfully than before because they would not want to see their parents  affected by the decrease in funds for elderly citizens .
Besides , we can see that the elderly nowadays look healthier and  than ever before .
This is due to the fact that our services for the population are now improvingday by day .
For instance , the quality of life has been made better as improvements in health care and sciences now make it possible for us to  .
Retirees probably do not need too much money; the main things they want at their age are to be satisfied , to live healthily with their family and to help their offspring to be more experienced .
Therefore , the decrease in funding for the elderly should not have a bad impact on the ageing population .
It is worth remembering that policy makers should also focus on other areas to develop their countries as well as reduce the pressure of the graying population .
For example , an effective solution to the ageing population is to increase the percentage in the governments' treasuries  such as the economy , science , transportation , education and some other areas .
The reason for this  is that those sectors play a significant role in the development of the nations .
Once the countries are strong enough , certainly the elderly will benefit .
To illustrate , spending money on economic research helps predict the trend of consumption and reduce the bad effects of unstable markets on the  nations' economies .
Moreover , improvements in science can not only help the people be but also decrease the size of hospitalisation and other medical bills .
Moreover , education is surely the most important area which governments must focus on as well .
The more effectively students are educated , the more productive and responsible the citizens we have .
With   , there is no doubt  that problems related to an no longer exists because authorities have great resources to deal with such problems .
Many critics  disagree with spending less money on the elderly because it contradicts traditional morals .
They say that because the number of households with elderly members is increasing as the people born in the baby boomer generation would be nearly 65 in 2012 .
Moreover , at present , there are still many people who can not take care of their parents and have to leave them in old folks' homes because they have their own family and they are still struggling to get by in this increasingly complex world .
However , in my view , placing a limit on  public spending for the elderly does not mean that we do not care about the ageing population .
Keeping our focus on the elderly is only a temporary solution .
How can we deal with this issue while we still lack support from other factors such as science and the economy ?
Governments should serve their elderly citizens over the long term instead of for the short term only .
Once they develop  strong economies and improvements in science , policy makers can not only focus on the graying population but also come up with the solutions to many other problems .
Overall , governments should change their focus on other factors of the country first before they  help the elderly .
Public spending , therefore , should be used to develop other important areas .
Once those main sectors are strong enough , the solution for the elderly can be implemented .
The increase inaging populations around the world is being hastened due to the long life expectancy and low fertility ratesin many countries .
Most countries have poured a great deal of resources into this increasing population .
However , if this trend of spending continues in the future  , it will be destructive to a country's financial structure .
Therefore , spending on the aged should be limited in order to transfer valuable resources to other sectors which also require the country's attention .
When we flip through the newspapers nowadays , we will usually read much news about countries being battered by the prevalent recession .
The countries in recession are trying by all means to revive their economy now .
According to the data calculated by the IMF (International Monetary Fund) to measure the impact of the financial crisis , the price of the financial crisis will indeed be high .
For instance , the G20 developed countries' GDP is expected to contract by 8% in 2008-09 .
Nonetheless , these costs incurred during the recession will only be about 10% of the spending related to elder care in the long-term  from now to 2050 .Due to the consequences brought by the financial crisis , it is critical for a country to divert more resources from  elderly-related spending to pumping up the dire economy .
The substantial cost of generous elderly care will not be fully supported if the countries' financial position is unstable .
Although many rich countries have accepted that it is time to reform their policies , the transformation is progressing very slowly due to the reluctance to introduce unpopular measures .
Such reluctance is affected by political factors like election .
Secondly , it is well accepted that a country should have  and appropriate development plans for gaining healthy growth .
The country should not focus too much of its effort on exploring the incentives for spending on  elderly care; instead , it should develop an adequate plan for the sectors which are equally important to the country's development .
For example , we can not neglect the significance of  education .
Education plays a critical role in helping a country grow from phase to phase .
The productivity and revenue of a country can be improved tremendously due to a well-established educational structure .
For instance , the federal government in Canada is promoting innovation  where its skills and learning agenda  "rests on the principle that in the knowledge economy , prosperity depends on innovation which , in turn , depends on the investments that we make in the creativity and talents of our people .
investing in innovation  will brew new knowledge for the economy which will in turn then create an environment with innovation excellence to protect and improve our quality of life .
In the long run , we are still maintaining our level of elderly care  a different way .
Moreover , a country which insists on providing maximum resources to the elderly care will face a dilemma when proposing a financial budget .
While elder care will inevitably account for a large portion of expenditure , the consequence of this improper budget is the financial burden of raising funds  , which will result  in a full load of debts and raising taxes .
The original intention of helping the elderly would then be tainted as the resulting situation would in fact cause suffering for more people .
On the contrary , the alternative to  helping the elderly lead a better life is not only limited to a large spending budget , but it is also achieved while the country boosts the economy through different incentives , like supporting the entrepreneurship of people by cutting taxes and giving allowances .
It creates an environment where people will have accumulated more wealth in the early stage of their life so they can support themselves in the later stage of their life .
In  reality , some elderly employees challenge the raising of the retirement age as this delays their eligibility for their pension .
It is a challenging task for the government to persuade people to agree over such an adjustment .
In a nutshell , the solid development of a country is built on a healthy  financial position and an unbiased development plan .
Having a superior elderly care system does not mean having  great success in governing a country .
On top of that , spending should not be narrowly limited to  elderly-related spending only , but resources should instead be evenly allocated over all the sectors instead of overlooking their importance .
During the baby boom in the 1960s ,  education system in Singapore was not very good .
Many people focused on working instead of studying , so the literacy rate was not high .
Aging problems did not arise until recently , when those who were born during the baby boom period are turning 50 to 60 years old .
This issue has led to a heated debate on whether we should limit the spending of public funds on the aged .
It is undeniable that spending on the aged is important; however , we should not neglect the more important areas like education and economy to make sure that the future generation does not suffer from the same problem again .
I believe that the education is one of the more important areas where public money should be spent on .
In fact , a good education is the only way out of the rat race , to a better and secure future .
Although Singapore literacy rate is relatively high as compared to the rest of the world , I still believe that should be donethrough , for example , increasing  mandatory schooling for Singaporeans until secondary school and providing more funding for students from poorer background .
Funding can be in the form of disbursing , subsidising school fees and developing more scholarship programs for the children of needy families .
These incentives will encourage children from  poorer families to study further .
With higher education , people will be able to earn more income and thus save more for the future , for instance , in the form of forced savings like the Central Provident Fund or life annuity schemes .
This will decrease the number of elderly persons that require funding from the government to get by in their old age .
More highly educated people also tend to plan ahead for their retirement .
They are more responsible and dependent on themselves .
Beyond that , Singapore should also spend more on educating citizens to lead a healthy lifestyle and work longer .
For example ,  encourages retrenched or older workers to upgrade themselves to increase their employability .
Education may be one of the ways to minimize the percentage of the elderly relying on government funding .
Another area that Singapore should also spend more money on is in developing the economy .
It is when the country's wealth can continue to grow that the economy is stable .
We should spend more money to attract talents from all over the world and transform Singapore into a world class financial and medical hub .
Coupled with better education , it will not be surprising that the disposable income of Singapore would also be increased .
This will improve the standard of living for Singaporeans and will eventually contribute to a better healthcare system in Singapore .
As Singaporeans become more well off ,  research for innovative products to tap on the sliver industry (market for the old people) will result .
Similarly  , the users of the innovative products will be in a better position , financially , to afford it .
With that , the sliver industry will become a lucrative market and more companies will be willing to invest time and money into developing innovative products for the elderly .
The government should also encourage companies to tap on these markets .
Recently , 5 companies have received a $500K grant from the government to develop elderly friendly products for the silver industry . 
Besides focusing all her resources on education and the economy , Singapore should also be spending some of her resources on the aged .
There is an immediate problem here and we cannot ignore that these 50- to 60-year-old elders as they have contributed to the success of Singapore in many ways .
Even if Singapore successfully brings Singapore education and economy to greater heights , there will still be people who fall through the cracks .
These people will need even more help in this highly competitive society .
Beyond that , solutions like nursing those elderly in other countries like Malaysia where expenses will be lower are not well received by the elderly themselves .
Therefore , we still need to spend on maintaining the welfare of these people .
In conclusion , by spending more on both the economy and education , we will be able to decrease the effects of the aging problem .
By investing in education and economy , Singaporeans will be able to generate more disposable income and hence , be less reliant on  government funding when they grow old .
Still , we should not forget to leave some for the aged as they have contributed in many ways to the country .
We should still be a responsible country which will take care of its citizens .

Friedland (2005) says that "policymakers must not only concern themselves with the rising expenditure related to programs to support a growing elderly population , but they must also consider the net impact of these expenditures have and changes that would occur if these programs did not exist" .
It is a well-known fact that the global society is growing old and old .
Because of this , it is important to make a policy that will be able to support the elderly in their late life .
However , it is still not the best thing to do .
It is quite a pity to limit  public spending on the elderly  However , if we limit  public spending on the aged , the money can be diverted and used to develop the country in other areas , such as economy and education , which may eventually lead to  more advantages for the country .
Nevertheless , if we limits  public spending on the elderly , the first one to suffer is the younger generation who have to take care of their parents .
They will have to spend more money for their parents while sometimes they may not even be able to fulfil their own needs .
Just imagine if the parents have  cancer and they have to go through a surgical operation which will cost the younger generation thousands of dollars .
This will bring more burden on the young .
Besides , there are also  parents who have  children working overseas or even have no children , which may eventually lead them to  leaning on no one except  government .
Therefore , if  government  limit  public spending on the aged , a lot of the young and elderly will suffer .
On the other hand , by diverting the money into some other areas , the government can gain some advantages in certain areas .
The first one is into the area of the economy .
By diverting the money to develop the economy , the government will be able to create more jobs so that it can reduce the unemployment rate as well as increase its Gross Domestic Product , which is the indicator of the economic health and standard of living in a country .
Besides this , Friedland (2005) suggests that "with sufficient economic growth there are more choices and fewer persons in need" .
Therefore , by diverting the money in the area of economy , we can prevent the elderly from  depending on the government help .
The second one is in the area of education .
Based on   statistics for the year 2008 in Singapore , 68 .2% of  residents who are 55 years and above have only graduated from secondary school .
It is one of the reasons why the elderly earn less money and therefore need the government help .
However , by diverting the money into the area  of education , we can provide the young with  education that will help them in their later life .
By providing them with good education , we can also prevent the same thing happening again .
Moreover , with a higher level of education , they will be able to learn how to invest well , which will eventually lead to higher earnings and which may also result in the increase in the Gross Domestic Product , which is good for their country .
In conclusion , even if the limitation on the public spending for the elderly will result in more burden for the young and elderly  ,  because of the long-term impact that it may have , such as more jobs , better education , and increase in Gross Domestic Product .
Moreover , it is better to try preventing things from happening rather than just try covering them up all the time .
Nowadays , the  has become a real concern not only for the government but also for the public .
The vast increase in the the aging population has led the economy to a lack of effective workers .

Some of the most well-known strategies for dealing with the aging population are extending the retiring age , lengthening  and encouraging financial planning during economically active year .
These strategies' point is that if people are given more opportunities to work , they may be able to save enough money for their retirement .
However ,  many real problemsarising from the reality that  make this strategy inappropriate .
Since the retirement age comes from much careful research on human health as well as ability to work , extending it irresponsibly may be harmful for the workers .
When more elderly people are employed , there will be less workplace for younger , more effective workers ; this is really a huge waste of human resources .
The second thing is that not everyone is able to make an effective financial plan during their economically active years .
It requires some basic financial knowledge which is difficult for the normal worker to know .
There are still many things to deal with before supporting these strategies .
In spite of focusing only on the aged , diverting money into the economycannot only bring benefits to the country but also help solve the aging problem .
If the government invests more money in theeconomy like reducing tax for  companies , allowing more foreign investments ,  , the concern for lack of effective labor among aging population  may be addressed .
In addition , agrowing economy provides  more sufficient funds to increase the pension and improve the welfare for elderly people  .
Furthermore , when the economy is developed , salaries of  workers will  increase such that they will have more savings when they retire .
Spending money for the economy seems to be a wise choice for the government .
Improving education is also a way to develop countries and a solution to the aging problem .
With more money invested in education , the schools  and universities will have more modern educational equipment , better teachers , and most importantly , reduce  tuition fees so that more people can study and have better education .
As a result , with higher education , people will have more chances of earning higher salaries , thus increasing their savings  for later needs .
When people are given some basic knowledge about managing money , they will be able to do financial planning , which will help them to use their money wisely and reduce waste Furthermore , elderly people with better education tend to have more active , healthier lives than  others and are not a burden to  society .
For example , since elderly people have some knowledge about nutrition , they will have the ability to choose healthy food like vegetables , beans , and fish instead of high-cholesterol food  like butter , sugar , and meat .
Good education is  necessary not only for  society but also for people who do not want to face financial difficulties when they retire .
In general , aging population is a global problem and needs to be solved as soon as possible but we have to consider the solutions carefully .
With the uncertainty of recent strategies for this problem , we should divert our money and effort into other areas which have more potential benefits .
By doing this correctly , we will be able to develop our countries in many aspects , including the aging issue .
The word aging has always been greatly feared by most in  society .
The reason for the fear is basically due to the fact that aging makes us fragile .
The moment  we become old , it implies that we are closer to the end of our lives .
We can hardly move as freely as the young , productivity is much lower and most of the time we are bedridden because of illnesses .
Life will be sheer torture instead of enjoyment .
The aging process , to me , means  progressive steps to become old , the transition to  illnesses , immobility and lack of money for retirement .
To prevent such situations from happening , research and development in science and medicine , innovative infrastructure projects and social policies have been constantly crafted  to reduce the effect of these problemsand make  life of elderly so much easier and more comfortable .
Hence , I agree to a large extentthat current research and development/policies have helped to ease the the aging process .
The aged are weak and vulnerable against various diseases .
As one's age increases , the body immune system deteriorates .
The ability to fight against germs and viruses becomes much less effective .
As a result , the older the people , the more they are susceptible to illnesses .
Any small disease can be much more fatal to the elderly .
However , as medical science and technology develops at a breakneck pace , many of the illnesses are no longer feared .
Doctors have better knowledge of the diseases .
With much improved equipment and tools , they are able to treat illnesses with much higher efficiency .
Through research and development , more effective medicines have been invented to cater to different types of problems .
Diseases , such as tuberculosis , which were deemed incurable in the past , can now be easily treated by the level of medical procedures .
Vaccinations are formulated to prevent us from even getting the diseases .
These breakthroughs  thus they can enjoy the  of their lives healthier , happier and with less suffering .
As medical procedures get very advanced , the cost of medical treatments is too heavy a price to bear .
However , if money is spent  from illness and ease pain and suffering , the lives among the elderly are still made more comfortable than before .
Hence , research and development in medical science has helped to ease aging process .
Other than health , decreased mobility has given elderly persons the most headaches .
As mobility decreases , daily major activities are greatly reduced too .
This significantly decreases the amount of entertainment an elderly person can enjoy .
In order to facilitate movement of older people , there are several developments in the infrastructure of the society .
For instance , in Singapore the elevators in  older HDB flats can only stop at certain levels .
Residents who live on other levels will have to climb staircases from their home to the lift .
However , under the new development , elevators in the newly built HDB flats can stop at all levels , thus making it easier for senior citizens to go up and down the flats . . Other than making the lift accessible to all levels , conscientious efforts have been done to further simplify the lives of the elderly .
Some elderly people can hardly walk up or down any stairs , thus ramps are paved outand hand railings are erected in parks to assist them walk around .
Owing to research and development in  social infrastructure , the elderly are allowed to pursue  leisure and entertainment .
As an aging population can be a big problem to many countries , several social policies are put in place to ensure the old have enough money after retirement .
In Singapore , for example , all working adults have to contribute about 14 .5% of their salary into a CPF account and their employers have to contribute 20% .
All the money deposited into the CPF account will be invested by the government and in return , offer a 3%  annual compound interest to CPF contributors .
By reaching the age of 55 , they are allowed to withdraw their CPF funds and use them for retirement .
They can use the money to go for holidays and pursue other interests .
The lifestyles of elderly people are maintained with the help of CPF schemes .
Therefore , the aging process is eased by current social policies .
The research and development of medical science , improvements in social infrastructure and social policies have helped in ensuring good health of the elderly , building facilities to create convenience for them and establishing CPF schemes to make sure the elderly have sufficient money for their retirement .
When problems related to health , mobility and finance are  solved , the elderly will be able to enjoy a much better improved lifestyle .
"To a large extent , current research and development/policies have helped to ease the aging process ."
It is true to say that  with different improvements from different fields , we can face the challenges and solve the problems  arising from aging population .
If these problemsare not solved , the median age in many first-world countries will reach 51 by  .
During the aging process , the elderly will face financial problems and may be abandoned by their children .
Although this problem is unlikely to be solved in the short run , many ways have been carried out to ease the aging process , particularly in social policy and science research .
the Singapore government improves returns on CPF Savings to help the retirees .
Some  people claimclaim that it is everyone's responsibility to plan financially for old-age to reduce dependency on children However , for those who are physically disabled and suffering from illnesses , they do not have the ability to work and look after themselves .
Improving returns on CPF savings will ensure the savings can last for the lifetime of CPF members .
Older CPF members who volunteer to defer the draw-down of their savings to the age of 65 will receive a Voluntary Deferment Bonus .
This policy is used to encourage them to accumulate more wealth to support themselves during  old age .
The government is considering implementing a longevity insurance scheme that provides basic and affordable plans to ensure long-life income .
Hence ,  the effort of Singapore government to improve returns on CPF Savings has buffered the impact of the aging problem .
Besides Singapore , countries around the world also put in efforts to ease the aging process .
The silver jobs fair , established to find jobs for people aged 60 and over , is part of a government effort in South Korea to assist a rapidly growing population of older Koreans .
This jobs fair has mushroomed across South Korea in the past year .
In the past , it was a tradition that adult children should take primary responsibility for the good care of their aging parents .
However , the phenomenon we notice today is that the elderly are dismayed to find themselves dependent on children .
Children often expect their parents to contribute to household chores when they move in and do not expect to be made responsible for their parents' well-being . .
Therefore , most of them need to work  and master new technologies in order to earn their living after retirement .
Though some  that the elderly do not perform well in their work , this group of people can actually bring improvement to the sectors they are involved in through  their own experiences .
This silver jobs fair has helped many older and unprepared Koreans to enter the last stages of their lives more easily in a culture transformed by longer life .
Viewing from the healthcare perspective , researchers have also taken a big step toward discovering that human hearts can grow new cells .
This is a significant research to help to ease the aging process as we know heart diseases are common among the elderly .
There are some people who claim that this breakthrough is only in the realm of basic science research but it is a good start for future use .
It was previously thought that the human heart is unable to grow new cells after birth .
However , there is a study that can disprove it .
The scientists reported the evidence that new heart cells are made through one person's life .
This study could help doctors to design treatments for the damage caused by heart attacks , which was previously thought to be irreversible .
Now , it is possible to say that we can regenerate heart muscles after a heart attack .
Therefore , it is a new hope for the elderly who are suffering from heart diseases .

It is a complex issue but not insurmountable .
