To a large extent , current research , developments and policies have helped ease the aging processa A fast increasing  the aged population has been occurring all over the world .
As people age , their income drops but their medical expenses are actually increasing .
Hence , every research , development and policy that will help them to reduce their burden is important to them .
To a large extent , current research , developments and policies have helped to ease the aging process .
Medical expenses are most likely to be the burden of aged population .
As humans age , metabolism rates and immunity will start to drop , and limbs and body organs such as kidneys , livers , and hearts will start to fail due to long years of usage .
That is when all the medical expenses start to rise as a result of health problems .
To ensure that the aged population is able to pay large amount of medical expenses which could happen due to their old age ,  has set up a few policies to assist them .
For example , Medisave helps when they are younger to save money for their future medical expenses  .
It allows more people to be able buy  affordable insurance since its premium  can be deducted from their Medisave accounts , while Central Provident Funds allow people to be less worried about their silver age expenses , include medical expenses .
These policies have helped to ensure that people will be more able to pay for their future medical expenses .
Although some people might think that the government forces them to contribute part of their income to CPF  , they fail to realize that this  can be good as it prevents them from squandering it on other less important merchandise .
Therefore , when they age , they will not be very dependent on the government , which  thus  can divert  funds into other important development plans .
Other than the expenses ,  science and medical discovery is one of most important factors that will help ease the aging process .
Since the increase inawareness of balanced diet , people have been consuming less salt , sugar or high fat food ,  thus reducing the chances  suffering  from chronic diseases like hypertension , diabetes , or cardiovascular diseases .
Although statistics have shown that people have become more vulnerable to these kinds of diseases , their chance of survival has been increasing as medical technology becomes more advanced .
In addition , medicines  used to counter hypertensionand diabetes have been popular .
Thus , these enable hypertension and diabetis patients  to work and live normally after taking  medicine .
What will happen if older people need these medicines but these medicines are not affordable to them ?
The medisave and medishield they bought will help them pay for their expenses; although not fully  , it would still  significantly .
Architectural improvement has also linked aged people both with and without disability to be able to travel by themselves .
For instance , the SMRT company has installed lifts at every MRT station and provided bus services that are able to carry wheelchair users .
With these little extra efforts provided by the company , it would be more convenient for the aged people to ride MRT or public bus .
A decade ago , most Singapore HDB apartment lifts are not accessible on every floor , thus it was very inconvenient for older people as they still  to take the stairs which might have imposed more danger to them .
Seeing this problem , the government decided to upgrade the lift systems , so  most HDB apartment lifts are accessible on every floor now .
The cost of this architectural improvement required a large amount of funds , but what drove SMRT , SBS Transit and the government to spend  much money on these upgrades even though these may not have affected  profits  ?
It was because  may have seen  future benefits from these upgrades as the improvements would not only benefit aged or disabled people , but they would also reduce people's travel time thus increasing their productivity .
Hence , we  find that government policies have helped people to be more able to meet their medical expenses ,  science discovery has helped improved aged people's health conditions , and architectural improvement has made aged people's life easier .
Combining all points mentioned above , we can conclude that current research , developments and policies have not only been helping ease the aging process but also have brought a lot of other benefits as well .
By the year 2030 , one in five people in Singapore will have aged 65 and above .
If there is a limit to the budget meant for the elderly , the quality of life that the government provides for the elderly will be affected .
Lack of family support , unemployment due to low education level , and social and political impact on the country are some of the factors why public spending on the aged should not be limited .
It should instead be increased gradually over the years .
Traditionally , the family has been the main source of support for the elderly but over the years , due to the effects of massive migration of young adults and higher cost of living in Singapore , more elderly are being deprived of such support .
Many of the young adults are leaving Singapore because of the stifling atmosphere of the country and the political and intellectual lockstep enforced by the government .
Some are also attracted by  job offers overseas .
With these young adults leaving the country , the elderly are the ones who suffer because they are  left alone and most of the time , their children do not have the intention of coming back .
Tribunal cases of elderly demanding financial assistance from their children in Singapore have increased over the years .
Although the government is studying the best way to use the Maintenance of Parents Act to get such children to fulfill their filial duty , they should also set aside abigger budget each year  as a cushion in case the children themselves have difficulty financing their own families .
Most of the elderly do not have proper education that is needed in today's society in order to make ends meet .
With age catching up with time , their productivity decreases and eventually companies  hire new employees to replace them .
If the government were to limit  spending on them , they will face many potential problems such as unemployment or retrenchment , which will have a spillover effect on their children supporting them financially .
However , some companies do retain their older workers because of loyalty but if there is a crisis , they will still be the first ones to get laid off .
The government has done well in givingdoleouts to the elderly but this could only satisfy a percentage of the elderly population .
There are still many families who need the government's aid in order to meet their needs .
Our population is aging and by spending more on the aged , people can be assured that when they grow old , the government will be there to support them .
With this in mind , they will be spurred to work harder and contribute more to society .
On the other hand , if there is a limit on spending on the aged , people might tend towards individualism .
This will over time cause them to be more focused on their individual interests without taking the interests of society into consideration .
This will greatly affect Singapore since we are a multi racial society and working together towards a common goal is important for us .
Moreover , besides the social impact on the country , political impact will be another factor to take into consideration .
By not limiting the budget for the aged , the government can be assured of support from the elderly during a political election which may be critical for winning since Singapore is turning into an aging population .
According to Singapore statistics ,  the percentage of the elderly in Singapore is 8 .7% of the entire population and this number is increasing slowly every year .
It may not be the bulk of the population but it might be a significant percentage of votes .
Singapore has done well over the years in implementing projects helping the poor and consequently , it has gained the trust and support of the citizens .
It is therefore crucial to maintain or improve its image through  .

The government should gradually increase the budget for the elderly every year alongside its economic growth .
Instead of treating the elderly in society as a burden , the government should think of ways to harness their knowledge and experience  so that they can contribute back more to society .
In the recent years , along with the decline in birth rates , the proportion of the aged in our population has also increased .
This has led  to a major problem of our time , known as ageing population .
Governments around the world have been actively seeking measures to cope with the problem , one of which is to increase  public spending on the aged .
Even though public spending on the elderly is essential  in dealing  with an ageing population , it should be limited because of  underlying negative implications .
Instead , more  expenditure should go towards other forms of development .
Though some may agree that public spending on the aged largely aids  society in coping with the needs of an ageing population ,  it may also hinder the development of other sectors .
This is because , as the world becomes more globalised , what follows is the surge in the cost of living .
Services for the aged will become more expensive .
Hence , this implies that public spending on the elderly will have to increase simultaneously as well .
With greater expenditure on helping the aged , the country will have less funds for development in other areas such as infrastructure .
Therefore , with  inadequate input into these areas , the development of the latter will be neglected .
As such areas are the key pillars of a country's development , any slowdown in these areas will affect the country's regional competitiveness .
EU , for instance , has been dealing with an ageing population .
It has been predicted that the region's growth rate will be reduced by half in the near future as a result of over public spending on the aged .
[1] Hence , its impact on the economy is negative ,  .
Therefore , since expenditure on the aged puts the country's growth at risk , it should be limited .
Though many may claim that the bulk of the amount needed to support the aged should come from the government which has the greatest financial power to support them ,  this public spending should be limited .
The reason is , the government is not the only form of support for the aged .
The elderly's children are also another form of support .
If large expenditures were to be dedicated to helping the elderly , the children may   rely too heavily on the government to support their aged family members instead of both parties playing a part in sharing the burden of supporting them .
In Singapore , for instance , the government is not the sole party that is responsible for supporting the ageing population .
The government only contributes through  distribution of subsidies to help the aged while their children carry the responsibility of supporting them .
Therefore , to prevent overdependence on the government  , public spending should be limited and be diverted to other areas for better use .
Some may argue that limited public spending may not be ideal .
In the event that  government's expenditures on the aged is restricted while the number of elderly is surging , the needs of the elderly may not be completely attended to .
Such a circumstance will affect a country's development .
This is because since the aged's basic needs are not attended to , they have to work in order to fulfill them .
With the presence of the aged in the workforce , the latter will not be competitive .
Hence , since the workforce is the main sector that drives the economy , an ageing workforce which is inefficient will slow down economic growth and hinder the country's progress .
However , this usually assumes that there are no measures which prepare the people for old age .
Currently , many governments have implemented measures which enforce compulsory savings for old age , such as the Singapore government which implementa Medisave .
Hence , even though  public expenditure on the aged were to be limited , people still have  savings  which ,  when combined with the government aid , are more than sufficient to meet their needs .
Hence , limitation of public expenditure is still feasible and should be encouraged so that money can be diverted into other areas of the country's development .
In conclusion , it is inevitable for countries to deal with an ageing population .
However , apart from coping with the latter , countries must not neglect other parts of development which are crucial to these countries as well .
Therefore , it is advisable for public expenditure on the aged to be limited so that no other sectors are  sacrificed  .

Thirdly , limitation on public spending for the aged is not as bad as it seems .
For example , the government makes a policy which says that only 2% from the Nett National Product should be spent on older people .
If Nett National product of Indonesia is about 10 billion Rupiah per month , it means that 200 million Rupiah should be allocated to be spent on the aged .
Then , the government uses the rest of Nett National Product to improve Indonesia's economy .
After one year , due to economic improvement , Indonesia's Nett National Product rose to 20 billion per month .
Then Indonesia should allocate 400 million Rupiah to fund the elderly .
This example shows that spending on the aged will be raised together with the raising of Nett National Product which is earned from the improvement of the economic sector in Indonesia .
To sum up , the government of Indonesia should limit its spending on the aged and improve other areas of the country , especially the economic area .
In fact , limitation on it does not always mean a bad  effect .
We can use percentage system for the policy on it which means that the amount of spending for the aged will rise together with the improvement of the economic sector .
Now , the challenge for the government is to look for the best way to improve the economic situation in Indonesia .
As the proportion of the world's population in the older ages continues to increase , many observers are concerned that an ageing population will accelerate growth in health care spending as individuals tend to use more healthcare facilities when they age .
In the case of Australia , government spending on health rose by $6 .1 billion or $267 per person from 2003 to 2004 .
Increased health care spending results in a smaller ratio of the government's spending on other areas like infrastructure and defence leading to economic impacts .
I do not agree that public spending on the aged should be limited because spending money on the aged such as facilities and equipment is something that is definitely necessary for a society to be able to advance with no one left behind .
Rather than it being limited , public spending on the aged should be referred to as being controlled .
As long as needs are fulfilled , spending within a budget allows sufficient funds to be disturbed to other areas as well .
Public spending may not be appealing because there are no advantages and immediate benefits received from spending on the aged as compared to using these resources to invest in the economy , defence or infrastructure  .
Individuals do not see the benefit in investing in an aged population as they tend to associate it with having a high opportunity cost .
However , it may not be true because the repercussion of not spending on the aged will be even greater in the long run .
If we were to deprive our aged population of the basic amenities and equipment , what kind of image of the country does it portray to its foreign investors and even its own countrymen ?
The image and morality of the society will be adversely affected as a whole; foreign investors might lose confidence in the country as they have the impression that the country is uncompassionate and unfeeling .

Hence , this may lead to the possibility of an outflow of her people .
This is especially important to a country where the most valuable resource is its people , like Singapore .
Therefore the government should not limit public spending on the aged as these effects are long-term and permanent to a country's development .
To some individuals , the aged are outdated and relatively less productive as compared to the younger generation because they are not as well aware of the latest technological advancements nor as agile as the young .
Individuals do not see the value in retaining these older workers in the workforce .
On the other hand , far from the common thinking of these individuals , this aged population encompasses wisdom and experience which is useful in guiding the young as future leaders .
In the case of Singapore , her government is cognizant that these elder workers are assets .
With effect from 1 January 1999 , the minimum retirement age has been raised from 60 to 62 years .
In addition , the government encourages active participation of the aged in the workforce by offering free training to these workers .
This implemented policy highlights the importance of spending on the aged to ensure that they continue to contribute to the society and lead a meaningful life .
This will promote active ageing  .
In conclusion , public spending on the aged should not be limited because the impacts caused by the limited spending will lead to long run negative impacts on the country's economy .

Therefore ,  encouraging the older workforce to go for retrainingretraining will increase the productivity of these workers and hence their employability .
This will reduce the burden on the government as the government is no longer required to look after the basic necessities of the aged if they were able to be independent and self-reliant in meeting the needs of their daily lives .
Public spending on the aged should be limited for the overall sustainable growth in a country's development such as in the areas of national economy , education and defence .
In recent years , reforms to curb public spending on the aged have become a cornerstone on many national governments' policies .
As governments have limited budget , they cannot afford to spend limitlessly on the aged .
National governments are urgently seeking the best options to such challenges and one of the few options on the table is to restrict public spending on the aged .
While critics acknowledge the huge budget deficit is caused by the ballooning public spending on healthcare and activities for the aged among many nations , they are against the idea of containing public spending on the aged .
For many years , opponents to such plans believed that the European style of welfare states were the perfect models , where healthcare should be accessible to everyone and that care should be delivered to the aged without them having to pay for it .
They argue that the aged needs the best possible care in their sunset years .
Citizens of such welfare states were envied by many of their peers in other countries .
This system worked its magic for the past decade where the global workforce population to the aged ratio was approximately 9 working adults to 1 aged .
Stanford Center on Longevity (2008) .
But , the global upward trend in growing elderly population and a shrinking younger workforce coupled with low birthrates has turned against such a model .
There is a growing concern to rein in public spending on the aged as its continual increase can become a threat to a nation's economy which in turn can affect its survival .
Furthermore , excessive spending on the aged can hinder a country's growth , which demands equal attention .
Firstly , advocates of limiting public spending on the aged argue that optimal and prudent spending is the solution so that it is able to sustain the current and future aged .
For instance , the United States ihas currently the largest spending on healthcare as per percentage of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) (California Healthcare Foundation ,2008) .
Yet , there is little evidence  that the American system is superior .
The extravagant public spending on the aged does not justify its cause .
The average US life expectancy ranks 27th at 77 years .
In comparison , many nations are achieving higher life expectancy rates with significantly lower public spending .
Furthermore , the growing public spending for the aged has further taken its toil on the slow recovery of the US economy as it continues to grow the budget deficit .
If the public spending on the aged is not brought under control , the government will have to raise taxes to sustain its coffers which can irk its citizens and result in exodus of businesses if labor costs increase .
Secondly , for a country to prosper , it has to invest on its youths through education , which will boost literacy .
Therefore , the role that education plays in the economic development of a country is unquestionable .
Illiteracy often limits the economical growth of a nation where knowledge intensive industries are  highly valued .
Education will nurture the best brains which will in turn power the economy and bring wealth to the nation .
So , for the country's very survival , it cannot afford to neglect education .
Thus , spending on the aged has to be controlled for the benefits of future generations .
Thirdly , national defence is vital for a country's security and ability to defend itself against potential aggressors .
Defence will ensure the stability of economic growth in a country to deter internal and external threats .
In terms of internal threats , defence spending can boost a country's resources in time to deal with natural disasters while external threats can be in the  form of the need to protect the freedom of the country .
This makes defence spending equally important in the context of eeconomic progress .
In conclusion , public spending for the aged must be capped .
The government's coffer is not a ceaseless goldmine and if public spending for the aged is not brought under control , it will eventually run out , which in turn will affect future generations when they become the aged .
There has always been  on-going research , development or policies to help the easing of the process of aging .
How exactly do we define "easing of the aging process" ?
In the simplest terms , it refers to helping the elderly to age with convenience , to age with ease , and to age with grace .
Personally , I agree to a large extent that current research , development or policies in the architecture , economics and medical fields have help to ease the aging process .
There are three reasons which will be elaborated in the following paragraphs .
Firstly ,  mobility for the elderly has been improved .
In Singapore , the Building & Construction Authority (BCA) has been implementing a "Barrier- Free" blueprint known as the Code on Barrier-Free Accessibility in Buildings 1990 (Building and Construction Authority , 2006) .
This code contains restrictions and regulations which engineers and architects have to comply with make the built environment accessible-friendly for the elderly .
For example , the authority ensures the installation of lifts at every storey of Housing Development Board (HDB) flats and Mass Rapid Transportation (MRT) stations , as well as  ramps at all entrances of buildings .
However , people pointed out that the plan is not fully-developed and there are still several shortcomings .
They had commented on one shortcoming that there are still a large number of buildings which are still not fully-accessible .
With regard to this , the BCA has already stepped introduced the plan by applying another 5-year plan , known as the Barrier-Free Accessibility (BFA) Upgrading Program (2007-2011) to make sure that all buildings will be equipped with barrier-free improvements .
Furthermore , BCA has also set-up a $40 million Accessibility Fund for private buildings to be transformed into barrier-free buildings .
Therefore , one cannot possibly comment that privatized buildings are not accessible-friendly for the elderly .
In addition , lifts and ramps are currently being built at  older MRT stations such as Queenstown MRT station to help the elderly to travel from ground level to ticket gantries more easily .
With all these concurrent efforts by BCA , mobility has improved vastly for the elderly .
As such , they can age with more convenience and hence improving their connectivity with others .
Secondly , the Singapore government has employed initiatives to help elderly to extend their working lives .
This is to achieve reduced financial and emotional dependency on the younger generation by the elderly .
This is especially important for any aging population just like Singapore .
The news articles have also been reportedly quoting that the government hopes to reduce the impacts of an aging population by extending working lives .
As such , they came up with initiatives like Skills Program for Upgrading and Resilience (SPUR) , for the elderly who wish to work longer .
This program will enable the elderly to upscale their skills so that they can be retained in employment by their employers (Singapore Workforce Development Agency , 2009) .
Another initiative is the Lifelong Income For the Elderly under the Central Provident Funds Scheme (CFP LIFE) , whereby there is a fixed amount of income for an elderly who is aged 65 years  and above .
This will then ensure financial protection for the elderly when they reach the age (Prime Minister's  Office , 2009) .
However , people often question the effectiveness of these initiatives .
They may have doubts whether the fund is enough to enable a high percentage of elderly to work longer or can the companies cope with re-employment of older workers ?
With regard to this , the Prime Minister of Singapore , Mr . Lee Hsien Loong , had has reassured the public that the government will continue to revise the initiatives to make sure that the elderly can work longer with ease .
With regard to the ability of the companies to cope with re-employment of older workers , the government has introduced another program know as the ADVANTAGE !
SchemeScheme , which offers grants up to $400 ,000 to companies who are interested to re- employ older workers (NTUC NeXus , 2006) .
This is to help them to deal with changes in areas such as wage restructuring and the cost to re-train the older workers .
As such , with these initiatives , the public should  rest assured that the minimum of initiatives will be carried out to guarantee that the elderly can extend their working lives with least problems .
In this way , they can then work to occupy themselves and age with ease that they can at least contribute to the economy .
Thirdly , there are constant medical innovations to slow down the aging process; such as Botox injections , placenta injections , and skin-lifting .
These medical procedures are being shaped by the media that they can help the elderly (especially women) of  dealing with the physical changes in their body .
This will appeal to people who do not like the signs of aging  to be displayed on their body .
Thus , there are increasing numbers of people who are resorting to these procedures as they rebut that they can age with more grace by doing so .
On the other hand , people criticized  the negative impacts of in such procedures and the attitude of people who engaged such procedures .
They emphasize  the side effects such as the addiction to Botox injections and they often think otherwise of the attitude of this group of elderly .
However , as a matter of fact , any medical procedures will carry a certain number of risks .
Therefore it is up to the weighing of risk the individual wants to take .
It should be left to the individuals to decide whether they want to take such risks This is actually up to how the individual want to age and their way to deal with the process of aging .
If they feel that they can age with grace and happiness by engaging such procedures , they can do so by all means .
This is as long as they have fully considered the negative impacts of such procedures and agreed to accept them without condition .
As an outsider , we should keep an objective outlook on this issue and  not impede them from what they deem is the best for themselves .
We should only focus on the stand that these medical innovations do help those who want to age in the way  they define themselves  .
In conclusion , current research and development have indeed helped the elderly in their aging process in the ways as mentioned above .
Despite the fact that we do not know the exact measurements of how well these developments have helped the elderly , it is clear these developments are done to make sure our aging population can be well taken care of .
Furthermore , the most important thing here is that we can help everyone to age with ease , grace and happiness so that there will be less aging issues to be addressed .
I agree that to a large extent , current research and development/policies have helped to ease the aging process .
Over the past decade , improvements in the fields of technology and medicine have greatly aided in the aging process .
Further emphasis by governments with regard to public architecture has also made aging easier .
This could not have been timelier .
A study done by the United Nations in 2000 states that by 2010 , all developed countries would have an increase in percentage of senior citizens as a whole .
Advancement in technology has made aging much more pleasurable and enjoyable than before .
This can be attributed to greater awareness by technological companies of  the needs of an elderly individual , thus attributing greater emphasis to this field of research .
A noteworthy example is Accenture Technology Labs .
All the while , Accenture has been into business research and development .
In recent years however , it has branched out into a video analysis application scans streams from in-home cameras and detects when someone has fallen and automatically notifies kin and emergency services if necessary .
Another good example will be the electronic wheelchair .
Due to the weakening of their legs , many elderly faces mobility issues .
Previously , a person in a wheelchair would require another for assistance .
This made the user of the wheelchair extremely reliant on an able bodied person .
An electronic wheelchair was not an option as it was too cumbersome and prohibitively expensive .
Furthermore , the battery had very short lifespan and would require constant recharging , which further compounded problems associated with such wheelchairs .
However , over the past decade , improvements in the electronic wheelchair have made it significantly lighter and the battery is able to last longer .
With more companies manufacturing such wheelchairs , the cost of a wheelchair has declined sharply , thus making it more affordable .
Evidently , the aging process has been made easier by technological developments .
As the field of medicine rapidly progresses , many illnesses and ailments previously difficult to treattreat have now been reduced to mere inconveniences .
The field of medicine can be broken down into two broad categories: drugs and treatment .
In the category of drugs , improvement and discovery of new drugs allow greater management of age-related problems such as high blood pressure and diabetes .
According to the Lancet , a renowned medical journal , new drugs in the market allow patients to control their blood pressure or sugar level without the need for so much dietary restrictions .
On the treatment front , improvements in  pin-hole surgery have greatly minimized the trauma to the patient , leading to shorted recovery time .
An example would be surgery to repair the cartilage in the patient's knee , which gets worn out due to wear and tear .
According to MIOT hospital , the current pin-hole surgery requires no cutting , thus no bleeding and no need for anesthesia .
The patient can practically be up and running the day after .
With such leaps in the field of medicine , health problems associated with aging no longer are such  big issues as before , allowing people to have greater quality of life in their twilight years .
An often overlooked aspect when it comes to aging is the crucial role the government plays in it .
Social policies , especially with regard to the country's architecture , implemented by the government will have significant effects on the respective country's aging population .
More often than not , the construction and maintenance of common walkways fall under the prerogative of the local government .
Hence , in the developed European nations and Singapore alike , the authorities do build walkways which do not have sharp edges which make it difficult for wheelchair users to mount .
Rather , they taper the ends of the walkways into slopes with a non-slip coating on them .
This is an example of how social policies with regard to architecture can make life easier for the elderly .
In Singapore , the government has commissioned the building of elderly-friendly public housing .
The flats are equipped with non-slip flooring and many handle bars strategically placed to aid movement within the house , and many other additions which an elderly citizen may require .
To sum it up , social policies that influence architectural designs do play an important role in easing the aging process .
In a nutshell , development and improvement in the field of technology , medicine and architecture have helped to ease the aging process .
Expenditure on health , education , infrastructure , industrial and social amenities are examples of government public spending .
Today , the government emphasizes more on the aged and spends a large sum of money to assist them .
Quoted from the NHS Community Care Statistics in year 2009 , 1221000 older people are receiving some local authority supported care services which use  5 .9 billion .
This amount of money can be use for further development .
Therefore , public spending on the aged should be reduced so that more spending can be diverted to other sector of the country's development .
The government should increase education spending in order to nurture people to create a brighter future for  society .
Dr Bill Harrison stated that education is the key to a better future for our children .
Children who are well-educated will have more opportunity  to contribute  society .
Besides that , professionals should be given more incentives to further their studies .
The government should raise the salary for professionals as a way to motivate them .
Having a higher-education qualification can aid the government in education matters such as teaching .
Channel New Asia reported that two thousand more preschool teachers are needed in the next three years to meet the growing needs of the childcare industry in Singapore .
Moreover , reconsidering  the education cost can initially give the poor some opportunity to have education in rural areas .
Thus ,  this will definitely benefit to the society .
According to Wikipedia , statistic shows that 19 .6% from the resident non-students aged 15 years and above had no qualification in education in the year 2000 .
Furthermore , infrastructure development requires a higher percentage of spending compared to spending on the aged because infrastructure plays an important role in ameliorating the standard of living of a country .
Transportation is very important in Singapore because almost all will need to travel .
Singapore transportation consists  of Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) , Singapore Changi Airport and others .
The government should spend more on transportation by providing more facilities for the disabled and poor .
Other than that , improvement in waste management is required as pollution is a big issue till today .
More recycle bins or "Saving the Earth" events should be carried out by the government .
Furthermore , renewable energy usage such as solar energy , wind energy and water energy should be used more frequently in order to reduce the usage of nonrenewable resources .
For example , wind power generation has a significant share in total electricity generation in Denmark (around 20%) , Spain (around 11%) and Germany (around 7%) .
Hence , the government should pay more attention to saving natural resources .
Another significant area is  industrialization .
Industrialization can be a core concern of a country as it is the second largest sector in most countries .
Industrial agriculture requires a lot of funds to improve their harvesting and planting .
Wikipedia claims that intensive farming is an{agricultural}[HYPERLINK: http://en .wikipedia .org/wiki/Agricultural]production system characterized by the high{inputs}[HYPERLINK: http://en .wikipedia .org/wiki/Input]of{capital}[HYPERLINK: http://en .wikipedia .org/wiki/Capital_(economics)] ,labor , or heavy usage of technologies such as{pesticides}[HYPERLINK: http://en .wikipedia .org/wiki/Pesticides]and pesticides{fertilizers}[HYPERLINK: http://en .wikipedia .org/wiki/Fertilizers]relative to land area .
Agriculture requires high spending to enhance their skills .
Moreover , the manufacturing industry also needs attention from the government since manufacturing is satisfying the citizens .
Manufacturing factories create many products and sells them to  consumers according to their demand in the market .
In addition , the construction industry is momentous as it will determine how a country will be developed .
As we can see today , there is construction everywhere in Singapore and this proves that Singapore is advancing at a quick pace .
Singapore's building and construction industry account for about 4% ofgross domestic product and S$27 and S$32 billion construction demand estimated for the sector in 2008 , according to John Keung , CEO of the Building and Construction Authority (BCA) of Singapore .
Each and every sector of a country is undeniably important to make the country a better place .
However , each sector should have priority depending on its level of importance .
The government should think wisely and choose the sector which has more privileges .
In conclusion , government must pay more attention to other important sectors because every sector plays an important role for the sake of the country .
Therefore , The government should not focus too much of their spending on the aged .
It is the government's responsibility to take care of the people's welfare and support them financially .
Hence , it is only right that there are funds allocated to helping the aged .
Many countries have allocated part of the country's annual budget to helping the older generation .
For example , in Singapore , the Ministry of Community Development , Youth and Sports , often works closely with voluntary welfare organisations to provide community-based programmes and residential care for the aged .
This includes elderly homes and activity centres .
However , public spending on the aged should be limited as the people should be self-reliant .
Compulsory savings implemented in certain countries such as Britain , Australia and Singapore help ensure that the people have enough savings to meet their retirement needs .
Britain  introduced a compulsory pension scheme in 2006 where the employees have to contribute 4 percent of their monthly pay while their employers have to contribute 3 percent .
Australia's compulsory superannuation system also prepares the people for their old age .
These saving schemes in different countries would help ensure that the people have a minimum amount of savings after they have retired .
Hence they would most likely be more self-sufficient and public spending on the aged should be limited .
Sufficient government funding on the aged ensures that the elderly are well taken care of and they have a proper environment to live in .
An article from The Straits Times in 2007 states that the age group above 65 has a "higher rate of being homeless and poor" as well as "desperately sick" .
It is only socially and morally ethical that we take care of this more vulnerable group of people .
The government should hence allocate enough funds to ensure that all the elderly in the country have a place to stay and proper medical treatment should be made available to them regardless of whether they are able to pay .
However , while this solution reduces the problem of poor and homeless old people , it gives rise to other social problems .
Children of the aged may shirk responsibility and abandon their parents , thinking that the government would take care of their parents .
From a recent article from The Straits Times , some "Singaporeans were using the recession as an excuse to avoid paying their parents' nursing home bills" , even though some looked like they could very well afford it( Reference needed) In addition , 67 parents sued their children under the Maintenance of Parents Act last year .
If the government continues to fund the old aged , children may think that the government would support their parents financially even if they do not .
This would eventually lead to more children abandoning their elderly parents .
More resources can be diverted to education instead .
Children should be inculcated with moral values from young and taught the virtue of filial piety .
This would prevent them from abandoning their parents when they grow up .
Public spending should be emphasised , especially in countries with a large proportion of elderly .
Countries facing an an ageing population include Singapore , Japan and Italy .
Governments should therefore set aside more funds to support the aged and provide more facilities for them .
The Japanese government has established several facilities to meet the needs of the ageing population .
Facilities include nursing homes , residential care facilities and healthcare services .
Government expenditure on these facilities would help prepare the country for the ageing population .
This is however , only a short-term solution to the problem of ageing population .
Government spending on the aged should be limited and funds should be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
Education is an important area that requires public spending .
More productive children can be raised such that financial burden can be distributed over a greater and more affluent future generation .
Public spending on the aged should be limited such that funds can be allocated to other sectors of the country's development , especially education .
By educating the younger generation , we would be able to reduce public spending on the old aged on a long-term basis .
When talking about the most striking features of aging we cannot forget the progress of science and its effects on almost every aspect of human life .
There are many pros and cons about this issue .
Some people say that the development of science brings negative effects to human health , especially to the old .
However , I do not agree with this idea .
In my opinion , the contribution of current research and technology is very important in easing the aging process .
For some people , science brings  more harm than good .
They usually argue that technology development creates pressure and a more stressful life .
The rapid tempo of modern life also results in wide spread nervous disorders .
Additionally , the environment becomes more and more polluted just because of the increasing industrial concentration .
The use of pesticides and many other chemical substances make all products unsafe to use .
Moreover , our machine civilization is also responsible for numerous accidents and serious injuries for many people , which cause a lot of difficulties in their old age .
The human aging process has accelerated in  recent years .
Nevertheless , I strongly oppose this argument .
From my point of view , science and technology give us a tremendous promotion in reducing the aging process rate .
With advancements in healthcare service and medicine , along with a better understanding of the aging process , life expectancy for humans has kept increasing .
The unceasing experiments and research have led to numerous discoveries which explain  the reasons for  aging  as well as the ways of slowing down this process and the key factors to keep the gray hair away .
For example , a healthy diet with enough vitamins , minerals and other necessary nutrition , together with regular exercise and a healthy lifestyle will help humans live longer and maintain their prime of youth .
Moreover , the appearance of many technology appliances like computers , machines and transportation means also increase productivity and lessen workload , which create more time to relax and enjoy  life .
With this physical and psychological health , people have a tendency to lengthen their life span .
Moreover , when people get old , science also plays an important role to ease their old age .
Old age always comes up with many unpleasant problems and diseases , both  physical and mental  .
But now , with the assistances of science , we are no longer worried about this issue .
In most of cases , scientists discovered medicine and the cure as soon as they discovered the causes of certain diseases .
In addition to that , the work of medical scientists also reduced pain to a great extent .
In the past , operations were performed on individuals in a very crude manner .
Today , however , many surgical operations can be done with a small incision and without any pain by application of endoscopic technology .
Furthermore , the support of many convenient devices also provides the old a better preparation to face  old age .
As we can see ,  wheelchairs , audiphones , glasses . . . have contributed a lot towards assisting the old people in their life .
Together with these , the installation of lifts , user friendly machines and free barrier transportation systems everywhere are also the key for senior residents' access toa better life .
Moreover , the electrical devices in our daily life these days such as computers , televisions , washing machines . . . also make life more convenient , pleasant and comfortable for the aged .
They not only save their manual labour but more importantly , make friends and are entertained From all of these above arguments , we can conclude that government can use science and technology as an effective way to ease the aging process .
This is a good solution to cope with the increasing aging population , one of the current difficult global problems .
It not only helps slow down the aging process but also facilitates acceptance of old age .
Again , , we must thank  science for giving us a better life .
Public spending on the aged is the expenditure by the government covering  health , infrastructure and projects aimed at improving the lives of the elderly .
A large amount of the expenditure used is contributed by government taxation on the working citizens .
The other areas of a country's development include investing in education , military , economy and infrastructure .
Funding for the aged is necessary as there is a growing trend in the ageing population but more importantly resources should be allocated away from just the aged itself to other aspects of the country's development  that will indirectly aid the ageing population .
Furthermore , the money that is spent on the aged ultimately comes from the pocket of the working population .
Hence , more time and effort should be placed on the other areas of the country's development which will in turn reduce the negative effects of an ageing population .
Firstly , expenditure should be placed more on the economy itself because with economic growth , the working population will be more self-sustainable and be able to support themselves when they retire .
The fact that more elderly persons will be supported by fewer younger persons now and the problem will get more severe in the near future , it is important that emphasis be placed on improving the productivity of current working population and making sure that they have the ability to earn enough for their old age .
Increasing the productivity of the working population can come in the form of subsidised training schemes .
Such courses should be put in place to encourage the working population to upgrade themselves by attending such courses .
In Singapore , courses such as professional IT  By increasing employability in the society , the workforce will be larger and will be able to support themselves and the elderly better .
Thirdly , we must note that public spending on the aged turns out to be the healthy and the working population who are forking out the money .
If the working population were to pay entirely for the healthcare of the aged , then individuals will not take responsibility to keep themselves self-sufficient and healthy during their old age .
This would not be a fair arrangement .
The individual must be made to be accountable for his or her own health and not rely totally on the public spending by the government .
However , we must note that certain public spending on the aged cannot be compromised and must be put in place by the government in order for the aged to stay healthy and not be a burden to the society .
Instead of spending money on treating the illnesses of the elderly , money should be allocated to promote healthy lifestyle in the elderly .
For example , lessons in gymnasia and fitness centres can be conducted specially for the aged to encourage them to exercise and keep a healthy lifestyle .
In Singapore , we have the Wellness Programme to encourage healthy living through medical check-ups , regular exercise and social networking .
In the matter of medical care , the government should also take responsibility to ensure that doctors remain professionally competent , and that hospitals and polyclinics have the best available facilities .
In addition , the costs for medical care should be subsidised as some treatments can really be expensive and most of the people will not be able to afford them .
Therefore public spending on healthcare and activities to promote healthy lifestyle are still necessary .
Singapore is facing a fast growth of aging population .
Without immediate actions from both the government and the society , it might create problems for the country and the  elderly  themselves in the future .
Singapore's economy might be in danger due to lack of productivity , and the elderly might find difficulty in coping with the aging process .
Realizing this impending danger , the government has been taking some new directions in economic and social policies .To a large extent , current research and policies have helped to ease aging process .
In economy  , the government has helped older workers to be economically productive by encouraging employers to hire , re-hire , and retain more mature workers .
The older workers themselves are encouraged to grow and develop their skills to meet the companies' standards .
The government also lengthened the retirement age to be 65 years-old instead of 62 years-old .
All procedures of this program are arranged under the new law , Re-employment law , which will come  effect in January 2012 .
It is hoped that the longer the workers work , the more money they can save for their life after retirement .However , some people think that the policy is ineffective .
The Re-employment Law will take into effect in 2012 .
Meanwhile there is an urgent need to protect older workers nowadays since many employers still have the mindset that mature workers have outlived their productivity .
As a result , many older workers are not guarranted to secure their job after 62 years-old at this moment .
Realizing this challenge , the government has encouraged companies which are willing to apply the new policy before 2012 by giving grants to companies and preparing the older worker to be more productive by giving workshops and courses .
In social policy , the government has tried to improve the awareness among the young generation  to care more about the elderly .
The Ministry of Community Development , Youth , and Sports held a Young- Old Forum in Singapore Polytechnics recently .
In this forum , the young generation is expected to spend more time and be more understanding towards the elderly .The government also encouraged the elderly to lead a healhty lifesyle , such as not smoking , consuming a healthy diet , and exercising regularly .
A healthy body  is important because when the eldery are healthy , they will not feel useless or abandoned .
In addition , the governement has also increased its subsidies for day care , nursing home , and hospital to give the elderly a better quality of servies .
Nontheless , some people are concerned about the government's spending on providing various the  subsidies  for the elderly .
Since everything provided by the government is considered as a right of people , the more subsidies for the elderly , the more demand will be created .
Hence , there is a worry that the government will neglect the subsidies to other important sectors , such as education and defence .However , People should not worry about this because increasing subsidies for the elderly can increase the new opportunity for the young generation .
There will be more people hired in hospital , daycare , and nursing home .
It will also stimulate the young generation  to create new products to ease the aging process .
In other words , it creates new business opportunity .
The more business in the country , the richer the country since its economy will grow .
Therefore , the government can increase its tax base and the other fields , such as eduacation and defence , will not be neglected .
Needless to say , the current research and policies are not perfect yet .
However , to a large extent , they have helped the elderly to ease the aging process .
The existence of the new policies for helping the elderly in many fields , such as economy , social , and technology , shows that both the government and society care about the elderly .
This will benefit both the country and the elderly .
In the long run , Singapore  can still keep its global competitiveness level even though it has a big portion of aging population .
The golden generation itself will be happier since they will not feel  useless or abandoned .
By the year 2050 , the projected median age of many first-world countries will reach 51 if the current situation of low fertility rates does not improve (Peterson 2001) .
With that situation on hand , many policies makers and governments are debating on the amount of public spending that should be allocated for the aged .
In my opinion , public spending on the aged should be limited so that money can be diverted to other areas of the the country's  development .
The governments should stress the importance of filial piety to deal with the current situation and plan well ahead to pave the path for the future generations in order to minimize the impact of aging population which can be done by investing in certain areas in the country's development .
Children of the aged should be responsible for their own parents .
It is only reasonable and sensible for the children to take care of their parents as they are the ones that painstakingly brought them up , providing them with education and nurturing them into adults .
Unlike in the Asian countries , this culture is not very prominent in the western countries .
The  governments should encourage its citizens to take up the responsibility that is looking after their aged parents .
Doing so will not only lighten the burden on government agencies to use excessive amount of public spending on the aged , but the awareness of the importance of filial piety will be increased as well .
Reduced public spending and filial piety campaigns will have an effect that 'forces' the children to take up the responsibility for the parents .
By investing the money on areas such as healthcare and education , the future aging population will be better prepared .
The logical explanation of this claim is that when a person receives higher education , chances that he will be able to earn a much more substantial income as compared to those who are deprived from education is relatively higher .
What we could conclude from this is that he will be able to save more for his retirement and thus the need to depend on others such as government agencies or family members will be reduced .
Besides that , investing in the areas of healthcare will suggest that in the near future to come , the aged population will be healthier and thus less prone to illnesses that are associated with aging .
This is important as the problem faced by most of the aged population is the incapability  to cope with the high medical costs when illnesses such as strokes or heart diseases strike .
Therefore , instead of just focusing on solving the current situation by pumping excessive amount of money into the aged population , the governments should use the money that is saved from limiting the amount of public spending on the aged to prepare the current generation of adults for their future retirements .
Even though public spending on the aged population should be limited , assistance should be made readily available to those who are under privileged .
The respective governments must take into consideration that within the aged population there are people who are childless , single or even deserted by their own children .
These are the people that will really need help from the government agencies .
If the public spending were to be over constrained , it deprives  those who are genuinely in need of help from getting sufficient assistance .
This will only add on to the social implications , such as senior citizens going around begging for money , which most countries are already facing .
In conclusion , public spending on the aged population should be limited but not to such a large extent that it will deprive those who are really in need of assistance from getting aids .
Also , filial piety should be heavily emphasized by the government bodies concurrently with the implementation of limiting the budget on aged population .
The implications that come with changes tend to be too much for most governments to handle; yet  only through changes will the possibilities of a better future  emerge .
Therefore , with great foresight and careful planning , the governments could better prepare themselves for the up surging numbers of aging population by implementing the right policies and investing in the areas of country's development that will benefit both the aged population and the general society .
Aging issues have gained substantial attention from the public recently .
Along with it , we have also observed a huge increase in public spending for elderly housing , healthcare and retirement welfare .
Every policymaker needs to consider the effects of their proposed policies on this issue thoroughly before implementing .
Based on the possible future benefit brought by various policy options , it is reasonable for us to limit the financial budget for the aged and channel it to other economic perspectives despite the pressing calls for increasing public pensions for the elderly .
Some people argue that limiting public pensions for the aged will bring detrimental effects to their life .
I acknowledge the importance of essential healthcare , housing and retirement living expenses being subsidised by public pensions .
However , limiting public pension does not equal to removing it .
The key concept here is effective management of limited resources to achieve maximum benefit for the aged .
Increase in public spending may not solve the problems thoroughly unless we utilise the funds in appropriate ways .
We still have room to improve  our current welfare system .
If we can modify our system to be more efficient and effective without much increase in the governments' financial budget , we are able to make room for better use of public funds in other important aspects to aid our economic development .
This will in turn bring back more funds for the aged in the future .
As mentioned above , the country's development will determine its future financial capacity to solve various social problems including aging .
Funds pumped into elderly welfare will be exhausted with minor future economic benefits for the entire country .
In contrast , if we channel our funds to other economic activities such as developing infrastructure and tax incentives for entrepreneurships , we are likely to have a good yield for our future economy .
Most developed nations have their population rapidly aging .
Definitely , there will be an increase in public spending on the aged .
However , we should not place our focus in financing the aged .
Instead , the society is able to afford this growing the aging  population only when we can ensure that the growth rate  of our economy is able to match that of aging population .
Thus , economic development is a critical indicator of our capability to deal with the  aging problem  in the future .
Moreover , an aging population also presses heavily on our current working structure and environment .
We must deal with problems such as labour force shortage and low productivity to ensure the sustainable development of our economy before we could proceed to handle the costly expenses such as the healthcare , housing and retirement benefits of the aged .
Governments have wasted significant amount of public pensions on the aged due to inaccurate estimations and inefficient use of funds .
Firstly , they failed to recognise the fact that the daily living expenses of the elderly would be less than that of an  ordinary working person and established the retirement benefits system according to the average personal monthly spending of the working force .
A slight deviation of a few hundred dollars for each individual will sum up to a huge amount for the entire state .
Secondly , most countries do not target the needy people effectively .
Taking an example , the Retirement Insurance Benefits are issued according to the amount of social security payroll taxes paid into the Social Security Trust Fund in the USA .
With less contribution to the fund in their early working days , they will obtain less after they retire .
However , the low income group is the neediest group for retirement benefits and yet the least contributing group to the social security payroll taxes at the same time .
This retirement scheme further worsens the income inequality problem .
It is recommended that governments could conduct various assessments to distribute public pensions to those who really need it .
For example , Australia has implemented means-testing scheme for the Age pension .
The means tests begin to reduce the pension at fixed levels of income and/or wealth and the pension declines linearly to zero as income and/or wealth increases .1
In conclusion , for the future of the country , public spending on the aged should be carefully examined , and more focus should be placed on economic development instead .
We also need to note that it is important not just to cut the budget but also come out with a detailed alternative plan to support the aged .
Careful management of current expenses along  with an expanding economy  will be our only feasible cure to aging problems .
Based on an online report by Reuters , there will be 1 .3 billion senior citizens around the world by the year 2040 .This inevitable growing aged population will only increase problems such as healthcare costs , which could result in slower economic growth for countries .
Therefore , in order to prevent a scenario where a country's economy is not able to sustain this foreseeable problem , it must be agreed to a certain extent that public spending on the aged should be limited so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
By doing so , there are two main benefits which can help minimize the strain on the country's economy .
Firstly , with money being diverted to other areas , the country's overall economy can be boosted .
It is essential that the aged problem should be seen in the long term perspective where the country's economy is continuously strong enough to cope .
With strategic planning and close monitoring , these areas can both offer the necessary economic growth and also minimize aged related problems being posed .
An example of such an area is biotechnology where it takes advantage of the constant improvement in technology to research and create new products with the use of biological process to improve the quality of living .
Countries like Singapore , recognizing its potential , allowed stem cell research laboratories to be opened despite its controversy in moral values and religion .
An online article by New York Times suggested the reason Singapore did so was that it hopes in return , such laboratories will diversify its economy and add on to its research-intensive sector that will improve economic growth .
These laboratories also manufacture their products locally which can be distributed and used to improve the overall country's health at a low cost .
Diverting money to such areas proves to provide benefits in both contribution to the economy and aiding in the health where the aged ones are concerned .
Secondly , by limiting the public spending on the aged , the healthcare system with regards to the aged problem will thus have to be changed .
This  can be viewed as a benefit as the system will be changed to minimize the effect on the country's economy and the risk of a failed healthcare system .
To illustrate further , the aging population is growing and it is not feasible for countries to simply continue public spending and varying the amount as needed .
In other words , if a country were to continue with their current system and not consider the foreseeable problem , too much focus and money will be used in an attempt to resolve the aged problem .
By the time it is realized , it could be too late .
Countries are already recognizing this problem; an example would be the recent dispute in US healthcare system , where the democrats are attempting to cut down on the healthcare system in view of the current recovering and future economy , bearing in mind that the aged population is increasing .
Thus , it is essential that countries start reviewing and  new changes where necessary  .For instance , one step Singapore has taken is restructuring her healthcare system where elderly patients are treated inan acute hospital  followed by recuperation in a community hospital .
Hence , a change in the healthcare system will result in cost effectiveness as the aging population increases and efficiency in treatments .
In addition there will be a minimization of a risk of failing healthcare system as there is enough time to make changes and gradually adapt to them .
However , there is a risk involved in limiting spending on the aged .
Many citizens especially the elderly of a country will feel that the country is not concerned for their current and future health , therefore losing confidence in the government .
An example used again would be the recent attempt on restructuring the US healthcare system .
Although the  democrats are still at its proposal stage , the elderly are already starting to express their concerns for their current needs , together with younger citizens worried over their future healthcare .
In conclusion , the aging population is increasing and with it comes slower economic growth for countries .
It is crucial that countries come up with solutions that attempt to deal with this in a long term manner .
Many citizens especially the elderly will be upset over the limited support for the aged .
However , it is also time for these citizens to change their short term perceptions and start evaluating the possible long term problems if such measures are not taken .
Therefore , with good strategic planning by the country and the understanding of its citizens , limiting spending on the aged and diverting money to other areas of the country's development , is feasible .
Yes , I do agree that the current research and development or policies have helped to ease the aging process .
The current architecture improvement and research and development on technological products for the elderly have helped them to overcome the difficulty they face when their physical health deteriorates , thus , providing them an easier life at old age .
However , there is still an increase in the number of elderly suicide cases despite much psychological help from social groups such as The Singapore Action Group for Elderly and many others .
This is supported by the news report in The Sunday Times on 12 August 2008 which stated an increase in the number of suicide cases of elderly aged 65 and above from 69 cases in 2006 to 87 cases in 2008 .
From the statistics above , it has shown that the current research and development or policies may not be successful in helping the elderly to cope with the aging process such as becoming physically disabled or feeling less worthy  in the society due to loss of working ability .
Hence , the elderly become depressed over the problems they face in the aging process which leads them to commit sucide .
Although there is an increase in the number of elderly committing suicide , it is only a small number of elderly committing suicide in Singapore which represents less than a percent of the total aging population .
The increase of number of suicide cases may also be simply due to the increase in population size .
In general , the current research and development or policies may have helped almost all the elderly to cope with the problems in aging process .
Therefore , the number of elderly suicide cases is not significant .
Currently , there have been many upgrading projects carried out in the older estates where the population  consists of mainly elderly .
In these upgrading projects , there are lifts upgrading to make the lift stop at every floor of the block and paths made even with gentle slopes around the estate .
These improvements in the infrasuture of the older estates make the estates more accessible for the elderly .
This is because in the aging process of the elderly , physical health deterioration is one of the problems they face .
They usually have diffculty travelling around their estate as many of them may have problems climbing stairs and walking on uneven roads .
Some of the elderly  are also wheel chair bound which adds on to the diffculty to travel .
Thus , with the lifts upgade and even paths , they can take  the lifts just outside their doors and move around the estate with no constraint due to unaccessible paths .
This help to solve the problem they face during their aging process , allowing them to travel and socialise without being bound by physical restriction .
As the aging population continues to grow , there are many business opportunities in the aging population market .
Many have entered  the elderly products market to supply goods and services that suit the growing numbers of elderly .
This encourages more people to research and develop technological products that suit the aging population .
Hence , there are many technological products that are user friendly to the elderly in the market now such as the iNo mobile .
It is a very  simple-to-use cell phone with large key pads and SOS button .
These functions help those elderly whose eyesight has usually failed and are not  able to catch up with the techological advancement to be able to use a cell phone .
The SOS button also allows the elderly  who are usually more vulnerable to ask for help when they are in danger .
This shows that the current research and development has helped to overcome some of the problems the againg population may face in the aging process like failing eyesight and lack of technological knowledge , thus , easing their aging process and allowing them to lead a normal life .
The elderly in Singapore are enjoying a better quality of life under the current research and development or policies for them .
The current research and development in technological products and architectural improvement have helped the elderly to cope with the diffculties they may face at old age .
Thus , this eases their aging process through providing them a more comfortable and easier life compared to the past when there was no such research and development or policies available .
A new paradigm shift and various strategies are required to enable the elderly to be more physically independent since much could be done to forestall some of the negative impact of a fast aging population .
According to the National Institute on Aging (NIA) , in the last two decades , the rate of disability among older people has been reduced dramatically .
Progressive research and development have eased the aging population to a great extent by reducing the rate of physical illness and disabilities among them .
Practically , with the recent invention of electric wheelchair , disabled elderly can manoeuvre and are more physically independent .
Electric wheelchairs are extremely useful especially to those elderly who suffer from upper body weakness that prevents them from using a manual wheelchair .
This equipment encourages the golden generation who spend most of their time on the bed or chair to move around with the controls provided eventually brightening up their lives .
Regardless , electric wheelchairs are too expensive for most elderly to afford even though it helps them a lot in terms of independence .
Besides , entrusting an elderly who is not well-versed with technology with such contraptions might be dangerous should accidents happen .
Even so , Medicare has been giving assistance to elderly who need wheelchairs as long as the elderly provides a written prescription from the doctor stating the need for having such wheelchair .
According to the Oxford University Press University Press (2007) most elderly feel satisfied with the use of wheelchairs and even use it for shopping , visiting parks and socialising which proves that it is safe .
Apart from that , the British government policies on human equality , age discrimination and employment have helped the aged improve their lives drastically .
Most elderly face discrimination in employment and training opportunities to develop themselves and earn a living .
With the equality policy being implemented , elderly have the opportunity to be treated fairly especially by the employers .
Thus , they are able to accumulate more wealth and reduce their dependency on their children's monthly support .
Britain even implemented the policy on community service such as better transport link in order to provide the elderly with independent lives .
On the other hand , most employers unwilling to hire the older people as they are not as productive as the younger generation and might cause more liabilities to the company if they claim a large sum of money on their medical purposes .
Furthermore , a better transportation link means more money needs to be allocated by the government to this sector .
Well , improvement on the transportation not only helps the elderly , it also encourages the public to use the public transport which reduces pollution as well as traffic jams and older people are wiser in the sense that they are more experienced compared  to the na ve and impatient younger generation .
It is also not necessary that elderly will claim more money on medical since chronic diseases attack humans without the age barrier .
In the progress of developing mortality in old age , Natural Institute of Aging has done a lot of research to reduce the disabilities and burden suffered by the elderly through studies on the alteration of genes and hormones .
Information from the fields of biochemistry , genetics and physiology has been applied in research to repair tissues and replace injured cells by using stem cells .
Researchers have been furiously expanding their understanding on these pathology changes and identifying the parts of the brain to improve human memory abilities .
At the same time , scientists explore methods to replace dysfunctional cells and develop a protective brain cell into the brain to prevent Alzheimer .
However , these researches do not guarantee that the hormones they produce are useful and it costs a large sum of money to maintain such experiments .
Furthermore , not many people can afford to undergo such gene alter operations .
In spite of that , the government has allocated a large sum of money towards research in the annual budget to encourage new findings on hormones and genetics which could protect aging people in the future .
Subsidies are provided to the elderly to help them with their necessities which indirectly gives them the opportunity to undergo genetic and hormones exchanges .
In conclusion , research and development is the best method to help the elderly survive several conditions that compromise the quality of their health and independence .
Thus , to a large extent , current research and development as well as policies have helped to reduce the effects of aging process in many aspects .
Nowadays , balancing public spending is a big concern to most of governments since they need to carefully evaluate the most suitable spending areas for short and long-term plans .
Failure to make decisions in government budget will affect whole countries' systems including their economy . . . , education , or environment , etc .
This essay argues that public spending on the aged , one of the most major categories  that have recently invested in , should be limited for developing other countries' important areas , promoting their sustainable growths , and forming people's responsibilities .
First of all , large spending on the aged results in an imbalance of governments' expenditure .
According to World Midyear Population by Age and Sex of US Census Bureau , the population aged above 60 will rise from 20 .38% in 2009 to 21 .97% in 2020 , which means more governments' are spending on pensions and healthcare .
When the aged public spending has increased to a considerable proportion ,  governments will find it difficult to keep pace with the advances in technologies , commerce , and education , etc .
For instance , a recent Singapore government list in 2008 shows that pensions have been accounted for $912 billion that has been equal to 17 .8% in total expense .
And the largest category is health care with $925 billion , which was nearly spent on an elder assistance such as home nursing , medical treatment , and long-term care , etc .
In contrast , education , welfare , and environment , which are essential for countries' development , have only ranked as 3rd , 4th , and 8th categories respectively .
In the same way , Australia has spent nearly 10% on healthcare while USA has spent about 15% .
As suggested , "if the government does nothing it will experience a rise in the structural budget deficit .
This has many problemsno full-stop" (Pettinger , 2007) .
One of the challenges is the increase in the national debt and annual interest payments .
For example , Italy has already borrowed over 100% of GDP , resulting in a high % of GDP goes on servicing the debt , which will only increase over time .
