The elderly would hence feel more in touch with society and likewise , the younger generation would not look upon the elderly as a burden .
Such various government polices provides the aged with economic solutions , social solutions , healthcare solutions to the problems that they may face  hence easing the growing problems faced by an aging population .
Also , there is more focus on the importance of family ties and bonds .
"Strong family ties are the cornerstone of social cohesion .
Strong family ties bind families together and families shape individuals - their character , their instincts , and their values .
Strong families help build a connected community which is integral in nation building ."
(Children are encouraged to take care of their parents when they are old through various publicity and schemes , such as the case in Singapore , whereby people are given housing grants for choosing to stay near their parents and also providing tax relief for individuals taking care of their parents .
It is also by law in Singapore that children have to support their parents if the parents could not support themselves financially .
Such schemes and laws would protect the elderly from mistreatment from their family members .
Family members in return are more inclined to care for the aged themselves .
The elderly would hence feel happier and joyful and not feel left out and demoralized , easing the problems that they face .
However , since this only applies to the elderly with families , the general public and governments will still need to set up voluntary organizations to interact with the aged in homes or community centers .
In conclusion , through the various available health polices , government policies , social policies and technological advancements , the elderly now are able to lead a better more comfortable and  fulfilling life .
Despite the systems and policies being imperfect , it has definitely brought about benefits to both the aged and general public as a whole .
Yet , by further improving current technology and policies , the aging problem might eventually be resolved .
Ageing process in humans refers to a multidimensional process of physical , psychological , and social change  , 2009) .
Due to this process , countries with aging population are facing problems like economic growth and inadequate protection for the elderly .
Japan and Europe are two examples that have done well in tackling this issue .
In the years to come , more and more countries will be facing problems  from aging process .
Hence solutions are very  .
Thisessay will evaluate  the current measures undertaken  by various countries .
Firstly , elderly employment is a policy that was implement by some countries .
Steen Langebaek , president of AGE , an organization which aims to promote the interest of older people across Europe , believes that older people should be encouraged to study and work beyond retirement , whether through part-time work or on a voluntary basis ( , 2002) .
It means the elderly are welcome to continue serving in the workforce provided they are willing themselves .
This may eventually benefit both the individual and the company; elderly receive additional income from their work , whereas companies gain from the work produced by the experienced elderly .
Hence older people are an enormous neglected resource that should not be forgotten , they should play an active role in society .
In European countries , work organization and social security arrangement are flexible in providing options for combined work with retirement .
The combination of the two factors created more vacancy and elderly who volunteer to work .
Therefore , this measure had been very successful , especially in the Netherlands with 49% of elderly either working full or part time ( , 2008) .
Also , Silver job fairs , established to find jobs for people 60 and older , have mushroomed across South Korea in the past year as part of the government'sgovernment's effort to assist a rapidly growing population of older Koreans adrift in a changing society ( , 2009) .
From the above examples in different continents , it is inevitable to conclude that elderly employment is one of the policies that has been well adopted by various governments .
Secondly , science and technology have eased aging in various ways .
Japan had started to develop robots meant for the elderly .
"With Japan's aging population , we need robots that can alleviate the burden of human tasks ," says Toshihiko Morita , director of Fujitsu's Autonomous System Laboratory ( , 2006) .
This "mental commitment robot" is designed to provide comfort and companionship to elderly who are lonely or shut in .
With the introduction of robots , elderly have a better protection as well as reliance .
It is especially true for the single elderly who do not have any children to take care of them at home .
In addition , drugs have also been developed to slow aging .
Currently , the drug that helps to reduce aging is being tested and will be released into the market soon .
"It may be the ultimate free lunch on how to reap all the advantages of a calorically restricted diet , including freedom from disease and an extended healthy life span , without eating one fewer calorie .
Just take a drug that tricks the body into thinking it's on such a diet ."
( , 2009) .
This useful drug will ultimately increase life span , hence increasing the productivity of the workforce as people could retire at an older age because of this drug .
Thirdly , governments from various countries have provided retirement pension , medical scheme and policies to cure the aging population .
Singapore has implemented the retirement pension known as the  Central Provident Fund that allow elderly to fund for their retirement right from the start of their working life .
This policy has been effective as the compulsory contribution to the fund will be allocated to both medical account and general account , which does not only ensure stability but also healthcare stability .
The government could also save the budget on state pension at the same time .
In addition , the Housing Development Board of Singapore has introduced studio apartments that are catered for the elderly .
The forty square meter apartments include facilities like lifts on every floor , hand railings and alarm systems that are specially designed for the elderly .
The government has also promised to build more studio apartments in the upcoming projects .
( 2006) .
Overall , the governments have done well  to ease the aging process to a large extent with the above policies .
In conclusion , countries have used various means to ensure a better aging process for the elderly .
This will be further improved as the country is developing in other aspects like technology , education and economy .
However more attention should also be paid as the speed of aging population may exceed the speed of solving curbing aging policies .
Excessive government expenditure on the aged will impede the economic growth of China .
China's public expenditure for public health is rising at a high pace .
According to the National Bureau of Statistics (2006) , the spending for public health has been increasing at about 10% annually from 2000 to 2006 .
This is faster than the economic growth rate of China , which is about 8% (NBSC , 2009) .
A large portion of the public health expenditure actually goes to the aged .
The expenditure on elderly people is slowing down the economic growth .
Furthermore , the negative impacts of these policies will be more significant in China as its economic base is not so strong compared to developed countries such as the U .S and Japan .
Those who oppose cutting government expenditure on elderly argue that limited spending will cause social instability as many families with low income will suffer when the elderly generation needs medical support .
However , economic growth affects the nation's long-term well-being .
The money should be used more wisely .
For instance , Japan's economy situation shows us the consequences of abusing of the government budget on public health spending .
Japan is well known for its ageing problems with 22 .1% of the populations above 65 ( , 2008) .
The Japanese government has to spend a lot on the public health .
As a result , Japan has experienced a slow economic growth over the last 20 years .
Therefore , for China , being a country which is much less developed than Japan , to limit the spending on the aged will be a  wiser decision .
It will be burdensome to China's next generation , especially the tax payers , if the expenditures on medical and welfare programs are not held in check .
The extra burden of the medical and welfare programs expenses falls on the next generation .
The tax payers have to finance the medical expenses of their own parents and at the same time , pay for other elderly people's medical bills .
The negative impacts will be even worse in China due to its one-child policy since the 1970s .
In the near future , a couple has to support four parents .
If the government raises tax to finance the expenses on the aged , the younger generation would even face difficulties making a living .
Some sociologists argue that if the expenditure on public health is to be limited , the younger generation has to pay more .
The expenditure just shifts from public expenditure to private expenditure .
While it may sound true , someone in the society has to sacrifice in order to solve the current ageing problem .
If we continue increasing this expenditure and ignore the negative impact it has on the economy , Japan's present will be China's future .
Thus , it is reasonable for the Chinese government to limit the spending on the aged in order to improve the long-term well being of its citizens .
Last but not least , China's public spending should be limited because there are other sectors of  China's economy which need the money more imperatively .
China is still a developing country today and more of the government's budget should go to the sectors which are able to generate more wealth .
In 2008 , the total expenditure for public wealth in China was RMB 984 billion , which is about 3 .3% of the total GDP ( 2008) .
A portion of the money should be diverted into the sectors which are more important in the long run such as education and  According to the National Bureau of Statistics , the expenditure of the government on education last year was RMB 901 billion and on  was even lowerat RMB 213 billion ( , 2008) .
China has to be fully industrialized first before spending its money on the old .
Otherwise the problem will be accumulated .
Hence , a restriction of the expenditure on the elderly people should be implemented .
Growing old is now easier as compared to the last decade with more developments and policies put in place by the government .
Previously , the aging was a tough process having to deal with the many problems faced .
However , with the introduction of policies pertaining to three major problems faced by the elderly , namely economic , inadequate living conditions for the elderly and health issues , the changes have become easier to manage .
The elderly should be encouraged to return to the work force and adopt a later retirement age .
By doing so , it can partially relieve the society of the increasing financial burden of an aging population .
However , for this initiative to work , they have to first address the issue of their skills obsolescence .
Nowadays , with the rapid change in technology , the current skills sets that the elderly possess are mostly obsolete .
Hence , skills upgrade and training programs like those offered by Workforce Development Agency should reach out to more elderly and make it easier for them to upgrade themselves to reduce their barriers to entry into the workforce .
When the elderly returning to the workforce they will be able to accumulate more wealth and save more so that they will be able to be self sufficient when they are older .
Besides , returning to the workforce means that they will continue to contribute taxes , thus helping to reduce the burden on the society .
As they continue to work , they will maintain their Central Provident Fund (CPF) account which acts as a social security savings plan for them in the future .
The CPF account prevents the elderly from depleting their savings and allows them to be financially independent even when they finally stop working .
Therefore , it is essential to provide skills upgrading programs for the elderly and by doing so it will reduce their barriers to enter the workforce  and reduce the impact of aging on the economy .
The government is aware of the challenges faced by the aging population due to inadequate facilities and living conditions and has influenced the changes in the environment so as to make life easier for the elderly .
This is evident in the way the new Housing Development Board flats are built , especially the one room flats that are meant for the elderly .
For example , they are customized to contain various elderly friendly features such as the alarm system that automatically requests for help through a pull of a lever in case of an emergency .
Besides , features such as the building of lifts leading to every storey and the residence corners for the elderly to interact are also implemented .
In addition , to the housing conditions , ease of transport usage have also been give focus and have tremendously improved .
With the public transport system such as buses and trains installed with more seats dedicated to the elderly and customised for the ease of boarding and alighting especially for the wheel chair bounded .
Furthermore , road signs are displayed in 4 major languages to resolve the problem that there are some old folks who are unable to understand other language besides their mother tongue .
Although this much have been done to improve the living conditions of the elderly , the full benefits cannot be reaped if the plans are not widespread enough .
For example , not all apartment flats are equipped with a lift that serves every storey and not all buses are designed for the ease of boarding for the elderly .
Therefore , despite the fact that the changes are indeed useful , there is still a major pitfall here which is if the implementation is not island-wide , the full benefits cannot be realised .
The improving medical care and subsidies help the aging population cope with health problems which are inherent in old age .
According to the Ministry of Health , government subsidies for the elderly are provided based on the assessment of the patient's total family income and can go up to 75% of the total fees .
With this subsidy ,  more elderly will be able to  medical care as compared to before .
Furthermore , with the constantly improving technology in the medical field , many medical procedures have been simplified from surgery that requires hospitalisation to an outpatient procedure .
To quote an example , just 10 years ago , cataract surgery required a hospital stay of several days .
Now , the surgery can sometimes be done in less than 30 minutes as an outpatient basis .
With the improvement , not only the cost of hospitalisation is eliminated , many previously complicated surgeries have also become simplified as a result .
Nevertheless , these measures are only methods which make it more affordable and easier to seek treatment but it does not solve the problem .
The elderly have to be convinced to adopt a healthy and balanced lifestyle .
Therefore , besides providing subsidies , they have to be more proactive in reaching out to the elderly who are not likely to seek out information on staying healthy .
With the measures such as better economic situation for the elderly by encouraging later retirement , improving the housing and transport conditions and better health care for the elderly have tremendously changed the way aging takes place .
While it is inevitable to avoid the aging process , with such measures in place , it will make  growing old much easier than before .
With the overly successful "Stop at Two" campaign to curb the overpopulation in the 1960's , Singapore has since faced an ageing population as birth rate dipped tremendously .
Coupled with high-quality healthcare , life expectancy has also increased .
These result in a decline of the proportion of economically productive people .
In 2008 , Singapore was reportedly one of the Asian economies to be worst hit by an ageing population (UBS , 2008) .
Our long-term economic growth is estimated to be cut by 3 percent , while support for the elderly could cost the country more than 7 percent of our gross domestic product (GDP) .
With such a bleak outlook of our economy , our nation should be spending more wisely .
by entrusting the responsibility of taking care of the elders to everyone in  society , public spending on the elderly could and should then be limited .
Firstly , grown children should take care of their elderly parents .
By stressing on filial obligations and their duty to the aged , we can reduce the fiscal cost of elder dependency .
However , the higher cost of living today makes such obligations quite impossible .
With a high average inflation rate of 5 .83% globally (Goldman Sachs , 2008) , it is very difficult for grown children to support both their family and their parents .
Even so , it should not be an excuse as it actually does not take much to support the aged financially .
Young adults need to make an effort to save .
Especially in Asian societies , such as Singapore , older people are traditionally supported by their own families .
So , the grown children should continue with such tradition .
Nonetheless , in view of this dying tradition , the Maintenance of Parents Act is in place to tackle such issues .
Parents above sixty , who cannot support themselves , can approach the tribunal for an order to claim maintenance from their children , delegating responsibility to the children .
Hence , with children supporting their parents , the government could save on the extra national budget .
Secondly , there are policies made to help the aged remain self reliant after retirement such as the mandatory saving scheme known as Central Provident Fund (CPF) .
Nonetheless , the policies may not benefit all the aged .
For example , the CPF is not beneficial to the self employed unless they made an effort to deposit money into their CPF account .
Hence , the government has made several , not just one , policies .
For example , the lack of land in Singapore makes housing a valuable asset for Singaporeans .
To ensure all Singaporeans own their homes , the government gives generous subsidies for public housing .
As the nation prospers , these homes will appreciate in value , and Singaporeans may draw on this egg nest when they are old .
With such policies , the aged are ensured that they would have enough assets to remain self reliant and not be dependent on the government .
Hence , the government will then be able to divert spending towards  national growth .
Lastly , an ageing population places pressure on the entire nation and everyone should play a part to take care of the aged .
Retirement age is to be pushed back to 65 by 2012 .
The best way to be all right in old age is to have enough savings by working longer (PM Lee Hsien Loong , 2009) .
Hence , companies can contribute by employing them .
Nonetheless , many elders lack skills .
Yet , they are more expensive to employ .
However , it must not be overlooked that these elders are experienced and could contribute in a different way .
Employers could also offer other kinds of employment , it does not necessarily have to be the same job or pay as of their previous employment .
The government has also several programs to retrain older workers and upgrade their skills , ultimately , increasing their employability .
With jobs , the elders could then be self reliant .
Hence , spending on the aged population could then be limited .
The elderly population needs a huge amount of money for healthcare expenses .
Many elderly has deteriorated health with common illnesses like diabetes , eye cataracts , boneelder friendlyems , and heart problems .
These problems need continuous attention and therefore incur repetitive and expensive expenditures .
There is also a neto build elderly friendly environment like railings , lifts that goes to every floor of the buildings , and slopes .
In addition , there will be a need to have domestic helpers or day-care-centers to take care of the elderly when there is nobody else to look after them .
These can incur huge government expenses which can slow down the economy .
The elderly should be educated about the aging population , because the economy may be sevehaveydeterioratingif they are no longer able to support themselves financially .
Being financially responsible , the elderly should save up as much money as possible while they were young so that they can pay for their daily expenses .
In this manner , the working populatioenvironments more funds left over to stimulate economic growth , or even pay for trampswn retirement .
There will be an adverse impact on the economy if government spending on the aged is not limited .
Due to the a largeof raising taxes to provide for the elderly , local consumptions of goods may reduce significantly and foreign investors will consider relocating their investments .
If consumption of goods reduces significantly , there will be low credit flow in the economy , which will result in sluggish economic growth .
Also , when foreign investors relocate their investments , jobs will also be relocated to other geographic places , this result in fewer jobs for the population .
Even though limiting expenses on the aging population may sound irresponsible , doing this can be a way to help to cope with the problem .
Limiting expenses on the aging population will mean that the government will have more funds to utilize to attract foreign investors to the country .
They can also utilize these funds to improve public facilities to attract tourism; tourism is one of the economic activities that can generate extra income to the country .
People will also become more affluent to spend and stimulate the economic growwill result a result of economic growth , the government will be more able to pay for the retired elderly .
This will then become a snowballing effect causing further improvements in the economy .
besides  global warming  , an aging population is  another phenomenon that  is of concern to the world today , one that has no definite solution This aging phenomenon is most evident in developed countries like Japan , Germany and Singapore where fertility rates are low .
The growing number of the elderly  around the world has certainly created a huge iimpact which in turn has caused changes to the structure of current society .
Faced with this situation , governments and policy makers around the world have been providing solutions such as the introduction of economic policies , social policies , and architectural designs which benefit both the elderly and  society .
One of the main solutions to be offered is the economic policy that eases the financial situation of the elderly .
Some countries provide incentives to the elderly for their daily and long term needs .
One of the evident examples would be the health care subsidy which has been carried out by many developed countries such as Singapore , Japan , and the U .S . Others may object that too much is being spent on the elderly and this will hinder the growth of the country which is fundamentally more essential .
However , this argument may not be valid because the elderly are considered as an integral part of a country and cannot be totally excluded .
With the right economic plan and policies , the elderly can effectively contribute back to the growth of the country .
As mentioned by Singapore's Prime Minister Lee  , "aging should be redefined as an opportunity rather than burden to the society" .
Life-long employability would be one possible answer to this problem , as the elderly can be less dependent on state funding and , at the same time , contribute back to the growth of the country .
Furthermore , other than contributing to the country , the elderly parents are also an important part of the family as they possess invaluable knowledge and experience which can guide the younger generation .
(The Journal 2009)
As the aging population to some extent has had a negative impact on society , social policies play an important role in reducing the effect which could otherwise cause social disintegration within a country .
One important example would be the  Parents Maintenance Act of Singapore , which governs specifically the social relationship between parents and children .
One may argue that the social policy is not needed as it has already been perceived in the society itself .
However , the current economic situation and the decreasing fertility rate have left  young adults , who have no siblings to share costs with , no choice but to give up on their parents .
Furthermore , we should also consider the fact that society is changing over time and so does the social and cultural value of our traditions .
Particularly in Singapore , as a multiracial country , where many different cultures converge , the traditional Asian value of filial piety will continuously fade off .
Thus , social policy plays an important part to maintain this relationship and also to reiterate the importance of filial piety in the minds of the young adults .
As people get older , they tend to be more dependent on others in their daily activities .
This dependency may hinder the activity of the people around them which may otherwise be productive  .
With this in mind , countries have begun to provide elder friendly architectural design to assist elderly in their daily activities  .
For instance , in Singapore , more housing and transportation modes are designed to provide elder friendly designs such as: rubber flooring , alarm systems and supporting hand rails .
With the implementation of elder friendly designs , the elderly will be able demonstrate some level of independence .
Reduced dependency of the elderly would also result in better allocation of the country's resources , as young adults would be able to concentrate on their career and social organizations would be able to direct their attention to the more needy ones .
In conclusion , the problems of an aging population are likely to continue or even worsen over the coming years .
Including economic , social and architectural aspects of society , there are many other implementations that can be done to ease the aging issues .
With the success of these implementations , I believe the world can shift the paradigm of the aging phenomenon to have a sustainable positive impact .
Yes , I agree that current research and development/policies have helped to ease the aging process to a large extent .
In Singapore , the government and society have come up with various policies and strategies to assist the aging population .
For example , there are some organizations that help the elderly with their daily necessities; the government is planning on making a more elder friendly environment and having an Active Aging Festival .
One might object  that the government and society have not really done much for them .
For instance , there are still many who are living alone with no children to care for them .
This group of elderly usually live in small apartments with little contact with the outside world and they fall sick easily .
It is also quite inconvenient for them to move about , thus they prefer to stay at home and watch television , rest and not do anything much .
They just watch life pass by .
There were even cases of elderly dying at home without anybody knowing it .
Many are of the view that the government is neglecting the older generation .
There is a lack in government policies and regulation in ensuring that the elderly are well taken care of .
Another program by the government is the 'Enable Ageing-in-Place' plan to make places more accessible for the elderly .
This plan focuses on how elderly can travel safer and easier in public area using public transport .
We can see that some buses are now made with a platform accessible for people who are on wheelchairs; Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) stations with lifts and fare gates which allow them to travel just like many other commuters; Older HDB flats being upgraded to lifts that stops at each level and car parking areas now comes with wheelchair bounded slots .
These are just examples of the many strategies that the government has come up with to ease the aging process in Singapore .
Two years ago , the Active Aging Festival  was launched to encourage senior citizens to be more active in their lives Instead of living in the past , they are encouraged to pursue their dream and work towards their future .
The festival has been initiated by Council for Third Age (C3A) .
Its focus is on the six dimensions of wellness which an elderly will most likely be lacking in .
They are social , emotional , intellectual , physical , vocational and spiritual .
This festival consists of three main events , the Active Ageing Carnival , Grandparents' Day and Active Agers Award .
The idea here is to allow family members from young children to adult to get involved together with their elderly in the festival .
It turns out to be  fun and exciting for the elderly .
This promotes bonding among different generations .
In having this festival , the government allows the elderly to enjoy their aging life together with their family members .
An aging population is one of the issues that faces Singapore today . .
The Singapore Department of Statistics (Singstat) states in its Population Trend 2008 report that senior citizens aged 65 years and above make up  8 .5% of the population and that , it will continue to rise .
Having an aging population is a challenge and there is a need for public spending to assist the aged throughout their aging process .
However , the amount of public spending on the aged should nonetheless be limited so that the money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
Critics of this position point out that it is only right for the government to spend on the aged to recognize their contributions made to the country's economy .
However , doing so and not limiting the public spending on them would have dire consequences on Singapore itself .
Firstly , the national budget will come under pressure .
Having an aging population means that there will be lesser people in the workforce and this will have an impact on the country's economy  .
Further if public spending on the aged is not limited despite the decrease in the size of the workforce , the country's economy will be negatively affected .
In addition , the public money comes from taxing the workforce .
If public spending is not limited , this would mean that the workforce may be further taxed to provide sufficient funds for the aged .
Not only would this pressurize the workforce , it would also cause them to spend less as they have lesser discretionary income .
This action will ultimately affect the country's economy .
Thus , it is necessary to limit public spending on the aged due to the negative consequences that would arise from doing  otherwise .
One may argue that the high cost of living justifies the need for public spending on the aged .
However , measures have been taken by the government beforehand to help the aged ease their aging process .
One measure , linked through the Central Provident Fund (CPF) , is the CPF Life .
There may be a portion of the senior citizens who find it difficult to cope with the cost of living after retirement as they no longer have an income to support them .
Thus , in order to meet their needs , the government has came up with the CPF Life designed such that the elders will be able to receive a continuous steady stream of income base on their CPF contributions made during their working life .
Another measure that the government had taken was to include a Medisave account in the CPF Savings .
The money in the Medisave account was formed by a percentage of their income and could be used for hospitalization expenses .
As the senior citizens are more prone to health sickness , having this Medisave account would greatly benefit them .
Thus , public spending on the aged could and should be limited as the government had came up with several approaches to help deal with the aging process .
An aging population should not be the only issue that is given most attention to , as there are other areas of the country's development that would require  public money .
For instance , the government should spend part of the national budget in trying to increase the fertility rate .
Singstat mentions that despite the slight increase in fertility rate , the fertility rate is still considered low .
Having a low fertility rate would impact Singapore in the long run .
The government could probably use the national budget to provide incentives to encourage Singaporeans to do their part in increasing the fertility rate .
Thus , public spending on the aged should be limited as there are other areas of the country's development that would require the national budget .
In conclusion , though there should be public spending on the aged , it should nevertheless be limited .
This is because of the consequences related to doing  otherwise such as pressurizing the national budget as well as the workforce  .
In addition , the government has already done its part in preparing its citizens for old age through the CPF Life and Medisave Account .
Furthermore , there are other areas of development that would require the national budget .
I agree to a large extent that current research and development/policies have helped to ease the aging process .
The aging process means that as time passes ,  people will undergo a process of physical , psychological and social change .
In order to help the society and its people to cope with the changes , current research and development such as new technological inventions and employment schemes are being put in place .
Firstly , in many countries which have traffic lights at road conjunctions , the scenario of an elderly rushing to cross the traffic light is common because the elderly tends to have a slower pace in walking .
This is a concern for an aging population as there could be some danger posed in crossing the roads when the traffic light has turned red .
To minimize the risk of elderly fatalities , the Singapore Land Transport Authority (LTA) has invented an Elderly-Friendly Traffic System .
The system uses the Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) technology to identify any elderly pedestrians who want to cross the road , then extend the 'green man' timing , allowing the elderly to make their way across the roads safely .
It may be objected that if an elderly person took too much time crossing the road , it may cause traffic congestion on the road .
However , a countdown timer has been installed beside the 'green man' to signal to the pedestrians that the traffic light is turning to 'red man' .
Thus , the system is put in place for elderly to cross safely with a reasonable amount of time .
This example shows that the problems which will occur from an aging population have been well-thought through and measures have been put in place . .
Secondly ,  , mobile phones are used commonly and most  people around the world have at least one mobile phone .
With a large demand for mobile phones , phone companies have to compete with each other by inventing fanciful mobile phones with many functions such as Internet , games , music player and more .
However , with the shift to an aging population , the purpose of possessing a mobile phone changes .
The demand would be for its original functionality of maintaining contact and for emergencies .
Furthermore , as people get older , their vision will become poorer and responsiveness might be slower than before .
Thus , phone companies must take this opportunity to penetrate the market with elderly-friendly phones .
For example , Japan's phone companies  actually offer phone models which have bigger screens and larger font sizes , enhanced audibility and easier- to-operate keys to attract the elderly .
This will satisfy the needs of the elderly for a phone .
At this point , one may wonder , even if the phones are elderly-friendly , it will not be feasible unless the elderly knows how to use the phone .
In contrast , the Japanese phone companies which offer the elderly-friendly phones also offer a free one hour session on how to use the phone .
Therefore , this shows that the phone companies are attentive to issues regarding the aging population and have taken action to help ease the problems faced by an aging population . .
One argument against the large extent of current research and development/policies that helped to ease the aging process is the availability of jobs for the elderly .
Most of the companies are likely to avoid elderly employment as the elderly are often perceived to have lack of relevant knowledge and expertise for them to work or continue to work in the company .
However , it is not true as the government has implemented several schemes to help in the employment of the elderly .
For example , in Singapore , the Skills Programme for Upgrading and Resilience (SPUR) is an enhanced funding support scheme that will help both the companies and individuals to build stronger manpower capabilities and more enhanced skills .
Thus , with the encouragement and funding from the government , the companies will be more motivated to provide enhanced training for the existing employee or relevant training for the elderly to enter the company .
This will help in relieving the aging process .
Being one of the fastest aging populations in the Asian region , Singapore faces many challenges in trying to overcome this aging problem .
For the last 30 years , the young population in Singapore has shrunk tremendously .
Accounting for less than 4% of the total population back in the 1960s , today the elderly , aged 65 and above  constitute 7 .3% of the total population based on the Singapore Census of Population 2000 .
This projects a significant growth in the aging population over the years .
To accommodate  this current changing age structure , on-going development of government policies , covering areas like economics , sociology and architectural design , have been carried out aggressively through these years .
At this point , one may wonder whether the policies implemented are effectively easing the aging process .
Even though The government has implemented so many policies to help ease the aging process , some people still view this as insufficient . . From what we can see today , the trend of elderly staying all by themselves or staying in the old folks' homes has been on the rise .
Although some of the government's policies are initiated with the goal of encouraging the young to look after their aged parents , it does not seem to work out as planned .
Due to the changing beliefs and values of the younger generation in the 21th century , many of them hope to achieve freedom in their financial status , personal life and other aspects of their life and thus deem that staying with their aged parents would cause a burden to them .
The Government should try educating this younger generation on the correct mindset before exploiting the full potential of these implemented policies .
However , government initiated policies are not as inefficient after all .
One of the main causes for a growing aging population is the low fertility rate in Singapore .
In today's society , many couples choose to have fewer children due to the high living expenses and financial burden .
Due to that , Singapore is facing a serious declining fertility rate that  is resulting in a huge difference between the aged and the young .
To overcome this problem , government policy is implemented to encourage Singaporean couples to have three or more children if family finances permit .
This includes the implementation of financial incentive schemes , such as the Baby Bonus scheme , to parents who are having their second or third child .
Under this scheme , a Children Development Account (CDA) will be opened .
For parents having their second child , the government will contribute S$500 per year into the CDA account and up to another S$1000 each year to match the combinations from their parents .
For parents having their third child , the amount contributed will be doubled .
Purpose of this financial scheme is to assist parents in the payment of the development and education of their children .
Through these implemented policies , it will help facilitate the growth of the fertility rate .
To further tackle the rising trend , the Government has implemented different housing schemes so as to better allow the families to look after their aged parents rather than putting them in old folks' homes or leaving them to look after themselves .
Examples of housing schemes include the Joint Selection scheme , which helps the parents and their children in their application for separate flats but in the same block or housing estate .
Multi-Tier Family Housing scheme is another scheme which allows preferential treatment in flat application , lower-down payment and also maximum loans for those who opt for it .
The applicants can request for flats that are larger in size with enough space for two independent households .
Through this policy , it helps to create responsibility awareness of the younger generation to look after their aged parents .
Furthermore , it also enables the aged to continue living in the environment that they are familiar with .
Support services and subsidies are provided to families with aged dependents so as to assist them and at the same time , help the aged to remain physically and socially active .
Catering to the upward trend of the aging population , initiated programs such as free health check for the elderly are implemented to encourage the elderly to constantly conduct full body checkup to ensure that they are in good health  and also to advice them on the dos and don'ts in their everyday life so as to maintain a healthy lifestyle .
Besides that , incentives are also beingprovided for the elderly to further motivate them in conducting health checks .
With these , it will help to ensure that the elderly are physically and mentally healthy and thus more productive in their old age .
Nowadays , governments and policy makers all around the world are facing the problem of a fast aging population .
Indeed , a lot of research and development besides policies have been implemented in order to ease the aging process especially from the aspect of medicine , economics and technological inventions .
Modern science and medicine has brought many benefits to mankind .
Disease like Parkinson's disease which is known as an incurable disease is now largely controllable due to research  done to discover the cause of this disorder .
Of all the neurodegenerative disorders , Parkinson's disease is second to Alzheimer's disease in the number of cases , with more than 1 .3 million patients suffering from it in major countries .
Parkinson's disease usually develops after the age of 65 .
Currently , research and development  Solvay Pharmaceuticals Asia is progressing well on working with the newly invented therapy of SLV308 and SLV318 to improve symptomatic treatment of Parkinson's disease .
With the acquisition of the Swedish company Neopharma in 2005 , they were also able to enrich their product portfolio with the Parkinson's medication Duodopa .
Duodopa is intended for people suffering from late stage Parkinson's disease , while SLV308 is for the less advanced stages .
Together the products are expected to fit well alongside each other .
If the medications are successfully improved , Parkinson's disease will be highly  controlled .
Research has also been done on other  illnesses to find out the most efficient medications .
Compared to before , the research and newly invented medicines have helped to ease certain aging processes to a certain extent .
Technological inventions should also be taken into account as they are also essential in easing the aging process .
According to Science Daily , computer scientists have designed technologies to help the elderly maintain their independence .
One device uses optical sensors to oversee people as they pick up and use items .
Another device  uses radio frequency identification technology to track which medications have been take and when .
Besides , a team of researchers from UGR has created a system with Artificial Intelligence techniques which notifies elderly people or people with special needs who forget  everyday tasks .
These technological inventions enable the elderly to live independently and with these helpful inventions , they will no longer be classified as burdens .
Moreover , the inventions of a wheelchair controlled by a magnet on the tongue will also enable some elderly people who are unable to move freely move easily , wherever and whenever they want .
These inventions have indeed helped a lot in easing the aging process .
In a nutshell , it is undeniable that in this globalization era , research , development and policies have been doing their part in easing the aging process .
With these inventions , people nowadays are leading comfortable lives and the aging process is no longer tough for both the elderly and the young  .
Hence , everyone should appreciate these innovative inventions instead of abusing them .
Globally , there is  rising concern about the rapidly aging  population , especially in the developed countries , for example , the U .S . Census Bureau projects the number of elderly Americans will nearly double to 71 million by 2030 .
Many countries are starting to pump  money into research and to introduce policies to ease the aging process as it will lead to problems like widening of the tax base and healthcare shortages .
While current research and policies have helped to ease the aging process , there are limitations to these policies that make these policies not as effective  .
The policies that the government introduced and  current research have indeed helped to buffer the aging process .
The government has introduced effective economic policies to ease the aging process .
These economic policies are important as they will help to promote economic growth for the country .
Without growth , a country will not have the financial ability to be able to provide welfare benefits and to support the needy , usually the elderly .
One of the economic policies introduced is encouraging longer working lives .
For example , the Singapore government extended the CPF Minimum Sum withdrawal age from 62 to 65 , which in turn delayed the age of retirement .
This policy is effective in the sense that it not only increases the size of the working population so that the government will not have to increase the tax base , but also helps the elderly to save up more money for their future needs after they retire .
Therefore , this economic policy helps to promote growth for the country and also helps the elderly to prepare for their old age .
Medical research is one crucial element in easing the aging process .
When dealing with an aging population , the government knows that healthcare is one major sector that they cannot neglect .
As people havea longer life expectancy  , the aging population is going to make up a quarter of the population by the year 2030 in countries like Singapore .Therefore , more people will be demanding better health care as they grow older . .
This is because as people grow older , many are bound to suffer from age-related diseases such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease .
Thus , the government is investing large amounts of money into medical research on age-related diseases and bringing in new medical technology .
This research and technology will be used in finding new cures for certain diseases , developing of new treatments and increasing the success rate of surgery .
For example , in the United States , there is federal funding of $1 .4 billion annually in research that is crucial to finding ways to treat and prevent Alzheimer's .
Therefore , these investments on medical research will definitely be very useful in the near future .
However , there are limitations as to how effective the research and policies will be .
The research and technologies brought in are very expensive which makes it available only for the people who can afford it and the poor , who can barely make  ends meet , will not be the beneficiaries .
Some argue that the government has given a reasonable subsidy in healthcare , especially for the poor .
In addition , in the case of Singapore ,  people can fully utilise their Medisave funds , which they have saved up from their working lives , to pay for their medical bills .
However , these are really not enough to cover the high medical bills for most people , especially those who suffer from illnesses that require long- term treatment .
For  low income earners , they may have depleted their Medisave funds after one surgery , and for  subsequent treatment , they will have to either fork out their own savings or , as is often the case , they will refuse to seek treatment , which thus aggravates their illness .
So , more efforts from the government is needed in this area so that affordable healthcare will be accessible to everyone who needs it .
Aging population is a problem that no country can escape , so what the government can do is to reduce this aging process with the help of  research and policies .
However , there are limitations in the policies , thus the government can look into alternative methods so that  people will truly benefit from these policies and research .

After World War II , there was a rapid increase in the birth rate across the globe and Singapore too , faces the same problem .
With an increase in the fertility rate accompanied with an increase in the life expectancy of the population , Singapore was soon faced with an overcrowded population .
In order to prevent the situation from deteriorating , the government imposed strict policies in an attempt to reduce the birth rate .
For instance , civil servants are not entitled to paid maternity leave for the third and subsequent child .
In addition , public hospitals charge increasingly higher sums for each additional birth .
This move was proven to be effective as the fertility rate in Singapore dropped from 3 .0 in 1970 to 1 .7 in 1980 .
However , by 1986 , the Singapore government became aware of the low birth rate problem within the country and hence decided to come out with the "Have Three or More , if You Can Afford It" policy .
Monetary incentives are given to both the parent and the third and subsequent child .
Nonetheless , the policy did not work due to the rising cost of living and additional responsibility for each additional child .
With improved medical facilities these days , the life expectancy of the population has increased .
With low birth rates and longer life expectancy , the aging populationhas become a long term problem for Singapore .
Knowing the difficulties in encouraging Singaporeans to have more children , the government and related organizations decided to carry out research studies and implement policies to ease the aging process in different areas such as the medical field .
In order to combat the shrinking workforce caused by the rapid ageing population and a declining fertility rate , the Health authorities must first gear up their medical field and prepare for an aging population .
Due to the fact that older patients are more prone to hospital admittances than  other age groups , providing better medical care facilities and services not only helps to reduce the chance of re-admission , it will also facilitate better chances of making a full recovery .
With less frequent visits to  hospital , the amount of money spent on medical bills would decrease .
Hence , the elderly would be able live longer with their retirement funds .
However , to develop the medical sector , huge sums of funds have to be involved which may in turn hamper the development of other sectors .
Moreover , the drugs have to be tested so as to ensure the effectiveness of the medicine and that they are safe for consumption .
On the other hand , with the rise in aging population , it is necessary to invest heavily in the medical sector as poor medical facilities will lead to more health problems within the country .
This will then result in an increase in the amount spent on medication , thus adding a greater financial burden to the shrinking workforce .
With the constant rise in the cost of living , families can no longer rely on a sole breadwinner as they need to support both their parents as well as their children in terms of food , shelter and education .
Hence , it would be a wise decision for both adults to work in order to ease the financial burden of the family .
However , by easing the financial burden of the family , it may result in neglecting their obligations to look after their parents .
Furthermore , if either of their parents contract a long term disease which requires a significant amount of care , both  adults will be in a dilemma about whether to look after their parents or to carry on with their job so as to ease the financial burden that is added  because of the medical bills .
Either decision requires one party to sacrifice , thus the Singapore government decided to offer more step-down care services which provides basic medical care to the elderly after the patient has been stabilized .
With these services , working adults can still fulfill their filial obligation as children and maintain a manageable financial burden .
In the recent rally speech by the Prime Minister Lee Lee Hsien Loong , he mentioned that "the best way to keep health care costs down is to maintain healthy lifestyles" such as going for regular checkups and exercising regularly .
To ensure that the elderly maintain a healthy lifestyle , the government has started to build elderly fitness corners around  neighborhood .
Occasionally , the neighborhood polyclinics  also provide free medical checkups for the elderly .
Then again , even though it is the health authorities who are responsible for providing  better medical care to the citizens , senior citizens also have to play a part in ensuring their own well being .
It is their responsibility to go for regular checkups and seek proper medical treatment instead of self medicating if one is not feeling well .
This would then allow them to identify the possible illness and seek proper treatment early so as to reduce the chance of it developing into a terminal disease which would then in turn reduce the amount of money spent on treatment .
Hence , even though the government and health authorities offer facilities to ease the aging effect ,  people must also take the initiative to utilize them and be more proactive in keeping a healthy lifestyle .
In a nutshell , the medical sector plays a significant role in easing the aging process by providing a high level of medical care and wellbeing to  senior citizens .
However , the elderly themselves are also responsible for their own wellbeing by maintaining a healthy lifestyle and going for regular checkups .
Thus , if the elderly are able to take advantage of the advanced medical facilities offered to them , it will certainly play a big role in helping  society to ease the aging process .
Aging  is a time induced process that causes physical , psychological and social changes . . Its impact has been widely felt in developed countries .
Longer life expectancy and a continuous fall in population have caused the aging population in Singapore to increase .
In response , Singapore has devised strategies to cushion the impact .
In view of these strategies  , it can be argued that the current research and development  policies have helped to ease the aging process .
The first policy development is in themedical field .
There is an increased demand for health care services by the aging population .
Having quality health care services at affordable prices is viewed as one of the most important needs for the aging population .
The first strategy implemented by Singapore is to have a seamless community-based health care system .
This strategy calls for having private clinics to be within a hundred metres from the home .
The polyclinics , community hospitals , long term care centres and regional hospitals should be located within two to six kilometres .
The aim is to minimize the number of hospital trips made .
It has already been carried out in the northern and western parts of Singapore .
The second strategy devised is the implementation of means- testing .
This strategy calls for graduated levels of subsidies that are based on either the patient's income or the house type .
The subsidies can be up to eighty percent of the total bill .
It is supported by reducing the subsidies of the financially well-off .
Thus , the two policies have helped to ease the aging process by cushioning the impact on the health care services .
The second policy development is in the economic field .
Three main factors have caused the total fiscal cost to be increasing at an increased rate .
Firstly , more subsidized health care treatments is being sought .
Secondly , treatment costs have increased in relation to the tremendous advancements made in medical science technologies .
Thirdly , more financial help are being sought from the government .
The first strategy implemented is the creation of the Central Provident Fund (CPF) .
The purpose is to provide a compulsory and comprehensive savings plan for Singaporeans .
In response to the changing economic landscape , several major changes have been made .
Some of the changes are the increase in the the CPF minimum sum and the partial withdrawal of  retirement savings upon reaching retirement age .
The second strategy implemented is the raise in the retirement age to sixty two years old .
The original retirement age was set at fifty five years old .
As people are living longer and healthier , there is an increased need to save up for future expenditures .
Allowing later retirement will allow wealth accumulation .
Another benefit is that valuable working experience can be retained and imparted to the inexperienced .
This will lead to a higher productivity rate .
Thus , these two policies have helped to ease the aging process by cushioning the impact on the economy .
However , critics have pointed out that it is the motivation of individuals , instead of policies , that has to ease the aging process .
Having a quality and affordable health care system will be ineffective if individuals do not take care of themselves .
Without the determination of individuals to work past their prime and increase their wealth accumulation , implementing good economic policies will also be ineffective .
However , the critics failed to pointed out that even though individuals may be unwilling to save up; the economic policies implemented have actually helped indirectly in wealth accumulation .
Unless the individuals are self-employed , part of their monthly salary will go towards CPF and special interest rates are given for the amount held .
They also have not point out that Singapore has taken basic measures to ensure the general well-being of its citizens .
For example , it is compulsory for newly-born to have the BCG vaccination against Tuberculosis .
The integration of  health care service providers through  medical policies will result in a higher quality and more affordable health care system .
As for economic policies , having the CPF and raising the retirement age allows additional wealth accumulation .
Thus , the development of these policies has helped to ease aging process to a large extent .
It is norm that ageing is often associated with illnesses such as Parkinson's and  ,and as a result , it is a concern of many .
Thus , medical breakthroughs by the University of Nottingham in  research regarding to the slowing down and preventing of Parkinson's and dementia  has definitely relieved many .
Although , some may argue that breakthroughs in  research do not severe the root of the problem as those who are ill  the diseases are still not cured .
However , one must realized that  breakthroughs can help the aged to be better prepared or even prevent contracting with  diseases .
Additionally , since there is a breakthrough , the possibility of a cure cannot be ruled out as well .
Besides , if more are able to slow down or even prevent themselves from getting the disease , the aged can lessen their medical costs which will lead to a reduced cost of living .
Therefore , medical research greatly enhances the confidence of the aged to face the eventual ageing process .
Similarly , economic policy like the Central Provident Fund(CPF) also aid in the ageing process of Singaporeans .
CPF is a saving fund employed by the government .
It enforces working adults to save a portion of their monthly salary , so that they will have a sum of money upon retirement .
Consequently , this will bring about less monetary problems when people are aged .
It is true that the policy forces a person to save but if this policy is not in place , it is likely that one will have to work beyond the age of retirement .
However , it is also not guaranteed that the saving in CPF will be sufficient , especially with the prolonged life expectancy of many .
Therefore , recently adjustments have been made to the policies to ensure that the retirees' saving can last them through their life .
In the past , a lump sum was given to the recipients , but now the recipients will get the money in their CPF account on a monthly basis till they pass on .
Another plan in CPF known as Medisave .
This helps the aged to meet health care needs and hospitalization fees , so that the aged can afford the usage of healthcare facilities .
As can be seen , the CPF policy has not only help the aged to cope with monetary issues after retirement  , making sure that their savings are sufficient for their retirement but it has also made it certain that they will be able to afford  healthcare facilities if required .
Lastly , the HDB grant policy also displays how the government helps to ease the ageing process .
The policy aims to promote filial piety while helping filial children to decrease the burden of owning a property with a $20 000 grant .
This policy not only helps to minimize the fear of not being taken care of when one is aged , it weakens the negative idea that living with parents only increases one's expenditure .
It also diminishes the worries of aged parents that their children will not have a roof over their head .
Clearly , the current research and policies have helped to ease the ageing process tremendously .
Breakthroughs in the medical research field , not only provide a cushion for the aged with regards to old age illnesses but also help to reduce their future medical expenditure .
Similarly , the CPF policy , put into operation by the government lessens the worries of ageing as medical and life expenses  are already well planned for .
Finally the HDB grant policy decreases the worries of the aged living with their children .
It is relatively hard to deny how much ageing has been made much easier .
Aging is a continuous , complex , and dynamic process .
Aging  as defined by Wikipedia is the process of physical , psychological , and social change .
Physical change means that one's health will be likely to deteriorate as one ages .
While psychological change in general refers to the change in mental abilities and behaviors .
Social change in general points to the change in attitude towards life .
The rate of aging differs from person to person .
However , everyone will have to go through it eventually .
Fortunately , advancements in technology , economic policies and social policies implemented by the government has helped to ease this process .
Although elderly individuals can realize tremendous benefits from the advancement in technology , nevertheless , technology brings with it problems too .
Some elderly individuals may feel  left behind by the pace of technological change .
In today's modern world , most information is digitalized .
Elderly individuals , who lack access and training needed to familiarize themselves with modern technology like the internet , may find themselves at a disadvantage .
This is because they will miss out on opportunities to access  the large database of information , goods and services online .
However , efforts have been made to help these elderly individuals .
For example in Singapore , the government has launched the Wireless@SG initiative to provide citizens with free internet access .
Hence , elderly individuals will also have the opportunity to use the internet .
Moreover , the government is also providing subsidies to help these elderly individuals to purchase a computer .
In addition , there will also be concentrated efforts towards educating  elderly individuals to use the internet .
Therefore , they too can also enjoy the ease of getting information , goods and services online just by a click .
The internet also provides a platform for elderly individuals to network and socialize with one another without stepping out of their house .
This is veryconvenient especially for elderly individuals who have difficulty moving around .
Apart from that , advancements in technology also brings about the inventions of new gadgets that have significantly improved the lives of  elderly individuals .
For example in Japan , a mobile phone manufacturer has come up with a mobile phone that has a large key pad so that the elderly can use it without straining their eyes .
Similarly , wheelchairs are being made automated , so that elderly individuals , who are too weak to walk , will still be able to move around freely and independently .
Economic policies implemented by the government have also helped to ease the process of aging .
For example in Singapore , the government has implemented the Central Provident Fund (CPF) LIFE scheme that will provide lifelong income for the elderly in their retirement .
Under this scheme , they can get around $360 to $440 per month upon reaching the age of 62 .
As a result , elderly individuals can enjoy their retirement without having many financial worries .
Elderly individuals are generally more prone to illnesses as their immune system may have weakened due to aging .
In addition to that , they are more likely to be plagued with old age diseases like Parkinson's or dementia .
The government foreseeing that personal medical expenses would rise as one ages , has implemented the Medisave scheme to meet elderly people's healthcare needs .
Basically , this scheme helps individuals to put aside part of their income into their Medisave account to meet their future personal medical expenses .
Therefore , they do not have to worry about medical expenses when they are old .
Besides that , the government also provides financial assistance to needy elderly individuals who do not have the means to pay their medical expenses .
Social policies have also been implemented to ease the process of aging .
For example in Singapore , the government has set up a $10million Golden Opportunities Fund to create more programmes , activities and learning opportunities for  elderly individuals .
This fund will be used to construct more elderly-friendly facilities in all sports centres and within housing estates .
Therefore , through this policy , elderly people can pursue the lifestyle of their choice , be it sports , learning , or contributing through volunteering in non-profit organizations .
In conclusion , advancements in technology , economic policies and social policies implemented by the government have helped to ease the process of aging .
Elderly individuals are able to live freely , independently and fruitfully while pursuing their choice of life after retirement .

Currently , 7% of Singapore's population is over the age of 65; however , by 2030 , this will increase to 20% (Inter-Ministerial Committee on Aging Report 1999) .
Thus ageing population is one of the challenges Singapore will face in the near future .
There has been much attention placed on this issue and its implications .
It is undeniable that there have been many policies implemented to ease the aging process .
However , the extent to which these policies help to ease the ageing process remains rather limited due to the limitations of the policies .
Firstly , the Parents Maintenance Act can now address the  concern of the increasing number of parents who are neglected and abandoned by their children . .
It may be successful in getting the children to pay the maintenance of their parents ; but by enforcing such law ,   .
The act ensures that the child or children have to support their parents since they will face serious consequences they did not .
However , it is a question of whether if they have done it willingly .
Filial piety is supposed to be a virtue to be upheld , a respect for parents and ancestors , and yet now we need a law  to make sure everyone uphold it .
Does this imply morals are being eroded in this society ? 
Furthermore , Parents Maintenance Act may not be entirely successful in getting the children to pay for their  parents' maintenance .
This is because the act is only applicable if parents made a report against their children and  if the parents were aware of such an act , as well as  ready to do that to their children .
And children can only abide by the obligations if they were financially stable .
Therefore this act is rather ineffective in solving the problems of unwanted  parents .
Other strategies in solving the ageing problem would be to increase the birth rate .
With an increased population , there will be an increase in the workforcewhich would in turn lead to an increase in income tax Thus ,  this will solve the problems of labour shortage  , as well as  the heavy financial strain placed on the economically active population .
A pronatalist policy has been implemented since the early 1990s  , and yet the effectiveness it has on birth remains questionable .
Despite much efforts have been put in by  government to shape a policy that aims at lessening the financial burden of having children , fertility rates continues to  remain low .
It could reach as low as1 ,08 , which is way below replacement rate .
The pro-natalist policy focuses mainly on  cash incentives such as baby bonuses of $3 ,00 for the first and second child , up to $6 ,000 for the third and fourth  child; as well as  the government contributions in the form of a dollar-for-dollar matching for the amount of savings the parents contribute to their child's Children Development Account .
However , in Singapore , the financial burden is less of a concern when we are targeting at the 'productive group' of the population .
, so when they are encouraging population growth they are targeting at the educated ones , who are also the financially stable ones .
Thus cash incentives are not a strong enough factor to encourage them to give birth , as money is of a less important issue to them .
On the other hand , it can also be argued that  and the government's help in terms of baby bonus and Children Development Account is temporary .
and it makes people think twice about giving birth , given the other considerations such as high cost of living in Singapore and the increasingly competitive society we are living in .
All these make the task of raising  a child well challenging .
Therefore , the pro-natalist is rather unsuccessful in easing ageing population through the encouraging of births due to  other considerations people have when they decide to have a child  , and these considerations may not be related to cash incentives . .
In conclusion , the two policies have shown their ineffectiveness in easing the problems of ageing population .
Rather than having one policy to cater to the whole country , there can be different policies implemented to cater to different levels of income group .
I agree to a certain extent that the current architectural development in Singapore has helped in the aging process , the architectural development in Singapore was not barrier-free .
Aging process causes difficulties in movement The current scheme that the Singapore government is using is called the Barrier-Free Accessibility (BFA) () .
"This BFA Code requires all new buildings , as well as the existing ones to undergo major retrofitting works , to meet certain barrier-free requirements ."
From the quote , the key words are 'new' and 'certain' .
'New" refers to any building that comes after BFA has been implemented .
"Certain" means that it is  .
The statement highlights that  to a large extent .
The current BFA Code focuses on the accessibility to and within a building .
It does not address the issues on accessibility between buildings , and from buildings to nearby public facilities .
Therefore the public owner has a part to play: for example in shopping malls ,  , industrial estates , invested properties and private properties .
But that is only for buildings that do not belong to the government sector .
Buildings like the Housing development Board flats are built or upgraded to have desirable levels of  accessibilities .
Measures taken by the government to help ease aging process in residential areas are  sheltered linkways which are upgraded to allow the elderly to access from residential blocks to markets .
Other measures include the installation of more ramps in residential areas , which are designed to have a gentle gradient so that it is user-friendly for people in wheelchairs , as well as new lifts replacements with bigger button showing larger text and better lit buttons in lifts so that the old who are visually unsound can see and press for the correct floor .
Measures are taken by the government to help ease the aging process in non-residential areas by creating better public accessibility , for example , the Land Transport Authority making plans to improve accessibility to reach public transport like MRT and bus stops .
The National Parks is also working to into its designs for parks so that even parks can be allowed better accessibility .
Government efforts alone are insufficient .
Private building owners need to adopt similar measures to achieve  for aging population .
A large amount of development has been done by the government to help ease the process of aging but it is not enough due to the fact that the BFA Code only covers new buildings and government developments .
Existing developments by private entities still do not have better accessibility .
Since the implementation of the Code on Barrier-Free Accessibility in Buildings (BFA) in the 1990s , there has been an increase of improved buildings with better accessibility .
However , there are still many pre-1990 buildings that remain "inaccessible" .
Hence , I agree that the current architectural development in Singapore has helped in the aging process to a certain extent .
In October 2007 , UD was added to the BFA to provide a more complete set of guidelines for design in buildings .
UD is a new guideline that has recommendations that can be applied to commercial , residential buildings as well as public and community facilities .
But it is only a Guide; and its applications are not compulsory .
This means that there is no obligations to follow strictly to the guidelines; in other words ,  .
In effect , UD does not help in the development of better accessibility for people who are aged .
Therefore , a revised code on Barrier-Free Accessibility In Buildings , which is a  5-year Barrier-Free Accessibility (BFA) Upgrading Program (2007-2011) has been added to support the upgrading of existing buildings .
All areas intended for access by any group of people like employees , students , etc , to places such as workplaces , training institutions , hospitals , etc , should also be made accessible to their immediate target users besides the public .
The current BFA Code focuses on essential requirements confined to handicap features or facilities which are deemed to be of minimum standards essential for its intended use . 
The government also tries to encourage participation from the private sector , by setting aside a sum of $40 million as Accessibility Fund to upgrade building that are built before the 1990 and not compliant to BFA .
The Accessibility Fund also includes the upgrading of all key areas and necessary facilities in Singapore , so as to provide the bare minimum accessibility by the year 2011 .
Despite this effort , private sectors are still not incorporating desirable features in their designs to help make the buildings in Singapore to be 100% user-friendly to all intended users because they only meet the basic standards of accessibility needed by a building .

This will affect the country's development in both the social and economical aspect .

However , there have to be a limit as to how much we spend on them so that the money can be diverted into areas like health , education and defense , which are much more important  and crucial to the country's development .
