Public spending on the aged has been rising rapidly  because people need more health care as they grow older .
This has been a major concern for the government because such massive yet increasing spending on the aged would mean a high possibility of economic and fiscal crisis for the near future (Public Sector HealthCare Roundtable , 2009) .
Therefore , public spending on the aged should be limited to a certain extent , not only to avoid the high possibility of economic crisis in the near future , but also to divert the resources to other areas such as education and infrastructure development , which are essential for the economic growth of a country .
The increase of public spending on the aged is necessary because of the growing numbers among the aging population .
However , there are other useful measures that could be taken to reduce the amount of public spending on the elderly .
For example , Peterson states that "elder dependency should be reduced by encouraging later retirement , longer working lives , and lower barriers to elder employment" .
(citation) Another strategy that he stated would be to emphasize filial obligation and encourage the willingness of tomorrow's grown children to look after their aged parents , so as to lower  government spending on the elderly .
This could be achieved through informal and familial channels (Peterson , 2001) .
Therefore , public spending on the aged is necessary , but we should not eliminate other possibilities that will ease the spending
In addition , education also plays a crucial role for the wealth and future development of a country .
For instance , education teaches us the correct attitude and courtesy , thus making us civilized .
In addition , it assists us in the development of our virtues and values , and it also cultivates us into mature individuals , who are capable of planning for our futures and taking the correct steps .
When  people are well-educated , the advancement of a country's economy will be promised (Manali Oak , 2008) .
Education at the secondary and tertiary level will prepare  students to be efficient when they enter the working society , by equipping them with the necessary knowledge and essential skills .
When the efficiency of the workforce is high , it will benefit the economic growth of the country  .
Therefore , public spending on education should not be compromised due to the ageing population .
Infrastructure development affects the economic progression of a country; therefore , it should not be overlooked .
For example , the accumulation of deficit incurred by the American public infrastructure over the past several decades has resulted in a variety of infrastructure bottlenecks-traffic congested roads , clogged ports , and an antiquated air traffic system , which undercut the economy's efficiency  .
This clearly shows that if a country were to neglect its infrastructure development , it will affect the economy greatly .
Infrastructures that are designed and built for tourists will be a significant source of revenue for the country; hence , appropriate amount of public spending should be incorporated to develop such infrastructures .
For instance , the Infrastructure Development Finance Corporation in New Delhi said that by increasing public investment in infrastructure development , it would then attract more private investment (PTI , 2006) .
This would mean more income will be generated .
Therefore , infrastructure development is a crucial segment that affects a country's wealth .
In conclusion , public spending on the elderly should be limited , so as to divert the money into other areas such as education and infrastructure which are essential for the country's economy .
Public spending on the aged can be reduced by increasing the retirement age , or stressing filial obligation .
The government should divert the money into education to equip the people with the right attitude and working skills , so as to ensure  stable economic growth for the country .
Governments should spend sufficiently on infrastructure development because public infrastructure deficit will cause the economy to be less efficient .
On the other hand , public spending in infrastructure development attracts more private investment; hence generating greater income .
If a country neglects other aspects such as education and infrastructure development , but over focuses  on public spending on the aged , its economy will suffer drastically .
In Singapore , the population is aging rapidly .
An aging process means the process of growing old and getting more matured .
"The United Nations defines an aged population as one in which greater than 10% of its residents are aged 60 and above .
In year 2000 , the percentage of the population among Singapore which aged 65 years and above is 7 .2% , and 10 .6% for 60 years and above .
By 2030 , this percentage is predicted to reach 18 .4% for those aged 65 and above , as Singapore is the second fastest aging country in the world"  (Koh) , The Singapore government has carried out many policies to ease the aging processto ensure that growing old in Singapore will be a satisfying and fulfilling experience .
The government has been focusing mainly on economic policies , which are more effective ways in easing the aging process in Singapore's population .
One of the government economic policies which is successful is the Central Provident Fund (CPF) scheme .
This is a "national social security fund which was established in 1955 as a form of funded retirement savings plan"  (Mehta) .
Singaporeans are required to deposit a certain amount of their salaries into their CPF accounts .
"Employers are also required to contribute 16% of the employee's salary into the employee's account"  (Mehta) .
The contribution rates differ according to age and income of between 8%to33% .
Compared to other countries , Singapore has a much higher rate of contribution .
Some people might complain that the CPF is ripping away so much of their money that they do not have enough  to spend .
However , this is the main purpose of CPF --- to save and reduce on spending .
The high saving rate is to enable the elderly to support themselves in old ageand to provide  for old-age dependency .
Some other people might say that CPF savings is not enough to provide for their  retired lives .
Nonetheless , it is up to the individuals to plan  their  personal savings for their future as the CPF is just a way to help those who might not have planned their savings for oldage .
This is the intention of the government to protect its people .
It was a  strategy  implemented by the government in September 2002 .
"It is an affordable severe disability insurance scheme which provides basic financial protection to those who need long term care , especially in old age .
It provides monthly cash out to help pay the out-of-pocket expenses for the care of a severely-disabled person"  (Healthcare Financing - ElderShield) .
ElderShield is viewing at the increased life expectancy of Singaporeans  , which translate to people living longer as  compared to in the past .
Therefore , one should   deposit some savings during the productive years to prepare for old age disabilities .
Some people may think that  this scheme  is not needed and is a waste of money because they already have their account and they assumed that they will never get severe disabilities  .
This concept is wrong .
Firstly , "ElderShield and MediShield both provide different types of coverage .
ElderShield will pay you monthly cash payouts if you become severely disabled for any reason , whereas MediShield helps you pay hospitalization expenses , only if you are admitted to a hospital"  (FAQs on Policies) .
Looking at this policy , we  know that the government is really trying to ease the aging process in the population .
Apart from the two policies above , the government has also implemented the Public/Society Scheme , which acts as a 'safety net' for elderly Singaporeans . 
All in all , though  the government economic policies have some flaws , the policies have  done much  in making the lives of elderly citizens of Singapore easier and more comfortable .
Hence , the government financial policies are  successful  .
As the country will have less working force in 2030 , the government should invest more money on education to obtain a stronger working force to support the country and the large group of elderly .
"Each additional year of schooling appears to raise earnings by about 10 percent in the United States , although the rate of return to education varies over time as well as across countries ."

Singapore will not be able to solve the ageing issues if the younger generation of Singapore is lack of moral and only put their focus on themselves .
However , Singapore has already invested much money in education , and by putting more money inside education may not have a better outcome .
The truth is the world is changing fast and many developing countries such as China , India and Vietnam are catching up with Singapore .
If Singapore stops her development in education and put her focus mainly in ageing issues , she might lose in the future .
Thus , invest money in education is important , relevant and important .

In  Singapore , ageing population is a major issue that the nation has to deal with , considering the fact that 315 ,800 of the population were at the age of 65 and above in 2008 (Annex .
A); and  that figure will only continue to increase , judging from the constant increment in the median age of our population since 1998  (Statistics 2009) .
It is clear  that public spending on the ageing population is essential .
However , the argument is that there cannot be unlimited public spending directly targeted at the aged because there are other major concerns with the economy and society that the government of Singapore has to deal with .
By placing an unlimited amount of public spending directly targeted at the aged , the government will be neglecting  economical , social and political issues which in a way , act as platforms for achieving better living conditions for the aged  .
There is absolutely nothing wrong in allocating a bulk of the public funds to the aged .
The yearly Singapore Budget Speech actually recognizes the fact that someone has to make a policy  to justify  the  amount of public spending in peace times or states of emergency (Gerald P . O'Driscoll , 2002) .
In addition , from the economic perspective , Singapore will never be a leading nation if there is no control  over public spending  .
Channeling more funds into the financial worldmay provide a higher possibility of a better economy , although no single entity till date can guarantee that .
Nonetheless , the government has to seriously consider the fact that a better economy will bring about higher employment rate , higher real income and lower  inflation as indicated by the Consumer Price Index , and all these will enable  Singaporeans in the workforce to save for the future .
In other words , financial planning , of which Peterson in "A Graying World" states to be a strategy to a new paradigm of ageing , (Peterson 2001) is important .
This is when more than 600 financial institutions in Singapore make the country one of the top ten most sophisticated financial markets in the world  , according to  the World Economic Forum .
(Kei 2009) For the government of Singapore to substantiate its standings in the financial markets of the world , it has to continue to provide incentives , which may come from the areas of world-class infrastructures , investment avenues , tourism and tradeand those that  require a sizeable amount of public spending , in order for the experts in the field to come in .
The government  has to groom potential leaders and scholars to understand the importance of financial planning before they can lead and share .
Grooming then , comes in the form of a more sophisticated infrastructure for learning and monetary incentives or aids in the form of  scholarships and bursaries .
One should not forget  that through the functions of education , the government can increase or influence the citizens' thoughts and awareness on being socially and morally responsible to the populationwhich include the aged as well .
In addition , the government has to work hand-in-hand with social organizations , like the which helps  ethnic groups financially , especially  the  aged . 
In conclusion , we have to consider public spending on the other areas of concerns other than that of an ageing population  
"Public spending on the aged should be limited so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development ."
I do not totally agree with the statement .
A country's developments should be all-rounded but it should not be achieved at the expense of the health care for the elderly in the society .
First and foremost , the elderly are financially vulnerable in the society and need  public funding for their health care .
Though Peterson  (2001) maintains that the elderly could depend less on  public spending by seeking employment or depending more on their families , such a method of reducing and limiting elder dependency is not feasible .
Being old does not mean the loss of health for the elderly , yet there  are  social prejudices against the elderly when they seek for employment at their age .
In this competitive age , employers will tend to favour the non-elderly over the elderly as the latter are nearly retired and often associated with  diseases .
In addition , people are having lesser , if not , no children these days .
In 2008 , Singapore's birth rate was 1 .28 , well below the 2 .1 mark which is needed to meet the future requirements of the Singapore's development .
Such a societal trend reduces the possibility of the elderly tapping on filial obligation from their children to support them in  future .
Therefore , such unfavourable trends continue to place the elderly in need of  public support for their health care .
Where should the limit of  public spending on the aged be drawn  ?
Peterson  (2001) also argues that "health" should be redefined by the government and that the government should draw a limit to its support for the health care of the aged .
A limit on spending would lead to the imposition of a limit on the range of health care for the aged that would be funded by the public .
In the context of health care , different people require  different treatments .
If a certain limit were to be uniformly drawn across the public-funded health care , some elderly could  be cut off from the treatment that they need .
Furthermore , the elderly may suffer from  diseases which tend to be chronic in nature  , like cardiac and rheumatologic diseases .
Prolonged treatment is needed .
Yet , a limit on health care support could mean that some of these elderly would be denied of the necessary medical attention that they need .
There should not be a limit  on  public spending for the health care of the aged .
A balance should be struck in providing for the elderly and concomitantly , driving the country's development .
In The Graying World (2001) , Peterson argues that a lack of limit in public spending would "impoverish future generation" .
However , the withdrawal of governmental support in the health care for the aged would shift the responsibilities of looking after the elderly to the families of these aged and burden the development of the country in the long run .
As argued by Friedland and Summer  (2005) , the costs incurred by the families would "end up getting shifted back to the public sector through less direct and often more expensive means" .
How would this assist in driving the country's development ?
In addition , discontentment could be stirred up as people may question the lack of governmental efforts in the taking care of its citizens .
Therefore , instead of striving for better development for the future generation , setting a limit on health care for the aged could burden and prevent a country from developing better , in the way that it should be .
Public support for the health for the aged is for a real cause .
Hence ,  public spending on the healthcare of the aged should be carried out flexibly and should not be viewed as a hindrance to the development and progress of a nation .
It can be said that aging could be supported by oneself or by one's children and hence the need for public spending would be reduced .
In a modern individualistic culture , a person should be conscious and prepared for his post-retirement .
He should strive for independence and accumulate a surplus of wealth for his old age when he is working .
In an Asian society , where filial piety is stressed , it is the obligation of a child to support his parents; the aged will depend on their children and their own savings to live .
Thus , the emphasis is diverted to other areas of the county's development so that  the country's economy may grow , and the people will have a much larger income to support either themselves or their parents .
Money should be spent on education , research and growing the country's economy so that people can have larger income to tap on .
In addition , instead of spending on the aged , policies could be made to encourage higher birth rates and stress the importance of filial piety as a value so that the aged can  depend on their children .
In this way , focusing on growing the country's economy as a mean to help  support the aged seems  wise .
However , regardless how much the economy is growing , not every person is going to accumulate enough wealth for their old age .
There is a gap between the rich and the poor .
The rich is going to have a wealthy and comfortable life in their post-retirement but the poor is going to struggle with their daily lives paying for the necessary service bills , medical bills and  food .
Elderly who are poor  and who have no children or whose children have deserted them are only going to live on their depleting savings .
If their savings ran out , they would face difficulty acquiring income as their abated bodies may prevent them from finding a job .
They would end up living on the streets if no help were given to them .
Furthermore , these elderly cannot afford expensive medical bills .
Hence , help is heavily needed from the government to keep the poor aged alive .
Grants and subsidies should be given for health check-ups and medical treatments .
Everyday provision of living facilities and food is also needed for those who are poor  , as we should not leave them on the streets .
Hence spending on the aged should not be severely limited .
Besides , long- term medical bills for chronic diseases are so expensive that they undermine an average income person's total wealth .
Diseases that are common to old people , such as cancer , kidney failure and diabetes , require long-term medical attention and  expensive treatment  .
As a result ,  an average income earner would not be able to afford payment even if his income were huge .
While it is very unfortunate to have any of these illnesses , every old person is prone to falling prey to them as their bodies weakened .
While the wealthy could struggle to fight the illness , the average man and below would not be able keep up with the medical bills if no subsidies on medical treatment from the government were given .
Does it mean that he is not going to be allowed continuation of medical treatment to sustain his life ?
Subsidies are needed to sustain medical treatment or elderly who are sick are not going to received adequate treatment .
The aged have work very hard to develop our country in every way and they deserve a good rest for the rest of their lives .
It's ethically not right to leave them on the streets or not to relieve them from the unaffordable medical fees  , just because they have become incapable of contributing to  society .
It is also against human rights to leave a helpless person to be tortured by illnesses and then leave him to die .
Selfishness and cruelly will develop in society when we decide to leave the aged to fend for themselves .
Selfishness undermines unity and cooperation which ultimately will lead to the failure of a society .
Cruelty leads to insensitivity towards death and violence , which may link to increased crime rates .
Hence , if we focused too much on pushing  forward our economy and progress and neglect to take care of our aged , we might just lose  our values  .
By limiting public spending on the aged , there is most likely to be  more old people struggling with medical fees .
It is ethically not right and impractical to limit public spending on the aged to spend on other areas of development .
As each year passes , there seems to be an increase on public spending for the aged .
This seems to be a very popular trend , as a lot of developed countries , such as Spain and the United States of America , tend to increase their public Spending on the elderly .
Public spending is very essential to a country's development , and should be utilised sensibly .
spending on the aged should be limited so that the money can be diverted to other sectors of the country's development  , like public transportation or the army .
Public transportation is one area that could be improved if a country limited its spending on the elderly and raised its spending for the former .
The major problem with public transportation in this country is that it is privately owned and the fares are ridiculously high .
"The privatization of public transport has not delivered the improved service standards nor shorter arrival times , while fares have been increasing based on the justification that being private transport operators , they are not charity and need to make profit for their shareholders ."
(Cheong , 2008) .
According to a Singapore census held in 2000 , around 52% of Singaporeans go to work using public transportation .
That is a staggering figurebecause over half the population uses public transportation , and yet the conditions are  poor and the are high .
This  seems very unreasonable .
The Government can play a major role in creating a solution to this problem .
If they limited the amount being spent on the elderly , they can use their money to  buy back the public transportation , and provide reasonable fares to the public  .
Another thing they can do is improve the conditions of the buses .
Pollution is a growing concern to the environment , as observed by Zolla (1996): "small land area of the central business district led to severe traffic conditions including congestion , reduced traffic speeds , and environmental problems ."
Some of the buses used outside the city are fairly old , and unless they are disposed and substituted by newerbuses ,  the environment is in danger .
These are some reasons why limiting public spending on the aged could contribute to the development of the country .
Another way the government could use  public spending more effectively is to spend more on the Ministry of Community Development , Youth and Sports , which is also known as the MCYS .
By limiting the money being spent on the aged , the government could help a very important sector in the MCYS .
The Ministry's main mission is "to build a cohesive and resilient society .
MCYS seeks to fulfill its mission by fostering socially responsible individuals , strong and stable families , a caring and active community , inspired and committed youth , and a sporting people ."
The main thing here is that they support families .
The most important aim here is to build strong and stable families .
In that way the elderly have their families to look after them .
And if for some reason the younger ones in the family do not help their elders ,  they can be sued under the "Maintenance of Parents Act , which allows parents to sue their children for financial support ."
(Wijaya , 2009) .
This policy clearly shows why the government should limit its spending on the elderly , and spread it around to other more useful sectors .
It is no secret that Singapore has one of the fastest aging populations in the world .
"The island state's median age will rise from 36 presently to 41 by 2030" (Wijaya , 2009) .
Many people would use these figures to support their claims that public spending on the aged should not be limited .
however , it will cause major problems within the country's health care system .
Even though the elderly continue to get money from the public , they still cannot pay their medical bills , nor can their children .
"With the growing number of senior citizens and cash-strapped children who are unwilling or unable to shoulder the burden , the Singapore government will find it difficult not to bear more of the costs ."
(Wijaya , 2009) .
The solution to this problem would be to limit the money spent on the elderly .
The money should go instead to the country's health care expenses .
Countries like Sweden and the United Kingdom face no problems when it comes to healthcare , as over 80% of Health Care expenses are covered by the public funds of both  nations .
That is why it would be a fantastic idea to limit money spent on the aging .
To conclude , it would be very wise of the government to limit its spending on the aged , and to divert the money to other areas of the country's development .
There are a lot of sectors more deserving of the moneythat could be beneficiary to both the young and old , like improving the public transportation in the country .
In the recent years , global aging issues are of significant concern .
The population in many developed countries is aging , and Singapore is no exception .
If fertility rate does not increase , these issues will worsen , as the average age of the population will increase .
If this trend continues , by 2030 ,  one out of every five Singaporeans will be  65 years old or above .
The aging population will definitely cause a great impact on the society .
Over the years , the new researches , developments and policies in Singapore have definitely helped to ease the aging process to a large extent .
And as far as these developments and policies are concerned , ageing workforce and the cost for elderly healthcare are  important factors that the government has to look into .
By looking into these factors , the country can greatly decrease the impact of the liabilities these elderly have on the country .
To prevent the older generations from being a burden to younger generations , the Singapore government has come up with several policies and acts which allow the elderly to stay in the workforce for a longer period of time .
One of the acts enforced is the Retirement Act .
Under this act , the minimum retirement age in Singapore is 62 years old , and thus  allowing the elderly to stay longer in the workforce .
This can be beneficial to them in several ways .
Firstly , they can accumulate more wealth through their work , of which they can then use it to support themselves in their old age .
Secondly , working provides them with a good environment to maintain and even build up their physical and mental health .
This is made possible through communication with their colleagues , which can help them to stay optimistic .
Thirdly , by working longer , they may also help to ease the financial stress of their family members .
Another worry that arises is the cost for health matters .
An ageing population with higher life expectancy is also associated with higher numbers of chronic and other medical conditions .
To help families in Singapore cope with the extensive treatment cost , the Ministry of Community Development , Youth and Sports (MCYS) has come up with services and programmes that provide affordable healthcare and eldercare services .
MCYS have both intermediate and long-term healthcare facilities .
Intermediate healthcare facilities include community hospitals , day rehabilitation centres for the elderly , and long-term healthcare facilities include hospices , home medical , nursing or therapy services and nursing homes .
These facilities mostly cater to the needs of families with financial difficulties .
However , some Singaporeans have the mind set that these services and programmes are not of utmost importance to them as they  have their own medisave account to pay for their hospitalization bills .
Some  Singaporeans might not think that later retirement is a good idea .
For example , companies might think that it is  a burden to hire an elderly worker , as he or she might not be able to cope with the stress and workload  .
There are also worries about the health status of the elderly workers .
Therefore , they would rather hire a worker with higher qualifications , who is more competent , and most importantly , younger .
However , little did they know that the medisave account might be exhausted after a week .
Associate Professor Paulin Straughan said: "One hospitalization , for example , a stroke can set you back at tens of thousands of dollars .
Where are you going to get that money ?"
(Associate Professor Paulin Straughan , 2009) .
Therefore , without the help and support from welfare organizations such as MCYS , majority of Singaporeans might not be able to handle the high cost incurred for taking care of the elderly .
Also , when companies hire a worker , have they ever taken into consideration that experience does play a part in the working society ?
Without the past contributions from these elderly workers , these companies might not be able to be where they are today .
Therefore , it is important that companies try to retain elderly workers , especially when the Singapore government will provide incentives for them when they do so .
Clearly , as our country is nearing the "graying era" , the importance of these policies and acts seems to be more obvious to all .
These can be seen from the willingness of people to stay longer in the workforce , and to be enrolled into the services and programmes provided by MCYS .
Ageing issues can be further eased if family members took the initiative to encourage their elderly members to stay longer in the workforce , so that they can contribute more to the society , and help to ease household financial stress .
The elderly could also accumulate more wealth , and also  stay healthier and wiser .
In the current context , public spending on the aged has been significant , especially in  developed countries such as Singapore .
With better education system , there will certainly be more literate women joining the workforce , and this may result in them having late marriages .
We will also expect the life expectancy of people to increase due to better healthcare facilities and technology .
Without any doubt , it will be common to see an increase in the aging population .
As such , governments were pushed to invest resources , especially  monetary to solve problems  .
These may include  having a barrier free and accessible environment , a scheme to take care of the elderly and subsidies on the healthcare .
This spending on the aged is necessary but should be limited in order to  balance the spending between the aged and the country's developments on infrastructure , education and skills upgrading .
Infrastructure is one of the areas that the government can develop  .
More railway lines can be built to allow easy accessibility  from one location to another .
Expanding the railway line will  reduce the time spent on traveling  .
It focuses on the general public as a whole , which rangesanging from the young to the elderly and handicapped rather than mainly on the aged .
However , as construction is in progress , it often causes high pollution level and is unsightly .
But , the ultimate aim of investing expenditure on such a large scale project is to increase the standard of living of people .
Another instance could be the upgrading of roads to cater to the increasing number of vehicles , and to reduce road congestion .
It also facilitates  driving within Singapore by making it smoother and providing alternatives roads , which were lesser as compared to the past .
We may also have noticed that our buildings are often undergoing maintenance and upgrading , as it is part of the government's scheme to maintain the condition of buildings , minimizing the wear and tear after years and most importantly to create a better environment for the public to live in .
The above mentioned could be another area to which the government can divert their expenditure  .
Education is another area that the government should focus on as it aids in the development of the country .
The government can invest in additional amenities in schools , such as gymnasiums; swimming pools; and indoor sports halls  , so as to provide a conducive environment for the students .
Besides that , expenditure can be channeled into increasing the subsidies in education to encourage people to study .
When people are educated , they will be able  to contribute to the workforce in the near future .
Moreover , funds should also be diverted to provide skills upgrading for the workers  .
For instance , a scheme such as "Skills Programme for Upgrading and Resilience" (SPUR)was introduced to improve and upgrade the workers' skills .
The aim was to increase the employment rate by encouraging  retrenched people or the elderly  to improve and upgrade themselves on the necessary and essential skills to continue to stay in the workforce .
However at times , people may be reluctant to take up such programmes which they perceive as useless .
As Peterson's (2001) has stated , it is important for the elderly to have a later retirement to reduce elderly dependency .
It is a fact that if the elderly were employed , they would be able to support themselves with their savings .
In order to achieve that , the elderly workers  must consistently upgrade themselves to keep up with the existing demands of their jobs  , as employers are looking for the most cost effective resource for the organization .
Thus , this not only benefits the general public but also the aged .
In conclusion , although money spent on the elderly can ease the problem of an aging population , it is only effective for a short term and is not a feasible solution .
It will only create more reliance on the government .
Therefore , we should take into consideration the problems that we will encounter in the long run .
By investing enormously in the aged , other areas of developments for the country will be neglected  , and this will result in more social problems .
Hence , spending on the aged should be restricted  so that  resources  can be divided equally based on the needs of the various sectors .
There should be a limitation on  public spending for the aged .
Over the years , the expenditure on the aged has relatively increased due to a shift towards an aging population .
This is mainly due to the increasing needs of healthcare and welfare services for the elderly .
Should more public spending be used to cater for  the ageing population ?
We need to consider other  sectors   development for the country .
Providing better healthcare and welfare services is more important than before due to the ageing population  .
Policies change over time according to the needs of the elderly  .
As people are enjoying  higher life expectancy today , more spending is expected to provide better healthcare facilities and other services for the aged .
It is observed that in certain countries that are faced with aging population problem , there is an significant increase in hospitalization rates as well as physician services over the years .
However , the increased health costs should not be borne solely by the government .
People are more educated and can work longer to  support themselves today .
Furthermore , to stimulate economic growth , the government needs to work out carefully  the national budget allocated different sectors in the country .
Therefore , we need to consider other government expenditures such as education , infrastructure as well as research and evelopment (R&D) .
Education spending has always been looked upon as a significant matter in the government's agenda .
It has played an important role in supporting economic growth and promoting social integration .
Many education policies have been reviewed and improved over the years to promote the importance of education .
Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam said that "despite the recession , the government will upgrade both the 'hardware' and 'software' of the education system" [ (Tan ,2009) There should be sufficient funds set aside to provide updated facilities for  schools , as well as to maintain the quality of the teaching force .
By ensuring that the younger generations are well educated  , we would be assured of achieving growth and stability for the nation .
Thus ,  public expenditure  on education should never be overlooked .
The government should also focus its spending on developing infrastructure .
The government will increase public sector construction spending to between $18 billion and $20 billion in 2009 .
This is significantly higher than the $15 billion contracted in 2008 and $6 billion in 2007 .
(Key Budget Initiatives , 2009) .
As the economy thrives  , infrastructure such as commercial buildings , bridges , roads and rails are developed constantly .
Infrastructure  reflects  how developed a country is and enables people and goods  move about quickly .
For instance , the transportation network in Singapore is always developing to provide citizens with top grade transportation as far as possible .
A recent development will be the introduction of the Circle Line to the existing MRT network .
Iconic infrastructure developments arethe Integrated Resort (IR) and casino  , which   aimed at attracting foreign investment and tourist attraction .
The remaking of housing estates is seen in various estate renewal programmes such as Home Improvement Programme (HIP) and Lift Upgrading Programme (LUP) .
Expanding infrastructure spending reflects a country's economic favourably and helps  in more foreign investment .
The focus on Research and Development (R&D) has become more prominent  .
Many countries set aside huge amount of government funds for R&D activities .
For example , the South Korean government plans to increase investment in research and development by more than 10 percent a year in 2010 .
Many people see science and technology as a longtime investment and thus expenditure on R&D has not been affected even in the current economic crisis .
Singapore will become a biomedical hub that is globally competitive and will also turn into a trusted centre for scientific and related commercial activities .
Investment in R&D boosts economic growth , increases productivity and generates new product to improve the quality of  lives today .
The needs of a country will  constantly change according to the fluctuation of the economy .
Even though public spending on the aged has increased due to the shift towards an increasingly population , there should be a limit on this spending so as to divert the assets for developing other areas .
The educated aged group  should also be able to   plan for themselves in terms of  healthcare and social services .
The proportion of public spending on  various sectors should be divided properly in order to promote economic growth and maintain a sustainable development for the country .
As fertility rates remain stagnant , many countries are experiencing aging populations .
Governments have thought of many measures  to help improve the aging population situation .
They have invested time and money to research on policies that can help solve the aging population crisis .
Since such a trend is  likely to happen in the short run , much has been done to buffer its negative impact on society .
Therefore , I agree to a large extent , that current research developmentand policies have helped to ease the aging process .
Demographic changes such as a growing population will have  serious consequences on health issues in developed countries .
National budgets and economies will come under pressure as growing numbers of elderly persons are supported by relatively fewer younger persons .
To deal with such challenges , governments have only two options , and one of which is to reduce the future old-age dependency burden by increasing available resources .
This means coming up with policies that can increase the size and productivity of the current and next generation's working-age population .
Alternatively , governments can reduce the amount of money spent on welfare benefits for the elderly .
Firstly , elderly dependency should be reduced by encouraging the elderly to retire later , and by lowering barriers to elder employment .
This can be achieved by increasing the eligibility age for public pensions and government incentives .
As people work longer , the amount of wealth generated would be greater .
If they retired at a younger age , the amount of people left in the work industry would be lesser , resulting in a higher dependency ratio .
By lowering the barriers and making it easier for the elderly to be employed , more elderly people would have jobs and would be able to generate income for the country .
For example , the retirement age in Singapore and Britain used to be 60 and 65 respectively .
However , as of today , the retirement age of Singaporeans has been increased to 62 , and that of Britain is expected to be increased to 68 by 2050 .
This would lead to smaller dependency ratios for both countries , thus lightening the burden on the working class .
The size of today's economy and tax base can also be increased by encouraging greater productivity among the non-elderly .
This can be achieved by sourcing foreign talents from other counties to immigrate to Singapore to contribute to our labour force .
The revenue of the country would in turn increase and the government can use it for other investment and research purposes .
Therefore , the government has been granting permanent residency (PR) status and citizenships more freely than before , as well as providing incentives such as tax rebates to attract foreign companies to invest in Singapore's economy .
The Foreign Talent Policy would thus result in a larger workforce and ultimately lead to increased revenue for the country .
Secondly ,  healthcare for the society is very important .
As the society is facing an aging population problem , the retirement age would increase .
Older people tend to have more health problems and need more medical attention .
They tend to see the doctor more often .
By providing medical benefits and asking them to go for checkups every year , the number of elderly with severe health problems can be reduced .
The government should also spend more money on finding cures for common illnesses that old people are inflicted with .
These measures would ensure that medical problems are treated early and more effectively , thus contributing to a healthier workforce and ultimately , a more productive labour force .
For example , in Singapore , citizens are encouraged to go for medical checkups every year and various medical benefits are provided so as to ensure that our workforce stays healthy and efficient .
However , some may argue that the topic on "health" is very subjective as everyone's body condition is very different .
It is very hard to predict when your body system will malfunction .
The check up could only allow you to have early detection of your illness .
It does not guarantee the recovery from  illness .
Therefore they argue that more and more money would be spent on researching  new technologies to cure the illnesses .
However , research has shown that for many diseases like diabetes , kidney failure , heart diseases and so forth , the chances of recovery are much higher if the disease were diagnosed in the early stages .
Therefore , the opponent's argument does not stand .
In conclusion , I feel that no matter how much research is being done , it will not completely solve the aging problem .
It only helps to alleviate the problems caused by an ageing population .
The only way to really solve this problem is to increase the birth rate of the country .
Only by having  more children will the  burden be spread over a larger and more affluent future generation .
Therefore , I conclude that although current research and development and policies have helped to ease the aging process to a large extent ,  they have not managed to fully solve the problem .
With the decline of fertility rate in recent years , statistics have shown that in Singapore , the ratio of younger persons aged 15-64 to every resident aged 65 and above fell from 10 .4 in 1998 to 7 .5 in 2009 .
This would suggest an imbalance in the population ratio of number of young person to the number of older people .
As a result , Singapore will face the dangers of an aging population .
Hence ,  public spending on the aged will increase .
At the same time , with the rising economy ,  national expenditure would eventually increase .
"The family has traditionally been the main source of support for the elderly in Asia , and Singapore is no exception .
In recent decades , academic debate has centered upon gauging the effect of modernization or industrialization on levels of familial support  .
This interest intersects with the awareness of policymakers in Asia that traditional family support of the elderly may decline in future ."
(Cowgill and Holmes , 1972) .
This would indicate that the government should be prepared to meet the need of welfare services for the aged .
For instance , facilities such as Day Care Centres and Old Folks Homes will be in high demand as the ratio of the elderly to the younger generation is higher in the near future .
In the long run , if the government focused only on the development of the country and neglected the aged , it will result in economic inequality of "the poor getting poorer , the rich getting richer" concept .
This would cause the people to lose their motivation to work harder for the country  , as well as their belief in filial piety which is commonly known in Asia .
In Singapore , the government has strongly upheld the belief that familial support of the elderly is ideal , but if the individual family could not handle their aged , the government would have to interfere to help .
However , focusing solely on the aged population would not be the best approach .
The government should also focus on other areas that contribute to the development of the country , such as education , technology , military and research and development (R&D) .
This is because there is still a need to contribute to the country's economic growth   to sustain the well-being of its people .
The government can limit its expenditure on the medical fees for the older population and use the money to invest in the education of the younger population and develop the country .
Community centres can organise more activities to encourage the older generation to exercise and stay healthy .
This would  decrease the percentage of them being sick and also help them to build  healthier and happier lifestyles .
However , too much help from the government can lead to its people being too dependent on the government .
This would result in  the lack of motivation to work .
Therefore , the government can introduce policies to encourage its people to invest in their future during the early stages of their lives .
This is to ensure that when they do not have the ability to work anymore , they will still be able to support themselves without much help from the government .
In conclusion , public spending on the aged should have a limit .
This will allow the people to learn to be more independent in supporting themselves when they retire .
This would not only benefit the nation's development but also improve its the well-being of its people .
Furthermore , better education for the younger generation would lead  .
Even though there is a need to support the aged , the efficiency of the country should not be compromised .
Due to the advancement in technologies and the implementation of efficacy policies by the Singapore government , the problems that accompanied the aging process have been alleviated to a large extent .
Take for instance , in the past , due the lack of current research and developments available , most elderly who were diagnosed with illnesses were unlikely to recover and in most cases , they would have to stay in bed for the rest of their lives .
Furthermore , in the past , elderly  spinsters and bachelors of whom they have no family members to turn to in their old age , often faced financial problems after they have stopped working .
However , unlike the past , most elderly now are coping well with the aging process  physically , economically and mentally .
As indicated in the statistics pertaining to the health status of the senior citizens ( National Survey of Senior Citizens , 2005) , it is stated that "among senior citizens aged 55 and above , only 35 .8% reported to have a clean bill of health ."
As such , it would seem that despite the great advancement in the area of medical technologies , a substantial percentage of the elderly is still suffering from medical ailments such as high blood pressure , bone or joint problems , diabetes and sight problems .
This may suggest that the current medical technologies have not helped to ease the aging process .
On a closer look , although the present medical technologies may not be able to slow down the aging process , these technologies may help to prevent  medical ailments from occurring and also in some cases , alleviate the sufferings which the elderly have to go through .
For example , the invention of high blood pressure and diabetes monitors helped people , especially the elderly to be more aware of and to be more able to monitor their own health conditions .
With proper medication , the 2 medical ailments would have a lower probability to lead to kidney damage  .
The  treatment of this illness is more difficultthan the common ailments .
As such , the advancement in medical technologies have shown to ease the aging process through  medical innovationsthat  prevent common ailments from exacerbating into serious illnesses  .
Although , in today's context , around 66% of the senior citizens aged 55 and above are provided with regular cash contributions from their children( National Survey of Senior Citizens , 2005) , there is still a significant number of senior citizens who faced financial difficulties in their old age , especially if these senior citizens are retired singles .
Hence , in order to aid the elderly through the aging process , the Singapore government has implemented several policies and measures to ensure that there is adequate protection for the elderly .
One good illustration would be the new CPF LIFE scheme (Introduction to CPF life) that will be launched in September 2009 .
Under this new scheme , it will offer members with a life-time income whereby the members will receive a sum of money monthly for as long as they live and the amount will depend on the cash savings they have in their Retirement Account .
Furthermore , besides ensuring that the elderly will have sufficient funds for their living expenses after their retirement , the Singapore government also ensures that the elderly are able to cope with the hefty and long term medical expenses in their old age through the implementation of policies such as the Eldershield (Healthcare Financing , year) .
"ElderShield is an affordable severe disability insurance scheme which provides basic financial protection to those who needs long-term care , especially during old age" (citation) .
Thus , the elderly will be able to draw on the monthly payout to aid in paying for his or her long-term care expenses .
Hence , with the implementation of such policies , majority of the financial difficulties that the senior citizens faced in their old age would be alleviated .
The elderly would be able to rely on the monthly payouts from the various schemes to cope with their everyday lives even if they had stopped working .
Lastly , the grieving process (Old Adult Mental Wellbeing , Health Promotion Board , year) is part and parcel of the aging process whereby for the elderly , it is more common for them to lose their family members and friends in their old age and thus , this makes each single loss even more unbearable .
However , with the current developments and advanced medical help available , these sufferings would be reduced .
The healing process will only start if the elderly are willing to seek and accept support from various sources .
For instance , one such facility development of which the elderly would be able to seek help from would be the REACH Elderly Care Centre  , where the elderly would be able to receive day care , supervision and supportive help .
In addition , the place also serves to offer ample opportunities for the senior citizens to mingle with other people and take on meaningful activities so that they would be healthier  both mentally and physically .
Furthermore , with the advancement in medical sciences ,  the elderly can also seek professional help such as consulting the therapists and psychologists to assist them in getting over the grieving process , if the intensity of the grief does not fade off after a long period of time .
As such , with the different types of facilities and medical developments available , the elderly no longer have to suffer in silence .
This further substantiates the fact that current research and development have indeed helped to ease the aging process .
It is ironic that how everybody wants to have longer life expectancy but yet , no one wants to grow old .
Nevertheless , the aging process is  an unavoidable , undesirable , problem-ridden phrase of life that we are required to go through  .
However , with the advancement of technologies and implementation of effective policies , the problems associated with the aging process are eased to a large extent . . With the help of the technologies and various , the elderly would definitely be able to better manage their lives in  old age  .
The Singapore population comprises  its citizens and permanent residents .
Between the year 1947 and 1964 ,  approximately 1 million babies were born .
These baby-boomers will reach 65 years old by 2012 and form the largest aged population that Singapore has ever experienced .
Therefore , the government of Singapore should not limit public spending on the aged .
Singapore is a developed country where the government has already spent millions on the country's development .
Singapore's government has invested millions of dollars over the  years to ensure that Singapore grows as a modern and sophisticated city .
The government has pumped money into various areas such as the transportation system , infrastructure , education , technology , health and welfare benefits for its people .
The government uses these developments  to boost the economy .
Singapore's transportation system is well-known to be one of the best in the world .
Almost all parts of Singapore are very accessible by road .
Another factor is the education system in Singapore .
The government promotes tertiary education to acknowledge its importance .
As one of the developed countries in the world , Singapore has only its citizens as its resource .
The government hopes that with compulsory education , its people will be provided with the necessary skills to foster the economy .
Although the standard of living in Singapore has increased , Singapore citizens are  able to cope with it .
This is because the government provides subsidies to the people in  housing , healthcare and education .
With these developments , Singapore has produced a skilled workforceand an and efficient infrastructure  .
These developments attract many foreign investors to  this country .
Today , there are about 3000 Multinational Corporations (MNCs) from all around the world .
Factors which have attracted the MNCs to do business here is  a corruption- free government .
Hence , MNCs feel safe and secure to trade and set up businesses in Singapore .
In fact , the strategy used by Singapore's government has proved to be a success .
For  instance , The economyhas shown  growth that averaged at 8 .0% between 1960 and 1999 to 9 .9% in 2000 .
As a developed nation , Singapore has already established herself .
There is not much  that the government needs to spend on developing the nation .
With a skilledworkforce , advanced facilities and infrastructure  , as well as  with the presence of MNCs , Singapore's economy is expected to grow in years to come .
Water , housing , transport and infrastructure are already available .
The issue is to maintain them  .
Advanced facilities and infrastructure such as the upcoming Integrated Resorts (IR) are expected to draw millions of tourists to Singapore .
Hence , it will benefit the economy .
Now the government should focus on sustaining and maintaining all these developments that are already in existent .
Furthermore , land is scarce in Singapore .
Singapore economy will still be unpredictable .
Knowing that the baby-boomers would reach 65 years old by 2012 , the government should invest on them .
This is necessary because if the baby boomers started to pull  their money out of the banks and the stock market , it will affect the total government spending .
They may not be able to pay taxes if they have lost their jobs and thus , the government should consider spending its funds wisely .
It should be aware of issues that Singapore will be facing in years to come  .
Thus , this would allow  to   remain employable .
By working longer , baby boomers could accumulate savings for retirement and  share their and experience with the society .
More funds are required to encourage later retirement  .
It is only through upgrading of skills and knowledge that the effectiveness of elderly employees would be increased .
Although the elderly are prone to illnesses and more funds are for them as compared to the younger employees in an organisation , they have the experience to guide the younger employees .
Due to a fast-paced and stressful working environment  , the elder generations would not be motivated to extend their stay in the workforce .
Thus , the government should nurture the younger generations to be productive through the use of public funds .
Although the elderly could only do the minimum for the society and the country , they made up a higher percentage of the population and should not be ignored .
There is a need to develop a  sense of urgency  over the an ageing population issue .
In shaping Singapore's economy , the government should not neglect the social issues associated with ageing population .  
According to  Singapore Department of Statistics , the Singapore resident population has grown older with the median age of resident population rising from 35 years old in 2003 to 36 .4 years old in 2007 .
The proportion of elderly person in Singapore aged 65 years and above increased from 7 .4 per cent in 2003 to 8 .5 per cent in 2007 , making it  the second fastest an an ageing population in the world after Japan .
The increase in life expectancy and decline in fertility are the two main causes of ageing population .
Singapore is concerned with the growth ofageing population because many older persons have minimal or no income .
Public spending on the aged should  not be limited , though other aspects of public spending should not be compromised too .
This is to maximize spending on the aged .
The burden on an average working class adult has increased with yearly inflation and higher standards of living .
Pressure on the working population will be exceptionally high  which may in turn cause social problems .
Therefore , health care for the aged should be included as part of the public expenditure fund  , to lighten the burden of the working population  .This is an investment that should not be overlooked .
The elderly often find themselves abandoned by their children  , and this is due to a greater emphasis on individualism among the younger generation  .
This has  eroded  traditional values such as filial piety .
Hence , the government can intervene by supporting the elderly using public spending to make sure that they are self-sufficient .
Policies implemented by the Singapore government like Medisave and Medifund are good examples .
In addition , the government should provide for public facilities , amenities and services , to cater to the needs of the ageing population .
These include day care centres , wheelchair-friendly access , subsidies for medical costs and transport .
Therefore , government spending on the aged is important and should not be limited .
Having established that public spending on the aged should not be limited , other aspects of government spending , however , should not be neglected  .
Money could be diverted to tourism and military uses ,  as these may be  crucial areas  that require public spending .
Money could be diverted to the tourism industry where it plays a key role in contributing to the country's income .
According to the Singapore Tourism Board , Singapore achieved a record of 9 .7 million visitors in 2006 , from 8 .9 million in 2005 , and is hoping to achieve a target of 17 million visitors by 2015 .
In order to achieve the target , Singapore has recently invested a substantial amount of money into the  development of the two integrated resorts in order to remain competitive among Asian countries and other popular tourist attractions .
The Integrated Resort is one of the many strategies that Singapore adopts to generate more economic growth and boost the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) .
Compared to the many areas of development , military defense is among one of the important  because it serves as a deterrent to protect a country's sovereignty .
Money spent on purchasing weapons and armours is necessary to ensure that the military men of the nation are well-equipped in an event when war occurs .
In addition , money could also be expended on local or overseas training to ensure that the military men are trained with relevant knowledge to defend the country .
There are many areas where public spending should be used for a country's development .
In developed countries like Singapore and Japan where ageing population is an issue , the importance of public spending on the aged can outweigh that of other aspects .
On the other hand , developing countries may invest most of their public spending on infrastructure instead of on the aged because economic development is likely to be their primary objective .
It would be unwise to limit healthcare spending on the aged since different countries have different needs .
In conclusion , public spending on the aged should not be limited  .
Instead , the government should allow its public spending on the aged to hover at certain percentage .
In this materialistic world where we live in , when something loses its value , it will be forgotten  .
Many elderly are neglected by their children and have become homeless  .
There was  case of a daughter who cheated  her mother into selling her apartment  and taking away the  money , leaving her mother homeless on the street .
The  National Welfare Association will lessen the burden of  neglected elderly by providing shelters for them in Old Folks Home  .
However , such approaches will  not remove the root cause of the problem .
In addition , it will generate the idea that it is okay not to look after the elderly as the government will step in and provide the elderly a to stay .
This  will only encourage more infilial children to neglect their elderly parents .
Hence ,  sustainable solutions to the aging problem  start with  the children who are supposed to be taking care of them .
The root cause starts with children who have no wish to take care of their parents .
This can be due to many reasons .
One of which is the lack of financial income .
Japan is known to have many homeless elderly and by analyzing  the country' performance , it is known that Japan has the highest expenses among many countries .
Besides the cultural aspect , this gives us a slight indication that the people there may have problem handling their finance .
In Singapore , this is especially true for people who fall under the sandwich generation that have to pay for the expenses of their children and  parents .
Taxpayers' money  can be used to generate more jobs and higher income for the people , resulting in better economic growth .
In this way , the children will have better financial means to take care of their parents .
Educating the society on aging issue helps in the long run .
Just like  isues such as  smoking and yellow ribbon , the issue of aging  should be highlighted in the country .
This approach not only brings awareness to the people , but also educates  the people on what will happen to the elderly when they are being neglected .
Understanding the issue will change the way the society thinks about aging elderly , taking it to the level of humanity instead of practicality .
Laws should also be implemented  to help control the issue of the elderly being neglected .
Fine should be made on families that neglect their parents .
Laws should not be made severe , as there are also many reasons to why one has to neglect their elders .
Issues like financial problems and time allowance may prevent one from taking care of their elderly .
In this way ,   the welfare of the elderly will be taken care of by their families and the number of homeless elderly will be lessened .
In a nutshell , public spending should be  wisely used to provide aids to the elderly .
Instead of giving help directly to the  elderly , the government should tackle the root of the problemby getting the people  to take care of their elderly parents .
This can be done by improving on the economy , educating the young on the importance of taking care of the elderly and implementing laws  .
These approaches may not produce immediate effects , but they are useful for the future generations .
Throughout the years , the issue of aging has become a tremendous challenge for the developed countries .
Due to an increase in the standard of living , better medical treatment is available and this has caused the life expectancy of the people to increase .
People are marrying later in life and this has caused a fall in the fertility rate .
Young people are now faced with the insurmountable task of supporting an ever increasing population of the aged .
As a result , public spending on the aged has been on the increase .
Some may think that it is a waste of the taxpayers' money to fund such a spending as there can be no potential benefits to be reaped .
However is this the correct attitude to hold towards the elderly ?
Should we hold back the aid for the aged who had contributed to the country's success ?
That shouldn't be the case .
This essay will argue that public spending on the aged should not be limited to a large extent .
It will touch on the moral issues inherent and also argue that it is actually detrimental to a country's future if its aged are not well taken care of , even if the money saved by limiting public spending on the elderly is spent developing other areas such as education and research and development .
At first glance , spending on education may seem to be more important than aiding the elderly as what we teach the youths will determine the future of the nation .
An education provides a platform for the youths to face the challenges in the future .
When faced with difficult decisions , the analytical skills learnt in school will help us to determine how to deal with these problems .
Hence , for a small country such as Singapore of which human resource is the key factor to  success , it is important that the citizens constantly upgrade themselves with the latest knowledge .
Therefore , the government should devote more capital to ensure that the education system remain relevant in today's dynamic global economy .
This certainly seems to be more important than pouring money into public spending for the elderly .
Some may say that it is more important for a country to have an excellent research and development sector than healthy , happy senior citizens .
Research and development plays an important role in the innovation process which results in high quality products and  successful businesses .
Research and development will very likely increase the levels of overseas investment as foreign multinational companies will see the country as a good place for business .
Therefore , with a strong research and development sector , a country will be more likely to succeed economically .
Again , public spending on research and development seems definitely to be more important than spending public money on the elderly .
After all , what can a group of healthy , well taken care of senior citizens bring to the country ?
Their knowledge has long become obsolete and there's not much value they can bring to a country anymore .
However , is it really true that the elderly is irrelevant to a country's development ?
This is not the case .
When the government provides sufficient money to look after the elderly , what is developed is the intangible moral value of gratitude and piety .
When a nation looks after their elderly without reservations , the lesson conveyed to its populace is that one should always look after the people who have contributed to our development .
As a result , what we learn then is to be grateful to the people who have aided us .
Such values are the essential element of the society .
It helps create strong lasting bonds between citizens and the result will be a more cohesive nation .
What about education and research and development ?
A strong education system and a strong research and development sector in a country that is not unified and chaotic will not be able to reap the benefits that they are supposed to generate .
Thus , public spending on the elderly does provide important benefits to the country and should not be limited  .
Lastly , a country that does not take care of its elderly sufficiently runs the risk of having its younger population abandoning it and migrating to other countries .
No one would like to stay in a country with insufficient care for them in the future .
Majority of them would think that their hard work have not paid off .
They have worked so hard to contribute to the economy but   the government does not provide sufficient care for them when they are old .
Hence , no more future leaders will be staying back to help the country to boost  the economy and run the country .
Therefore , public spending on the elderly should still be continuedin the form of financial policies and benefits .
In conclusion , we should not see the elderly as a burden but an asset .
Even though other sectors such as education and research and development are important to us , we should not forget our earlier contributors .
They are the ones who build up a nation from the basic to what we have now .
Therefore , we must be grateful to those who have helped us and created a sense of belonging to everyone .
In this way , younger generation will then work harder for the nation in  future .
The baby boom in the 1960s and the current low fertility rate in Singapore has made Singapore into one of the fastest aging population in the world .
Living expenditure for the elderly has increased in terms of  rising medical costs and standard of living .
Therefore , it is necessary for the government to review the public policies for the elderly .
Essentially , the expenditure used to finance medical and welfare programs should be proportionate to the larger aging population .
The people are the assets of Singapore and they have contributed to the country's strong economic position .
As the population aged , it is the responsibility of the government to take care of its people .
Spending on the aged should not be limited .
The improvement in medical research has lengthened the life expectancy of the people .
However ,  longer life spans will inevitably incur a larger amount of long term health care expenses for the aged and the deterioration of physical mobility and communication might cause them to lose the ability to work and be self-sustained .
The situation is worse for a segment of the elderly  who are unmarried and inadequately educated .
They stand in the least advantageous position should there be a limit on  public spending on the aged because they do not have families to depend on and the depletion of their savings will eventually result in  starvation and homelessness .
Moreover , without the government's support for the elderly , the burden of caring for these elderly will fall solely on the "sandwich generation"of   individuals who will be financially responsible for their family , children and parents .
This is especially straining for individuals who are less financially well off .
In the long run , this financial responsibility may be too much for the working population to bear .
Hence , there is a need for the government to intervene by using part of the public funds to care for the aged population and ease the burden on the working population .
Singapore has invested much of our public spending on the other areas of the country's development  , like defence and the economy .
Although these areas of development are necessary for the  development of Singapore , we should not neglect the importance of public spending for the aged .
By providing more for the elderly and improvising health care polices , the government can actually improve the living conditions of the aged  , which will in turn reduce possible social issues .
Furthermore , if the government can maintain social stability in its country , it may then focus on the other aspects ,  such as defence .
Ultimately , it is the responsibility of the working population and the the government to take care of the elderly .
Other than taxation from the working population which is compulsory , it is necessary to garner support from the government to provide social welfare services , day-care centres , social support and improvisation of health systems .
Such coordination between the working population and government will benefit the aged who are concerned with the provision of welfare from the state and this will give them a sense of security .
An ageing population is a worldwide issue that is faced by all countries .
As a population gets older there are  social , political and economical impact on everyone .
The social impact would be that people  have to work harder because  the younger generations have to be more productive to make up for the elderly's low productivity .
An aging population will have a serious consequence on health issues in developed nations because more medical support will be needed by the elderly .
National budgets and economies will come under pressure as growing numbers of elderly persons are supported by relatively fewer younger persons .
It will hinder the countries' growth in the long run because more tax payers' money will be used for public spending on the aged .
However , public spending should be diverted to other areas of the countries' development , like the economy and the technological sector , which may help in prolonging and enhancing the quality of life for the elderly .
Investing in  economic growth will reduce the stress on the younger generation as more jobs will be  will be available  .
More businesses will start and more jobs will be created  ,  , which means more people will be employed  .
Thus , there will be  more income tax which means more government funds to help support the elderly .
When more work is available , more people will be able earn and save more  , and this  means that the standard of living for the working people will improve and they will be able to support the elderly as they are more affluent .
An increase in economic growth will also mean that people are earning more  , and thus there will be an increase in the taxes  which  will be used in providing better medical support to the elderly  .
Thus ,  this will provide for both the working people  and the elderly  .
Investing in technology in the form of research and development will allow  medical advancement as well as better facilities for medical cares .
New drugs or medicine will be available for the sick elderly and more cures for diseases and sickness will be available to help the elderly This may reduce the stress on the working force in the sense that they don't have to worry about their elderly parents .
New technology or medicine to prolong and enhance the quality of life will be available for the elderly and this will reduce the stress on the working force  and in return increase its productivity  as they are more focused at work and they are able to  spend more time at work .
This will allow for better economical growth for the country  , which in turn means more funds for the government to spend on the elderly  .
Investing in the social welfare of  working adults by providing better qualities of life and better living standards will help to reduce their stress and allow them to  provide better for the elderly .
Some of the facilities provided by the Singapore government were  park connectors  near working industries and central business district  .
This  allows working people to enjoy working and still have a good quality of life .
This helps to encourage working people to work and play better and gives them a better standard of living .
In conclusion , public spending on the aged should be limited and the money should be diverted to the other areas of the countries' development , like economic growth , research and development and the welfare of the people  .
This will allow  the people to solve their own financial problem  and allow the government to invest and provide for other areas of the country's development .
Public spending has constantly been an issue in any nation .
Politicians and law-makers are often debating on how much money should be spent on each sector of the country .
With the rising number of elderly in an aging nation , the amount of money spent in this sector would increase as well .
However , there are other areas that require cash inflow to facilitate and push the society forward .
Such areas include the military sector , the security sector , the education sector , the research and development sector , etc .
Thus , the government should not spend too much on the elderly and neglect the rest of society .
When one grows old , his body will go through many and soon , he will not be as fast or agile as he was before .
The government steps in to make the environment more user-friendly  , which includesthe installation of  handrails along steps and stairs , the building of  gentle slopes around the housing estates and the upgrading of lifts to stop at every floor in older flats .
The elderly become more vulnerable to illnesses and diseases as they age and it would take a much longer for them to recover , unlike during their younger days .
Rising medical costs and inflation would pose  a problem for the aged , even for those who had prepared an amount of savings for their golden years .
The government would get involved once again to provide subsidies for the elderly in medical bills and so on .
Terrorism is a growing threat today as it is getting more complicated to understand the terrorists and fight them .
