Technology can be used as a solution to cope with the current healthcare challenges we are faced with .
However , in the future , healthcare systems have to be reformed to deal with the increased needs of healthcare support required by the aged .
While the advancement in healthcare industry can help prevent diseases and other consequences of aging , medicine alone is inadequate .
A healthy lifestyle is important for the elderly to enable them to cope with stresses physically , emotionally and mentally .
It also helps to reduce the risk of disease .
An ageing population is currently a global phenomenon that occurs in many parts of the world .
Singapore has currently one of the fastest growing ageing population in Asia , with the current one in twelve citizens being the age of 65 and over set to increase to every one in five in 2030 .
Hence , public spending on the aged in Singapore has a high possibility of rising in order to cope with the shift in aging structure .
However , limitations should be set on the public spending on the aged to a large extent in order to promote the country's development in other areas .
In Singapore , where there is a reasonably low birth rate and top-notch health care which helps prolong people's lives , population aging is inevitable , hence being prospective-looking , the strategy that is feasible would be to reallocate  funds and attention to other areas , in particular , Education and Tourism .
The diversion of capital into the Education Sector will enable Singapore to identify more opportunities .
Singapore is presently building an education hub in Asia , investing millions of funds to boost her image and economy .
As foreign students start pouring into Singapore , it is projected that education services will generate about five percent of the gross domestic product .
Moreover , a high quality education system will be beneficial for the next generation , as exhibited by the ripple effect .
The increased education quality will extend an average Singaporean's working span allowing an increase accumulation of savings .
This will indirectly help to solve some of the problems posed by an ageing population , as it will help to reduce elderly dependency and changing Singapore into an independent society where elderly will be less reliant on the government .
The tourism industry is another area Singapore should divert her funds into as the industry is highly influential , affecting other related industries such as the hotel and service industries .
The tourism industry posted high revenue of S$14 .8 billion in 2008 , a 4 .8% increase from 2007 .
This increase has demonstrated the potential of Singapore's tourism industry and making full use of every opportunity presented in this sector will be vital , owing to the colossal impact this industry has on other industries .
For instance , the upcoming Integrated Resorts (IR) will without a doubt stimulate a positive impact on the economy , both financially and image-wise .
Therefore , by reallocating more funds and attention to this industry , it will bring about a positive change in the Singapore tourism industry and economy as a whole .
Nevertheless , the choice to not limit the public spending on the aged will only help to solve today's problem of the ageing population .
On the other hand , diverting capital to the education and tourism sectors will not only help with the country's developments , but will also help to solve the current problems with today's generation of the aged .
This win-win situation will allow Singapore to embrace itself for the future challenges and reduce elder dependency .
In conclusion , the decision whether to limit public spending for the aged in order to divert it into other areas is a very debatable issue .
With many pros and cons on both sides , this issue will definitely meet many different opinions from different people .
Nonetheless , the decision to divert funds to other area's for development such as education and tourism will be the most viable one , solely because of the fact that not only does it help with Singapore's development , but also coping with challenges that arises with an  ageing population indirectly with time to come .
Hence , Singapore should continue to focus and direct her attention and spending onto the tourism and education sector so as to reinforce the country's development and strength .
Old age , for a normal person , is the last stage that one has to go through in his life .
This is the stage when the elderly have to face the changes in their physical appearances and also mental sensitiveness .
They start to have wrinkles on their face and their hair colour turns gray or white .
Their memory power starts to become weak and they tend to forget things easily .
This aging process has made old people suffer from functional and mental disabilities , causing them to feel inferior and being alienated .
This is the time when the psychological practitioners and the government have to step in to help ease the aging process of the elderly .
Psychological treatments have helped the elderly to cope with their emotional problems .
People tend to be emotionally unstable when they reach old age .
This is because they feel they are not capable of doing things that they can do when they were still young .
They have problems getting promoted or hired because of their age , and also are afraid of being asked to retire earlier , causing them to have work pressure .
Special care that they receive from their family members and the society makes them feel old , and indirectly contributes to their emotional problems .
These may , sometimes , lead to depression .
Most people think that psychological treatments are meant for those who have serious mental problems .
They feel ashamed and choose not to approach psychologists when they are emotionally unstable or depressed .
It is this kind of misconception they possess which causes their mental illness to worsen A professional person , in this case , the psychologists , can offer help by counselling the elderly and giving them useful advice to encourage them that they are not the group of people who always require special help from the others , and also to let them feel that they are accepted by the society .
The government can help ease the aging process of the elderly through the implementation of social policies which encourage later retirement , longer working life and lower barrier for the employment of the elderly (Peterson , 2001) .
By working longer , the elderly can accumulate more wealth , which can be used in their post-retirement life .
Some people may say that old people's working ability starts to decrease when they approach retirement age .
The aging workforce will then decrease  work productivity and lower the nations economic development .
However , it is proven by John Rowe and Robert Kahn in their study that those who continue to work and participate in social activities after their retirement life are very unlikely to experience physical and mental decline .
There are still a portion of elderly persons who age successfully .
The working experiences of some elderly individuals can be  a good asset to the development of the society .
Therefore , in order to introduce this policy , the government has increased the retirement age of working persons , and has given fewer incentives to fund their after-retirement life , so that they will prolong their working life .
In conclusion , psychological treatments such as counselling and also the implementation of government's social policies have helped to ease the aging process .
Although it has become an arising issue that the aging population will have a great impact on society and also the economic growth of the country , more emphasis should be given to the older generation , as they are an important asset to the nation .
Therefore , more measures have to be taken to make the aging process an easier one for the elderly .
In general , our society is aging and there are problems associated with an aging population .
In Asia , Singapore is one of the fastest aging populations .
According to Inter-Ministerial Committee on Aging Report (1999) , currently 7% of its population is over the age of 65 , and this number will increase to 19% by 2030 .
There are three broad aspects of problems associated with the ageing process , namely the physical , emotional and financial aspect .
Physically , the aged will feel weak and body ailments will increase as a result of wear and tear of the body .
Emotionally , the elderly will feel lonely as their parents , friends and in some cases their life partner has departed .
Financially , the old no longer work and they can only depend on their savings or their children for their daily expenses .
Current policies such as Medisave , HDB's rules on housing where the young live near their parent and parents' maintenance act are therefore put in place .
Unfortunately , these policies have played a little role to ease the aging process for most of the elderly .
Currently , there are policies implemented to help the aging population in three different areas , physical , emotional and financial .
First , the elderly have weaker health and are more susceptible to chronic illnesses .
Medisave policy is introduced to aid in healthcare needs such as paying hospitalization expenses and selected outpatient treatments .
Next , to meet the elderly needs of emotional support , the government implemented additional grants on HDB housing to foster family bonding .
To illustrate , if couples are staying near or together with their parents , they have priority over regular applicants when they apply for new HDB flat .
Similarly , those buying resale flats benefit from a higher housing grant , approximately an additional of 10 ,000 dollar .
In this way , it enables the young to continuously get in touch with their parents .
Moreover , the elderly can help to take care of their children , if any .
Lastly , the  elderly lose income upon retirement , therefore , they have to depend on their savings or children for their expenses .
In cases where the elderly cannot support themselves financially and their children refuse to take care of them , Maintenance of Parents Act had been implemented in 1996 .
Consequently , parents can demand financial maintenance from their children through family court .
On the contrary , "the elderly will use between three and five times more health-care services compared to the younger generation" (Straits Times , 2007) , thus Medisave would be still inadequate to assist most of the elderly in their course of aging .
Besides , Medisave can be easily drained especially on chronic illnesses , which can tote up to a huge amount .
Furthermore , women of older generation in Singapore had particularly low average incomes because they received lesser education .
As a result , the amount of money in their Medisave will be very limited .
Moreover , most of the aged Singaporeans are not insured by anything else .
In essence , most of the old remains incapable to afford their medical expenses despite with the help of Medisave .
Even though it is essential for the government to allocate public spending on the aged since the effects of the ageing population will impact the national economy and society , unlimited funding on the aged may have negative implications on the economy .
By 2030 , the number of elderly in Singapore will increase to 18 .7% and the number of working persons supporting one elderly person will decrease to 3 .5 persons .
These statistics have proven that population aging is enduring and this means that tackling the challenges that come along with it is a long term process for the government and government spending on the aged will continue to increase .
Hence , unlimited funding instead of proper allocation of public spending on the aged may drain the economy .
Since a primary source of revenue for public spending comes from taxation , the government will have to increase the tax rates in order to finance its unlimited spending on the ageing population .
This may lead to unhappiness in and weariness of the working population especially given that the number of working persons supporting an elderly has decreased .
High levels of taxation may also lead to a decrease in domestic and foreign investments .
Unlimited funding may discourage people from staying employed and accumulating savings to see them through their old age as they may have the tendency to rely on the benefits provided by the government .
Unemployment will cause the workforce to shrink and result in an economic slowdown .
Therefore , it is important for the government to develop policies like the Central Provident Fund Scheme that helps the government to limit spending and assist the elderly to be self sufficient at the same time .
As the only natural resource available in Singapore is people , human capital is crucial to the survival and progress of the nation .
Hence , the Singapore government should be far-sighted to see the value of education and should set aside funds to continue investing in it .
In order to have a well-trained workforce to cope with a knowledge-based economy of the 21st century , the government has to provide  more funds to ensure that the people are receiving a more all-rounded education by introducing a more extensively planned academic program , building more educational institutions and hiring and training more educators .
The Singapore government has unveiled in its 2001 concept plan that the vision for Singapore in the 21st century is to become a thriving world-class city .
In order to become a world-class city , the government has to pump in funds to rejuvenate and upgrade existing areas for living and working , creating more recreational space and continue to develop the commercial and industrial sectors .
A world-class city also means that the nation should be safe and secure .
Thus , the government also has to invest in research and development of defense technology which can deter small and vulnerable Singapore from any potential invasion .
As evident , the government has to handle many areas of concerns with regards to developing the nation into a world-class city .
Therefore , the government may require several years and a huge amount of public spending to achieve the vision of becoming a world-class city .
The challenges that come along with an ageing population are unavoidable and Singapore has to make preparations now to confront them .
Even though the government has implemented measures such as the CPF scheme and building of more healthcare institutions , more remains to be done .
As the pace of population ageing increases with time , the issues may become more complex because of the changing expectations and preferences of the population .
With a demand for a higher standard of living , the government may have to divert more public spending to look after the increasing needs of the aged .
However , as the government also needs to focus public spending on other areas of developments , the government can look into adopting an integrated approach which urge better cooperation between key agencies and emphasize the need for community support .
Everyone has a responsibility to assist seniors living among us and people need to change their mindset of seeing the elderly as  a burden to the society when in actual fact , the elderly are the knowledgeable and experienced resources of the society .
According to the United Nations (UN) the number of elderly people has tripled in the past 50 years and will continue to rise in the near future .
In developed countries , the median age rose from 29 .0 in 1950 to 37 .3 in 2000 , and is forecasted to increase to 45 .5 by 2050 .
Declining fertility , along with longer life expectancy , attributes to an aging population .
In order to cope with the rising numbers of elderly , the government has increased public spending on health care programs and subsidiaries .
Although an aging population is a global phenomenon , public spending should also be allocated in other areas of the country's development such as tourism or housing to help increase economic growth , to make Singapore a global city .
One of the major problems the elderly face today is the lack of financial security .
Singapore is not a welfare state unlike countries such as America and the United Kingdom .
Elderly who were not able to save enough will face the problem of making ends meet when they are old .
Furthermore , global inflation and rising medical costs will add to their financial burden .
Thus , their only solution is to turn to the government for assistance .
The Singapore government has recently introduced a new CPF policy which provides lifelong income for the elderly , instead of the current policy where payouts only last about 20 years .
However , such programs are a burden on the country's budget .
Tourism is an important aspect that Singapore could further dispense its budget on .
According to the Singapore Tourism Board , in 2006 , Singapore achieved a record of 9 .7 million visitors , compared to 8 .9 million in 2005 .
An estimated sum of $12 .4 billion was spent .
Singapore hopes to achieve a record of 17 million visitors by the year 2015 .
With such a high volume of tourists , more hotel rooms are required to accommodate them .
Strong competition from the region also requires Singapore to be unique from its neighbouring countries .
With no natural attractions and little resources , Singapore has no choice but to create man-made attractions such as resorts and casinos , or to come up with attractions that is only attractive to foreigners .
Such attractions require large amounts of money .
However , the benefits outweighs the negatives as it helps to create more jobs and attract foreign investors to invest in its thriving tourism which will help boost the country's GDP .
Education is also a very important development in a Global City .
The lack of education is one of the problems that elderly face in today society , thus leading to poor financial management .
As Singapore is small and doesn't have any natural resources , it is shaping its economy into a knowledge-based economy .
In order to achieve such goals , more resources should be channeled into the education system , such as providing additional funds to needy students , which allows them to break out of their poverty cycle; improving the infrastructures of schools and universities; and recruiting more teachers .
With a better education system , it allows Singaporeans to enter the workforce with better skills and increases their employability , thus preventing the problems which current the elderly are facing  .
Housing is also another major issue that Singapore faces .
Singapore currently has a population of slightly more than 4 million people .
The average population density is about 6814 per km  , thus it is one of the most crowded cities in the world .
To cope with the increasing population , more high-rise residential buildings known as HDB flats arebeing builtt .
These flats are heavily subsidised by the government to make it affordable .
More money should be invested in older flats , such as providing upgrades to the current facilities to improve the quality of life of citizens living in such areas .
Public spending on the elderly should not be removed .
However the government may have to consider limiting it .
Without limiting it , there will be over dependence on the government , worsening the current situation  .
If public spending is allocated to areas such as housing , education and tourism , the new generation will be more financially secure than their parents .
It will also help Singaporeans to stay ahead and be competitive in terms of employability and marketability , furthermore contributing to the country's GDP growth which helps in the overall  development of the country  the long term .
In 2007 , a Financial Times's reporter  mentioned that with the low fertility rate and an increase in life expectancy , Singapore would soon have only 2 .2 workers to support each elderly person[i] .
With such a low number of working adults to support the elderly , there would be a need for the government to at least maintain its current expenditure on the aged .
Therefore , public spending on the aged should not be overly limited .
Though public spending should be used fully on the aged , there are other areas of concern that the government money should be diverted to , such as the healthcare system .
Recently , the Singapore Prime Minister , Mr Lee Hsein Loong ,  stressed the need for a step down care system during his National Day Rally Speech for the nation's 44th birthday .
The step-down care system requires Singapore  hospitals to link with community hospitals , this , in turn , will enable long term  patients to enjoy a suitable care while saving money on hospital fees .
As the community hospitals charge less .
However , Singapore should not make use of the budget for the aged to improve other areas .
This is because Singapore will be suffering from an aging population by the time it reaches year 2030 .
If public spending for the aged is not well utilised for the next few years , Singapore will be having problems when the time comes .
Though the government has encouraged children to fulfill filial obligations by taking care of their parents , with their own family to take care of , children of these elderly parents would not be able to bare the financial burden .
This further emphasizes the need for a helping hand .
For the past decade , the Singapore government has  been emphasizing the value of self reliance on its citizen despite the economic ups and downs .
Policies , such as the Central Provident Fund (CPF) , has been implemented to ensure that Singaporeans are able to support themselves after retirement .
However , recently , many found that the amount is insufficient to keep up with the rising cost of medical fees , resulting in the use of the children's CPF account .
Currently , the common age group of children , whose parents are elderly , are in their late 40s or early 50s , and it is common that the children's CPF account is emptied because of the hefty medical bills .
If this vicious cycle continues , the future generation will suffer .
An extreme example would be when a grandfather uses and depletes the CPF account of the parents , and when the children grow and their parents suffer from long term illness , such as diabetes , they may use their CPF account if they do not have sufficient cash on-hand .
Therefore , the government should not limit their public spending on the aged .
In the above paragraph , the vicious cycle occurs when the elderly depend on their children but , what will happen to the elderly if the children refuse to fulfil their filial obligations ?
As a matter of fact , these old folks will be left on their own , with the support from welfare organisations .
However , for most cases , welfare organisations can only help in getting daily necessities for them .
When it comes to financial assistance , the welfare organisation , too , will have difficulty in helping the elderly .
This is because donations from the public are used to support the basic daily operations of these organizations , thus leaving little or nothing to help these old folks financially .
This , therefore , requires  further assistance from their next supporting pillar: the government .
Though decades of self-reliance has taught Singaporeans to stand firm and learn how to support themselves and their family  , now they can no longer do so .
With the rising cost of medical facilities , the elderly with the support of their children could no longer rely on their own CPF accounts and their children's income to pay the fees .
If such scenarios are already occurring to those elderly who have family , the situation would be worse for old folks who have no one to turn to except for the government .
If the government refuses to help these people who had once contributed to the country , who can they rely on ? ?
Therefore , even if public spending is required in other areas , public spending on the aged should not be limited .
As the saying goes "Time and tide wait for no man" , ageing is an inevitable process one has to face .
As an individual grows older , one will become more susceptible to various ailments and diseases that may render one incapacitated in some way or other .
(Illnesses of The Elderly , 2008) .
Moreover , one will become physically weak as one ages and this will lead a higher tendency to cause a lesion to oneself .
Thus , accessibility in the built environment is especially crucial as the number of people with mobility difficulties will increase significantly over the next 25 years in Singapore () .
This leads to a sudden need of facilities and technologies to cater for this particular group .
Consequently , the government has implemented several policies to lessen the burden of the ageing process while researchers have come up with brilliant inventions to increase the convenience and comfort level for the majority .
To put it simply , the technological inventions' researches and architectural policies have helped to ease the ageing process to a great extent in terms of convenience and comfort level .
However , the  ageing process is putting a strain on users' pockets financially even though the introduction of the facilities benefits them in terms of comfort and convenience .
To illustrate , although the Lift Upgrading Programme (LUP) that is introduced in Singapore is heavily subsidised by the government and the Town Councils , the beneficiaries are still required to pay a large sum in order to enjoy the benefits .
The maximum amount which the flat owners have to pay is capped at $3 ,000 (HDB , 2006) , and this amount is not a diminutive amount .
Although the residents have to pay to enjoy the benefits of convenience , the amount of benefits enjoyed by the residents are definitely more than the value that they have to contribute , in terms of long-term usage .
Seeing that , the policies or acts that were implemented under Building Construction Authority (BCA) and Housing Development Board (HDB) have improved the standard of living for the people .
The BCA states that "a $40-million Accessibility Fund had been set aside to upgrade buildings built before 1990 .
This fund is also used to upgrade all key areas and essential facilities in Singapore to provide at least essential accessibility by 2011" (BCA , 2009) .
Under this scheme , the LUP is introduced and it is designed to improve the flat's access and personal convenience by the Singapore government in 2001 (HDB , 2006) .
Since lifts in HDB blocks that were built before 1990 are not providing 100% access to every level , any existing building under Housing Development Board (HDB , 2006) will be altered and added with lifts that stop at every floor .
This change has made a significant change to the residents , especially elders who are physically weak .
Thus , there will be no need for them to climb the staircase where they might have the tendency to fall when using it .
Other than the LUP , Singapore government has also inputted public ramps to ease elders from climbing the stairs under the same scheme .
These strategies have aided in easing the ageing process effectively .
To give an example , The Straits Times on 31 August 2009 , reported that two new ramps , a covered shelter connecting the 20-year-old station to the nearest bus stop in Yishun Avenue 2 , as well as an additional drop-off point have been constructed for the elderly residents living at Nee Soon South , where it housed approximately 50 ,000 elderly residents (The Straits Times , 2009) .
Hence , the government policies with regard to architecture have helped to ease the ageing process effectively .
On the contrary , with the alteration made to the flats , the elders might rely too much on the lifts rather than using the staircase which could be the only form of exercise for them .
Thus , the convenience might unintentionally exacerbate the health of one being due to the lack of exercise .
Due to the fact that negative effects occur when one is too dependent on the usage of facilities , the town council has solved this problem by building Fitness Parks for elders to exercise to maintain a healthy body .
Moreover , the elders would have a more conducive place for them to do exercises as well as to treat it as a place for gathering .
Hence , the government policies with regard to architecture have helped to ease the ageing process effectively .
Besides that , other countries such as Japan that is facing ageing population problems have spent a large  amount on researching and testing on technologies to create healthy lifestyle products and medical equipment .
Therefore , the end products produced in terms of medical and lifestyle products will be costly and unaffordable to purchase for those financially weak elders and thus , not many elders will be enjoying the benefits .
This means that the elders will either have to work , use their savings or to approach their relatives for money to buy the products .
Hence , the elders who use these methods to obtain the products will only worsen their ageing process with financial worries .
Despite the fact that the end products might be expensive , it is still beneficial .
technological inventions have played another imperative role to ease the process of ageing .
Numerous innovations have been developed to ease the problems faced by everyone .
With the help of bio-technology , various types of massaging equipments and machines have been invented to ease the process of ageing .
This technology usually helps to ameliorate the health of users such as improving blood circulation , which helps users to have a healthier body; especially for elders who tend to have weaker bodies .
As these equipments or machines may calm down , give strength , relax the body , improves self-sensation and trigger regeneration mechanisms (The "Medical Club Ltd" , 2008) .
For example , OSIM has come up with many innovative healthy lifestyle products that provide such benefits .
In addition , there is a robotic suit that reads brain signals and helps people with mobility problem ()  launched in Japan , .
It is an invention that may have far-reaching benefits for the disabled and elderly .
Hybrid Assistive Limb (HAL) is a computerized suit fitted with sensors that read brain signals directing limb movement through the skin of user .
() .
This is extremely beneficial for elders who have lost the strength to handle daily's needs .
Hence , their lives could be eased by using this invention .
To sum up ,  current research has done a marvelous job on inventing new technologies that have helped to ease the ageing process of elders and the disabled .
The advanced technologies have proven to enhance the comfort zone with  sophisticated medical equipment and lifestyle electronic products .
Over the past few decades  technological advances has increased significantly .
At the same time , the aging trend somehow seemed to have caught up with it .
The post war baby-boom generation is now starting to age , due to advancement in medical science and increased standards of living .
The average life expectancy has also increased , meaning that the elderly population will form a majority of the population  .
More emphasis will have to be placed to catering to the needs of the elderly , so that they can transit into the aging phase more easily .
Thanks to modern research and development , the aging process has been made less painful not only to the elderly , but to the societies as well .
As a person ages , physical changes in one's body occurs and their functions degrade with time .
Traits such as one's mobility , as well as visibility will be significantly reduced as compared to their younger days .
The chances of injury increases with age , as proven by statistics .
It was observed that more than one third of the elderly fall each year , and the chances of falling increases proportionately with age , and that three quarters of elderly falls were caused by "non-elderly friendly" design flaws of buildings .
If this trend were to carry on , national budgets and economies will come under pressure , as a large sum of money will have to be spent taking care of the elderly .
As a result some government campaigns might have to be delayed or even cancelled due to shortage of funds .
Therefore , a prevention measure , in the form of upgrading public facilities have been implemented to prevent this from happening .
One way is through advancement in technology .
Technology has always been beneficial to man .
With each passing day , technology evolves and moulds new inventions which can make life better , and easier .
Technological inventions can help the elderly overcome the limitations of their body due to old age or sickness , and in a way , prevent accidents from happening due to these limitations .
This can be achieved through introduction of inventions such as step-free buses , which helps ease the difficulty of elderly climbing up the steps of the bus .
Other inventions such as slip proof tiles and solvents can effectively cut down the possibility of falls due to slippery surfaces .
We are living in a concrete jungle , and as the population ages , the design of the structure has to evolve accordingly so as to cater to the needs of the people staying in it .
Architectural design with elder  friendly considerations will be crucial so that the chances of an injury in their homes will be kept to a minimal .
As stated earlier , proven through statistics , three quarters of elderly falls were caused by "non- elderly friendly" design flaws of buildings .
A series of upgrades are therefore implemented , in countries like Singapore and The United Kingdom , engaged in the 'UP' project .
In this project , buildings are being modified so that the lifts can stop at every level of the building .
By doing so , it effectively reduced the chances of the elderly having to use the stairs .
There has also been an increase in usage of slip free tiles in wet markets , a place frequented by the elderly .
Distress warning devices were also installed at every elderly home unit to ensure that they have a channel to call for help in event of trouble .
However , these are long term investments and the advantages will surface as time goes by .
Furthermore , people , being a country's most valuable asset who have once contributed to the economy during their prime , should be entitled to all these inventions which will make their age transition less painful .
In a way its a form of 'paying back' by the government for their contributions to the country's development over the past few decades .
It is no longer a secret that our society is facing an aging population problem .
The government faces great challenges as the increase in the proportion of elderly aged 65 years and above grew from 7 .4 percent in the year 2003 to 8 .5 percent in the year 2007 [ .
There are many conflicts regarding the welfare of the elderly , for example , the government has been blamed for neglecting the emotional needs of the elderly .
Such situations cannot be helped in the short run .
Nevertheless , the current research and development and policies have helped to minimize the painful effects of the aging process .
As the world developsand progresses in medical science as well as in other fields , fields it has enabled the human race to make suitable changes .
These changes allow us to fight diseases , as well as make improvements in the quality of life .
The main objective of this report is to discuss and analyze the extent to which these various factors have helped ease the aging process .
Thirdly , the relief of the aging process can be established through family obligation .
This is achieved as people are encouraged or compelled by the law to carry out their duty as offsprings .
The Family Court of Singapore has established laws to ensure that an adult child has to put forth effort to support their own parents through informal and familial channels , for example: Parents Maintenance Act .
Thus , this gives a form of security to the elderly that they are loved by their children .
The change in the research and development of the country is so rapid that the elderly finds it difficult to catch up with the changes around us .
The world has become so IT savvy that almost all trades require employees to be equipped with IT skills .
As a result , the elderly are often rejected when searching for a job due to their inadequate skill set .
Thus , this gives an impression to the  aged that they are redundant and useless in the society .
Low self-esteem grows in the hearts of the elderly and can cause psychological instability , especially when they have been the head of the family in the past .
This drastic change cancause the elderly to be unable to keep up with the pace of the society .
Equipping of skills can be done with the support of the government by encouraging the elderly to take up courses at an affordable price .
Therefore , it enables the elderly to make use of the skills learnt to join the workforce , enabling them to increase their esteem level .
An ageing population or what has been coined the "silver tsunami" is a phenomena faced by developed countries around the globe and Singapore is no exception .
Currently , one in 12 of the population is above 65 , but this has been projected to hit one in five by 2030 .
(Lee , 2009) .
Factors such as improvements in sanitation , medical technology , and public health awareness have raised the life expectancy of Singaporeans , resulting in an ageing population in Singapore .
The challenge of an aging situation will cause social issues such as the shrinking workforce to be faced with an increasing burden of supporting the elderly .
In 2000 , one elderly person was supported by 9 .8 working persons .
This will decrease to 3 .5 working persons per elderly person by the year 2030 (Vasoo , Ngiam , and Cheung , 2000) .
This sharp reduction in labour growth is expected to cause the average GDP expansion to slow to 3 .9 per cent between 2006 and 2030 , down from 6 .9 per cent from 1981 to 2005 .
Thus it is crucial to solve the issue of an aging population as it has a domino effect on the social and economic aspects of the society .
Thirdly , the healthcare cost in Singapore currently accounts for 4 .5% of the gross national expenditure , being one of the lowest figures compared to countries such as Sweden and the United Kingdom .
A research report by Nanyang Technological University's David Reisman highlighted that 36% of health-care expenditure was government financed in Singapore in 2007 .
This was comparable to the percentages of much poorer and less developed countries such as Indonesia and Zimbabwe .
However , the recent global economic crisis and inflation in Singapore have caused the government to focus on the economic aspect of the society in an effort to bring Singapore out of a recession .
The building of the Integrated Resort is one example of Singapore's economic decision to spend money in this area of the economy where rewards are deemed to be centred on .
Defence which the government has spent quite a huge sum on , aims to protect the nation from increased threats of other countries and finally education which  is important in grooming the future leaders of society .
These are just some examples of other areas of the government's expenditure .
Therefore , although it is true that Singapore comparatively spent less , we have to balance it with other crucial sectors .
"Aging does not denote a process at all , but merely describes a medley of unhappy outcomes ," claims Richard A Posner (1995) .
These unhappy events will involve the deterioration of  health as well as the occurrence of mental and physical disturbance .
But of course , it is not right for anyone to say that the older generations should be taking care of themselves and not bother others isn't it ?
Furthermore , it can be argued that research and development policies have relieved the aging process in a very successful way .
The development of medicine in this era has shown its capabilities to ease the aging process .
In the ancient times , the development of medicine was so superficial that many did not get to live their old age because they died of lethal diseases such as leukemia .
But with the development of medicine from the East or West , people can not only live to their old age , but to live their old age in a more comfortable way as well .
For example , Anti-Ageing in western medicine involves specific and detailed analysis of blood , urine and saliva to ascertain the level of hormonal imbalance and cellular damage caused by ageing and Traditional Chinese Medicine acts as a complementary treatment to western anti-ageing medicine which includes acupuncture .
Therefore , the combination of both sides has helped to ease the aging process
Other than that , architecture has helped older generations to have access to various places as well .
Architecture usually involves the building of infrastructure in a place that can benefit users who are unable to access the area normally .
Nowadays , in the Singapore context , we have special entrance and places for the disabled or older persons in MRT Stations . . Other than that , we also have ramps for wheel chair users and playgrounds for the older generations to keep their body healthy and fit .
All these infrastructure allows the older generation to have more freedom in their action and they do not need to compete with the younger generations .
Thirdly , the search for foreign talents is often considered as higher priority compared to the employment of older generations when it comes to the country's development .
This results in the lack of employment by the older generation and thus they will have financial issues trying to support themselves .
However , social policies that are introduced by the government have helped the old folks through various ways in terms of savings and employment and many more .
The most obvious policies that benefit them are the Special and Retirement CPF account , which are being topped up as much as possible by the government .
Although incentives are given to companies who hire local older generation workers , the upgrading of skills of the older generation has been done as well , in order for them to be more competitive in the job market .
Therefore , it is proven that social policies have to work together with the older generation's effort to ease the aging process .
Clearly , as the population of the older generation increases , the importance of research and development of policies grows larger .
Imagine , how life would be for the older generation now if we are still using methods from a few decades ago ?
Other than that , with the current pace that the world is in now , medicine , architecture and social policies must work hand-in-hand to establish a sense of security for the older generation .
If we do not pay attention to the needs of the older generation , we would be considered as people with no sense of appreciation to what the older generation has done for us .
In today's society , people are particular about their physical appearance .
The first impression is important as it determines how others perceive the person to be .
As the baby boomers are now approaching their senior years , there is an obsession for youth and beauty .
Therefore , to a large extent , current research and development have helped to slow down the aging process .
The negative effects of aging are major problems which the aging population is facing As people get older , it becomes more difficult for them to complete their daily tasks due to the loss of muscles and strength and health problems such as diabetes , cancer and dementia are commonly found .
Therefore , scientists and researchers have conducted experiments to identify solutions to ease the aging process .
Research has shown that reducing the calorie intake can decrease the negative effects of aging .
This is because it helps to reduce damages on vital cells and tissues which are crucial in prolonging the lifespan of a person .
Thus , illness such as heart disease , cancer and diabetes and other disease can be prevented .
Christiaan Leeuwenburgh , Ph .D . , an associate professor of aging and geriatric research at the UF College of Medicine stated that with lower calorie intake and moderate exercise program , significant signs of dysfunction in the aging process are found in key organs such as the liver (Christiaan Leeuwenburgh , 2006) .
Thus , with the results from experiments and researches , it would be beneficial to ease the aging process .
However , the mind plays an important role in controlling the beliefs and thinking of an individual which helps to ease the aging process .
It is amazing to see a sixty year old woman exercising at a gym and dressed like a forty year old working adult .
If the person holds thoughts that they are old and incapable of achieving great things , then she will succumb to the negative effects of aging .
However , if the person maintains a positive attitude and lives a healthy lifestyle , the aging process could be slowed down .
For example , if the person suffers from back pain , instead of lamenting on it , she needs to change her mindset and tell herself what she can do to improve on this weakness .
This would enable the person to regain its youthful lifestyle .
Therefore , this shows that research and development and policies are not the only factors that reduces the aging process , the mindset and attitude of a person is also a contributing factor  .
As people age , some of them are unsatisfied with their appearance .
Fine lines would gradually appear on their eyelids , foreheads and mouth .
As a result , they feel inferior and have low self-esteem .
With technological innovation , there are many types of equipment in the market which help to reduce the aging process .
For example , the invention of laser technology aids in the removal of wrinkles in areas such as the eyelids , foreheads and mouth .
After receiving approximately four to six sessions , visible results can be seen .
Besides , the creation of nano liposome technology enables active ingredients to penetrate the skin and deliver the vital nutrients more efficiently .
According to John Kressaty (2008) , the head chemist at 3Lab ,Inc who was in charge of the product h" Serum , an age defying booster , supported that clinical studies has shown with the use of this technology , that there was a fifty percent reduction in the depth of the wrinkles after using the product for four weeks .
Therefore , technology has played a vital role to eliminate or slow down the negative effects of aging .
A declining  population and a longer life expectancy results in an aging population , causing a high dependency ratio in some countries .
This creates further problems such as a less efficient economy and a rise in public expenditure to meet the increasing needs of the elderly .
Hence , solutions have been suggested to reduce the heavier burden of the young in future , and one of the solutions proposed is to limit public spending on the aged .
The idea that public spending on the aged should be limited so that the money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development is feasible as these developments may actually help to gain greater benefits for the aged .
However , it should be noted that the limitation should not be too much to the extent that the aged are neglected and are not being provided with the basic needs of living .
The aged are citizens of the country and they deserve the necessary welfare rights .
The general perception is that over spending of public funds on the aged would lead to over-dependency  on the government .
Hence the burden of costs would hinder the growth of the country's important developments , and one of which is the economy of the country .
In Singapore , the government allocated huge sums of money to build the two Integrated Resorts and host the Grand Prix Formula One night race to promote tourism and investments , leading to an increase in revenue .
With this additional wealth in the economy , the government would then have the capability to have more choices to look after the aged , for instance , holding more welfare programmes .
However , diverting the resources to boost economic growth may not always result in a guaranteed protection of the welfare of the aged .
This is because ,  the wealth may not be distributed appropriately and furthermore , there is always uncertainty in investments and returns are not guaranteed .
For example , it was reported recently that the Singapore state-owned investment company , Temasek Holdings , has lost over $US4 billion on its investments in organisations such as Merrill Lynch .
[1] Therefore , despite the benefits economic growth could bring to the elderly , it is still necessary to set aside a portion of the government spending for the elderly as a safeguard to protect their basic interests and not only to rely on the revenue earned to help the aged .
It is argued that development in the healthcare sector is important and this benefits the aged as well .
Investment in the healthcare sector could bring about new and more efficient medical technologies .
New cures of diseases may also be invented , like  Alzheimer's disease , which is a common illness among the elderly and it does not have an exact cure at present .
This would thus benefit the elderly who would require an increasing need for healthcare services .
Hence , it is perceived that public spending on the aged could be reduced and be switched to the healthcare sector in providing more quality medical services for all in the future .
However , we should not neglect that these new technologies come with high costs , and it is unlikely to benefit all elderly as many are not financially self-sufficient .
It is thus necessary for the government to subsidise healthcare costs in ensuring the availability and affordability of these services .
It is part of the government's responsibility to meet the basic needs and look after the well-being of the citizens .
Therefore , even though the aged could greatly benefit from the advancement of healthcare services , public spending on the aged still should not be limited to a large extent so as to ensure sufficient funds to maintain affordable healthcare costs for the elderly .
Lastly , infrastructure development is also said to be a crucial development of a country and funds should be diverted to support this area of development .
An improvement in the infrastructure of the country such as having an efficient transport network system brings economic advantages , as seen in the case of China , the rising economic giant .
Hence , this leads to an increase in national income which could then be used for the aged in future .
However , we should also keep in mind that infrastructure development not only improves the economy , but also improves and brings convenience to the lives of people , especially the aged .
Some money should be set aside to provide tbasic housing and transport facilities that are elder friendly .
for example to build lifts with grab- bars and lower the platform of the buses .
Although the government's spending on the aged may be minimised to develop a country's infrastructure for greater economic benefits , there should be at least some effort by the government to satisfy the social needs of the older citizens by building an elder-friendly place , making it a comfortable place for them to live in .
In conclusion , public spending on the aged should be limited as over- provision would cause over-reliance of the elderly and lead to an inefficient and low productive workforce and population .
The money could have been put into better use by diverting it to other productive developments to improve the country's economy and overall standard of living .
Yet it is also impossible for the government to limit the spending too much as the elderly should also be entitled to the basic rights and be provided with the basic necessities .
Too little provision may represent an increase in the social costs for the families of the aged and more difficult lives for the communities .
Adopting other solutions to reduce the effects of an aging population , such as extending the working lives of the elderly , may also require the government's spending to provide incentives for them to work longer .
It is thus important for the government to reach a balance and spend the public's money appropriately to have the optimal effects on the aged , population and the country's essential areas of development .
The trend of an aging population is becoming more common nowadays .
One of the main reasons for this situation may be a result of the post World War II baby boom and also the shift in women's role in the society .
As the post war babies age , coupled with the fact that many women are delaying marriage and having lesser children , the population of the elderly has become increasingly significant in proportion in the society of many developed countries today .
The problems pertaining to the process of aging are also becoming more prominent .
Today , with constant breakthroughs in medical research and development as well as reassessment in  social policies , the aging process has been eased for many .
Nevertheless , a small portion of the aging population is still experiencing much difficulty in the process of aging .
In the field of medicine , new developments and technology have helped the aging population to improve their physical appearance as well as provide cures to their ailments .
Particularly in the field of aesthetic medicine , anti-aging procedures such as Botox injections and face-lifts are becoming more common and readily available to the aged .
The American Society of Plastic Surgeons (ASPS) has reported that more than 6 .3 million women chose to have cosmetic plastic surgery in 2000 and there is an uphill trend over the years .
These procedures seemingly help to turn back the hands of time and stall the physical process of aging .
This is extremely helpful to the aging population and especially for women who are known to be more concerned about their outward appearance .
The improvements in appearance may relieve the emotional stress of aging and gain further access to many opportunities .
However , these aesthetic procedures are costly and usually not subsidised by the government .
Generally , the improvement of their outward appearance through the means of plastic surgery would be exclusive to only those who can afford it .
Therefore , only a limited number of the aged will benefit from these new developments in aesthetic medicine .
Nonetheless as time passes , new technologies are constantly being introduced and the prices of relatively older aesthetic procedures will eventually become more affordable to the majority of the aging population .
Thus , current developments in aesthetic medicine can greatly help to ease the physical process of aging .
As demographic shifts take place and the aging population grows , social policy reforms are required to cater to the problems which arise in the aging process .
In Singapore , the government has reassessed the ElderShield policy in the year 2007 .
According to Singapore's Ministry of Health , the policy is an affordable severe disability insurance scheme which provides basic finances to those who require long-term care during old age .
Singapore citizens and permanent residents are covered by the scheme at the age of 40 .
The recent ElderShield policy together with previous policies such as the comprehensive social security saving scheme , Central Provident Fund (CPF) , provides a basis of financial support for the aged .
As the population ages , it is more difficult for them to work as efficiently as before and their market value also falls .
In addition , the elderly are more likely to suffer from health issues and incur high medical cost .
Therefore , it is important for them to build up a financial reserve to support themselves in their aging process .
Despite the introduction of these policies , there are still some elderly who are excluded from these schemes .
Some elderly women have remained a housewife for decades and they have not worked in the workforce before thus there is no contribution to her CPF account .
In this case , it is dependent on oneself to save from the money she receives to support her in the future .
This is especially true for those who do odd jobs where the employers do not help to contribute to their CPF account .
Although the current social policies can help to build up the financial capability of the aging population and make their aging process easier , there remains an unprotected group .
Nonetheless , the government has also introduced the Interim Disability Assistance Programme for the Elderly (IDAPE) , a government assistance scheme providing financial help to needy and disabled elderly Singaporeans , who are not eligible for ElderShield because of their age or pre-existing disabilities .
The government also recognize the heavy cost of elderly patients who require immediate and long-term care (ILTC) services as they are admitted for a long period of time .
Thus , government subsidies are given based on the patient's eligibility and financial status .
Therefore , the different social policies have been introduced to complement one another so as to ensure the entire aging population receives a form of financial support when they are in need .
As such , it is possibly true to say that the current social policies can indeed help to ease the aging process to a large degree .
In conclusion , the aging process is indeed one that is difficult to cope with but with the current medical technologies and a wide range of social policies and reforms the elderly are more protected .
The policies intends to  benefit as many aged as possible and thus it is possibly true to say that the technologies and the policies have helped the majority of the aging population to cope with their problems more effectively today .
The advances in science and technology has brought both opportunities and challenges to our society .
One of the difficulties is the increase in life expectancy , the result of considerable improvement to life's quality ,  leads to the growing burden  in developed countries over the years .
Adequate preparation and judicious policies are musts to ensure the sustainable and stable social progress in this baby-boomer transition period .
The appropriate financial need scheme and the retirement saving fund from individuals is one of the six fundamental approaches for demographic-transform-based policy planning (Peter G . Peterson , fall 2001) .
Based on Singapore's context , veterans' retirement saving scheme is a feasible solution to ease the aging issue but there are still some problems that need to be carefully analysed .
The Central Provident Fund (CPF) in Singapore is an inclusive social saving plan that require savings from the labour force in order to better prepare for an aging population in terms of retirement , health care , home ownership and family protection  .
The fact that it may pose serious challenges for financial resources and the caring from the younger generation when the aging population changes rapidly urges people to alter the way they support themselves .
For example , by 2030 , only 3 .5 economically active persons will be supporting one elderly whereas the number now is 10 in Singapore .
(Singapore CPF Board , 2009) In addition , Singapore's aging population might decrease a 3 percentage segment of its long-term economic growth and the elderly support programme from Government could cost more than 7% of GDP according to the recent national report .
Therefore , employees and employers are asked to make personal contributions and supplements to CPF which includes involvement from public sector , corporate fund , industry fund , retail fund and small fund from financially sophisticated people .
Having the fastest demographic change , but by applying  sensible planning and policies , currently , Singapore's CPF achieves the highest exposure than any other retirement plan in Asia and adds from 16 .3 to 30 .4% to Gross National savings rate .
(Asher , 1995) Alleviating the aging structure , the contributions to these savings are deductible in Singapore as the Governments aim to address basic needs and medical expenses security and stability for aging population .
Therefore , Singaporean citizens will be more sensibly confident and well prepared for their old age when they have financial guarantee for retirement years .
However , more effort needs to be put into strategic planning for bridging the retirement saving gap as this , basically , is a method of short-term  .
The debates on this national strategy also lies on the ownership of the money raised in this government programme and the  part of employees and employers .
Additionally , the income differentiations , low level of commitment from individuals and lack of awareness from a certain number of populations can be the main obstacles to the achievability of the policy .
Together with improvement from financial security , more effort is needed to put in living arrangements , health care and employability to ensure a better living condition for the elderly .
All in all , the result of retirement saving scheme is acceptable in the society as a whole and it is an undeniably necessary step we need to take to cope up with the burden of a speedily aging population .
Singapore has a low population and a transparent administration in compared to other Asian countries to attain high workability from this programme and hopefully , it can reach a higher level  when the health care and employability policies are implemented .
In this modern world we live in , a country cannot develop without considering the aspect of globalization .
The main aim for almost all countries is attaining economic stability and progress .
We do not deny that the elderly have their values .
However , we have to be realistic and accept the fact that the elderly have very little contributions in terms of economy as they are not able to join the work force as they are too old to work .
Therefore , we emphasize that public spending on the elderly should not be totally absent but limited .
With globalization , countries are now more integrated .
Hence , we can achieve economic growth through investments in other countries; especially highly developed ones such as China and India .
For example , Singapore has limited resources and land area , thus in order to expand their economy , more overseas investments are needed .
Also , this increased integration would also mean people are able to travel between countries more easily , bringing about tourism which is a highly profitable and marketable economic sector , therefore the need for public spending on hotels , recreational facilities ,  etc .
As globalization becomes more widespread , countries are exposed to tougher and higher levels of competition as can be seen by multi national companies moving to low labour cost countries like China .
Being a country highly dependent on the foreign market and  , Singapore has a need for better skilled workers in the future as competition is bound to reach more advanced levels .
In order to do so , education plays an important role .
Hence , there is a need for public spending  in terms of better training for teachers , better school facilities such as advanced technological equipments and schemes for an all rounded curriculum .
However , public spending for education does not only have to be for the young .
The elderly can also be educated on how to take better care of themselves , reducing their dependency on the society and help them ease the aging process .
People today are less willing to have children , which resulted in low birth rate .
There is a need for government to spend on "baby boomer" campaigns .
For instance , Singapore government came up with a Baby Bonus scheme to supports working adults' decision to have more children by helping to lighten their financial costs of raising children .
According to the Baby Bonus scheme (2009 , August ,4) , "A cash gift of up to $4 ,000 each for the 1st and 2nd child and $6 ,000 each for the 3rd and 4th child .
All children born on or after 17 August 2008 will also enjoy government contributions in the form of a dollar-for-dollar matching for the amount of savings contributed to the child's Children Development Account (CDA)" .
Currently , these policies are not working as well as the government's expectations , seeing that the future generation in an ageing population is essential , public spending would be needed to intensify these campaigns so as to improve its efficiency .
Regarding issues of elderly illnesses and recreation , there are actually adequate facilities for them .
For example , Singapore has a well connected system of foster homes and hospices providing the elderly with a comfortable environment  .
Furthermore , community activities are well planned with many interesting ones to accommodate their interests .
However , if any spending were to be done regarding this aspect , it could be spent on promoting the establishment of more non-profit organizations volunteering and holding charity events to help ease the elderly problems .
The impact of globalization on our society has been rewarding yet punishing .
With the availability of birth control methods and equal opportunities given to women in terms of education and in the workplace , the aging population is inevitable .
In addition , expenditure on a new born baby is extensive .
However , with the current economic growth , majority of the populations are educated and are able to support themselves throughout their golden years after retirement .
There is much concern due to the negative impact on the stable economy and society caused by a graying population .
What is therefore needed is a wise plan for limited yet sufficient public spending on the aged so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
According to the text "Doomsday Predications about Population Aging Are exaggerated" written by Robert B . Friedland and Laura Summer , it mentioned that the population aged 65 to 75 is healthier , wealthier and better educated compared to those in past generations .
Due to the rapid economic growth , majority of the populations are earning enough for a living and are already having sufficient savings for old age .
This is commonly supported by substantial insurance policies and personal savings .
On average , the working population holds 5 to 6 insurance policies which is adequate for health and financial coverage .
On top of that , the government has implemented mandatory schemes like Central Provident Funds to ensure that all Singaporeans have sufficient amount of money for the latter part of their lives .
Human aging is known to be a continuous , complex and dynamic process that  starts with birth and ends with death .
Everyone will eventually grow old and experience the effects of the aging process .
Even though it is a natural process , which every individual knows that he or she will have to undergo , many still fear the process of aging and dying .
To minimize the fear among this increasing group of people , research and development in areas such as medicine and technology and social policies supported by the government have helped to a very large extent to ease the aging process , be it physically , emotionally or socially .
The development of anti-aging medicine such as anti-aging injections , special mineral waters and other products and services like hormone replacement has helped to slow down the fundamental process of human aging and prolong human life .
Anti-aging injections such as Botox is one of the anti-aging medicines that many elderly , especially  older women ,depend on as a solution for youth .
For the majority , physical appearances are usually the first sign of aging; hence , look-conscious individuals turn to Botox when they want to retain their looks or to look even better when they age .
Hence , only when they look physically good , will they feel good emotionally as well .
Naturally , when they feel good , their self-esteem and level of confidence will gradually increase .
Therefore , this will lessen the feeling within them that aging is a helpless yet painful process .
However , not all people can afford this substantial amount of money to invest in such anti-aging medicines as it is more often than not , expensive .
Therefore , they might turn to counterfeit products that may cause even more harm to their body .
This will not pose  a threat as it can be overcome with strict regulation by the authorities on anti-aging medicines .
Besides the  amount of anti-aging medicine available in the market ,  advanced technology has also helped to ease a generation into old age despite the fact that some elderly people might not be able to accept these complex technologies .
From simple gadgets to complex computer systems , marketers are developing almost everything to ensure that the elderly do not face any difficulties in the transitioning process .
For example , some luxury car companies such as Lincoln offer night vision that projects an infrared image of the road within the car .
With such an invention , failing eyesight will not be the reason to stop old people from driving; therefore , they will not feel emotionally affected by the inability to drive .
Elderly often perceive that old age is a barrier for them to continue doing things that they like because there is a big difference in them physically .
However , this is not always true because technology can overcome some obstacles that they face during the aging process .
For instance , at the Institute of Technology's AgeLab in Massachusetts , they invented shoes with battery-powered vibrating soles that will stimulate nerves to improve balance for the elderly .
As there are many other complications if an elderly person were to fall down , such inventions help to prevent the elderly from falling down .
Apart from depending on the invention of new anti-aging medicines and the development of new technologies , social policies catering to the welfare of the elderly are equally important in helping to ease the aging process .
According to Stansfeld (1998) , loneliness , lack of social support and isolation are identified as major risk factors that when combined can increase the risk of stressful life events in old age .
Therefore , policymakers need to implement new policies to ensure that elderly people enjoy a happy yet productive life even when they age .
This is to minimize the emotional and social implications that old age will bring about .
Indeed , current research and development in areas like medicine and technology and the implementation of new social policies have helped to lessen the discomfort that the aging process will cause among the elderly to  a large extent .
However , it definitely cannot ease the aging process for the elderly totally as this process is still a natural process .
This can only be achieved when the elderly do not perceive themselves as suffering from old age .
Moreover , they need to adopt an attitude that refuses to succumb to the traditional stereotypes of them as the process of aging is controlled by one's beliefs , thinking and  .
In addition , individual effort like getting sufficient sleep and nutrition has to be made to slow down the aging process physically and mentally .
In conclusion ,  actual age does not inhibit one's ability to living life to the fullest .
With the right mind and attitude , one can easily and comfortably overcome the aging process especially with the aid of the latest medicine and technology available in the market as they play an important role in helping to ease the aging process .
Remember the old adage ," Take The Bull By The Horns ?"
This saying used in the ageing process implies that people must do everything in their power to look into the difficulties faced as they age  .
This has been a vital issue globally because slowing down and easing the aging process can extend  life expectancy and  .
To deal with such challenges , research and development as well as the implementation of policies have come into the picture .
Over the years , research and development in all fields of study has been constantly changing and improving the life of older people .
Architecture is one of the fields in research and development that plays an essential part for the aged .
In addition , social policies have also played a major part in solving the ageing process .
National policy  which pays special attention to the elderly has been ameliorating over time for the benefit of the older people .
To start off , the definition of "ageing process" is required .
The ageing process (Wikipedia) refers to the multidimensional process of physical , psychological and social change .
Therefore , the process of ageing could eventually , pose problems especially in physical aspects such as arthritis , rheumatism , and various types of impairment .
Implementation of both , research and development and policies could help to solve these issues , but it does not alleviate them entirely .
As  policy changes and the need for technology increases ,  .
For instance , the Central Providence Fund is a policy which helps people to save for their retirement .
As a result , the elderly , who depend on the fund , would have the mindset of not saving up for an emergency or the thought of having longer working periods .
Thus , those elderly who have subsequently used up their funds will then seek  financial help .
Moreover ,  policies or welfare schemes are only provided  for cases which require specific attention .
In this case , not all elderly people will be  .
Furthermore , if the technologies which are inaugurated in the buildings become faulty , some of the elderly who are used to the devices will not leave their comfort zone .
This in turn , creates 
Even though research and development or policies in  can have  an unconstructive impact , it still has a positive impact in aiding the ageing process .
In countries like Japan , the United States and Singapore , research and development has come up with technologies for the welfare of the aged .
In Singapore , some buildings such as the Buddha Tooth Relic Temple have installed the stair-climb device on the rail of the staircase to help the elderly to move from one storey to another easily .
Hence , there are other  devices developed that have helped to relieve the accessibility of the aged as they move from one place to another in the building .
On top of that , Singapore has also implemented policy for buildings such as the Barrier Free Accessibility Upgrading Program (BCA , 2002) .
In this program , the government has set aside $40 million into the Accessibility fund so as to encourage owners of  buildings to provide accessibility features in  existing or new buildings(BCA , 2002) .
Therefore ,  having accessibility features like ramps and accessible toilets helps to minimize the problems faced by the aged .
Likewise , National policy has also helped to improve the lives of the elderly .
The government has considered  various aspects of policy such as employment , financial security , health and recreational needs , social services and institutional care , and family relations .
As reported , "most of the elderly are in favor of raising the retirement age due to financial security"( Ministry of Social Affairs , 1983) .
As they grow older , the need for adequate income is essential to sustain  the high cost of living in Singapore .
Thus , in order to ease this issue faced by the aged , the government has raised the retirement age beyond 62 and introduced various schemes .
To enumerate , schemes like the ADVANTAGE !
Scheme (WDA , 2007) and SME Manpower Scheme aims to encourage and allow  employers to employ older workers .
Other than  employment policies , the government has also implemented policy to aid in the health care of the elderly .
The health care policy provides supports such as financial assistance , manpower assistance and the allocation of premises to  non-governmental organizations which is also known as , the Voluntary Welfare organization (VWO) .
The services provided by the VWOs are day care centres , hospices , nursing homes and many more .
Henceforth , the policies  Generally speaking , issues related to ageing are inevitable but solvable .
Solutions , for instance , decision making for the policies and development of technologies through research can definitely influence the aged .
Certainly , there are pros and cons of the latter situation .
Nevertheless , the pros have offset the cons as shown previously .
IIt is recommended that more policies  be considered and technologies  be developed  in order to improve the life of the elderly .
Other than that , the elderly must also play their part by creating more awareness in society and participating actively in the policies or devices produced for them .
It can be argued to a certain extent that current public spending on the aged should be limited so that the money saved could be used in other areas of the country's development .
The problem of an aging population is an issue for most  developed countries .
For instance , in Singapore , the number of people over the age of 65 will hit a high 19% by year 2030 .
(Population Asia 2009) .
Judging from the statistics ,  the elderly will form a relatively big portion of the country's population structure in the near future .
This implies that the impact of the aging society will increase with time .
Therefore , it is important for  countries to tackle the situation before it reaches its peak .
But nonetheless , countries that are already dealing with the problem of their aging population have identified the limitations of the policies that are implemented .
For example , in the context of Singapore , we have been holding pro-natalism campaigns since the 1980s , but there is still an insignificant rise in our replacement rate .
This indicates that perhaps the emphasis towards the investment of the country's revenue should be diverted to other area such as economic investments and improving the education system to further boost the rate of advancement of a country .
Firstly , public spending on the elderly should be limited and not be reduced .
in additionl , a pool of reserve funds should be available to cope with the rise in aging population as well .
This is because the problem of an aging population affects the rate of development of a country in the long run .
And if this problem persists , it will gradually become a roadblock for the future advancement of  society .
As such , the country should still pay attention to the proper handling of the issue .
The approaches that countries usually adopt to solve the aging issue include the prolonging of the working lives of the elderly and the provision of an array of welfare pension schemes for them .
The idea of extending their retirement age is beneficial to both the elderly and the company itself .
