With prior knowledge , people will be mentally prepared for the aging process .
In addition , they can seek treatments in the early stages to prevent worsening of the conditions or even get cured .
This will also in turn save huge amount of money for the people , as later treatments will require one to pay a higher price .
Knowing the symptoms of a disease does help too .
One example is that when an elderly is having doubled or blurred vision , sensitivity to light and glare , he or she might be having cataract .
Thus they can seek treatment or go for a cataract surgery if needed .
Research and developments have also seen implementation of the latest technologies being used in hospitals , clinics and some even at home .
New age technologies like these have helped doctors to react within precious seconds in saving a person's life .
They can also assess the their patient's condition in a shorter and more accurate time frame .
For example , elderly with high blood pressure can check their blood pressure anytime and anywhere with just a push of the button on a compact , portable blood pressure monitor .
Thus , all these researches in medical field have aided the aging process tremendously .
From the medical sector , we have learnt that prevention is better then cure .
With that , architecture too has moved towards a more elderly-savvy approach in buildings and public areas to prevent unwanted accidents .
At this point , one may wonder if it were a waste of resources to invest in architectural aids because these structures are costly and do not serve as much purpose as compared to the other sectors such as medical .
However , these aids have proven to be essential despite their costly structures .
In areas populated with elderly  , such  as Redhill or Tiong Bahru , railings have been installed not only on pavements but also in public toilets as well .
Tiles or pavements with better friction have been placed in toilets to prevent the elderly from slipping .
In addition , one of the major projects that the Singapore's Ministry of Transport has developed is to install lifts in almost every MRT stations , which creates a barrier free route .
All these developments  help the elderly  , the disabled and pregnant women as well .
Thus , developments in these area are definitely worthwhile .
In conclusion , all the research and developments  , as well as  policies that the government has invested in , have made aging a more joyous and less terrifying journey .
Thus , current research , development and policies in the economy , medical sector and architectural sector have helped to ease the aging process to a large extent .
One of the biggest issues the world is facing now is the problem of an aging population .
Thus , there is an increasing number of concerns as to how to solve the problems of an aging population .
One of the most direct ways of dealing with the problems is to divert more government spending to the aged .
However , the amount of government funds available is limited .
By directing more funds to the aged , there will be lesser funds for other areas of the country's development .
Therefore , public spending on the aged should be limited so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
Critics argue that by limiting the government spending on the aged , it would increase the negative impact of an aging population .
When lesser amount of government spending is given to the aged , the individuals and families will end up paying more .
Their financial burden will increase with financial related social problems following behind .
However , without limiting the government spending on the aged , the people may become too reliable on the government .
They may not take the initiative to save their money for future uses .
This could create serious problems for the government as it will cause additional pressure on the national budget and the economy .
The children may even end up not supporting their parents at all .
An example would be the increasing number of elderly suing their children for not supporting them in Singapore .
From August 2008 to July 2009 , Popatal (2009) found that there were 172 people who have filed applications at the Tribunal for Maintenance of Parents .
This is much higher than the average of 100 in previous years .
The elderly are being forced to get help from the government as their children are not willing to support them .
By limiting the government spending on the aged , the children will not push all the responsibilities of taking care of their aged parents to the government .
They will not form a habit of relying too much on the government .
Public spending on the aged should be limited as the elderly today are healthier as compared to people of the same age in the past .
The advances in research and development have made it possible to cure illnesses that are otherwise deadly .
For instance , according to the Ministry of Community Development , Youth and Sports (MCYS , 2009) in Singapore , the percentage of residents aged 55 years and above who are physically independent are as high as 92 .2% in year 2005 .
This means that they are capable of finding a job to support themselves without having to depend on others .
This is also proven by the fact that the Ministry of Manpower (MOM , 2009) increased the retirement age in Singapore from 55 to 62 and the age is still expected to increase to 65 by year 2012 .
More elderly are now able to participate in the workforce actively .
Minimum help should be required from the government and so public spending on the aged should be limited .
Another reason why public spending should be limited is because a country does not only consist of the aged .
There are other sectors that need  government's help .
If the government's spending on the aged is not limited , the other sectors will be neglected .
The education sector is an example .
The education sector is very important to a country as it nurtures the young and turns them into useful adults .
The government helps the young by issuing bursaries and scholarships  , as well as encouragesthe students to study hard and helps those who are poor but are eager to go to school .
Without setting a limit on the government funds spent on the aged , all these will not be possible .
There will be lesser amount of skilful adults in the workforce and this may in turn slow down the economy .
Without economic growth , the government may face a deficit .
Taxes may have to increase and takes a bigger toll on the people .
Hence , it is important to limit  public spending on the aged so as to divert it to other areas of the country's development .
In conclusion , it is important to limit the spending on the aged so that people will not be too reliable on the government .
They should also be aware that the elderly are now healthier and  are capable of supporting themselves .
A country does not consist of only the aged and spending too much government funds is unnecessary and will cause a negative impact on the economy .
The population in the world is aging rapidly and the number of persons aged 60 or over is expected almost to triple , increasing from 737 million in 2009 to 2 billion by 2050 globally .
(United Nations , 2009) This signals the need to deal with this pressing issue of aging Population .
Fortunately , many countries have recognized this need and have come up with different strategies to tackle the aging issues .
Many countries' current strategies have been formulated with the elderly in mind and hence they are able to address the needs of the elderly , thereby easing their aging process .
"Aging" is defined as the process of becoming old .
(Oxford University Press , 2005) Hence , easing the aging process would mean making the course towards old age an enjoyable and less tedious one for the elderly .
In the Singapore context , there are many different approaches in place and the few main ones include the implementation of the Central Provident Fund (CPF) , development and improvement made to the existing healthcare system and elder-friendly infrastructure and the implementation of the Tax Relief Scheme .
All these have  helped to alleviate the aging process and allow the elderly to enjoy their twilight years to the fullest .
The CPF in Singapore has played a crucial role in helping to reduce the fiscal cost of elder dependency as it compels citizens to save in advance for their old age (Central Provident Fund [CPF] Board , 2009) .
Critics of this plan have debated that it is unsuitable as high costs of living makes it difficult for people to save more of their earnings for  pensions .
Thus it is incapable in helping to relieve the financial burden of the elderly .
However , this may not be true as with judicious planning of their spending , it is not impossible for them to save more while they are still active in the work force and be financially independent in old age .
Also , other social issues associated with an aging population ,   like declining birth rate and people living longer , have indicated that there will be fewer working adults available to contribute to the society and to support the aged .
Therefore , this has increased the significance of the CPF as it compels people to save in advance lest they are unable  to support themselves during their old age .
Furthermore , the CPF has helped to rule out the possibilities of younger generations neglecting  the importance of saving for their old age  .
Hence , the CPF has indeed helped to ease the aging process and the financial burden of the elderly as it requires people to save in advance and also informs citizens on how much they should save in order to be self- sufficient for their old age .
This gives people  a sense of security in their twilight years as they are now  able to enjoy their lives without much financial worries .
Apart from the CPF , development and improvement made to the existing healthcare system and elder-friendly infrastructure have also eased the problem of disabilities and old-age illnesses .
These actions are superficial and inadequate as they do not directly deal with the problems related to old age; and therefore are unable to ease the aging process .
However , this may not be the case as with improved healthcare system; it helps  the elderly because their healthcare needs will be better taken care of .
An example will be the introduction of more community hospitals to provide better and affordable healthcare services to the elderly .
In addition , with the development of more elder-friendly infrastructure within the community ,  the community will become barrier-free , safer and more conducive for the elderly .
One of such projects is the lift upgrading programme (Lee , 2009) .
The improved lifts will stop at every floor and this will  better cater to the needs of the elderly .
Additionally , to allow the aged to move about conveniently , many places , including public transportations have been made wheel-chair accessible .
Hence , with a safer environment and with the provision of elder-friendly infrastructure and unhindered access to the public facilities , the elderly will be allowed to move about freely and enjoy their old age .
Implementation of the Tax Relief Scheme such as The Aged Parent Relief is also an important step to improve the retirement security as it encourages children to take care of their parents , thereby easing the aging process (CPF , 2009) .
At this point , one may take advantage of this scheme to claim the tax reliefs for one's use as it is nearly impossible for the government to keep track of where the money is being spent on .
Thus the elderly parents may not be at the receiving end .
While this may indeed happen , the government has taken a further step to discourage this from happening .
For instance , the government has passed the Maintenance of Parents Act to allow elderly parents to file lawsuit against their children who have failed to carry out filial obligations (Khalik , 2009) .
Hence , this act has helped to deter the children from making use of the tax relief scheme inappropriately and has also sustained the main objective of the scheme to promote filial piety .
Thus , with the potential "loophole" being dealt with , the tax relief scheme will be able to help in lessening the financial burden that the children have to take on from looking after their parents .
All these helped to encourage the children to look after their parents and at the same time , ensure that the elderly parents will be at the receiving end .
Hence , these approaches have increased the seniors' confidence and security during their twilight years .
Overall ,  strategies such as the introduction of CPF , the development and improvement of the elder-friendly infrastructure and healthcare system and the implementation of tax relief scheme have indeed helped to ease the aging process to a large extent .
These strategies have helped to ensure that the elderly are self-sufficient during their old age and also allowed them to live in a more conducive and barrier-free environment .
Although there is still room for improvement , current strategies have already done a pretty great well in ensuring that the individuals have saved enough for their old age and  increasing their sense of  security .
All these have indeed made the process towards aging a more enjoyable and fulfilling one and  allowed the aged to truly enjoy their well-prepared twilight years .
Expenditure on the elderly is taking up more of the government budget due to the rapidly aging population .
Money that can be otherwise spent on the country's developments has to be used in settling the problem of the greying population .
Countries are spending more and more money on health care , infrastructure and transportation specially custom-made for the elderly .
Due to this , the country's development in other areas has to take a step back , thus resulting in the inability to attain its potential .
In the  essay , I shall discuss the problems that are brought about by the increase in public spending on the aged and the areas that could have benefited if the fund were to be used on them instead .
When a country like the United States'' elderly population increased eleven-fold between 1900 and 1994  , it  is evident that there will be an increase in personal assistance for the aged (Hobbs , 1993 , 25-1104) .
This will translate into an increased funding  to provide care for this group of people .
On top of the money being put aside for health care  for the aged , barrier-free facilities like wheel-chair friendly roads and transportation system have to be planned to accommodate  them .
To deal with these global aging problems , governments  have to reserve a large proportion of the already limited public spending for the elderly .
This result in a reduction of the government budget for the country's development in both economic and social terms .
The fund used on the elderly could otherwise be spent on allowing the country to have better economic growth by building a better infrastructure  and an  education system .
In this way , the general population will be able to benefit from the increase in income as a result of the economic growth .
On the other hand , it is not morally right to leave the aged to fend for themselves , especially when they had contributed in one way or another to the country's development in their younger days .
It is true that the government should reward the aged for their contributions; but in order for the country to continue enjoying a sustained growth , the public spending have to be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
In addition , the responsibility of supporting the elderly does not only lie on the shoulders of the government , the elderly themselves should plan for their retirements when they are still economically active .
This is done by implementing policies like the Medisave system , where Singaporeans have to put aside a certain percentage of their income into the Medisave account (Central Provident Fund) .
This system is to ensure that the senior citizens will be able to live on their own savings in the Medisave account .
Not only that , the children should also be show filial piety for their aged parents .
In cases where the elderly are childless or physically ill due to aging ,  it will be the government's duty to take care of them .
However ,  contrary to what is commonly believed , Pat Thane (citation) argued that , they are not inevitably unhealthy .
As  living conditions improve and technology advances , people are able to lead a healthier lifestyle and live longer as compared to the past .
Thane also said that " many tasks can be performed as well by people in their seventies as by younger people , even when they involve quite heavy physical or intellectual demands" (Thane ,1991) .
As a result of the above mentioned arguments by Pat Thane , the Senior lecturer in Social Science and Administration at Goldsmiths College , London , being old might not be translated to being a burden to the society .
The elderly , especially the "young elderly" , would surely be able to earn a living on their own if they do not have the luxury of  children supporting them .
Therefore , an aging population might not pose problems as feared .
In summary , public spending on the aged should be limited because of the fact that the elderly should have planned for their old age when they were young and they might still be able to support themselves if the need arises .
A country will be able to progress if its citizens do their part in planning for their retirement  .
Many countries are facing the problems brought about byan aging population  .
For instance , the workforce gets smaller as elder workers retire and the working class has to pay more taxes because of  a slower economic growth and the need to provide more healthcare services for the aged .
Even though the world is facing an aging population , public spending should not be spent only on the aged as there are many other areas that need to be taken care of in a country's  development .
The aging population is already a problem in many countries such as Japan and Singapore .
Therefore , public spending had been reviewed to address this problem and  to reduce the negative impact of the aging problems  .
However , due to  practical reasons , a country has its limitations in supporting the aged .
Hence , countries should assess the other important areas that public spending should be focused on as well .
On the other hand , if public spending on the aged were reduced , many social problems would arise in the country .
As the aged are used to receiving allowances and subsidies , the lack of government aids might affect their lives .
They would be unable to support themselves , especially with the increasing  healthcare costs .
According to the Singapore Department of Statistics , the Consumer Price Index for healthcare had  increased  3 .6% from February 2008 to February 2009 .
This would mean higher costs of living for the aged .
Therefore , in this case , moral issues need to be considered as well .
Children of the aged they should do their part in taking care of their parents after their retirement .
In conservative countries such as Singapore , children are expected to taking care of their parents by providing them with allowances to meet their daily needs .
Children should remember how their parents have taken care of them when they were young and hence , should do their part in demonstrating  filial piety and take care of their aged parents , instead of relying on the country to help .
In order to ensure that the aged are properly taken care of by their children , government could introduce policies and enforce them  .
This would help to enforce  moral values and also directly reduce public spendingthat could be diverted to other areas of development .
Other areas of development include addressing social issues such as the decrease in the birthrate and the increase in child abuse cases .
In Singapore , the Marriage and Parenthood package with the extension of the Baby Bonus attained only marginal success in increasing the birthrate of Singaporeans .
The median age of citizen mothers at first birth had increased over the years from 28 .6 in 1998 to 29 .4 in 2008 , thus causing the fertility rate for the prime childbearing age group of 20 to 34 to decline .
Hence , public spending could be used to introduce more programs and subsidies to encourage people having larger families instead .
With increased birthrate , Singapore would be able to resolve the problem of aging population in the near future .
Besides aging population , other social issues such as child abuse are also crucial problems that need to be addressed .
According to the Social Statistics 2009 conducted by the Ministry of Community Development , Youth and Sports , the number of child abuse cases investigated in Singapore had increased from 154 in 2007 to 176 in 2008 .
This significant increase indicates that attention should be diverted to address this problem .
Public spending could be used to ensure that there are ways to reach out to the abused victims in the society .
In addition , it is essential to increase public awareness through campaigns and seminars to givethe public a better understanding on child abuse .
With this , the society could play a part in creating a safer environment for children and hence , enhancing the social development in Singapore .
Even though many countries are facing aging population , there is a still a limit on what can be done .
Thus , countries should not be overwhelmed by the problems of aging population and overlook other potential problems .
In conclusion , public spending should be used on the aged but also not neglecting other problems  which hinder the country's development .
Too much of the nation's budget is being spent on aiding the elderly and the government should limit and channel these funds to other more important areas for the country's development .
For most countries , part of their national budget will be spent on funding the aged each year .
For example , $121million is set aside as Senior Citizen Bonus in Singapore this year (Budget Highlights , 2009) .
The elderly receive subsidies in various areas such as housing and medical benefits .
As the elderly today are able to survive without subsidies from the government , these funds should be put to better use and be directed to support the country's development .
The society has stressed on the importance of filial piety which requires children to take care of their parents .
Children are obliged to take care of their parents and this will lessen the burden on  society to take care of the elderly .
Thus , less funds are needed to help these elderly .
Excess funds should then be channeled to other areas for the country's development .
Many may think that with the obligation to support their parents , the  family members will bear a heavier burden  .
However , providing for the parents is not an additional burden for the children as there are benefits when they take care of their parents .
For example , the tax relief for adults who live with their aged parents has been increased to $5000 and the CPF Housing Grant Scheme to encourage young couples to stay near their parents ("Round Up Speech" , 2007) .
Therefore , it is not true to say that  working adults bear a heavier burden from supporting their parents because government incentives are provided .
Hence , the government should limit the amount used to aid the elderly as their financial needs are taken care of by their own family members .
Nowadays , the elderly are able to support themselves .
Chan (1999) showed that elderly respondents with CPF accounts are significantly less likely to rely on children as their main source of financial support .
Evidence suggests that as CPF coverage widens , reliance on children will probably decrease .
The government has implemented policies to help citizens prepare for their retired life .
Policies such as compulsory CPF and Medisave savings both require citizens to set aside part of their salaries to meet their future  needs .
Even if the elderly can support themselves , some may argue that since they pay taxes  , they  should be allowed to use the funds set aside for them .
Funds directed to other areas for the country's development will also benefit the society , such as  the construction of handicapped-friendly ramps and upgrading of HDB flats' lift to serve at all levels .
The taxes that they pay may be channeled to support these upgrading works and benefit everyone .
With these policies implemented by the government , the elderly do not need so much financial assistance to meet their needs .
Everyone should be responsible for themselves .
The aged should  continue to work  beyond their retirement age when they are still capable of supporting themselves .
In recent years , the government has been promoting elder employment and raising the eligible age for employment .
Hence , the elderly should have no problem finding jobs to financially support themselves .
Others may think that the elderly have already contributed their share to  society and should now retire .
However , instead of letting them idle at home , the retired should be allowed to return to the workforce and continue to contribute to the economy .
Not only are they able to benefit financially , they are also able to share their precious experiences with the younger generations .
With the elderly returning to the workforce , they will be less dependent on the government subsidies and thus , less funds should be set aside for the elderly .
The elderly will be supported in their retirement   by their working family members  , and gaining help from government policies (CPF savings , Medisave funds and Elderly bonuses) .
There is no need to worry about the large sum of financial aid required by the aged .
All in all , funds should be limited and directed to other more important areas for the country's development so that the country will be able to remain competitive in the economy and achieve sustained economic growth .
As developed countries globalize and industrialize , the aging population is one of the most prominent problems faced by them .
They not only struggle to balance the social needs and interests of different demographic groups but also to sustain economic growth .
Countries like Singapore and Japan have a social security system in place to help the aged , and at the same time , a substantial sum of public spending is allocated to look after their health and welfare (Takayama , 2005) .
However , public spending should also be allocated to other areas of the country's development ,  such as education , small medium enterprises (SMEs) and the infrastructure   .
These areas would  benefit the public and are effective in tackling the aging issues in the long run .
Therefore ,  public spending on the aged should be limited so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development to strike a balance while tackling the aging issues .
Education is a key area in which public spending should be utilized to increase a nation's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) .
per capita , labour productivity and international competitive edge .
One nation's economy success depends on the quality of the workforce (Edwards , 2008) .
Highly educated future generations will tend to earn more incomes and be more health conscious , thus less reliant on government for health and welfare (Friedland and Summer , 2005) .
Singapore owes its economic success to the good management of the education system and meeting the demand for skills through training the workforce to meet and keep up with the economic changes (Lee , Goh and Fredriksen , 2008) .
Singapore's social security system , which focuses on self-reliance and individual savings , is in line with the compulsory saving scheme , the Central Provident Fund (CPF) .
The CPF Education Scheme allows people to use the ordinary account to pay for  tertiary education in  local institutions , and at the same time , encourages more people to further their education (Mehta , and Wee , 2004) .
Education can also be a channel for the nation to emphasize filial obligations in order to increase willingness of the future generations to take care of their parents when they are old (Peterson , 2001) .
As part of the Singapore's education system , National Education aims to foster national cohesion , a sense of belonging and good moral values (Ministry of Education , 2009) .
Nevertheless , educating the workforce , including the aged , on the importance of planning for retirement and continuous skills upgrading are also essential .
This allows the workforce to start accumulating their wealth until the retirement age and at the same time , especially for the aged to remain productive through skill upgrading (Peterson , 2001)
Public spending should also be allocated to implement various schemes for the development of the Small Medium Enterprise (SME) .
sector .
The various schemes aim to help the SMEs increase their revenue and attract investors through upgrading the existing business operations and creating gateway and funding opportunities (Spring Singapore , 2009) .
In 2008 , the National Research Foundation (NRF) announced that 75 million Singapore dollars were set aside to support the Proof-of Concept grants (POC scheme) for the SMEs to strengthen innovation and entrepreneurship as the sector contributes over 40% of the GDP and half of the employment workforce (Loh , 2007) .
At the same time , the government also provides grants to support SMEs to recruit , retrain and retain their workers , especially the older workers , to ensure productivity .
Two examples of the grants are the Human Resource Capability Package developed by SPRING Singapore and the Singapore Workforce Development Agency (WDA) , which improves and strengthens SMEs' human resource management capabilities  , as well as  the ADVANTAGE !
Scheme , which motivates SMEs to recruit older workers (Ministry of Manpower , 2006) .
These will help to lower the barriers to elder employment , enabling them to work longer and accumulate more wealth for their retirement (Peterson , 2001)
Infrastructure is another area where public spending should be set aside for as it benefits everyone in the long run .
Enhancing and upgrading of common places such as sport facilities , schools , public housing estates , roads and parks are to satisfy the needs  of the public .
It can also be seen as an evidence of public spending .
In 2009 , the Singapore Senior Minister of State for National Development announced that the government plans to spend between S$18 and S$20 billion on infrastructure projects and another S$15 to S$17 billion in 2010 and 2011 respectively .
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong noted in the National Day Rally Speech 2009 that new general hospitals (Khoo Teck Puat Hospital and Jurong General Hospital) would be built in response to the healthcare needs in Singapore , and  on top of that , there is also a need to build step-down care .
Twinning the current general hospitals with  community hospitals , which are run by charitable organizations , will make healthcare affordable for all , especially the aged .
For example , a bridge would be built to link Tan Tock Seng General Hospital to Ren Ci Community Hospital that enables  patients from Tan Tock Seng General Hospital  to be moved to Ren Ci Community Hospital for rehabilitation and the patients may pay lesser for health care costs .
The 2008 yearly report from the World Health Organization on global health statistics stated that Singapore utilizes 3 .7 percent of its GDP on healthcare , which is generally low as compared to the United States' 15 .4 percent .
Singapore uses only one-fourth of its taxes , which is about only $381 per capita on health and individuals pay for the rest (Callick , 2008) .
This shows the importance of tackling the roots of the high cost of healthcare instead of using the public spending directly on the aged .
Aging issues are very complicated but not indomitable .
For all nations , wise planning on public spending and wise policy planning are very crucial as they influence one's future (Friedland and Summer , 2005) .
Creating welfare dependency on the government only solves the issues temporarily .
In order to prevent this , public spending on the aged should be limited .
Instead , it should be used on other areas of development to tackle the roots of the issues and improve the quality of life for the aged .
Public spending refers to the expenditure incurred the government , which may include expenses on  military , health , education , infrastructure , development projects , and the cost of servicing (paying off the interest on) overseas loan .
Aging problems are likely to cause a substantial increase in public expenditure on health .
But the steady development of a society as a whole needs a balance of public spending on all aspects .
Thus the government should be cautious in expanding spending in the aging population , taking into account the impact on economic growth .
Many recent reports (citation) from developed countries have found that ageing will have only a small effect on the healthcare expenditure in future , thus spending on the aged can be limited within a certain small scope of the proportion of GDP .
For example , reports from the United States , the United Kingdom and Australia have reached similar conclusions .
There are two reasons why researchers have reached this conclusion .
Firstly , the older population is not spending a large proportion of the country's GDP , and the fact is not simply that the  greater the proportion of older people  , the greater would be the  spending  .
For example ,  Sweden and  Australia have similar  ,  .
In 2000 , 17 .3% of the Swedish population was aged 65 years or older; it spent only 8 .6% of its GDP on health .
This is less than the 9 .3% spent by Australia in 2001-02 , when only 12 .7% of the population was 65 years or older .
Secondly , many countries have adopted effective strategies to make the expenditure on health for an aging population  small and manageable , Here are some of the strategies: (1) stratify the old by age and sex; (2) ; (3) increase transparency about self-employed income to ensure fairness in the financing of social insurance systems , including the new long-term care insurance .
But , the aging problem may be exaggerated , due to a variety of reasons .
Firstly , the factors that increase the financial expenditure have been over-emphasized  .
It is true that older people use more health care services than younger people and that the proportion of older people in the population is increasing .
These factors do have a certain impact .
For example , the proportion of people in the UK who require help with activities of daily living in 1991 is half of that in 1976 .
Secondly , some groups of people may require a significant increase in public spending on the aging population .
One group is the old .
Compared to long-term economic development , they may be more concerned about their own welfare .
Another group is the government .
With an increasing number of elderly voters , politicians may provide excessive benefits to the elderly to win votes .
If the government finds that aging is a heavy burden , it is bound to decrease the necessary public expenditure , thereby forcing more people to use private health institutions .
Thirdly ,  increased fiscal spending may be due to other factorsinstead of the aging population .
Here I list three of them .
Firstly , the cost of pharmaceuticals and diagnostic tests have increased .
The report published by the Australian Federal Government found .
Thirdly , normal doctor's prescription prefers newer drugs and the drugs are inclined to be expensive , but not necessarily more effective  . 
If  public spending on the issue of aging were unrestricted , the coming wave of retiring Baby Boomers may wash away projected budget surpluses and  erode existing spending priorities .
For example in America , it is already estimated that over half of federal domestic spending  went to people 65 and older .
The burden of the government will increase as the richer old people  For example , in  Korea , there is  pressure on the government for increased outlays on pensions and  healthcare .
Thus it requires additional tax revenue .
In conclusion , the public spending on the aged should be limited , so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
Many countries , including Singapore , are facing the issue of  aging population .
There are many implications for this issue and one of them is that the spending by the government on the aged has increased in order to deal with this issue .
This affects the amount of available funds  spend on other areas of the country's development ,  such as the economy , education and infrastructure .
Thus , in today's society , much has been debated on whether public spending should be limited so that more money can be diverted to other areas for the country's development .
In my own opinion , I agree to a large extent that public spending on the aged should be limited .
One of the reasons to limit public spending on the aged is that there is a greater need to spend money on education than on the aged .
For countries such as Singapore where labor is vital and is the only resource , spending on education is important for the future growth of the country .
Furthermore , in Singapore where it is currently experiencing a low birth rate , developing  the young is crucial to ensure there will be sufficient  local talents in  future .
This is to ensure that Singapore will be able to stay competitive  in the future .
Therefore , in the long run , spending on education will generate economic benefits for the country .
On the other hand , if this same amount of money is to be spent on the aged , there will be no economic benefits generated by them for the country .
Hence , if the government did not limit its spending on the aged , there would be a  budget  left for developing the education sector .
This may affect the country in the long run .
It can also be argued that there is a greater need to spend on infrastructure development as it is  important  .
to limit spending on the aged means that there will be a larger amount of funds available to spend on infrastructure development .
This fund allows the country to develop proper infrastructure such as roads , electricity and even water supply to attract more foreign investors to set up firms in the country .
Superior infrastructure attracts foreign investors to set  up business in the country as it reduces production cost and also increases accessibility for their business .
Attracting foreign investors is important as foreign investments contribute to the country economic development .
Therefore , if government spending on the aged  increases due to aging population issues , the budget on infrastructure development will be lesser and this may affect the country's economic development  .
Another reason to limit public spending on the aged is that there is a need to set aside a larger amount of money for economic development especially  when there is global economic downturn .
As the economy is a key area of a country's development , the government should spend more money on economic development in order to sustain a healthy economic growth .
In addition , a prosperous economy will lead to the increase of wealth .
This means that the burden of supporting the aged by the society will be lessened .
Thus , developing the economy will bring benefits to both the country and the aged in long run .
On the flip side , spending on the aged is  equally  important  .
To limit spending on the aged does not mean that government should not spend on them .
As they are part of the country's population , there is a social responsibility to take care of the aged .
Moreover , this group of elderly had worked hard for years when they were young and had contributed to the economy and society .
I conclude that there is a need to limit public spending on the aged as there are other areas that require money for the country's development .
After all , the aged is not the only area that we should look into when deciding on the allocation of public spending .
There is a need for the government to take a wider perspective on the different areas that need money  when deciding on how much money is to be spent on each area .
Throughout the entire world ,  leaders of developed countries are concerned with the problems of an aging  population .
A country's budget would be spent in a few key areas such as defense , healthcare , environment , transport , research and development and education .
Public spending on the aged is necessary but should be limited in order for the money to be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
If majority of the spending is focused on the aged , it would limit the growth of the country  , which  would consequently lower the standard of living for all .
Firstly , with a shrinking workforce and an increase in expenditure required in welfare , the country will need to focus on developing the further generations .
"All who have meditated on the art of governing mankind have been convinced that the fate of empires depends on the education of youth" --- this quote by Aristotle clearly states that education is the crucial factor to determine a country's success and progress .
With proper education system , the young will be more productive when they enter the workforce .
Hence a highly skilled workforce in turn will boost the country economy and sustain the additional demands of a graying population .
The population should also be instilled with a strong sense of responsibility towards their parents from young through education .
Therefore a portion of public spending should be given to  equip the young with the right mind set and skills which are relevant to the needs of the workforce .
Secondly , a key area which requires funding is  research and development sector .
With strong support on research , new breakthrough can be discovered to cure chronic illnesses or age related diseases .
The cost of health care could be lowered with advancement in science and  medication which are more effective  .
Effective medication would translate into a shorter time spent in hospitals .
Therefore it lowers the elderly's burden on healthcare and improves or stabilizes the health of frail elderly .
Healthier elderly are able to return to the workforce and contribute to the country's development .
It may be argued that the amount invested in research does not produce equal rewards .
However , without continuous trials and errors ,  new innovations could not be made .
It is due to the persistent effort of researchers that many of today's technologies have been discovered .
Research and development on the defense of the country is also essential .
A country would be considered extremely vulnerable  with its graying population (less able-bodied individual) and outdated weaponry .
Thus with adequate funding on the research and development ,  the country will be at a better position .
Thirdly , an emphasis should be placed on the country's healthcare system .
With a shrinking workforce and an ever-increasing cost of living , the aged would  have difficulty coping with daily expenses and  medical bills .
Critical illnesses could empty  the elderly of their retirement fund and thus the government should provide medical subsidies .
If the government did not provide any form of aid and shifted the responsibility to the family or society , there would be catastrophic consequences .
Society could deem the government as unsympathetic .
Those who are more affluent might migrate  , which could cause a loss of investors and talents  .
This may affect the country's development .
Statistics have also shown that there is an increase in spending on prescribed medicine ; from $535 in 1999 to $1410 in 2001 (Goulding , 2005) .
Families footing the medical bills will in turn have lesser capital for the other expenses; namely , the children's education and  daily necessities .
Needy households might encourage their children to take up part time job to supplement the family finances .
Children might  grow up to be ineffective workers as their education have been disrupted .
This would negatively affect the society and the country's economy on a whole .
A developed country with a graying population brings about a shrinking workforce .
If spending were focused  on the aged it could cripple the country's economy and halt developments .
With appropriate  spending on key areas such as education , research and development and healthcare ,  the country could progress despite the additional demand of an aging population .
Leaders of the country should balance the benefits of individual , society and country with care to maximise the country's potential for development .
Dealing with baby boom had always been the predominant issue in the past decades .
Sectors like housing and consumers'market had to be carefully taken care of .
The economy underwent a series of revolutionary changes due to the  surge in population , hitting greater heights as the trend continued .
Now , the perennial concern of a fast an aging population has surrounded the world .
Increasing elderly spending has shrunk the budgets of many countries , especially the developed ones where the problem of aging population is more vivid .
If no effort is being put to limit the increasing healthcare and social security costs , expenditures on other priorities will soon come under pressure .
Although spending on the elderly is inevitable in the face of aging population , careful spending is necessary in diluting the effect of fiscal consequences .
Limiting elderly spending does not confine to only within the present .
It is about coming out with a permanent solution which would curb  spending in the long run .
In Australia , the mean-testing pensions have helped to cut down a significant amount of aging population costs .
However , statistics have shown that the nation's health care spending will still nearly double from 6 .4% of its GDP in 2002 to 11 .5% in 2025 due to the larger proportion of elderly in relative to its population .
Therefore , the fiscal outcome may not turn out to be ideal because other expenses such as education and national defence will end up being squeezed .
So it can be deduced that limiting elderly spending in the present does not equate to paying off in the future .
To deal with such challenges , the proportion of GDPs spent on healthcare and social security for the aging population should be aimed to scale down permanently .
Governments should spend more money on creating healthcare awareness .
As the average life expectancy in the world increases , people are living longer and they may become more vulnerable to contracting chronic illnesses at  old age .
Promoting healthy lifestyles and imparting valuable knowledge on healthcare are some of the options .
It is important for the elderly to know how and where to seek for help once they have contracted an illness  .
They can tackle the illness at its earlier stage , thus reducing the hefty healthcare costs if it were treated at a much later stage .
Eventually the economy will benefit when people become healthier and spend lesser on their healthcare .
After all , the benefits of this measure will definitely outweigh the limitations , and the measure is able to cut down the amount spent in the medical sector in  future .
Freidland and Summer (2005) suggest the importance of increased productivity of future workers , regardless of age , for better economic growth .
However , in the future , the bulk of the working population will have to come from the retiring baby boomers .
There are several limitations to the extent of how  productivity can be increased among these workers .
Firstly , for the more well-off elderly , they are less willing to work as they want to enjoy their retirement .
Secondly , more health issues will surface if the elderly are to work more or longer , especially for the less well-offs as most of them have difficulty in paying for their medical expenses .
Hence , in order to have  better economic growth , the process should be viewed with a more comprehensive perspective .
Government should provide a wider protection net for the elderly , such as implementing health insurances , promoting health campaigns  and  better welfare programs so as to reduce the mental and financial burden on the aged .
And this means spending on the elderly is required .
Although economic growth is important in providing care for the elderly , the limit  on the elderly spending should be set carefully , so that they would not create any adverse effects on the economy .
As the elderly will likely to form the core of the population in  future , they are becoming the major source of the economic growth .
Thus , their welfare and healthcare should be well taken care of .
When this condition is satisfied , economic growth then can be sustained to cater for other areas of country's development .
The aging population in Singapore is increasing .
This implies that there are lesser young people to support the larger group of elderly .
Therefore , the government has to channel more resources to look after the welfare of the elderly , especially in the healthcare sector  .
Additional hospitals , such as the Jurong Hospital , are being built in Singapore to meet the escalating demand for healthcare and to provide better services .
However , this may result in the elderly being over dependent on the government .
Eventually , this will strain the country's economy and development .
Thus , public spending on the aged should be controlled so that money can also be diverted to other important areas of the country's development .
This  gives rise to the problem of  the aged being self-sufficient and self-supporting in old age .
The elderly are physically disadvantaged in the workforce .
Moreover , employers often hesitate to employ them as the  society is technologically inclined  .
There are many young professionals who , although may not have  work and management experience ,  have the much sought after skills .
Thus , it might not be easy for the elderly to work and support themselves .
In addition , the elderly might be reluctant to work due to being over reliant on the government .
Apart from providing financial support to the elderly , the government should try to help the elderly in other ways so as to reduce the dependency of the elderly on the government .
Hence , public spending on the aged should be restricted .
"The Government has a duty to look after the elderly , he said , but it cannot replace the love and warmth of a family ," said PM Lee in the National Day Rally 2009 (2009 , Aug 17) .
The government has been constantly emphasizing the importance of filial piety and the duty of  children to look after their parents .
From young , the students are taught the values of filial piety .
In Singapore , filial piety is enforced legally .
The government came up with the Maintenance of Parents Act in  1996 and has been studying to  use  legal pressure to ensure that the children will take care of their parents  .
This would reduce the reliance of the elderly on the governmentand subsequently , the government's budget on the elderly need not be as huge .
The government has highlighted to the public the importance and benefits of Financial planning for  old age .
financial planning allows  people to provide for themselves when they have retired or are incapable of supporting themselves financially .
Thus , they would be less of a burden to the government .
The CPF sets aside a sum from their monthly salary to prepare for the rainy days and their old age .
The various aspects of the benefits of CPF include retirement , healthcare , home ownership , family protection and asset enhancement .
Hence , self supporting is another way to reduce dependency on the government .
The government has a duty to take care of the aging population .
However , they should limit  public spending on the aged .
The responsibility to look after the aged should be shouldered by the children as well .
In addition , the aged could prepare themselves for their old age  , and thus reduce the burden of others .
Limiting  public spending on the aged reduces their dependency on the government .
Also , more money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
Ageing population is a pervasive phenomenon affecting countries worldwide .
Governments have been working on strategies to deal with this problem .
One of the strategies is to increase the birth rate of the country .
For example , Singapore has implemented the baby bonus scheme to lighten the financial costs of raising children .
However , the government not only has to deal with reducing ageing population ,  but also to attend to the needs of the aged  .
There is a need to subsidize the aged for their healthcare , transport , facilities  .
More public spending has to be channeled to cater to the needs of the aged .
One may argue that public spending on the aged could be used on the country's development .
The development of the country is important but public spending on the aged should never be limited under all circumstances .
Public spending on the aged should not be limited .
The aged  deserves to receive the best welfare given by the country .
It is known that they had contributed to the country  during the prime  of their lives .
Their contributions should be recognized .
A practical way of recognizing their contribution is to provide them with subsidies and growth packages .
By limiting public spending on the aged , it may signify that the government perceives  the country's development to be as more important than the welfare of the people .
Some  people would resent the government for seeing development more important than its people .
In  extreme cases , some of them would hold protests to vent their anger towards the government .
There could be a social backlash if the government were to limit the public spending on the aged .
The people may view  the government as not wanting to take care of the aged , and see them as a burden .
This could cause the people to be skeptical about their welfare  in  future .
The morale of the local workforce could be affected .
Some people may seek to migrate to countries that will look after the welfare of the aged .
And the migration of the workforce would lead to a shortage of workers in the country .
Shortage of labour would impede the growth of the country .
Therefore , this would affect economic development of the country  .
On the other hand , limiting the amount of public spending  on the aged could help the country to develop more effectively during a crisis .
If the country faced an economic downturn , its revenue would be reduced .
This calls for a need for the government to spend on areas which could boost the economy .
Money should be spent more wisely in helping the country to get out of an economic downturn .
With  reduced revenue , the government should be more flexible in limiting the public spending on the aged .
By limiting  spending on the aged ,  the government will have more funds available to get the country out of an economic downturn .
More public funds could be allocated to education , and upgrading the skills for workers and building projects .
In the economic downturn , the government could use  their reserve funds instead .
This could be a morale booster for the people because the spending on the aged  is not reduced despite the economic downturn .
To conclude , the effects of limiting public spending on the aged should never be underestimated .
The government should weigh the social and economic cost of reducing public spending before making a decision . 
Limiting public spending on the aged is important because it indirectly controls the funds which would be channeled into other areas of a country's development .
This accounts for the difficulty in deciding the amount of funds to be diverted to helping the ageing population as many believe that money directed to boosting a country's economic growth is more practical than spending it on an ageing population which offers no economic returns .
Hence , a country should decide on the amount they want to commit on the ageing population as different amount would lead to different results .
For a country which places a low limit on  public spending for the aged , the amount of investment being channeled into other areas of the country's development would be lower than another with a higher limit on  public spending for the aged .
For example , Britain spends more on its ageing population as compared to America and its level of investment in research and development is lower than that of America .
However , this is not to say that  public spending on the aged is the sole factor for the cause of lower investments in other areas of a country's development , though it is only one of the many factors .
Nevertheless , it still affects the level of funds from being diverted to a country's development .
A low limitation limits the funds being diverted to other areas of the country's development such as education and economic developments .
This may result in a slowdown in the progress of a country because the progress of a country is dependent on its ability to keep up with the competitive global economy .
With less funds being pumped into areas such as technology and infrastructures , investments may flow out when other nations offer better incentives .
This would then lead to an overall fall in the revenue of a country which will translate into a drop in the public spending on the aged (Weil:1997) .
Thus ,  negative results are  achieved , with neither the aging population nor the country's economy benefitting from it .
However , it may be argued that countries such as Britain are still progressing well in the global economy despite a high level of spending on the aged population  .
This shows  that a low limitation on public spending does not equate  a halt in the progress of a country .
In addition , the low level of limitation would mean that quality healthcare is being catered for the elderly as sufficient money are being invested in them .
This may lead to a healthier ageing population which may then contain the spread of elderly illnesses (Dunnell:1995) .
This containment could possibly lead to a fall in money being diverted to the aged population as they are healthier now; and thus increasing the funds being diverted to other areas of the country's development .
On the other hand , a country with a high limitation of public funds allocated to the aged means that more funds are being diverted to other areas on their country's development .
For instance , Singapore spend approximately 9 million on her ageing population , encouraging elderly independence instead .
Thus , she has a greater amount of money to be diverted to other areas .
Again , this is not to imply that the spending on the aged population is the sole factor leading to investments in other areas of Singapore .
With  lesser funds being channeled to the aged population , more of it may then be used in areas that can spur the development for a country .
This may allow improvements in fields such as infrastructures , research and development , education and technology .
Hence , it may attract more investments and that can generate more revenue of a country  , which in turn may increase the spending on the aged population (Weil:1997) .
Hence , a win-win situation is achieved .
However , the increase in investments may not necessary lead to a rise in the revenue of a country because an outflow of capital may occur as those investments are foreign based .
Also , one cannot be sure that the increase in revenue would be diverted to the ageing population as a country may continuously tap on the increase in revenue to spur more economic growth .
Lastly , by having a high limitation , it may mean that proper healthcare and medical technology are not provided for the ageing population and this may lead to a poorer health standard among the aged .
This would then translate into a more serious problem as the country would then need to pump in even more money to increase the health standard of the elderly in the future (Weil:1997) .
Hence it can be seen that different levels of limitations on public spending produce different results , which can be both good and bad as shown above .
These results may not be the same for all countries because each country has its own unique way of implementing different policies to deal with its ageing population .
But there is no doubt that public spending on the aged should be limited because it affects the level of funds being diverted to areas that aid the development of a country .
However , more importantly , it is the levels of limitation that a country has to take note of .
Different countries will have  different level of limitation because of the differences they have within their societies .
In conclusion , each country should understand its society well and implement a limit which will best benefit its ageing population and economy .
Fast-aging population remains a precarious global challenge in today's world .
This unprecedented demographical shift with the number of dependent adults surpassing the number of dependent children envisages serious negative impacts , from declining of work forces and real GDP to sharp increasing of elderly fiscal cost , that will impoverish and subsequently impede developmental growth .
Among all , the astronomical healthcare-cost issues generate most controversial arguments as more chronic degenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's or arthritis are perceived as an inevitable component which tend to manifest in the later life .
Nonetheless , current research and development as well as policy have preeminently help to alleviate the dire consequences of the aging process  .
Alzheimer's or Alzheimer Disease is the most common form of dementia mostly diagnosed in people aged 65 and above .
It is well-known as a terminal disease leading to cognitive impairment , memory loss , apraxia , aggression , muscle mass and motor skills deterioration and ultimately death results in complication by external factors .
According to Bonin-Guillaume , Zekry , Giacobini , Gold and Michel (2005) as well as Meek , McKeithan and Schumock (1998) , dementia specifically Alzheimer's is one of the most costly diseases for society in Europe and the United States , placing great psychological , physical and economic burden on caregivers and governments .
It is speculated (Alzheimer's Disease International , 2006) that the figure of dementia patients in Asia Pacific will quadruple to 65 million by 2050 .
This could be a calamitous tribulation to the nation .
However , scientists are now offering glimmers of hope by making headway on research to diagnose , treat , prevent and optimistically to cure this devastating disease .
For example , last year , Prana Biotechnology in Melbourne (Reader's Digest , Sept 2009) developed PBT2 that targets and reduces beta amyloid , a sticky protein hypothesized to be the cause of Alzheimer's which form plaques that kills brain cells .
Memory and learning behaviours are reported to improve drastically sometimes within hours being given the drug .
Other drugs such as Rember , are announced to delay progression of the disease up to 81 percent while Dimebon promised to power and halt the perishing of brain cells (Reader's Digest , Sept 2009) .
Researchers also hope to develop early detection methods which  help by prescribing preventive medication before the actual occurrence of the disease .
Moreover , advanced molecular understanding of scientists towards life-span reveals that contrary to common belief , aging is actually regulated by specific cellular pathways instead of being an uncontrolled gradual breakdown process .
This implies that aging perhaps can be influenced with the manipulation of certain cells .
The breakthrough took place with the discovery of Sirtuins , a group of anti-aging genes (Dipp , Guarente , Westphal , 2007)  (Kennedy and Valter , 2006) .
The theory by a group of researchers from Harvard Medical School (as cited in Reader Digest , Sept 2009) suggests that "with more Sirtuins , DNA repair would be more efficient"  , enabling the subject (mouse) to maintain a youthful or healthy gene pattern into old age , eliminating traits of aging and subsequently increasing lifespan by 24 to 46 percent .
In short , based on the findings ,aging may one day be reversible .
Critics have argued that though these researches are seemingly impressive and hopeful , there is simply no concrete empirical evidence on their practical significance or effectiveness .
Furthermore , these findings fail to address the exigent issues of aging societies presently facing .
Yet , one should be constantly aware and confident of the actualization of technology's development for a promising future on account of the past .
Also , policies are implemented in attempts to dissolve current concerns .
Countries like Singapore who have long promulgatpromulgated self-reliance do adopt certain policy framework such as  the 3M's--- Medisave , Medishield and Medifund simultaneously with Eldershield , to protect and support citizens on  Healthcare cost .
Government subsidies on a wide range of intermediate and long-term care services such as community hospitals and dementia care centers are available for patients  , especially elderly who require continuing care after hospitalization .
between the Oxford Institute of Ageing and the Singapore Council for Third Age (C3A) are launched to educate  , as well as promote active aging among Singaporeans (The Oxford Institute of Ageing and Ow , G , 2009) .
In conclusion  , society should now move toward a new paradigm : aging is not a burden  on the economy or the development of a country .
Although fertility rates have fallen , longevity has increased .
Advancement in technology has certainly  transformed the definition and experience of aging .
An aging population has been an issue in recent years as the increment in the social needs of the elderly and  public spending  , as well as the burden on the younger generations have governments probing  into the issue .
Despite these significant consequences related to an aging population , "they (Governments) must realize that any further expansion of retirement benefits would only impoverish future generations and limit future public spending" (Peterson , 2001) .
As concerns have been raised on the effectiveness of excessive money injected into financing social welfare policies to arrest short term issues , the improper use of public spending will likely to create much burden for the next generation .
These measures almost certainly do not benefit the nation in the long run .
Therefore , public spending should be spent on other sectors of the economy  .
There is little doubt that social welfare policies can alleviate the difficult situations that  aging populations are facing today .
Direct monetary policies can provide a significant income support for them .
For example , the public assistance program can provide the elderly with a sense of security for food , shelter and daily necessities .
Some of the elderly have no dependents and they live by themselves , while others are looking at hefty medical bills and healthcare costs as their health deteriorates .
As the aging population grows ,  spending should increase proportionately  to ensure that the elderly are taken care of .
This can prove beneficial to the elderly as significant changes in living standards are achieved .
At the same time , the economy benefits from it since there will be fewer costly social issues . 
Excessive public spending only adds to the comfort of the aging population and does not effectively benefit the economy .
As the elderly will not be encouraged to work ,  they will take for granted that the government is providing everything for them .
For instance , if a physically fit old man is given monetary assistance beyond the minimum amount , he will not be compelled to work  , especially if the benefit  made up a large part of his salary .
Another example in Singapore can be the availability of funds allocated to town councils for social welfare services  .
The government has not effectively utilized tax payers' money to the best of its ability .
As resources are being poured into  different sectors in the economy , growth will increase along with public spending .
This is ensured by the motivation for personal gains in the economy as each seeks to benefit the most out of the stimulus that governments would inject into the economies .
For instance , as more money is being pumped into the infrastructural development within a country , the industries benefit  , with lesser taken to set up plants , tax benefits and cheaper rental .
All these will drive the costs of doing business down .
As these costs decline , businesses become more profitable when they effectively try to make use of the incentive from the government and this may translate to better salaries  .
The elderly can then benefit from larger social budget allocation as the economy grows .
At the end of the day , public spending should always be limited to finance the basic needs of the aging population .
Governments should weigh the costs and benefits associated with each dollar being spent on social policies and the economy .
They must then determine where the necessary point is to effectively solve the issues an aging population is facing and then channel the remaining resources into the other sectors of the economy .
With proper policies  , "public budgetary resources would be used only to secure minimum standards and basic social services"  (Tanzi .
V . and Schuknecht , 2000)Till then , only  can the economies as well as the aging population benefit  from the effective use of tax payers' money .
Public spending on the aged should be limited as money should be spent on other areas such as defense and public infrastructure as they play  more important roles in a country's future development .
Currently , most developed nations such as Japan , Singapore and Australia are facing problems on their societies turning grey as the numbers working to support the old are dwindling .
This causes social security problems which question the ability of the young to support a larger number of people .
An aging society means a smaller working force which would result in lesser tax payers This might cause in a decline in government fund .
It is not feasible for a country to spend more on the elderly when funds have a possibility of being decreased in future years .
Money for the aged can be saved as people should take care of their own parents when they become old .
In the Singapore's context , each child has to take a compulsory module of moral education in their early years of schooling .
It teaches the importance of family coherence and the virtue of filial piety .
With these values in placed , responsibility in taking care of the elderly should not be pushed to the government but should be shouldered by the people themselves .
A step further was taken to reinforce this idea .
The maintenance of parents act  protects the future of the elderly , allowing the elderly to sue for monetary needs if their children refused to provide . 
Funds should be used more on developing talents instead .
The problem that the aging population is facing right now is the lack of human resources .
We should now invest in creating and attracting talents , both local and foreign  , to reduce the impact of the dwindling working force .
Taking Japan for example , by year 2050 , one in three Japanese will be past their retirement age as the average birth rate is reported at 1 .23 babies per woman .
One of the solutions is to do a "replacement migration" where  foreign talents are recruited to strengthen the  human resource in certain countries .
A country can secure these talents by setting aside funds for education , giving bursaries and scholarships to attract foreign students whom will in turn stay and work .
Other than talents , providing the people with a high level of security is essential .
There are currently growing fears of terrorism after the September 11 attacks  .
Funds should be cast aside for security purposes , such as military technology to protect the people from external threats .
Only by living in a safe country then can one enjoy the benefits of living to a ripe old age .
Moreover , a dwindling population signifies that there are lesser people to defend the country .
Therefore , technology is highly needed to replace the loss of manpower .
However , not all elderly are well supported by their children .
During the wallstreet meltdown in 2008 , many have lost their jobs .
With huge families facing financial crises , the government will have to stand in to provide for the elderly in need .
Not only that ,  elderly who are being abandoned or are childless are disadvantaged as there is no one to support them  in the future .
Therefore , the retirement age should be extended and people should be educated to work longer and save more for their future livelihood .
The elderlylderly should be more independent instead .
Some portion of the funds can be saved if people start to become responsible  .
In an aging societywith lesser tax payers , government funds will eventually drop and this will provide a huge cut in possible public expenditures needed to sustain a country .
With the portion of money saved , it can be used in other areas of developments , which will bring about a better living environment for the people .
Therefore , funds should be limited in the area of spending on the aged .
This year , our government intends to spend $42 .1 million on community- based and residential programmes for the elderly and the disabled (Singapore Budget , 2009) .
Let us just think about the money that is going to be spent on the elderly .
Now , the problem some may question is whether such expenditure is too much .
Why not use the money in other areas so that these areas can improve ?
However , we need to realize that the older population  refers to people who are not only oldbut are also facing certain difficulties in supporting themselves and they may  help to do better .
Thus , I do not think that we should limit the amount of money to be spent on the elderly .
As mentioned earlier , one reason why we should not limit the spending is that it may not be fair to the elderly when  there may be those who are really in great need of  support from the government .
We do know that the older population has a higher chance of facing illnesses and inconveniences in their physical movements .
Furthermore , based on the Census 2000 data , in Singapore , we have 14 percent of the elderly who only live with their spouses and 12 percent of the elderly do not live with their immediate family (citation , 2000) .
These elderly are facing problems in their lives .
In this case , they may not have the financial ability to take care of themselves without any help from the government .
Hence , it is the government's duty to  render the help to them instead of limiting the help they can receive .
Another reason why we should not limit  public spending on the older population is because of the fact that the phenomenon of ageing population is expected to continue growing .
By limiting it , the amount may not be able to cater to all the needs in the future as the limit is set on the basis of a population at a particular time .
Yet over the years , when this group of people increases , especially at rather high rate , the amount needed will be more than the amount being put aside  . 
However , there is always an opposite side to the issue .
If we did not limit the amount we are spending on the elderly now , this amount would increase proportionately with the increasing number of the elderly in the future .
This will cause the proportion  left for developments in other areas to be reduced in the future as well .
In an article in the Reuters , it is indeed believed that as the United States faces growing number of  older people , pension and healthcare services are pushed up and thus , compelling major increases in public expenditure (Maggie , 2009) .
However , I see the argument in another way .
The amount of money that the government can use for developments in other areas may not increase even after limiting the spending on elderly .
This is because in actual fact , the burden is shared by the families of the elderly as well as the government .
The government does not pay the full cost .
If we limit the amount the government pays , the additional cost falls on the shoulders of the family members which will then be shifted back to the government by the family in other means (Robert and Laura , 2005) .
Since no difference is expected , be it limiting the amount or not doing so , we should try to reduce the pressure that will be felt by the majorities in the future , such as having to pay for the high expenses for the elderly at home .
After looking at both sides , we can see that the older population is not a small group of people and the number will continue to increase in number in the future .
Thus , to cater to the needs of the older population , which may also be the largest group of people within the country in the future , it is best not to limit the amount .
Instead , keeping it flexible , such as to have it increased in times of great need will be a better choice .
Our society is aging .
The Madrid International Plan of Action on Ageing (2002) highlighted: "since year 1950 , the average life expectancy has increased by 20 years and is expected to extend a further 10 years by 2050" .
This increase in life expectancy has been said to be the result of better public health care and advances in medical care .
Governments , realizing that there will be profound consequences followed by this global demographic transformation , have now come out with different strategies and policies to ease the aging process .
Nevertheless , the effectiveness of current research and policies in helping to ease the aging process are doubted by the public .
In fact , it calls into the question whether the elderly really benefit from the policy implemented in the aspect of financial security , employment and living arrangements  .
In terms of economics , old age financial support is the government's main concern and therefore mechanisms that provide citizens with financial security in old age have been introduced .
For instance , the Central Provident Fund (CPF) , a comprehensive financial savings plan for the workers , has been implemented in Singapore .
Although the CPF was aimed to give security to the retired elderly by providing income to support their basic needs in old age ,  it has been accused for its deficiency .
Shantakumar (1999) , Asher (1996 and 1998) , Lee (1999 an 2001a) ,  pointed out the lack of universal coverage and the lack of adequacy of funds for retirement security in the CPF scheme , especially for the low-income elderly (as cited in David R . Phillips and Alfred C .M .
Chan , 2002) .
