Along with the criticism , recent National Survey of Senior Citizens 2005 (Ministry of Community Development , Youth and Sports , 2005) showed that only 41 .3 per cent of the elderly aged 55 and above had CPF savings and , of these , 61 .6 per cent felt that their CPF savings were inadequate .
Meanwhile , in a study by Asia Times Online (Megawati Wijaya , 2009) , it was shown that   less than 5% of the current elderly population rely on CPF disbursements for their livelihood .
All  these prove the failure of the CPF scheme in providing a secure future life for most of the elderly .
Apart from that , the government's initiative in raising  retirement age is also seen to be not effective .
In Singapore , the retirement age for its citizens will be raised from 62 to 65 by 2012 and eventually to 67 along with the higher life expectancy of its ageing population (Reuters - The Inquirer , 2007) .
It is undeniable that by increasing the retirement age , the elderly will be able to accumulate wealth and eventually the strain on their finances  will be ease .
However , people should take note that the problem now is not about the mandatory retirement age of the elderly , but  the employability problem faced by the senior citizens .
Most of the elderly claimed that they could not find a job even though they have the willingness to extend their retirement age .
The National Survey of Senior Citizens 2005(Ministry of Community Development , Youth and Sports , 2005) showed that among the current generation of the elderly , only 28 .2% of them are employed .
This data shows the seriousness of the employability problem among the senior citizens .
Therefore , unless the employability problem is resolved , the increase in the retirement age might worthnothing to most of the elderly that are now  unemployed .
Besides that , the a ttractive financial incentives for  co-residence with  parents which are introduced by the Singapore government have faced certain criticisms .
Inevitably , after the financial incentives such as tax reliefs and priority housing have been introduced , there are more adult children who live with , or nearby , their elderly parents .
However , the anncrease in  co-residences with  parents does not imply increase in the willingness of the children in taking care of their parents .
No one can guarantee that children who live nearby their parents will eventually take good care of them .
There are children who live nearby their parents just because of the attractive incentives .
As suggested in  Channel NewsAsia (Asha Popatlal , 2009) , there are more elderly citizens applying to the Tribunal for Maintenance of Parents over the last 12 months .
"From August 2008 to July this year , 172 people filed applications , much higher than the average of 100 in previous years" .
(citation) This figure shows that  the rate of co-residence increaseswith the cases of parental abuse .
Therefore , it is possible for people to remain dubious about the effectiveness of promoting co-residence in improving the quality of care of the elderly by the adult children .
In conclusion , to a large extent , current policies implemented have not helped much to ease the aging process .
It is mainly due to the deficiency in the policies themselves .
For the CPF scheme , there is lack of adequate funds to ensure retirement security .
For the later retirement act , there is employability problems among the elderly that need to be resolved .
For the co-residence  , there is doubt on the quality of care that the older parents received from their children .
Therefore , current policies should be re-evaluated in their feasibility and should be amended in order to reach the ultimate goalof easing the aging process .
''Public spending on the aged should be limited so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
''I  fully agreed with this statement .
Nowadays , a lot of countries are having aging problem , especially advanced counties like Japan , Sweden , Germany , Singapore and the United State of America .
This global aging is also starting to affect some developing nations such as Malaysia and Thailand .
According to the journals 'A Graying World' and 'Doomsday Predications about Population Aging Are Exaggerated' , the population of aged 65 and older is anticipated to more than double by year 2030 and furthermore median age in many first-world countries will reach between 52 to 54 by 2050 .If the fertility rates do not rise again , the problem will be worsened  .
Demographic changes due to growing aging population will have  serious consequences on health issues .
Governments are forced to spend more money to overcome them .
For instance , Singapore needs to restructure the whole health care system due to the aging population as mentioned by the Singapore Prime Minister .
However , the funds have to be used wisely and diverted to other fields of the country's development .
Firstly , governments have to continue to raise the retirement age in line with rising life expectancies .
The elderly are encouraged to work longer to accumulate more wealth ,  which could be used to support themselves .
Moreover , a tardy  fertility rate has increased the importance of having an workforce in the market .
They could help to boost  economic growth by being involved in different kind of sectors .
For some countries with little economic growth , the society faces few choices on how to care for those who are least able to care for themselves .
On the other hand , with sufficient economic growth there are more choices and fewer persons in need ( Robert B . Friedland and Laura Summer ,2005 ) .
Secondly , money can be diverted to the education sector  .
Well educated people tend to have higher incomes and better health generally .
These people are not only helping the government to cut down expenditures on health care , but also helping the country to generate more income ,  as well as to stabilize the economy .
That is why a lot of countries are spending  a large portion in education .
To illustrate , education expenditures always occupy  a larger segment in the fiscal budget in Singapore and Malaysia .
Besides , public policies that encourage and facilitate education , basic research , and the application of promising technologies can enhance the well-being of current and future generations of older people ( Robert B . Friedland and Laura Summer ,2005 ) .In other words , elites are able to invent more advanced technology to accelerate nationational development .
All advanced nations are using high technology in every field .
For example , Japan is one of the countries which uses the most advanced technology in manufacturing .
Its car industry almost dominates the world market and has always produced the top-selling cars in most of the countries  .
For instance ,  Honda and Toyota are preferred by a lot of car users .
These companies are not only making cars , but are also involved in technology exploration to benefit people .
The Japanese government  gives subsidies to these companies to create something more innovative in solving  daily life problems .
Consequently , Japanese is one of the most civilized races in the world .
In contrast , North Korea is still a communist country and it is conservative .
Everything is under government control and civilians are not given any chance to involve in monopoly or private business .
All the market judgments are determined by the government itself .
Moreover , most of the funds are spent on nuclear research and relatively there are less spending on  people's needs .
This  causes the majority of North Koreans living in poverty .
In addition , governments could give subsidies or incentives to encourage people to increase fertility rates .
Nowadays , people are more educated and usually having small families .
If governments provide subsidies to encourage couples to have more children , fertility rates might be changed .
For example , the Singapore government gives different types of incentives and benefits to encourageparents to have and raise children .
The increase in fertility rates is very important to every country as it could generate more manpower  , as well as reinforce the country's military strength .
In a nut shell , every country needs to consider wisely about public spending on the aged .
Other fields of the country's development are important too .
Therefore , governments may have to choose the most sustainable and efficient way to plan for their national budgets .
The Survey of Senior Citizens (1995) showed that although the health status among respondents aged 60 and older was generally good , more than 30 per cent have received treatments for some chronic illnesses .
The majority of respondents had little or no formal education .
About 25 per cent males and 69 per cent females  were never married ,  widowed or divorced .
Collectively , these findings suggest that the elderly must rely on others for financial and social support .
Another policy is to ensure that Singaporeans are financially secure after retirement .
The Central Provident Fund (CPF) has been the state institution to provide economic support to older Singaporeans .
Currently , Singapore's CPF has the highest coverage of all retirement plans in Asia (Asher , 2006) .
In 2007 , Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced that the age at which individuals can withdraw their minimum sums will be increased from 62 to 65 .
This move will increase the period of time for individual savings to last during retirement .
CPF LIFE was launched this month to provide Singaporeans a lifelong income into old age .
Members will receive a monthly income depending on the cash savings they have in their Retirement Account for as long as they live (http://mycpf .cpf .gov .sg/Members/Gen-Info/CPF_LIFE/CPF_LIFE .htm , accessed 14 September 2009) .
In addition , for individuals 62 and above , the Housing Development Board will buy back the lease of their apartment and provide a shorter lease of 30 years for the same flat .
There would be two payouts; a lump sum up front and monthly installments for the rest of the individual's life .
All these schemes ensure adults have at least a source of cash income available to them during old age .
However , the main source of financial and emotional support for older persons in Singapore still rests with the family .
Approximately 60 per cent of older adults live in households where other family members pay for all the expenses .
One-fifth of older adults are self sufficient and there is almost no dependence on welfare (Chan , 2001) .
Additionally , co-residence or living in close proximity to children remains the norm in Singapore .
Only 9 .3 per cent of the 60-plus lived alone or in other arrangements , and 5 .8 per cent lived only with their spouses .
The majority received financial or in-kind support from their children , if these were present (Yap , 2008) .
Existing policies would be rendered inadequate without the family being responsible for the care of its older members .
Nevertheless , filial obligation should be stressed .
The Government has introduced schemes to encourage Singaporeans to maintain their parents such as the legislation on filial piety , which is as the Maintenance of Parents Act (Vasoo , Ngiam , 2000) .
Under this scheme , elderly parents who have no other support can claim financial aid from their children .
Taxpayers who maintain their parents or grandparents in Singapore are also given income tax relief .
These social policies should be credited in helping the current generation of older adults cope with the emotional and behavourial challenges of the aging process .
An aging population has been talked about much in recent years .
Goh (2007) stated that countries like Singapore and Japan who face a fast aging population are expected to have a projected median age of 54 and 55 respectively .
Hauner , Leigh , and Skaarup (2007) believed that countries with a high and rising old-age dependency ratio will expect their age-related spending to escalate by 4 percentage point of their GDP (Gross Domestic Product) over the next 45 years .
As a result , governments and policy makers around the world are ready to set aside a larger portion of their countries' budget to cater for age-related spending , with healthcare for the elderly as most of their top priorities .
However , to avoid compromising the development of other sectors , it is essential for policy makers to limit  spending on the elderly by looking into viable alternatives .
Prime Minister Lee (2009) suggested that although it is the government's duty to look after the elderly , children should do their filial duty by taking care of their own parents .
However , some might argue that the burden of their own families and the high cost of living in Singapore make it hard for them to provide for their parents' living expenses .
While this may be true , it is still possible if these working adults can make adjustments to their lifestyles by cutting down on unnecessary expenses like the purchasing of luxury items .
This way , they are able to provide for their parents instead of abandoning them in a home or hospital .
Even though the government can look after the aged , Prime Minister Lee (2009) has pointed out that it is ultimately the warmth and love from the families that they need .
Majority of the elderly are not concerned with how much their children give them ; instead they are satisfied as long as their children are able to spend time with them and show their love and concern for them .
By taking care of their own parents , these working adults can be positive examples for their children .
Under the influence of their parents , these children will be more likely to follow in their footsteps and will voluntarily take care of them when they are old .
Therefore , it is highly encouraged that children should fulfil their filial duty by looking after and caring for their own parents .
Chow (2008) proposed that mandatory medical savings scheme should be implemented in order to tackle the challenges of an aging population and the rising medical costs in Hong Kong .
Critics of this proposal have pointed out that the money set aside for this scheme will go to waste if the elderlypassed  away even before they can utilize them .
However , governments of many countries have urged that such saving scheme that offers health protection can be unpredictable .
By implementing a mandatory medical savings scheme , its contributors will have a ready sum of money to deal with any hefty medical cost which they may incur when they get older .
In this way , it minimizes the chances of them  being unable to afford their medical bills , and at the same time reduces the heavy burden on government subsidies .
The scheme provides not only protection for its contributors .
In addition , a substantial payout from the medical insurance will be awarded if he or she is to encounter any mishap  , of which   death or any form of disability would render the contributor being unable to work .
This ensures that the family is still able to sustain themselves financially in the event that the contributor is unable to provide for the family .
Hence , implementing a mandatory savings scheme is essential to its contributors , their families and the government .
Lee (2008) proposed the plan to limit social welfare spending in South Korea in order to invest in programs that will increase the country's economic growth .
At this point , one might wonder if this move will compromise the welfare of the society and the elderly  .
While this may be a problem , a potential growth in the country's economy will allow for even more funds to be made available for the area of social welfare in the future .
With a limited social welfare fund , people will rely lesser on the government and more on themselves .
Hence , it encourages them to work harder and save more in order to be better prepared for old age .
Furthermore , the limited spending on social welfare releases funds which can be diverted to other key sectors .
For example , these funds can be used in the research and development of  cures for terminal illnesses like cancer .
So , limiting spending on social welfare might just prove to be a feasible strategy which benefits the country in various aspects .
Countries with a fast aging population face an ongoing battle against the ever increasing welfare and health care costs .
It is therefore crucial that the governments and policy makers do not recklessly sink huge portion of their countries' spending on these areas .
Instead , they should be looking at viable solutions that do not compromise the development of the other sectors .
Therefore , a boundary to the spending on the elderly should be set in order to avoid increasing the burden on future generations and upsetting of the development of other key sectors as mentioned earlier .
"Until recently , the ills of old age interested only poets and philosophers .
However , this has changed because governments and policy makers in the developed world are now confronted with the unprecedented problem of a fast aging population"   (Peterson  , 2001) .
The aging population has become a major issue in many developed countries , including the United States , Japan and Singapore .
Increasing population of the aged created many problems on the society .
Clearly , both governments and the public are becoming more aware of this issue .
Governments in various countries have come up with different policies to address the problem of an increasingly aging population .
As the problem of the aging population worsens , governments have to spend increasing amount of money to counter the problem and at  the expense of other areas of the country's development .
It is important that governments take note of this and control their spending so as not to neglect  other more important areas such as  education and the economy .
Governments are stressing on filial obligation and hope to increase the willingness of tomorrow's grown children to support their own elderly parents .
However , such practices are not common .
It is crucial for the government to spend money on the aged  , as not doing so will lead to social problems .
Already , we are seeing a breakdown in extended families .
The young no longer see filial piety as being important .
The elderly who are unable to support themselves and are being abandoned by their children will have nowhere to turn to if the government turned its back on them .
This will lead to increased crime rates , begging and vagrancy in the country , which are harmful for society .
However , this is not the only area where government spending is required .
As countries spend more money  on the aged , other important sectors such as defense and education may get neglected and become under budgeted .
These sectors are as important as , if not more important than , spending on  an aging population .
For example ,  in an increasingly challenging global economy , it becomes increasingly important for countries to focus on education to maintain a skilled workforce .
An educated workforce increases productivity , which drives the economy  to increased wealth .
By increasing public spending on an aging population , governments risk overlooking other areas of the country's development  .
Moreover , healthcare cost has been increasing .
New technologies and treatments for the aged are relatively expensive .
Governments have been spending too much money on the subsidies to help the aging population .
People may take advantage of the the government subsidies to pay for  expensive new technologies which are not necessary .
Governments should specify the types of treatments that it considers essential and subsidise these treatment , while leaving non-essential treatment cost to be borne by the consumer .
Limiting public spending will make sure that government does not overspend on treatment that is not essential  , so that the money can be diverted to other areas .
It is hard to cure the illnesses of the aged .
Governments may be spending too much money over expensive medical infrastructure such as  new facilities to suit the elderly .
Medical facilities can only prolong their lives  , which do not have any significant impact on the country's economy .
Instead , the governments can divert the money into other projects that are more beneficial to the country's development .
In Singapore , one of such projects includes the investment on infrastructure .
Such spending generates revenue and boosts the economy .
For example , a new entertainment centre can attract tourists  , which will increase foreign spendingand benefit the tourism sector .
Governments should be cautious of their spending on expensive medical infrastructure which does not contribute to the country's future developmentand should focus more on the nation's areas of development that do .
It is important and  governments plan their finances well to benefit different sectors of the country .
Public spending is increasing rapidly with the growing aged population that governments are losing control of their spending .
Governments should adopt a wider perspective to ascertain whether the spending is necessary or  the money should be diverted to other areas .
Public spending should be controlled to establish a balanced outcome for both the young and the aged .
If the usage of public funds is not well balanced , it will not only affect the country's development , but also put the country's future into jeopardy .
It is undeniable that aging population is still one of the current issues that are affecting our world nowadays .
It is predicted that the problem will be worse in the future: many of the people in the first world countries will reach the median age of 53 .
Therefore , much should be done to help ease the aging process to avoid social and economical problems in the future .  
Of all the different aspects of development that have been done to ease the aging process , the most significant field is medicine .
The aging population has forced a restructuring of the whole healthcare system .
In Singapore , to provide a better life for the  aged  , many new hospitals are built ,  such as the Khoo Teck Puat Hospital in Yishun and the Jurong General Hospital .
With these new hospitals , the  aged patients get better treatment  .
They do not have to wait too long and travel too far to a particular hospital to see the doctor .
More  hospitals are built to provide appropriate service to the elderly .
With this , the elderly will be able to enjoy their stays in  hospitals and do their medical check ups regularly to maintain a healthy lifestyle .
Although more hospitals were being built  , many  aged patients with financial problems can't afford  to go to them .
Knowing this , the Singapore government provides sufficient financial aid to help the poor elderly .
Subsidies are given to the eligible ones to help them overcome this problem .
On the other hand , there are also researches done on illnesses which most commonly affect the  aged .
Researches on healthcare are being done to help maintain or improve the health of the elderly .
Better solutions are hoped to be found in order to help the elderly with their health issues .
For instance , in the United Kingdom , researches on dementia are being done to find a better solution to cure the patients , who are mostly the  aged .
According to Rebecca Wood , the Chief Executive of the Alzheimer's Research Trust , the population living with dementia is forecast to double within a generation .
To help ensure less elderly from suffering from dementia in the future , researches are now being done by the UK .
Much investment have been put into this research to defeat this illness which is currently and will to continue to haunt the  aged .
Some may argue that these researches do not help to ease the aging process because most of the time and money are wasted as the proper solutions are never to be   .
But it is better to try rather than to allow the devastating disease continue to haunt  the older generations .
Besides researches and developments in the field of medicine , social policy also plays a  role in helping to ease the aging process .
Many countries have taken this step to  lighten the burden of the elderly  .
In Japan , the government has imposed the "National Pension Scheme" on all its citizens  .
In this scheme , a basic  pension is provided for all citizens who are above 65 years of age and have contributed for 25 years or more to the country .
This scheme is helpful in easing the burden of the elderly as it provides financial security for them .
The  aged can then be independent and they do not need to rely on their children for money .
The  aged can live a comfortable life without worrying or without seeking for financial aid  .
On the other hand , with these schemes , children need not do their duty to take care of their parents .
This may result in social problems in a country .
The younger generation will not be filial to their parents and will not bear the burden to take care of the older generation and will  push the burden onto the government .
Although such thoughts may arise ,  there are no better ways to guarantee a better life for the  aged .
Clearly , all these researches , developments and policies have helped the aging population to get a better life .
This effort should be continued  as this would guarantee the living standard of the  aged .
Thus , with the living standard of the elderly guaranteed , the social problems can also be avoided in a country .
In conclusion , the issue on the "graying world" can be solved and well taken care of if necessary steps are taken to prevent it .
Caring for the aged is definitely an act to be applauded for and encouraged .
Some might have the perception that caring for the aged is the theiresponsibility of the country .
Nothing could be further from the truth; to care for the aged is to be taken upon by respective dependants , such as their children .
In fact , the ideal situation would be that they should actually take the initiative to be responsible for their own welfare .
If the country were to spend its budget entirely caring for the aged , then many citizens would shove responsibilities and  would  not care for their own health , since the healthy , as represented by the country , would care for them .
While it is important to care for the aged , it is just as important to take into consideration and not neglect other areas of the country's development .
Thus public spending on the aged should be limited .
Since birth , parents would give the best to their children  , from clothing to education and this should be reciprocated .
Being able-bodied and in good health , children should not forget their parents' kindness towards them .
They should assume this responsibility by providing for their parents .
On the other hand , a substantial amount could be saved if not spent in caring for the aged , thereby enabling more funds to be diverted for the country's development in many other areas .
To rely on ourselves would still be the best option  .
For a start , prior planning is crucial  , when from young , one should  be  actively saving .
This would be  beneficial in the short run , when facing emergencies , or in the long run , when facing retirement .
Policies that encourage skills upgrading have also been introduced to enable the aged to re-enter the workforce .
This is further enhanced by incentives being offered to companies that hire them .
Instead of grieving with regrets of having to work after reaching the retirement age , they could actually be optimistic and take this as an opportunity to be active in the society  , where they could  establish friendships through interactions at work .
Not only could they be able to sustain living through earnings obtained from working , the aged could also keep a healthy mind and body .
Although it would be ideal if the government need not  be 'burdened' with expenses to care for the aged , it is not feasible .
There are those who are without any dependants and savings to see them through their retirement years .
In addition , it could also be dreadful for those who are not well equipped with education or skills to work and who really needs the country's help .
Even so , the country should not be obliged to care for them entirely .
Help given could be in many other forms instead of just monetary  .
With policies such as those that encourage the aged to acquire new skills , the government could also provide aid by compensating the loss in
income during that period of 'learning' .
Although help is given , it is not encouraged for the aged to continuously be reliant on it .
Instead , with the skills acquired , they should 'venture' out and earn a living of their own which would in turn reap many returns in both monetary  and health .
It is also true that  "work can help us stay physically active , mentally alert , socially connected and financially self-reliant" (Yap , 2009 , p . 7) .
To rely on the country's help is definitely not a solution in caring for the aged .
In fact , every single one of us has a responsibility and role to play  in caring for them and the country .
When the country's resources are not focused mainly in caring for the aged , it could be diverted to other areas of the country's development , such as the economic and social developments .
Limiting  public spending in caring for the aged and diverting it to other areas of the country's development would reap success in the long run  .
Many  many would be able to enjoy economic and social benefits then .
A country always has to be ready to with any form of challenges .
One such challenge  would be the ageing population .
To find a solution to that problem , certain amount of the public spending has to be diverted to it .
However an ageing population is not the only concern of any government .
Therefore public spending on the aged should be limited to allow diversion of the funds to other areas of the country's development .
One of the reasons why public spending on the aged should be limited is due to the emergence of other better alternatives .
According to Robert B .Friedland and Laura Summer (2001) the working population would be able to share a large proportion of the responsibility , with the government taking care of the aged primarily .
One of such initiatives would be the baby bonus package which has been introduced in several countries .
In the case of Singapore , the government has increased the cash gift for the first two children from $300 to $400 .
This is one of the long term efforts that the government has decided to invest in so that their public spending on the aged would be reduced in years to come  , as the future working population starts to emerge .
Another temporary measure would be to increase the working population by encouraging immigration into the country .
Canada has experienced the highest per capita immigration rate in the world and expects an increase of 23 .1% of population growth over a period of 25 years (Wikipedia , 2009) .
An increase in the working population will then allow more resources to be channelled  to other areas which demand such funds .
This proves to be a better solution because it allows the government to limit the public spending and  fellow citizens to take responsibility .
It is necessary that the country allocates sufficient funds required for its growth and to maintain its competitive edge  .
Therefore it is  necessary for the country to limit its public spending on the aged .
Singapore has decided to increase its public spending in the area of research and development (R&D) to $7 .5 billion (Singapore Budget highlights , 2009) .
Singapore sees an aging population as a potential risk and it  channels sufficient funds to the aged  .
Nonetheless ,  at the same time , it focuses on other areas of development as well .
Through its R & D , Singapore aims to reach greater heights in the research fields  .
This  would then yield substantial profits to the nation , without which the growth of the nation would be stagnant .
Therefore , public spending on aged should be limited and channelled to other areas of development .
A government should cater to  various groups of the population without any form of discrimination  .
4 .68% of  America's Federal spending constitutes  the  assistance category in which 4 out of 5 top assistant recipients come from the health sector (USA spending , 2009) .
The healthealth sector would be one of the areas where help is needed for the aged due to the rising medical expenditureand it is not  fair to burden them with the entire cost .
Nonetheless they should also take into consideration the cons of not limiting  public spending on the aged .
If that happens and the nation decides to be a welfare state  , then it will fail like  Britain  .
It would no longer be able to  have constant economic growths and that would  be detrimental  for the country .
As such  public spending should be limited .
This ageing population problem can be dealt with  by increasing the working population  , so that it could share the burden  of caring for the aged .
Public spending should also be limited because areas like R&D need more  funds to ensure constant progress of the nation .
Without a on spending the country would then experience a decline in economic growth .
Therefore , public spending on the aged should be limited so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
It is an ironic truth that Singapore is facing a demographic challenge as the population aged 65 and older is anticipated to more than double by the year 2030 .There is much concern about the current development and policies  , of which older people tend to be the principle beneficiaries .
Many policies such as  the Maintenance of Parent Act , Baby Bonus Scheme and later retirement agreement have helped to ease the aging process significantly .
Currently , much of the public discussions about an aging society involve the responsibility of  children to look after their aged parents  .
As we know ,  Asians pay great attention to filial piety and it is their traditional practice to live together with their parents even after the children are married .
However , life today is different from that of the past .
Some Singaporeans do not practise this tradition and they  abandon their parents in the old folks' home or hospitals .
Some of them even disappeared or changed their contact numbers after they have sent their parents to the homes .
This new social phenomenon could be curbed by implementing the Maintenance of Parents Act .
This act came into force in 1995 to give parents above 60 years old who could not support themselves the legal means to claim maintenance from their children .
Some feel the state has gone too far by intruding into the delicate relationship between children and their parents .
However , this enforcement of law ensure the seniors of a more secured life .
According to  statistics , over 400 parents have sought the aid of the Tribunal of the Maintenance Act since it was set up 3 years ago .
Therefore , we could conclude that this act is efficient in dealing with the aging population .
The problem of a growing aging population in Singapore could be curbed by encouraging late retirement , longer working lives , and lower barriers to elder employment  , as suggested by Peterson (year) .
Some might argue that the seniors are old and fragile to be productive  .
However ,  reality remains that later retirement will ensure the senior citizens  a high quality of life in their twilight years .
This is because they could earn money on their own and need not rely on their children for living expenses .
With financial independence , the seniors would not become a burden to their families .
Instead , they can age with respect and dignity  .
Not only that  , longer working lives enable the elders to remain physically , mentally and socially active for a long time .
Being occupied with work , the aged could actually use their brains more frequently and this reduces the chances of developing senile dementia and Parkinson 's diseases   .
As the saying goes , 'no man is an island'and social activities are essential for the aged to stay healthy .
The seniors could build up their social circles at their work places and this reduces their dependency on their family members .
Moreover , many have expressed their desire to work longer as they want to feel valued and being able to contribute to the society .
In a nutshell ,later retirement and prolonged  working lives are effective solutions to ease the problems of an aging population .
Last but not least , an aging population brings about a shrinking workforce  and  a significant decline in real GDP .
The critical challenge of the government is to ensure the productivity of future workers .
The main root of this problem is because of low birth rate .
Modern parents prefer to have fewer children  , as compared to the past generation .
They claimed that the living cost now is very high and they could not ensure a quality life style with more children .
Therefore , the government introduces the Baby Bonus Scheme which lightens the financial cost of raising children .
The parents will get a cash gift of up to $4 ,000 each for their first and second child and $6 ,000 each for their third and forth child .
Furthermore , all the children born on or after 17 August 2008 will also enjoy government contributions in the form of a dollar-for-dollar matching  .
As a result , the birth rate increases from 2 .1% (2006) to 2 .55% (2008)  .
In a long run , it is believed that the Baby Bonus Scheme would increase the population  .
Issues relating to aging are complex but not insurmountable  .
In a nutshell , it may be said without any fear of contradiction that the current policies have helped to ease the aging process to a large extent .
With the implementation of the Maintenance of Parents Act in Singapore , it is arguable that the younger generations are not only morally responsible for , but also compelled to taking care of their aged parents  .
However , the low fertility rate in Singapore challenges this argument because the financial burden resulting from the provision of aged parents is currently increasing on  fewer offspring .
It is definitely taxing for an only child to bear the financial cost of his orher parents .
Moreover , the rising cost of  healthcare  adds  further strains to the limited income of the younger generation , which often lead to  children being unable to fend for their parents and thus abandoning  them .
This is  shown in year 2008 , in which approximately 172 senior citizens  filed applications to the tribunal against their children (Wijaya , 2009 , ) .)
Hence , this shows that even with current government assistance such as healthcare subsidies and tax reliefs , , the low fertility rate in Singapore continues to urge the government toc speng on the aged in order to meet the needs ofane ageing society .
Singapore is a well-established country  with advanced healthcare facilities .
Many perceive the current public spending  on the development of healthcare facilities as being sufficient to meet the ageing demands .
However , this is often not the case .
Singapore faces a sharp shortage of medical specialists in the areas of geriatric field and palliative care and to the extent of importing foreign nurses into the medical industry .
This implies that the government has to invest more on training local medical specialists in these fields to meet the growing ageing needsand thus , more expenditure is required .
Furthermore , hospitals are constantly facing  shortages of beds and long average waiting time; the major factor of this problem is the geriatric patients .
The geriatric patients are often the ones who occupy the majority of  hospital bed space and they suffered from chronic illnesses that require regular follow-up consultations .
Therefore , in the recent 2009 National Day Rally speech , Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for step-down care such as  more community hospitals , day-care centres as well as nursing homes .
In this way , more competent healthcare is provided satisfy the  demands , since geriatric patients can receive treatment in acute hospitals and then recuperate in the community hospitals .
Therefore , the development of healthcare facilities to meet growing ageing demands would inevitably raise public expenditure on the aged .
In addition , some will disagree that it is not feasible to expand public spending on the aged because it would neglect the development of other areas such as the Research & Development sector and the Banking & Finance sector , resulting in the loss of competitiveness and investors' confidence on Singapore's economy .
However , most people fail to realize that limiting public spending on an ageing society's welfare system actually weakens the country's economy .
A neglected welfare system for the aging  causes social instability to the country .
For instance ,  citizens would feel cash-strapped with the rising healthcare costs and there would be myriad cases reporting about elderly poverty or abandonment .
Thus , foreign investments will decline drastically even with an advanced Research & Development sector or Banking & Finance sector because the social instability of Singapore loses foreign investors' confidence , and Singapore will incur severe loss in terms of economic competitiveness .
Therefore , it is feasible to expand public spending on the aged .
All in all , it has become a fact that Singapore is currently facing a rapidly ageing population   .
Many problems will arise should public spending on the aged be limited and this include  increased financial burden on the fewer offsprings , insufficient funds for rising healthcare development costs and weakened economic competiveness . 
On November 13 , 2006 , the Prime Minister of Singapore ,  Lee , said in a speech: "Singapore has treated social welfare as a dirty word .
The opposition and the Worker's Party have called for a permanent unconditional needs-based welfare system .
I think that is an even dirtier five words ."
In Hong Kong , welfare is seen as an individual's responsibility and the government will only step in to help those who are proven incapable of helping themselves (South China Morning , January 13 , 2007) .
The four economies in East Asia--- Singapore , Hong Kong , Taiwan , and South Korea have taken the approach to being a 'light welfare state' , in which they have achieved high standard of living without burdening the state with heavy social expenditures (Midgley , 1986) .
In contrast , the western welfare states that fund heavily on social expenditure have hindered the functioning of the private market .
Public spending on the aged should be limited to avoid heavy social expenditures and money can therefore be diverted to other areas for the country's development .
The old age dependency ratio is estimated to increase with longevity and the decline of fertility .
With no limits set on the expenditure of welfare for the aged , a country  will face enormous financial burdens in the funding of the public pension system , expensive healthcare system and long-term dependency expenditures .
The higher the expenditure of a country's welfare , the higher the tax rate will be to finance it .
It may undermine investors' incentive to invest .
Currently Japan is facing financial difficulties in gathering funds for their National Pension and Employee's pension insurance .
The Japanese government is now emphasizing on achieving economic growth rather than increasing welfare expenditures to support its growing aging society .
The Hong Kong government reluctantly implemented deficit financing from 1998 to 2004 to meet the growing expenditures of caring for the aged .
It is estimated that if the deficit budget continued , Hong Kong's $369 billion fiscal reserves would be wiped out by 2008-2009 (South China Morning Post , February 23 , 2002) .
Instead of limitless spending on the aged , funds should be diverted to develop economic growth , and in turn use the revenues gained to finance aging welfare .
There is a contradiction of a capitalistic society being a welfare state .
Limitless welfare for the elderly would impede the functioning of the private market .
When people are provided with social services that allow them to maintain a living , they are less inclined to work (Esping-Andersen , 1990) .
This means that people will not see the need to save for retirement funds or work to be financially secure , as they know they can depend on the government .
The abuse of a welfare system can be examined in the case of British National Health Service (NHS) .
Hon .Lianne Daziel , New Zealand's minister for senior citizens comments that "New Zealanders who are now sixty-five plus are more highly educated and healthier than their predecessors .
Their capacity for productive work of all kinds , not necessarily for pay , is a national treasure ."
Encouraging senior citizens to work will help them to contribute to  society , and at the same time , ensure that they are financially independent .
It is a win-win solution .
Some may argue that limiting public spending on the aged while funding other aspects of development will neglect the aging population's needs .
However caring for the elderly , especially those who cannot provide for themselves , is being prioritized as a national issue .
Besides having support from the government , the 'light welfare states' rely heavily on the private sector and family to provide care for the aged .
The government encourages financial independence by implementing pension schemes , adjusting retirement policy and providing employment opportunities .
There are also other public assistance programs for medical , housing , transportation , and even funeral preparations .
In addition , there are  public and private sector mix of welfare programs and organizations .
In Singapore , there are "over 300 existing voluntary welfare organizations and service providers" and recently , the Centre for Enabled Living (CEL) , with some help from the government , was launched to provide a first-stop referral service to the existing welfare organisations .
Family support and close kinship , which exists strongly in an Asian society , has also helped in decreasing the state's welfare dependency .
In conclusion , public spending on the aged should be limited  to curb heavy financial expenditures , and t 'welfare diseases' that would undermine any incentive to work .
It will not be a feasible plan to drain  money from national reserves to fill up a bottomless pit .
Money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development to earn revenues in order to support the aging population .
The responsibilities of caring for the aged are divided  between the private and family sector to lessen the burden on the state .
Help is readily available to those who are incapable of providing for themselves .
"Aging of population" is a  term used to describe  the shift in the age distribution of a population toward older ages(Leonid A . Gavrilov and Patrick Heuevline , year) .
Thus this refers to an increase in the population's mean age which is generally due to a decline in birth rate and an increase in life expectancy  .
Problems associated with an aging population will be the increase in social and healthcare cost and lower level of productivity .
As one ages , one's body tends to be more vulnerable to health problemsand this will add on to the medical cost which requires funding from the government  .
This would put greater stress on the younger generation in terms of  increasing taxes .
Moreover , we will also expect a shortage of labor which would affect the level of efficiency of the country .
Hence , ongoing medical research  and government's policies can help to alleviate these problems .
Firstly , medical advancements help to lighten the burden of healthcare cost .
The mass production of medicine lowers the cost of the drugs .
Moreover ,  polyclinics provide highly subsidized medical care which benefits the elderly greatly .
There is also an increase in research on healthier food and supplements that helps to inform and advise the public to adopt a healthier lifestyle .
However , these benefits may only favor a small group of the elderly , probably the more educated and richer ones as they are the ones who can comprehend the latest information regarding  healthcare research  , as well as  afford  health-checks and supplements .
Long waiting queues in polyclinics due to highly subsidized medical fees may deter  those elderly with real needs .
In addition , the location may not be accessible to some elderly  ,  , especially for those who are physically disabled .
From another point of view , government intervention may help to solve the problem .
In the case of Singapore , the increasing number of polyclinics that are set up throughout the island  resolved the long queues and inaccessibility problem .
Besides this , polyclinics are upgraded to offer a clean and fresh environment  .
For example , air-conditioning are installed and Nurse Clinician Service is implemented where patients with chronic conditions can make appointments in advance to reduce their waiting timeand this  further ensures the comfort level of the patients(Polyclinics Singhealth , 2009) .
Health screening at affordable prices organized by the government helps to identify potential health risks  .
In addition , free health talks  help to educate the elderly especially the uneducated ones and advise them to lead a healthy lifestyle .
Hence , these measures  enable the elderly to have a better understanding of their bodiesand therefore reduce the healthcare cost .
Secondly , automation helps to reduce the social cost and reduces the need for the younger generation to take care of the aging population .
Automations such as dish-washer allow the the elderly to do simple chores at home and it increases the level of independence of the elderly  .
As one ages , our body tends to suffer from pains all  , automation such as massage machines help to relieve pain and it might reduce the possibility for a doctor consultation .
Besides this , remote controlled lighting helps elderly to control the house lights with a remote controland therefore ,  minimizes the risk of falling in the dark .
Thus , the responsibility of the younger generation can be greatly reduced  , such as  the  need of caretakers and medical costs .
However , some may argue that this is the ideal situation and only a minority of the elderly will benefit .
Luxurious goods such as massage machines and lighting systems are only affordable for the rich and they may not cut down the chances of getting sick .
In addition , automation only reduces the need for human labor , but there is no guarantee that it is able to drive down social costs .
When viewed from another angle ,   government policies help to maximize the welfare of the elderly .
The setting up of community centres which  organize activities for the elderly ,   is beneficial for the elderly .
Hence , we can conclude that automation can be seen as a tool in relieving the aging process  .
Extended lifespanshave the the elderly to work more and longer .
Hence , higher productivity is achieved  , thus reducing the burden of the younger generation in paying taxes .
However , some may argue that the elderly may not be fit enough to work and  there are doubts  if the older workforce can achieve a similar level of efficiency that is expected from the younger workers .
Therefore this makes it more difficult for elderly to look for a job .
From another point of view , there is only a minority who are unable to work; the majority should continue to work as long as they are able to and thus will not be seen as an extra burden to  society .
In addition , countries like Singapore has started to tackle aging problems where the government is getting companies to rehire workers aged 62 .
Unions are also working with companies to help older workers find and keep jobs through retraining programmes(Valarie Tan , 2009) .
Moreover , extended working years should be encouraged as a result of longer lifespan and  increased literacy  of future elderly .
Therefore , it is possible that productivity can still be sustain among the aging population .
In conclusion , I agree to a large extent that  government policies that have been implemented  helped to alleviate the aging process .
Developments in the future will be expected to be much  better , and though aging process is inevitableits inconveniences  can  be minimized  .
The average age of human has increased drastically within the last  and this has led to fast aging populations that raised concerns among governments and policy makers .
According to  (2008) , from 1900 to 2005 , life expectancy at birth increased from 46 to 75 years for men and from 48 to 80 years for women .
The aging process has caused unprecedented problems  for society  , especially for the aged  , who   face plenty of illnesses when they  become older .
Besides that ,  countries face difficulties in supporting a growing number of the aged as there are many vulnerable aged who live alone and need assistance from  governments .
Therefore  policies have been implemented to ease the aging process and to  support  the aged  .
Undeniably , there have been significant successes in the strategies used .
To ease the aging process , the governments have to put in a great effort in the research of medicine to provide the best treatment for the aged .
Since there is an obvious advancement in technology when compared to previous years , there are more inventions in medicine and equipment to treat  illnesses .
However , some people may think that the aged will not be able to afford  the treatment  as better equipment and treatments will increase the cost  .
To prevent such a situatio from happening , governments have introduced  insurance schemes to reduce the cost of treatment .
For example , the Singapore government has introduced the CPF Medisave Scheme and Medishield Scheme which can cover part of the treatment fees: the patient need not pay any fees for outpatient treatments and Medishield will pay 80% of the actual expenditure up to the claimable limit .
Through this , government ensures that the aged get the proper treatments to reduce their sufferings  .
Thus far , The governmenthas introduced some new economic policies  to ease the aging process .
This includes lengthening the age of retirement  , so that the aged have longer working lives (Peterson , 2001) so that they can earn more money when they are still working to support themselves .
The strategy of lowering the barriers to elder employment is effective in increasing the rate of employment among the aged .
However , some people may think that the aged is a burden to  society as they believe that the physical condition of the aged cannot cope with the development of the country .
While this may be true ,  facts have shown that the aged can still contribute to the economy as they have more experiences when compared to the others .
They share their experiences with the young and this can help to improve the economy of the country .
The government  could use the money to help the  aged and ease the aging process .
In addition , community centers or community clubs have their policies to ease the aging process  .
For instance , An Area Agency on Aging (AAA) is designated in each of New Jersey's 21 counties to serve as the primary entity responsible for developing comprehensive , coordinated systems of community-based services for the aged .
It analyses the needs and existing services within the county and prepares a comprehensive plan for the delivery of services to the aged .
The community centers organize  activities such as performances , games and feasts to help them feel less lonely , cheer them up and make them happy and this has eased the aging process in the society .
There are also many enthusiasts and volunteers in the society who are willing to spend their time accompanying  the aged  , as they know that they can give mental support to the aged .
Peterson (2001) mentions that  aging process in a country will cause a shrinking workforce , long-term stagnation and decrease in real GDP .
As a result , the whole societ ,including the aged , will face a lot of problems as some of them are still seeking aid from the government .
Leaders of countries must rise above ideology and engage  practical realities to cope with the problem of a fast aging population .
Therefore , governments and policy makers have implemented some  policies  in easing the aging process  .
by doing this , governments can ensure the development of their countries and provide a better living environment  to all their people  .
For a country to do well , the government has to ensure that all areas of its development are well funded .
Healthcare , military , education , and research and development are just some of the key areas affecting a country's development .
With so many issues to be considered , it is certain that the funding available will never be sufficient .
Thus , it has always been a tough choice for the government to decide how much budget should be spent on the various areas of the country's development .
In recent years , the increasing severity of the aging problem has brought about yet another problem that requires action to be taken promptly .
One of the most direct solutions to the aging problem is to allow more public spending on the aged .
However , with the limited budget the country has , it is essential that the more important priorities are first taken care of before large scale policies are implemented to help the aged .
First of all , the country should spend the bulk of their budget on areas which are of great importance .
One of these areas would be that of the military The significance of the military to a nation is so great that it is not possible for a country to constrict its spending in this area .
With the ever present threat of terrorism , which has the potential to cause huge destruction , there is no doubt that investing in the military is of  greater importance than taking care of the welfare of the elderly .
The government should not hesitate to invest in the latest military technology and equipment .
This is to ensure that the country will be able to defend itself should any undesirable situations arise .
However , others may argue that Singapore has always enjoyed peace and that there are no signs of any conflicts with other nations arising .
Thus , are these large investments in military goods really required ?
Shouldn't we put the welfare of the elderly as a higher priority ?
With the increasing number of elderly coupled together with the issue of the low birth rate , the aging population problem has certainly become more pressing in recent years .
True enough , Singapore has been successful in avoiding any direct conflicts with other countries .
However , national security will always be one of the most important aspects to a country .
The consequence of a weak military has the potential to destroy an entire nation especially one which is as small as ours .
This dire effect is something we cannot afford , thus , investing in military goods will definitely be one of the top priorities of the government .
Secondly , the government should allocate its available resources wisely so as to obtain the most effective use of them .
To achieve this , money has to be channelled into  research and development  instead of spending excessively on the aged .
By doing so , our country will be able to progress more quickly .
New technologies and more efficient production methods will be discovered .
With these , the country will be well-equipped to ensure  sustained economic growth and to head towards a prosperous and progressive nation .
No doubt , some may argue that the nation should always show its gratitude to the elders of the nation by making sure that they are well taken care of .
However , if the country were to divert most of its public spending to the aged now , it is almost certain that it will face an arduous problem in the near future .
Neglecting the other areas of the country's development will hinder its progress and lead to limited economic growth and thus  a shrinking budget .
As mentioned by Friedland and Summer (2005) in "Doomsday Predictions about Population Aging Are Exaggerated" , with little economic growth , there are fewer choices about how to care for the elderly thus intensifying the problem on hand .
Therefore , it is  essential to ensure  healthy economic growth as it will provide many alternatives to the problems Singaporefaces .
As can be seen from the above arguments , due to the limited resources available , and the ever growing number of issues that need to be tended to , it is impossible to ensure that all areas of Singapore's development are well funded .
Thus , the government has to prioritize and allocate  resources wisely so that the goals of having a stable and prosperous nation can be achieved . .
Humanity has come a long way in evolving and adapting to the changing environment .
Through the years , it has managed to overcome several limitations , which in the past were nothing more than dreams .
It succeeded in landing on the moon and communicating over long distance , yet there are still some boundaries it still has to cross despite its best effort .
Aging is an inevitable process of nature .
While  the ticking clock in our body cannot be stopped advance technology and modern governance have made it possible for aging to be delayed and relieved to a great extent .
High-tech equipment and medication are available for the treatment of more illnesses as our understanding of medicine improves  .
Governments nowadays are  also doing more for the elderly population in their society . 
With more emphasis placed on healthcare by governments today and the advancement of  medical technology , people get to live longer .
Cancers are not as deadly as in the past and new vaccines are constantly being developed .
People , including the elderly , are made less vulnerable to  diseases , and in a way , people become biologically stronger .
This also means an increase in the productivity of the aged physically .
McClatchy Newspapers (2008 , October 20) suggested that with the miracle of modern medicine , 60 might be the new 40 .
However , most treatments do not come cheap and chronic illnesses , especially , take a toll on their finances as people live longer .
"One hospitalisation , for example , a stroke can set you back  tens of thousands of dollars ," as stated by Associate Professor Paulin Straughan , sociologist , National University of Singapore in Channel NewsAsia (2009 , August 19) .
In fact , most elderly are not rich and many cannot afford the treatments .
Friedland and Summer highlighted that some segments of the aged population might be overlooked and remain very vulnerable .
For this group of people , most governments intervene to help  subsidise  treatments they genuinely need .
Modern governments promise old age security , which ensures that their citizens can fend for themselves during old age .
The approaches , however , may vary from society to society .
In some like The United Kingdom and Canada , government pensions are distributed to the elderly .
In some others such as Singapore , the people are compelled to provide in advance for their old age  .
Some societies have laws in place to enforce children to take care of elderly parents .
For example , in Singapore , elderly parents may file in  court if their children do not provide for them .
However , there are various financial concerns about these methods .
In the case of government pensions , the heavy spending of public funds on the  aged may take a toll on other areas of the nation's development .
Thus a method that works in one society may not work in another and sometimes , multiple approaches have to be taken .
However , better healthcare and protection from the government result in rising age expectancy , which is a double-edged sword because on one hand , people live longer as shown in the report (Friedland and Summer , 2005 , Fig 1-2) and on the other hand , the proportion of aging population increases if the younger generation are not reproducing enough , This is the trend today in developed nations .
In today's fast-paced society  , there are several factors , such as high living costs and late marriagesthat discourage people from reproducing " .
Peterson has claimed that , "If fertility rates do not rise again , the problem will worsen as the median age in many first-world countries will reach 51 by 2050 ,"  .
As the number of elderly increases , with a great  , there might not be enough young people in the workforce to support the economy and generate enough money for healthcare subsidies and government pensions as mentioned previously .
While there are temporary measures to alleviate this problem , such as rising the retirement age and importing foreign workers , the key is still to increase the fertility rate .
The aging process has been eased with the modernization of our society as better healthcare technology and government welfare are available to serve the elderly .
However , this revolution has generated a rising aging population which may be a problem to all levels of the society .
Governments in developed countries should look beyond temporary solutions to the rising aging population and focus on getting people to reproduce .
While there are initiatives like maternity welfare and the baby bonus to encourage reproduction ,  more can be done  for the better .
Many people have argued that public spending on the aged is a must for countries facing the problem of an aging population as an ageing population has dire social , economical and cultural consequences on the country .
True as it seems , the question posed here is how  should  the government allocate its resources to cope with this problem .
As the saying goes , 'Give the man a fish and feed him for a day , teach the man to fish and feed him for a lifetime' .
Therefore , the use of the country's resources should be well diversified to different areas of the country's development so that no one area is compromised on .
With  elderly care hugely subsidized by the government , the aged will tend to be reliant on the government  providing for their old age .
This has caused the aged to be heavily dependent on the government and thus has developed a negative practice of the aged not saving for their own retirement .
It may be argued that the money which is not saved for retirement can be better spent elsewhere .
Adam Smith argues in his book Wealth of Nations that 'each individual is continually exerting himself to find out the most advantageous employment of whatever capital he can command' .
Although it is argued that the 'extra money' that the elderly possess will be better spent elsewhere , it may not be spent in the most efficient way possible .
Adam Smith also points out that individuals will act in their own advantage , not that of the society .
Therefore , the 'extra money' that the elderly possess at the expense of the government may not result in the most efficient allocation of resources .
With more money from public spending spent on the aged , this also means that there  is less money for the  other areas of development in the country .
Other areas of development that will increase the economic growth of the country will then be compromised .
One justification for economic growth is that with little economic growth , society faces fewer choices on how to care for those who are least able to care for themselves (Friedland and Summer , 2005) .
Critics of this position point out that when more money is spent on the aged , it  generates economic growth .
With better and more affordable healthcare services provided for  , the elderly can be healthier and more economically productive .
This will allow the elderly to be able to work for longer  and delay their retirement .
This will then increase the labour force of the country and result in economic growth .
However , this growth is limited .
There is a limit to the economic growth brought about by delaying the retirement age of the elderly .
Therefore , government resources should be allocated to areas of development that will generate potential economic growth which can be sustained .
This includes Research and Development (R&D) where more efficient healthcare methods can be devised .
By designating the role of the caregiver of the elderly to the government , "Asian values" such as filial piety will be eroded as children may shed the responsibility of taking care of their parents to the government .
It may be objected that these values are innate to one's identity and are not easily influenced or changed by other factors .
However , real life scenarios do actually show that these values can be influenced or eroded .
In Singapore , one is compelled to undertake the role of the caregiver and this  is backed up with law of maintenance of parent's act to ensure one fulfills one's filial obligations .
It is true that there are multiple advantages supporting public spending on the aged .
But in view of the many problems that a country would face if large amount of public spending are spent on the aged , it is only wise that the government  diversifies its public spending to other areas of development and strikes a balance among the other priorities .
The growing number of ageing population is an inevitable issue worldwide , especially in developed countries (Peterson , Fall 2001) .
Technological advancement enables humans to live longer .
On the other hand , the younger generation are chasing after 'an individualistic and 'live life to the fullest' lifestyle . .
This new generation would have the perception of enjoying life and not having family and children because they see it as a burden .
In the long run , this will translate into a low fertility rate in the country .
In the case of Singapore , the growing elderly population should not be accompanied by restrictions in public spending on the aged , which may come in the form of pension schemes , medical insurance , healthcare benefits and disability allowance .
This paper recommends that public spending on the elderly should not be limited so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
This is because the current benefits that are provided for the elderly are still inadequate .
In terms of welfare and poverty ,  less than 5% of households in the low income group  are beneficiaries of the state-funded system .
Only 0 .07% received public assistance in 2004 (Asher & Nandy , 2008) .
If public spending on low income groups is limited , there would be fewer elderly who could benefit from government aid .
Therefore , an increase in social disparity and healthcare problems would be an issue for the country .
Although public spending on the elderly is an endless process as they don't generate much productivity to the country , social responsibility as a nation needs to be promoted . .
There are many elderly people who are unable to support themselves and have to take up jobs like road sweeping and toilet cleaning .
Besides that , the elderly were once the people who contributed to the growth of the nation and economy .
Many of these vulnerable beings should not be left with little aid when they are in need of much care and help .
In the context of a developed country like Singapore , which was ranked the third competitive economy in the world (Anand , 2009) , sufficient funds are available for economic growth and other areas of development .
Therefore , thereshould not be a need to divert  public spending on the elderly to other areas of the country's development .
The nation's infrastructure , development and trade are in a desirable condition and the current spending on them is adequate to sustain  economic growth .
Hence , the government should not focus on limiting  public spending but on  ways to spend it wisely .
One example is  means-testing . 
In addition to that , the money that is spent on helping the elderly is partially their money which was deducted through tax payment .
Thus , policy makers have the responsibility to provide the elderly with  .
The aged should be able to enjoy  social security during their later years .
We have to be conscious that even though they are deemed as a liability , they are also part of the nation and should not be neglected .
Stressing filial responsibility and raising more productive children is a way to support the aged , as suggested by Peterson (Fall 2001) .
However , there are certain groups of elderly who are single , child-less , not on good terms with their children or who still need to support their 'parasitic' adult children .
On top of that , the elderly who are disabled and suffering from chronic illnesses need a large sum of money to deal with their condition .
They won't be able to get ample financial support from their children and have to depend on the government to provide this assistance .
Even with the assistance of MediSave and MediShield , elderly people suffering from terminal illnesses will not be able to pay for their high healthcare costs when their bank accounts are exhausted (Channel NewsAsia , 2009) .
Although this will create a sense of dependency on the government , it is an unavoidable situation where the government needs to care for its citizens . 
In summary the government should not limit  public spending on the elderly and divert it to other areas of the country's development .
This is due to the ascending numbers of elderly in the coming years that need to be dealt with (Friedland & Summer , 2005) .
These elderly were once the people who helped in building up the nation and the government should show their compassion and care for this vulnerable group by not restricting public spending on them .
It is vital that the expenditure on the elderly is delegated according to their needs so that wastage can be avoided .
Hence , more elderly people can benefit through this act and it would not be seen as wastage of the country's funds .
The aging processes in Singapore with its ensuing serious impacts , has caught people's attention . .
The aging process requires special attention because due to the low birth rate , Singapore has became an aging country with a large fraction of its population being aged .
The government is currently carrying out research and implementing policies to help to ease the aging process for both the elderly and the country .
Researchers are mainly focusing on healthcare and infrastructure .
The former involves finding out the types of age-related illness that are likely to arise when people reach a certain age and measures that can be taken to reduce the occurrence of the illnesses .
The latter involves developing public facilities that cater to the needs of the elderly who are physically weak .
Besides that , various policies have also been introduced to aid the elderly .
These policies include granting subsidies that help to reduce the high cost of living , various HDB schemes to encourages children to live close to their parents as well as the upgrading of housing estate for the elderly .
The research and policies that have been continuously implemented for the aged in Singapore have worked well because of the pragmatic approach that has been taken .
Research on healthcare and infrastructure has been constantly improving to ease the aging process .
Firstly , the government is currently researching  the possible type of chronic illnesses that are likely to surface at a certain age of life , at the same time as implementing control measures to prevent the occurring  illness .
As the saying goes , prevention is better than cure , thus the government sector such as the health promotion board and the Singapore eye care centre is constantly organizing campaigns to raise the awareness of the elderly regarding the serious consequences associated with the illnesses .
They also provide free medical checkups  the elderly usually aged 50 and above for early detection of the illness .
It is a good approach with some limitations .
This is because for the elderly  , who are illiterate and living alone , may not know that there are such campaigns going on as they are unable to read campaignspublished in newspapers  , or understand  advertisements telecasted over the television as they are mostly in English or Chinese .
Thus the elderly that only understand dialect will not get the message thereby defeating the purpose of the campaign .
Next , improvisation of infrastructure on public transportation and housing estates is another area of research that is being focused on .
For public transport , a portion of seats have been removed leaving a spacious area to suit the needs of the elderly that are wheelchair bound .
In housing estates , the government has upgraded  flats that are relatively old and inconvenient for the elderly .
Examples of upgrading is lifts that are now able to stop at every storey of the flat and within the lift there are handles for the elderly to hold on to for support while taking the lift .
Also all the squat toilets have been converted to seat toilets to avoid accidents of people slipping and falling when squatting and standing up .
This improved infrastructure kills two birds with one stone as it not only provides for the elderly , it also  benefits the handicapped .
Thus this research does not only serve for the elderly , it also servesother purposes as well .
Policies complement the research .
Given the high cost of living in Singapore , the government has provided benefits for the elderly by granting subsidizes on healthcare .
This policy works well because the aged would have their savings used for daily expenses such as food and necessities .
Apart from subsidies , the government have reorganized the healthcare system to cater to the needs of the elderly .
For example , the government have taken a step-down approach by including more community hospitals and nursing homes in the health care sector that are more affordable than staying in the hospital .
This policy is workable as the elderly can recuperate better in a community hospital as they do not have to worry much about the medical fees .
Also , community hospitals provide convenience as they are near the neighborhood thus enabling them to get medical aid soon after they fall sick  .
It also helps to assure their children that there's someone to attend to their sick parents when they are at work .
However , although the cost of healthcare is greatly reduced , there are cases whereby the elderly who are childless and do not have any savings or income  , do not have any medisave to pay for the large amount of medical fee incurred .
Even though there are subsidies , the elderly will still not be able to afford medical expenses .
The next policy that is suggested is to give rebates to those who purchase a house that is close to their parents .
This is  to encourage  children to visit their parents often thus giving them a sense of warmth and security  .
However , this is not always the expected scenario .
