They will then have to  work even harder to earn a living .
For example , they might  take up 2 or more jobs working day and night .
As a result , they end up with poor health  and reduced productivity in their work .
In conclusion , limiting  public spending on the aged does not mean ceasing  expenditure on them .
Instead , it achieves a balance  where the government can set a limit and provide adequate funding for them while focusing on other more important aspects like education  .
Public spending refers to money expended by a government to pay for areas such as defense , development projects , education , health , infrastructure , and law & order maintenance ,  and such spending is supported by taxation .
With an increasing number of elderly in  society , it is rather strenuous for the non-elderly to contribute to the tax base .
And it is in no doubt that the aged require additional spending on public pensions and health care .
However , this does not mean that public spending on the aged should be limited so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
One argument that suggests money should be diverted to the education area is that higher education would help to cut down the sizeable segment of the population who needs government aid during old age in the future .
This is because according to Robert B . Friedland and Laura Summer , people with better education are more likely to have higher incomes and better health .
This educational disparity virtually guarantees a diverse group of older people in the future .
However , they should take into consideration the fact that there are elderly from the past generations without good education who have not been able to save in their younger days .
Since they are old , retired and do not have much savings , large health and long-term care expenses will significantly deplete their resources  .
Thus , it is necessary for them to receive sufficient aid from the government .
Some think that spending money on the aged is like throwing money down the drain since it is part and parcel of life for them to grow old , age and die .
If public spending on the aged is limited , it would help to reduce the amount of tax people have to pay to support these elderly in the society .
But we must not forget that these elderly who require aid from the government now are people who once contributed to the country's development .
The contribution they once made , be it little or a lot , helped to build up the country , thus making it possible for people to live comfortably now .
Therefore , it is reasonable for the government to spend on the aged as an act of repaying the elderly .
Certain children who are capable of providing for their elderly parents refuse to do so because they do not want to waste money and assume that it is the government's responsibility to provide for the elderly .
However , it should be made clear to them that public spending on the aged should not be misused .
In order to prevent public spending from being misused , government should provide aid to the aged after assessing their living condition and how much their children can provide for them .
For example , an elderly who lives all alone by himself , without any children , will receive more help from the government if he is unable to provide for himself .
Whereas , an elderly who has children whose income is relatively stable , will receive less help .
After all , it is the children's responsibility to provide for their parents before the government steps in to help .
In this way , public spending will not be misusedand children are forced to be filial and therefore , the government does not have to set a limitation on public spending since the amount spent on the aged will be less .
In conclusion , public spending on the aged should not be limited because they deserve to receive help from the government when they need it as they once helped to contribute to the country's development .
In order for those elderly  to live reasonably well , but not to the extent of "luxuriously well" , government should assess the living condition of these elderly and provide them with the necessary aid they need .
In recent years , public spending on the aged has gradually increased , sparking countless discussions about whether public spending on the aged should be limited , so that the money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
Personally , I agree with such a view .
In countries where the population is not aging , public spending on the aged should be decreased and the funds should be channelled into other more important policies and schemes .
This would benefit the country , both economically and socially .
One of the reasons why the government should not be the one that supports the elderly is the simple concept of filial piety .
Filial piety is one of the virtues that have been around society for ages .
It emphasises  respect for parents .
Therefore , the costs of spending for the should be borne by their respective offspring .
Their children should be the one to support them through their old age as "repayment" for all that their parents have done .
It is not easy to bring up children ; parents have to scrimp and save just to give their children the best .
In general , for the first twenty years of anyone's life , they are fed , clothed and brought from adolescence to adulthood , all for free .
Parents also try to give their children the best education they can afford  .
So , should it not be only fair that their children support them through their old age , especially when they have no one else to rely on ?
Therefore ,  public spending on the aged should be cut down because the younger generation should be the one supporting their parents; it is their own duty and should not be left to the government .
Nevertheless , there will be special cases when such aged folk do not have children to rely on , either because they do not have kids , or due to some misfortune have lost  their children .
In these cases , it would only be right for the government to help them .
Hence ,  public spending on the aged should be limited , but not completely ignored .
Also , in every society where   exist , there will be a group of people who tend to "abuse" the system .
In reality , there are a number of those who try to leech off as much government funding as they can , despite their ability to support themselves .
After the aged retire , there are a large group of them who actually are still fit to workand  are able to do minor jobs to support themselves .
However , this is rarely brought up due to the fact that most of them do not wish to continue working into old age; they believe that they deserve to rest .
Although I believe that people who retire definitely deserve their  freedom , I completely disagree that most of them should be doing it at the expense of the government .
If their children are unable to support them through their old age for whatever reason , they should try to find minor jobs to support themselves , especially if they are still physically fit .
Therefore ,  spending on the aged should be minimized , and  funds that are allocated to it should be given out more wisely and strictly .
Some people disagree that  public spending on aged should be cut down , arguing that the cost of supporting an old person may be too much of a burden for  young adults nowadays .
The children of these aged folk do not earn enough to support their parents .
However , I feel that if there are increased funds in the other areas of  development , the burden would actually be lesser than it already is .
If  public spending on the aged is decreased or minimized and the funds are diverted to other channels to boost  economic growth , the country would be a richer society .
There would be a rise in wealth and the working population would actually have more monetary assets to support the aged .
Also ,  funds could be diverted into other sources which would result in an improvementin a country's cleanliness .
This can be accomplished through  increased technology , or investment into machinery that cleans up  polluted air .
The cost of supporting an old person is  no doubt largely due to  increased medical costs that come with old age .
However , if the country is able to find a way to improve cleanliness  , this will no doubt lead to a healthier population , which in turn means lower medical costs .
Therefore , it is a wiser choice to lower  public spending on the elderly because the net benefit from such an action would be much greater than if we were to leave the spending untouched .
However , such a policy would only work in countries that do not face an ageing population .
Countries that face the problem  are unable to carry out such a plan .
This is due to the fact that it is almost impossible for the younger generation to support the aged , considering  number of aged in society greatly outweighs the generation that supports  them .
Therefore , it would be wiser for the governments of such countries to craft other policies that would suit their own needs .
In conclusion , in countries where the population is not aging , public spending on the aged should be diverted to other more important sectors , such as research and development sectors .
This would in turn benefit the countries more than if they were to leave the policies untouched .
This essay argues to a large extent that current research and developmentpolicies have helped to ease the aging process because of the innovative  that Singapore's government and other organizations have provided  .
These solutions are mostly  in the area of medicine , technology and society  which  are essential in slowing the  and eradicating this problem in the future .
First , many people commonly associate health issues with the elderly .
For instance , in United Kingdom , a research done by Deloitte and summarized by Dr Michael Harris (Nesta , April 2009) showed that more than a quarter of fifty- to sixty-year-old elderly people have been  diagnosed with medical conditions and the numbers are expected to increase in the future .
One of the many medical solutions that helps to slow down aging and is available in the market is called the "Human Growth Hormone" drug (Somatropin , 2006) .
This prescription provides alternatives to improve old age health issues such as memory loss and weaker bones .
However , not many individuals are willing to adopt this medical option as they would want to age naturally and are afraid that this treatment will cause side effects as it is not commonly used .
It is possible for people to have this view because this medicine is not widely used in the market as further research is still ongoing to further improve its effectiveness .
Second , technology is advancing rapidly and users are expected to constantly upgrade themselves to keep up with the pace .
But the elderly may face problems in the process of keeping up .
Most of them will have trouble adjusting to new technology if they are already comfortable with the level of technological background that they are equipped in .
Moreover ,  health conditions such as deteriorating eye sight or poorer hearing can be a problem as well .
However , Microsoft has come up with technological innovation that helps the elderly deal with these situations due to their health concerns .
To illustrate , a Magnifier (Microsoft , March 2009) is made available in Windows so that the user can magnify part of their computer's screen in order to view it clearer .
Nevertheless , despite this solution , the elderly are still struggling to cope with the latest technology .
But they should be willing to adapt to technological changes as these are there to help humans cope with their daily activities ; there are also alternatives provided to these changes so that society would not to neglect the elderly .
Finally , society plays a major role in coping with the problem of an aging population with the country's government as a support .
In Singapore , the government has provided many measures to protect the elderly .
In fact , one of the measures includes the "Maintenance of Parents Act" (Statutes , "Maintenance of Parents Act" , Chapter 167B , June 1996) in which parents can demand  rights from their children who  neglected them .
This  helps to prevent grown up children from running away from their responsibilities towards their parents .
Moreover , companies are also encouraged to employ older workers even after these workers are past their retirement age (Channel NewsAsia , September 2009) .
To further attract the interest of companies to do so , recognition such as the "AARP International Innovative Employer Awards" is given out to companies which demonstrate innovation in  inclusion of elderly in their companies (AARP International , January 2008) .
Yet , despite such incentives being given out , many companies still choose to retrench those who fall under the older age group during the retrenchment period claiming that the elderly are less productive and effective .
While this may be true , it is possible to keep the elderly  from being retrenched  as they can take up  courses to improve their skills .
In conclusion , although such research and policies have yet to fully solve the problem of an aging population , they still provide alternatives for the aged and society to cope with the problem .
Thus , it is up to the individuals themselves to determine whether they  want to oblige to the policies implemented or try out those new alternatives .
Aging population is becoming a more and more serious problem , consuming a great amount of money from public programs .
There are several solutions proposed to ease this problem .
One solution is limiting the money spent on programs for the aged and diverting that money to other areas of a country's development .
Some critics say implementing this solution might imply that the government does not want to support the elderly; however , it is a practical solution to the current aging population problem .
Some people say this solution might cause financial difficulty to many elderly and their family , especially some critical segments of the elderly population , such as those who have particularly low income like older single women , or those who have attained little education ( Friedland and  Summer , 2005) .
However , this policy will only use up a part of the money used for the aged .
The remaining money will be used to serve the ones who really need the support from  government .
Those who can support themselves , either by their own savings  or by support of family , should help reduce  financial stress exerted on programs for the elderly .
In fact , there are more and more people who do not have to rely on the government help .
Friedland and  Summer (2005) also agree that "the population aged 65 to 75 is healthier , wealthier and better educated than persons in this age group in past generations" .
In fact , several countries have already implemented means testing systems that reflect the above idea .
In Australia , there is  means testing for age pension based on  income test and assets test to assess compensation payments (http://www .fahcsia .gov .au) .
Starting from 1 January 2009 , Singapore has run a means testing system in its public hospitals: a certain group of citizens with a certain range of income will have a different subsidy scheme .
For example , citizens who have average income lower than $3200 per month will have their hospital fees subsidized by 80% while those who earn more than $5200 monthly will only have their hospital fees subsidized by 50% (source: http://www .hospitals .sg) .
Most importantly , limiting public money spending on the aged will save a great amount of money for the government .
This money can be diverted to other needier and more important programs , such as educational , environmental  and other economic development related programs .
These programs are essential to ensure the development of a country in the near future (economic development programs) and in the long run (education programs) .
Friedland and  Summer (2005) state that the key word in fighting against aging population is economic growth .
As the economy develops , the country will generate more money and thus be able to spend a greater amount of money on programs such as health care support for the elderly .
In conclusion , a country which faces an aging population problem should consider limiting public money spent on the aged and instead use more of itforits development .
Such money can be considered as an investment for the country's economy .
Besides , a country could also  support programs that make this policy run more effectively , such as promoting children's willingness to support their elderly parents and implementing means testing programs .

Aging is a process of life that one would eventually go through .

Moreover , when the government provides support for medical and social spending , it will allow the elderly to have enough money to spend for their other leisure activities .
Therefore , public spending on the aged should not be limited in order to allow the elderly to age with dignity .

Until recently , there was  much concern about the consequences of over spending on the welfare of the aging population .
It is said that , if a huge portion of the public's money goes to the aging population , it will cause undesirable effects to the country in many ways .

Which means that the amount spent on the welfare of the senior citizens is also expected to be doubled .
Elder people tend to be the primary beneficiaries from the public spending .
Although , the welfare of the senior citizen may be important  it should not to an extent where the other areas of the country's development are being hindered .
What is therefore needed is to take a close look at the current situation and evenly distribute the public spending into different areas to ensure that the country is  able to prosper .

If the government does not invest enough in these areas , the country will lose its competitiveness , productive capacity in the economy and decrease in public services which will greatly harm the economy .
The importance of a quality educational system is not less than the importance of the aging population .
There is a need to educate the future workforce of the economy , and also to create a workforce which is truly competitive and productive .
Japan is a country with little natural resources and yet has a very highly educated population , which resulted in them being one of the  foremost and advanced countries in the world .
A population with poor educational background will find it hard to compete with other foreign talents with quality education background , thus losing out when it comes to employment and resulting in a huge percentage of the population being unemployed .
Furthermore , foreign investors will not set up factories in countries that are equipped with a poorly educated workforce .
Thus  education is equally important .
The amount spent on the defense should not be neglected as well .
Singapore is a country which is constantly  the target of  terrorists .
There were several terror attempts on Singapore , but it was foiled mainly due to  an effective and strong defense system .
A weak defense system can cripple a country's economy .
For example , New York City was once a major financial center in the world , but after  the September 11th incident , the majority of the investors left New York seeking safer alternatives .
This particular incident cost New York billions of dollars and also millions of job lost overnight .
In addition , defense is also used to safeguard the economic interest of Singapore .
Singapore , being a small country and yet having one of the strongest economies in Asia , has always been the target its neighboring countries .
Without a strong and effective defense , Singapore would have been an easy target .
Therefore , defense is one of the most important areas which safeguards theinterests of a country and the allocation of budget to this area should never be overlooked .

Aging is an inevitable process which is often a slow and painful process for the society in general .
With the current research and development and policies , I agree this has helped  ease the aging process to a large extent .
Due to the globally aging population , many countries have since started their research and development on the aging process .
The government has also stepped in by introducing various policies to suit the needs of the aging population .
This has indeed become a global problem with the extensive amount of medical research going on and the various policies that are being developed .
Thus in the next few paragraphs , I will explain in depth  the  research and government policies being developed to help to ease the aging process .
Firstly , the advancement in science in the 2lst century has brought numerous astounding discoveries to prolong good health in times of old age .
An example is that there has been quite a lot of research on the kind of food  one consumes which will help to retard the aging process .
An example of the above is  research done by Pusan National University in Korea stating that eating kimchi could reduce the risk of heart disease and retard the aging process by reducing the amount of oxygen the body burns((Ilbo , 2000) , 2000) .
Another discovery  was found in the last few years that drinking red wine in moderation helps to preserve good health and retard the aging process .
This is because  red wine contains a substance known as "resveratrol" .
"Resveratrol" is considered to be so effective when it comes to slowing the aging process because the amount of [pic]antioxidants that are present within it .
The [pic]antioxidants that are present within this substance prevents and repairs cell damage that is caused by free radicals in the body .
It is these free radicals that wreak havoc within our bodies because they damage cells , which not only cause disease but also aging .
Thus , one can see how extensive this research  being carried out to ease the aging process of mankind is . . Secondly , the government has come up with various policies to ease the aging process .
In this case , we will take Singapore as an example because of the policies being implemented for the aging .
Singaporeans all know of the term  "CPF" .
"CPF" stands for Central Provident Fund which is a scheme that helps the citizens to save up an amount of money for their retirements needs .
With Singapore's aging population , the government has stepped in by increasing the interest rate of CPF .
The government also implemented the "Minimum Sum Policy" to ensure that one has a specific amount in his or her CPF before allowing them to withdraw it at the age of 55 .
The Minimum Sum was set at $80 ,000 in 2003 and will be raised gradually until it reaches $120 ,000 in 2013 .
This helps one to save up more for retirement in the later years .
Another policy implemented by the Singapore Government is the "ADVANTAGE !"
scheme .
It was introduced in October 2005 to support companies to recruit and retain mature workers as well as to re- employ them beyond the retirement age of 62 (Berita Harian , 2007) .
The scheme has helped the elderly by introducing age-friendly initiatives such as job re-design , automation , wage restructuring , training and introduction of re-employment policies in the workplace (Berita Harian , 2007) .
At the end of April 2007 , 411 companies had already adopted the scheme .
This shows how effectively the government pushes the policy .
Therefore , one can hardly see how the policies do not help to ease the aging process .
Controversially , citizens have argued that these policies do not help them in the aging process because it has taken a toll on their nett salary after having money deducted to their "CPF" contributions which make monthly living allowances even less for them .
An example is the rise in the "Minimum Sum" scheme .
This has been proven to be untrue as the majority of Singaporeans supports the "CPF" schemes which encourages safer retirement and there are many citizen who even went to sign up for more policies from the government on their own accord .
To conclude , due to  a globally aging population , various research and development have been carried out to slow down the aging process and the policies implemented by the government for late retirement .
It is hard to see how such research and policies do not help to ease the aging process 
In  Singapore , the number of ageing people continues to rise at an alarming rate due to the high fertility rate in the past .
With the sharp decline of birth rates that we are facing now , the majority of Singaporeans will be faced with a harder task-  taking care of elderly family members .
Hence , I disagree to a large extent that "public spending on the aged should be limited so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development ."
There are three areas that I will discuss .
These are contributions that elderly have made; the different needs and problems of the aged and the responsibility of  the children .
Firstly , contributions to society made by the elderly cannot be ignored .
In the past , Singapore was an under developed country with swamps and kampongs  .
The living conditions were poor too .
If not for the elderly members of Singapore who contributed in helping to mould Singapore into a highly developed country today , many will not be enjoying the fruits of the labor .
They have laid a sturdy foundation only for most of us to benefit from it; the infrastructure , the technology , and the standard of living have made us what we are today .
As such , with all the hardships that the aged people have gotten through in helping to develop our country , it will be ruthless for us to leave them unattended or even setting limitations .
Ageing is viewed as an inevitable phase of life that we are compelled to live through .
Despite the challenges surrounding an ageing society , it is still depicted as the best part of our lives - 'the golden years' .
This description of old age is true as most countries have now increased efforts to address the challenges surrounding the graying population .
Therefore , I agree that current research and development/policies have helped to ease the ageing process .
One of the major problems faced by the aged is financial security .
Most elderly are worried about retirement costs .
One way to deal with the financial challenges of an ageing population is to enforce a compulsory saving scheme for their old age .
Like many governments around the world , the Singapore government has implemented the Central Provident Fund (CPF) whereby a fixed percentage of its citizens' salaries is set aside to the fund .
Recently , there have also been top-ups provided to their CPF accounts to further help them meet their retirement needs .
However , some may argue that no matter how large the nest-egg one has carefully managed to put aside , the sum is not sufficient to cover the rising cost of everyday life and healthcare services .
As a solution , the government also invests a considerable amount of resources in health promotion and disease prevention .
Not only are the healthcare services subsidized , a community health screening programme is also inaugurated for seniors .
These enable the aged to lead a better quality life without being anxious over financial difficulties .
It is regrettable that when we think of old age , what automatically comes to mind are visions of loneliness and neglect .
Over the years , efforts have been made to develop elder-friendly public infrastructure and housing as well as community based support services .
In Singapore , HDB flats are now designed with the ageing population in mind .
One example is the Studio Apartment Scheme .
These studios are built in such a way that it allows the elderly to be independent .
Some facilities include  lifts at every floor instead of alternate floors and  elder-friendly features such as non-slip tiles and grab bars .
Railing , ramps and passage way access to building are also  available .
With this , elderly people who have difficulty walking can get help by holding on to railing and at the same time exercise their leg muscles .
Ramps are also built for the wheelchair bound so that they can go in and out of the building without any help .
In addition , located within the perimeters are senior citizens' corners which allow them to mingle with one another .
However , one setback is the breakdown of family ties .
Children may not find the need to visit as they assume that the elderly already have  proper care .
Although some people claim that old people enjoy each other's company more than that of the young people , I find it hard to imagine an old person feeling very happy with only rare visits from his or her family .
Friendships may be important , but surely kinship is equally , if not , more important .
The government promotes close family bonding through education and celebrations such as 'Grandparents' Day .'
This way , the elderly can age happily in the comfort of their homes , surrounded by family and friends .
In conclusion , I agree that to a large extent , current research and development/policies have helped to ease the ageing process .
The elderly would feel more at ease knowing that help is forthcoming for them in their twilight years .
I agree that public spending on the aged should be limited so that money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
It is well-known that our society is aging and there are strategies currently in place to aid the aged that would lessen their financial burden or other needs .
Singapore may suffer from long term economic loss while possible government support for the elderly could cause a portion of its Gross Domestic Product (GDP) to decline .
To deal with the limitation of public spending for the aged , a budget amount should be set aside to allow enough funds to be used for building and developing infrastructure , creating employment opportunities and improving the standard of living to benefit the nation , as well as to increase its economy and  GDP .
Firstly , by having more funds , Singapore can build and develop new infrastructure .
Public transportation systems including light rail system , mass rapid transit system , as well as the current new railway network , Circle line , are well advanced to make the public accessible to any location in Singapore .
Constructing of overhead bridges and expressways has benefited the citizens too .
Developing housing facilities in new towns or designated places enable people to have water and power supply , modern sanitation and communication systems .
Currently , the government has set aside an amount to build integrated resorts , the casinos , and tourist attractions to attract tourists to  Singapore .
This would enable foreign currency/ exchange to come in and improve the economy .
Next , having more funds can create employment opportunities for the people .
Having hotels , shopping centers , transportation or other amenities would  improve the economy .
Tourists  spend their money on accommodation in hotels , shopping and entertainment , food and beverages in restaurants , cultural shows and souvenirs and transportation which would generate foreign exchange .
Employment opportunities would then be created for the local people  as hotel attendants , tour guides are needed .
As these people need to be hired , they can contribute to the society and sustain the economy .
Lastly , the government can use funds to improve the standard of living for the citizens such as  building more schools to provide better education , and have advanced healthcare technology so that citizens can enjoy the excellent healthcare services With such rising affluence , people would expect a better quality of life .
Given the current situation , most of the people in Singapore would be able to go beyond meeting their basic needs such as food , shelter , water , electric power supply , sanitation , health care and education .
If there's an improvement in Singapore's economy , citizens would receive high income to have good food and modern housing .
When people have an improved standard of living , they will be able to contribute to , and sustain the economy .
However , the rising standard of living can cause some factors that will contribute to the aging population such as high-quality health care , which helps people live longer .
Even though with the help from the government and fund raising campaigns set up by charity organizations , there will be still a sizeable segment of the population the government has to consider to continue to aid  .
With the rising cost of basic necessities and medical costs due to inflation in the future , those with no or low income  will suffer as these factors will result in the elderly not having enough savings or income to overcome the current economic climate .
Furthermore , social problems like quarrelling over money issues , or even stealing of money would happen in future .
Another point is that the elderly , in their younger age , would have contributed to the society and the economy .
Therefore , the government has to play a part to help the aged if they have any financial difficulties or in any other ways .
In conclusion , an aging population may cause Singapore's economy to decline .
However , since the elderly in their younger age may have contributed to the society and the economy , we should spend a certain amount of money for their needs if they have problems dealing with money issues .
But , the amount must be balanced and has to take into consideration  other needs such as improving and developing  creating employment opportunities and the rising standard of living of the nation .
The extent of public spending on the aged has always been a complicated issue in many developed countries .
Over spending may result in a shortage of resources in the development of the nation , while under spending may imply  negligence of government towards the aged .
We will discuss  whether to limit the public spending on the aged .
Firstly , with appropriate limitations , more money can be diverted to other areas of the country's development .
Upon having better technology and infrastructure developments , the country will be able to attract more Multinational Corporations (MNCs) to invest ,  thus increasing job opportunities .
For example , Singapore has  attracted MNCs such as Las Vegas Sands Corp . and Genting International & Star Cruises to invest in the tourism sector .
Integrated Resorts (IR)  will generate approximately 50 ,000 to 60 ,000 additional jobs .
It is also estimated that there will be a boost in the tourism receipts by 2015 and this will improve the economy of Singapore .
Hence , it can be clearly seen that with limitations to public spending on the aged , the money diverted to other areas can help in boosting the economy condition of the country .
Secondly , there is no transparency with regard  to the distribution of public spending .
Since no publications are made known , tax payers may be doubtful about the usage of their  taxes .
There had been cases of misuse of public spending within countries .
People may make use of charity opportunities to obtain money from the public and use it for their own personal benefit For example in recent news , Ren Ci's ex-director had been embroiled in a complicated money scandal .
It was reported that  he was supposed to loan an amount to Mandala Buddhist Cultural Centre but it ended up with his former personal aide .
This incident led to the distrust of the public towards charity organizations .
As a consequence , there was a dramatic drop in Ren Ci's donations from 9 .3 to 1 .1 million .
Limitations and transparency can be made to gain back  confidence  in public spending .
A third reason to limit the public spending on the aged will be that the aged population today is different from that of the past past .
They are healthier , wealthier and more educated than that of the past .
Many of them are within the top management .
They hold high posts such as Chief Executive Officer (CEO) , Chief Operating Officer etc .
They are capable of taking care of their lives and do not need the government's aid .
Other than this group of aged , there is also another group of aged who refuses to obtain help from others .
Due to their strong integrity , they believe that as long as they are physically fit , they will want to continue to work and support for themselves .
To facilitate this , McDonald's adopted a policy to recruit the aged population as their staff members .
As the aged  are able to take care of themselves , public spending can be limited so that it can be invested in other areas for enhanced development .
Finally , having no limitation on public spending on the aged will lead to an increase in dependency on the public spending by the aged .
Apparently , some persons will try to abuse the public spending policy .
They will have this mindset that since the government will be taking care of their lives , they need not work . .
Hence , they will rely heavily on the government subsidies .
However , there may be a small minority of aged who are physically unfit to work .
They will need subsidies from government in order to maintain their lives .
Hence limitations on public spending should be implemented so that only this needy group of the aged will benefit . .
In conclusion , with proper limitations on public spending on the aged , the excess money can be channelled to the development of the country , thus improving its economy  .
More trust can be gained from the public with transparency .
The aged population will also be encouraged to take care of themselves instead of over-relying on public spending .
Therefore , public spending on the aged should be limited .
In  modern societies , the aging population is increasing  .
The reason is that the more the living standard is developed , the more the life is lengthened .
Therefore , the government should consider carefully how it treats this special group of citizens .
However , there are some people who state that the public spending on the aged should be limited , so that the money can be spent on other areas .
I totally agree with this idea .
This essay will give some reasons that support thist idea .
To begin with , it cannot be denied that the youth are the most important part of the citizens in every country , not the elderly .
The young people are the workers who can contribute directly to the country .
The research has shown that before 30 is the best time to learn and work in our lives .
The young citizens can work better than the elder ones .
Hence , the increasing of the public spending on the youth is not unfair .
Moreover , in my opinion , if a country has few old people , it will not be a matter; but a country which has few youths  may cause a lot of problems about manpower resources .
However , the opponents of this position argue that the elderly may have a lot of experience , and so they are very important .
To me , that is not true .
Although the aged have experience , that was in the past .
The world is constantly changing , so everybody must learn day by day .
The Internet today is the most powerful tool that can bring a lot of iinformation and the youth can use it easily .
Secondly , I hold the view that if all the other areas of the country are developed adequately , the living standard of the aging population will increase then .
It is easily  seen that if all the other parts of the public facilities are improved strongly , the living standard will increase for all the people in the country , including the elderly .
As far as I am concerned , when the living standard is developed , the incomes of the young people will rise so that they can pay more money to help their parents , who are the aged also .
Another argument  is when the government pays so much on the other areas , there will not be any money to help the elderly .
This counter argument is good but it may be not correct because the government pays for the other areaswhich are also the public facilities , so that the elderly can utilise those facilities also .
In my mind , the youth have a duty to care for their old parents in the way that  their parents took care of them when they were young .
All in all , there are many reasons which support the idea that  spending  on the aged should be limited .
There are also many benefits for the aged citizens .
All things considered , I totally agree with this idea .
Aging , a biological process which every single normal human in this world must experience every day , has become quite a  serious problem for some countries in  recent decades .
Japan for instance , with its average age of population at 42 in the year 2009 , is having a quite serious problem with an aging population .
What is the actual problem with the aging problem ?
Basically , with the number of the working population dwindling  and the number of the so called "old aged" rising up , the expense for taking care of the "old" is increasing and the economy is facing a huge threat of collapsing .
This  , however , has been taken too seriously by some countries .
Although this problem is quite serious , over-emphasizing and spending too much on this problem is not a good idea .
I agree that spending for the old age should be limited for the "old" is not the only concern of a country .
There exists many other aspects of a country that needs more funding and , in some cases , spending more in these other aspects can actually help a country's aging population problem .
Education in a country is one area that can indirectly help in easing the aging population problem .
How can the education sector help ?
Firstly we have to take a look at the cause of the decrease in the  working population .
The decrease itself can be caused by 2 different things: low birth rate , which means the problem arises because of the shortage of youth; and low education , which means that the problem arises because the shortage of well-educated youths for the workforce .
In the latter case , reallocating the funds for taking care of the "old" to the education sector can help in both easing the aging population and developing the country .
One example of this case is Singapore .
With the education sector well funded , not only  can Singapore increase the number of workforce by increasing the number of educated youths , she/ it also manage to attract a lot of immigrants from the neighboring countries such as Malaysia , China , India , Vietnam , and Indonesia .
These immigrants and well-educated youth , in the long run , can ease the aging problem by becoming the workforce , increasing the size and moving the wheels of the economy and decreasing the elder dependency on the government .
Another aspect that can help in easing the problem is the industrial development of a country .
In contrast to the earlier education sector which helps in easing the problem by eliminating the cause , an increase in spending in this sector helps by reducing the effects of the old aging population: the collapse of the economy .
The aging population problem can practically stop the turning wheels of economy as the ones who turn the wheel are the industrial and commercial sector of a country , which needed youths as its workforce .
By spending more in this sector , one can hope that the economy will not collapse and immigrants are more attracted to come .
Japan , in this case , is one good example .
Japan , as one of the developed countries , has put great emphasize in its industries .
Their industries , starting from the modern gaming industries such as koei and konami to the more luxurious and "heavy" industries of sport cars such as Mitsubishi , are well-known to have a wide range of customers around the world .
With the industrial sector well-developed , Japan can still maintain its economy from falling despite  its average population age of 42 and proved that funding the industrial development sector can really help in easing the aging problem by reducing its impact .
Although one can already see from the examples above that spending on the old age should be limited and the fund should be reallocated to other sectors , one might still think that we are in debt to the aging population because of their previous effort and work in the past and that we have to show our gratitude to them by allocating some  for them , spending too much is still not wise idea .
Taking care of the  aging population and spending some for them is indeed the government's obligation and responsibility but one can already see that there are some alternative and better ways to solve and to take care of this population problem , as shown above .
Spending too much on the  aged population will not benefit the country at all as spending too much will only waste the funds and will not bring any development or solution to the problem .
On the contrary , spending in other areas might bring benefits as well as solutions for the problem .
The examples stated above have already shown the facts that reallocating the funds will greatly benefit a country .
Spending on education will help in developing the country and eliminating one of the causes of the aging population problem , while spending on industrial development will help in attracting immigrants and keeping the economy running .
These examples , with the fact that spending for the old age population will not bring any benefit have proven that it is better to limit and reallocate the spending for old age .
Just as the aging population is a serious problem , spending on the  aged population is also a problem if it is not done properly .
Spending on the aged must be limited and not too much as there are other aspects as shown above that also need to be funded .
On the other hand , spending on the old age should not be too little either as spending too little will cause the population to be upset and therefore decrease the government stability .
It is a challenge for the government to find the right portion of the spending that has to be allocated for the aged population in the country as it is one of the obligations and responsibilities a government has .
The better alternative , however , is spending more on the other aspects rather than spending on the aging population .
If one can solve the aging problem and develop the country at the same time by spending more on other sectors in the country  as mentioned above , why would one choose not to and spend more on the old age population ?
The aging problem is gradually growing into a larger concern for many developed and developing countries in recent years .
Furthermore , this problem is likely to become more serious in the near future as the lifespan of mankind keeps increasing .
This is when technology comes into play .
Technology plays  an essential role in helping to ease the aging process for the elders in mainly three ways .
First of all , technology makes it possible to retard aging to some extent .
The newest advanced technology offers new therapies , anti-aging products , and others For instance , the Laser ablation of Lipofuscin , a new anti-aging project , aims to tune the use of laser pulses in order to remove lipofuscin from aged cells , to hopefully cure or reduce aging .
(ImmInst .org) The accumulation of Lipofuscin is implicated in a variety of diseases such as Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease ( Muscle & Nerve , date ?) .
If this research concludes in a major success , it may completely redefine the meaning of being old .
Other anti-aging products such as a skin-care cream can contribute to making a part of the consumer's body stay young .
Now that humans can age at a slower speed with the help of technology , people no longer wake up to the horror that the reflection in the mirror looks so old that it does not correspond with the memory .
Secondly , technology increases elders' capabilities tremendously .
People's abilities in seeing , hearing , memorizing ,  decrease drastically when they reach a certain age .
Therefore , the tools that enhance these sensitivities have been proven useful to the elders .
While such inventions allow the elders to live independently , they also lower the chance of feeling old , weak , and incapable of doing things  .
For example , Microsoft introduced new functions in its OS , which can magnify characters , read the screen , voice control , (delete) .
The new touchless keyboard from Actbrise even lets users  input without the trouble of moving their hands ( Engadget , year ?) .
These new tools or functions have made it possible for many elders to enjoy the excitement of experiencing advanced technology .
Because elders can "catch up" with many latest inventions , they are less likely to feel abandoned by the progressing society compared to the older generations .
Last but certainly not least , technology promises a brighter future for all men , including the elders .
In fact , the future is not far away from the present .
Take a look at organs , for instance .
"Several different technologies for harnessing regeneration are now in clinical trials around the world .
One machine , being tested in Germany , sprays a burn patient's own cells onto a burn , signaling the skin to re-grow" ( Andrews , year ?) .
Similarly , the quality of artificial organs is improving at an amazing speed , while the need for organ replacement is growing at an even faster rate .
(Cascalho and Platt) It can be seen that future technology may lead to longer lifespan and better healthcare , as well as possible ways to make an elder's body literally young and energetic once again .
Technology has been playing a major part in helping ease the aging process .
It slows human's aging speed , makes up human's deficiencies when they grow old , and promises a brighter future that human can look forward to .
It is most likely that technology will continue to play an essential role in almost all our lives .
From a handsome young lad to a grouchy old man and from a pretty young babe to a nagging old woman , "Aging is a continuous process from birth to death , which encompasses physical , social , psychological , and spiritual changes ."
(1) During this process , an elderly will experience deterioration in memory , slower reflexes and mobility and strong desire to have familial support .
To a great extent medical and technological developments help tackle such changes hence help ease the process of aging .
Firstly , the most common psychological change that elderly will experience is deteriorating memory .
This change can lead to a lot of complications such as forgetting to take medicine for other illnesses , wandering around the streets because they forget how to get home and unable to remember things they had just did .
Personal digital assistant (PDA) can be used to help the elderly remember things .
With this device , one can set time-based reminders to remind them to perform periodic chores for instance to take their medicine .
In the medical field , there is a lot of ongoing research to find medical cures to slow down or stop the process of deteriorating memory .
There are various non-profitable organizations all over the world seeking cures for common illness among elderly an example will be for Parkinson Disease there is the Parkinson's Institute and Clinical Center in America .
(2)
Secondly , biological change is another change that aging brings about .
There are the obvious changes such as physical appearance and the not so obvious change in terms of muscular build and structure .
As one advances in age , their movement and reflex become tardier .
Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) technology is a new technology which is in use to help the elderly .
For example in Singapore , the Land Transport Authority (LTA) is looking into using RFID to help the elderly .
The traffic light will be modified to be able to extend the time for slow-walking elderly to cross the road when it detects an elder is going to cross the road .
(3) Muscular related problems are common among the elderly .
Various types of pain-killer are introduced to help ease the pain of the elderly .
Lastly , the sociological change that the elderly experienced is the desire to be closer to their family members .
Familial relationship is more important to them and they are more dependent on their children to look after them .
Work commitment makes it impossible for their children to be with them twenty-four seven .
Web-camera is a technology that can help bring members of the family closer .
They might not be able to meet physical daily but at least it is an alternative for the elderly to have their empty heart filled and know that they are care for .
Working children can also use web cameras to keep a lookout for their elderly parents at home and should any mishaps happen they can go to their aid immediately .
Based on the aging statistics conducted by the Administration of Aging , "the older population who aged 65 years old and above in America is numbered to be 37 .3 million in 2006" and it is expected to be rising where there will be "more than twice the number by 2030 ."
As the population aged , there will be a higher probability for the elderly to suffer from certain illnesses and disorders that will affect both their physical and mental health .
Some of the illnesses and disorders include Alzheimer's disease , chronic disease such as hypertension and diabetes and cataract .
However , as the technology becomes more and more advanced , countries will be able to tap into the newer technologies and develop more elder-friendly inventions that eventually ease and slow the aging process .
Firstly , Alzheimer's disease is "the loss of intellectual and social abilities that is severe enough to interfere with daily functioning ."
Based on research , the number of people suffering from Alzheimer's disease rise "from around 2 .8 million people to 5 .1 million today" and the probability of people "developing Alzheimer's disease doubles every five years after the age of 65" .
Thus to aid those elderly who are suffering from Alzheimer's disease , many researchers have used the current or newer technology to come out with different innovative solutions .
One of the examples will be a "reminder robot which is developed by the University of Tokyo" .
This reminder robot which is named as "Mamoru monitor every move its owner makes and verbally alert them when they are trying to do the same activity twice a day" .
This helps to prevent the elderly from forgetting and doing the same thing/action repetitively in a day .
In addition , the University of Tokyo has also developed another reminder robot where "it monitors a room with camera and senor to keep track of where pre-registered objects have been placed in the room ."
This helps the elderly to locate their items and ensure that they will not misplace their valuable items .
Secondly , chronic diseases such as hypertension and diabetes are very common illness among the aging population .
These illnesses require constant and regular medication and treatment from the doctor to keep it under control .
From research , "death rate from high blood pressureincreased25 .2 percent ,and the actual number of deaths rose56 .4 percent ."
To ensure that the elderly go for their treatment and take their medication constantly , researchers have come out with practical solutions that eventually alert/ remind the elderly to take their medications on time .
The first example will be the automatic pill dispenser called the Medtime XL .
"Medtime XL is a device for dispensing medicine where it reminds the user when the medicine shall be taken and making the correct dose available .
"Besides that , "alarm will also sound and pills rotate into position" based on the individual medication time and the "alarm will only go away after the users have turned the device upside down" to retrieve their pills .
The second example will be the "Ageing Lab's Robot Pet called the Pill Pets" .
Pill Pets is created by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) where "it reminds owner to take their pill or go to the doctor for regular treatment or checkup ."
If the elderly fails to perform the task required by the pill pets , the "pill pet will try a more visceral reminder which include simulating sickness or death ."
By having those inventions , children of elderly suffering from chronic disease will not have to manually remind their parent on their medication dosage and time through phone and thus train the elderly to be more independent .
Thirdly , as we age , the chance of getting a vision disorder such as cataract will be higher .
Based on research , "by age 80 , more than half of all Americans are suffering from cataracts ."
"A cataract is a clouding of the lens in the eye that affects vision ."
To help those elderly who are suffering from cataract , researchers have come out with various creative solutions that are closely related to their daily lifestyle .
The first example will be the Tek Partner TV remote .
"Tek Partner TV remote is a special TV remote that consists of large , illuminated buttons" .
The second example will be the "Accenda Voice-Adicted TV remote where "elderly is able to change the TV channel and play video through voice command" .
By having these elderly friendly inventions , it increases convenience and elderly would be able to better operate their television with their blur vision and there will not be too much strain on their eyes when they look and use the remote control .
However , the critics of this argument feel that the current technology does not help to ease the aging process , but instead , it infringes on the privacy of the elderly .
It is true that technological inventions  tend to infringe on the privacy of the elderly , but they still help to ease the aging process as the monitoring of elderly through various electronic ways are done at a good cause .
Due to the increasing aging population , there will be an increasing number of elderly that are likely to suffer from disease such as dementia .
By monitoring the elderly actions through web camera and reminder robot , children of the elderly can be better informed of the well-being of their parents and thus able to work at ease .
Other than that , monitoring can also give the elderly more sense of security as everything will be recorded down and they can easily refer to the recorded video without straining their brain cells to recall and find those items that they have misplaced it .

This can be translated into an increase of about 296 ,000 in June 2005 to 873 ,300 in 2030 .

Although no treatment has been discovered to cure such illnesses , the only way is to improve and come up with new innovative technology to help ease the current aging process .
Although critics argue that technological inventions have helped to ease the aging process , this however , may not be the case .
In overall , technological inventions may be a great help to the elderly .
However once the elderly become over dependent on technology , they will be at a loss once the device is unable to respond to expectations .
This will result in the elderly being unable to continue with their daily lives .
For example , there is no absolute assurance that device that will never breakdown .
What if an elderly who is operating an electric wheelchair suddenly breaks down in the middle of the road and the elderly got stranded in the middle of the road; this will definitely cause disastrous effects to the elderly and to the traffic .
Therefore this is the main reason why technological inventions may have not ease the aging process in Singapore .
Another illness that brings forth attention is mobility impairment .
As elderly aged , they will gradually lose neuro-muscular coordination which in terms means losing of muscle power or balance .
This will result in elderly suffering from falls and which in turn risks osteoporosis-related fractures .
[5] Technology is also able to relieve the elderly in this situation , for example the "HipSaver Hip Protector" is designed to help prevent elderly from sustaining fractures and minimize the forces of impact if they really fall .
This invention is an all-soft one piece brief with thin tapered elastic foam pads encased in a waterproof and airtight pouch .
It effectively protects the elderly by absorbing the impact from a severe fall .
According to this source , a controlled study is conducted on elderly over the age of 79 , and the percentage of elderly who uses the HipSaver Hip Protector had 199 falls over 26 months with no hip fractures while the group of elderly who did not use suffers 369 falls over 26 months with 16 sustained hip fractures .
At the same time , an air pad will inflate like a miniature air bag diverting the force away the hipbone .
The elderly can wear this comfortable Hip Protector for the whole day in comfort .
[6] Lastly  this deviceno need for a comma here it provides confidence and independent living for the elderly .
"In Singapore , the 3rd leading cause of death is stroke .
"[7] "Stroke is a disease that affects arteries supplying blood to the brain and causes sudden non-convulsive malfunction to the brain .
Unless the blood supply restores , part of the brain cells will die and this will cause irreversible permanent brain damage .
"[8] There is an increasing number of elderly who suffers from stroke and many of which became disabled .
Thus , as technology advances day by day , there are many various innovative solutions that help the elderly to solve the problems faced in their daily lives .
For example , a new invention called "My Spoon" has been invented to help disabled elderly .
"My Spoon" is a robotic arm which operates by controlling the joystick where elderly can be able to move it in 4 directions (up , down left , right) to maneuver the arm which can wield a spoon or a fork to bring the food to their mouth .
The elderlycould  use the joystick to select their desired food on the food tray .
One of the users , Takashi Fuzawa who had tried out this device , commented that this device has helped him to eat by himself without much help .
[9] This technology benefits the elderly by obtaining minimal help from the care givers to feed them and allowing them to gain confidence in living an independent life .
According to a report concerning the aging population in Singapore , "there is an increase of elderly living alone from 10 ,400 in 1990 to 25 ,700 in 2000 .
"[10] With more elderly living alone , the need for more care givers also increases .
Moreover , as elderly are prone to illnesses and accidents , they might suffer from severe falls and strokes .
However with technology improving drastically , many new innovative technologies have surfaced to assist the elderly .
With these elderly care devices and gadgets , the elderly can lead a safe and independent life with minimal help from care givers .
In conclusion , the importance of technology has created an impact in elderly daily lives and has helped to ease the aging process .
Based on a recent survey conducted on the impact of technology on the elderly , the majority of the elderly surveyed believe that advancement in technology "will produce better quality of life for themselves"(1) .
Indeed , advancement in technology has helped to ease the aging process in terms of health , lifestyle and safety .
Lastly , technological inventions can help keep the elderly safe in their homes .
Today , many companies provide home monitoring systems .
An example would be QuietCare .
QuietCare uses an "average of five to seven" sensors to monitor movement within the elderly home (8) .
It can detect , using infrared sensors , if there is "a lack of movement" within the home and notify the relative or a care person (8) .
Another example would be the intercom doorbell , which can help the elderly "respond to visitors without having to rush" (9) .
This , in turn , can help prevent injury caused by falls .
The most common invention would be the webcam .
An example would be Willing Webcam that has a built-in "motion capture detection sensor" (10) .
This sensor can activate actions such as "sending emails" , "SMS text message" or "sounding an alarm" (10) .
It can detect "the slightest movement in the home" and notify the user if there is an intruder (10) .
With such technologies at hand , the elderly will be confident to live alone knowing that their safety is well taken care of .
Governments should prioritise on problems which require more attention .
They can cut down spending on other areas rather than the funds for the aged .
For example , military spending should be reduced if the country is already enjoying peace and defense stability .
However , the military is deemed so essential that it is the "prerequisite" to all areas of development in the country .
Although the country's defense cannot allow for any complacency , the benefits of investing in a military can only be projected as a contributing factor to the economic growth .
Nevertheless , the aging population problem must not be overlooked by focusing on only the important factors contributing to the country's development .
In  contemporary society , the elderly are well taken care of in many countries .
Some governments even do it "too" well that a large amount of money , which should be spent on other social issues , is wasted .
There should be changes in the policies about this problem .
First of all , there should be a careful consideration about what  governments should pay for .
As for healthcare service , it is not reasonable that the elderly can have free or low-priced treatment for all kinds of sickness .
Instead , it should be limited that everyone mustn't have any priorities when they get treatment for any kinds of illness that are resulted from unhealthy lifestyles .
For instance , the obese patients must pay full-price for their treatment since obesity is the consequence of the lack of exercising in their everyday-lives .
Moreover , governments should only pay for each individual a certain amount of money based on his or her financial position .
That everyone gets the same amount of money is neither fair nor efficacious .
There should be a prudent consideration so that it's worth every penny .
By making more efficient policies , governments will be able to save a lot of money to spend on other aspects of society that are also very important .
For example , more money should be invested in education so that children are better educated and later become a profitable workforce for society .
As a result , they can support themselves more effectively not only when they are young , but also during their old age In addition , governments can spend more on developing technologies .
By doing this , more and more useful and efficient tools and machines can be invented which will improve the productivity of every economic activity .
So it will enable the economy to expand which means more jobs will be created for everyone .
Not stopping at this point , governments can also use money to encourage more researching in many fields such as healthcare , etc . . . That will definitely better the living standard of citizens and improve the economy as well as ease the aging issue .
By limiting public spending on the aged , more money can be devoted to the progress of the economy .
Larger scales of technological investment can take place thus gaining better profit .
This economic growth is important because it allows the country to have the power to improve its citizens' quality of life .
Safe drinking water and proper shelters can be better provided for the population as a result of this additional growth .
Citizens enjoying this better quality of life are less prone to diseases promoting a healthier life .
To add on , the nation will also be able to build more hospitals and enhanced medical services to provide the population including the elderly with better health care .
The elderly of the nation will also be benefiting from this economic growth indirectly  .Caregivers , consisting largely of working adults , will be earning more income in parallel to the nation prosperity .
Furthermore , non-profit organizations dedicated to take care of the elderly are able to obtain donations easier as the members of the public are more able to contribute .
Clearly , economic growth not only affects the population positively but the elderly are also benefiting from it .
With larger financial support given , the education sector can be improved further .
More teachers can be trained to facilitate the learning environment of students .
Additional Universities and specialized schools can be built to enroll more students therefore allowing more citizens to get an education .
Through education , working adults are able to deal with highly complicated equipment that enable them to bring revenue back to the country .
Educating the population not only improve the economy by allowing them to become more efficient , but also allow them to plan for their retirement .
This would reduce their dependency on the government when they are old thus cutting public spending on the age .
Elderly who wish to continue working are able to do so by attend upgrading courses to facilitate them in finding jobs .
However , the mentioned advantages to the elderly are only applicable to the aged who have caregivers and are able to afford health services and education .
Single and poor elderly would not be able to reap the benefits but suffered because of limited public spending by the government on them .
Effective measures to identify these needy elderly are needed to separate them from the wealthier cohort .
Following this , appropriate amount of help is given equally to them so as to fully utilize the limited resources .
Limiting spending on the aged population could bring about social instability , affecting society infrastructure which greatly affects a country's image in the international community .
We cannot abandon them as ultimately they are still an integral part of our society .
Government should spend much effort on taking care of them by providing financial support .
It would be the most direct means of showing concern for them .
Not doing so would lead to many social problems such as climbing crime rates , street begging and so on .
These social problems greatly affects a country's image .
When a country cannot even handle its own problems there is no way it could be given the chance to hold world class events such as Olympics which boosts its international reputation and many other areas .
The rippling effect that arises from the small social issue greatly affects a country's developments on many fronts .
Secondly , cutting funding with particular reference to the aged is undoubtedly seen as out casting the society group .
It portrays a government as practicing discrimination , which is a violation of human rights .
In modern world democracy , infringing on human rights is a grave matter .
Any government would be unwise to openly advocate for policies which discriminates against a particular society group .
Denying responsibility to take care of its less privileged elderly would draw criticisms from both international bodies and its citizens .
It would be deemed political suicide .
Ousting of the political party in ruling is only a matter of time .
What more of other areas of development can the political party talk about when its not the ruling party ?
Lastly , shrinking responsibility to take care of aged citizens will lead to drastic loss of talents in the country .
Citizens would consider migration and foreign talents would be less attracted to migrate into the country .
Knowing the government would not take proper care of them after they retire .
Perhaps in the short term pumping financial resources to areas such as technology and economy may produce expected results .
In the long term , the country will suffer from irreversible losses as progress is made by its people and remaining talents are insufficient to substantiate the growth .
The first measure is MediSave .
Under this scheme , every worker needs to contribute 6 .5 - 9 % (depending on age group) of his monthly salary to his personal MediSave account .
As people grow old , they tend to use more health care products and services .
With this savings ,  elderly people can be protected as they can use this fund to pay for hospitalization , surgery , and other medical expenses .
However , some people might think that if they suffer from those prolonged diseases , it can quickly drain  their MediSave balance .
In this case , they will not be able to pay for their huge medical fees .
To counter this issue , Singapore has come out with MediShield .
This scheme is aiming to help the people who suffer from major or prolonged diseases .
It subsidies the large medical bill needed up to 80% .
Therefore , with these medical schemes , the elderly people's healthcare can be secured .
The second measure is the Maintenance of Parent Act .
This is an act to handle the cases relating to children abandoning their parents in nursing homes .
According to the article from Sunday Times , it is said that more than 400 elderly people have been beneficial from the Maintenance of Parent Act .
Of the 424 applicants , 328 or almost four in five were successfully compelling their children to take care of them .
This statistics show that the elderly people can be protected by the law .
However , some children might think that living with their parents is  a nuisance because they need a lot of care and attention .
The health care spending is also another burden .
If you think in another way round , the parent's contribution to children may not be less than children's contribution to parent .
In addition , one must admit that the hardship of bringing out a child .
The parents need to teach them how to walk , pay for their medical and education fee , and etc .
Anyway , this is about the issue of filial piety .
Therefore , to protect the elderly people , the filial obligation must be stressed .
The last policy is the age-friendly policies which increase the employment of the older worker .
This policy aims to help the older worker to stay employed longer .
According to Xinhua News , Singapore's employment rate for workers aged to 55 to 64 is 57 percent today .
It is believed that it will increase until 65 percent in the next three years .
To deal with such challenge , Singapore's government has implemented many schemes to help  people work longer .
One of the examples is "ADVANTAGE !
Scheme" which has made more than 1 ,200 companies to employ 8 ,800 mature workers , to keep 19 ,300 existing older workers , and recruit more than 5 ,300 older workers .
However , some people might think that elderly people should stop working and enjoy themselves in their old age .
If they do not have sufficient retirement savings , it is very hard to enjoy themselves in their old age .
So , if people can work longer , they will be able to accumulate more savings that they could use to support themselves in their old age .
In addition , they could lessen the burden on their children .
Certain social issues such as poor quality of life and insufficient funds for basic healthcare may arise from limited funding .
In general , most of the aged in Singapore are economically inactive and have a lot of free time on their hands .
In order to prevent them from turning to vices such as gambling and drinking , organizing more activities at various community centres are required for them to lead healthy social lives .
As these activities require government funding , limiting spending on the aged will make organizing these activities impossible .
Aside from social life , having basic healthcare is vital for the aged .
When people get older , it is only natural that they are more prone to illness be it mental or physical .
At present , healthcare is dreadfully expensive and the aged may not be able to afford proper treatment should they fall ill .
Thus , if the government limits spending and does not subsidize the costs of these treatments , the financial burden on the elderly will be even greater .
It is true that some of the families are able to afford to support their elderly parents and it should be their responsibility to bear the expenses of their aged family members instead of the government .
Nevertheless , there are some low income families who face high costs of living and cannot support both their children and elderly parents .
Hence , there should be distribution of public funds to the elderly parents of these families .
On top of that , there are elderly who have no children , so if their financial conditions are unstable , they should  be given the necessary funds to make ends meet .
Firstly , as a country usually allocates its budget to various areas , any increase in spending on a particular area will mean reduced spending on other areas .
For example , if a country decides to increase spending on the aged , a smaller budget may be allocated for education , research and investment purposes .
Reduced spending on education can mean fewer educators and lowered standards of teaching , reduced spending on research can mean fewer incentives for researchers and for their research work and reduced spending on investments may mean less cooperation with international bodies .
Thus , a country's budget cannot be adjusted without much consideration and thought or  it can cause instabilities to the supporting pillars of the country .
Secondly , public policies can be put in place to help the citizens to save up for their golden years .
For example , Singapore has a Central Provident Fund (CPF) scheme that helps its people to save up from the time they start working .
Monthly , a percentage of their salary will be deducted and credited into their CPF accounts .
Employers  are also required to credit an additional amount on top of the employee's contribution .
The debiting and crediting process is automated , thus the citizen need not do anything but he will still be notified regularly with his CPF account statement .
With proper policies to help citizens save up , countries can not only find no need to increase their budget on the aged , they may also find themselves spending less which can also mean that more funds can be allocated to other areas of the country's development .
However , having a compulsory saving policy can be a double edged sword from the citizens' point of view .
For example the CPF scheme in Singapore states that the account holder must have a certain amount of money , which was saved up automatically since the start of his working years , before he can withdraw the entire amount at the maturity age .
If the account holder does not have a stable job , he will find that he has a hard time trying to reach the minimum amount thus also finding himself unable to use or even see his own savings physically .
Thirdly , if the aged have children , the children should also be responsible for their parents' well-being .
Having the children support their own parents will mean less dependency on the government .
Some children choose not to support their parents even though they can afford to do so , usually claiming that they need the money on other necessities and luxuries .
