Within the past half century , two major accidents at the Chernobyl and the Three Mile Island nuclear power plants have caused the public to have a negative view of the operation of nuclear reactors and also , the future of nuclear energy generation .
Presently , the most common energy source , which is  coal-fired power generator , has been causing detrimental effects on the environment by releasing tremendous amounts of greenhouse gases and subsequently causing a rise in global warming .
Furthermore , with increasing concerns regarding the future of our environment , there is also an increasing need to search for alternative sources of energy which would not cause as much harm to the atmosphere .
As a result , leaders of environmental organisations , such as Patrick Moore who is a cofounder of Greenpeace , are beginning to realise that nuclear power generation is one of the most secure , economical and environmentally- friendly energy sources available (Yousefzadeh , 2007) .
In 2001 , the Generation IV International Forum introduced six different generation IV nuclear reactor concepts which had been designed in such a way that when accidents occur , the damage will be contained (Butler , 2004) .
Out of the six reactor concepts , the Lead-cooled Fast Reactor (LFR) looks to be the most promising one .
With the past accidents in mind and considering the advantages that nuclear power has to offer , if sufficient research efforts are to be channelled to the development of the LFR , we humans can certainly benefit from it in the long run .
When the Chernobyl accident occurred in 1986 , thirty-one people were killed immediately and many more died due to the radiation-related effects of the accident ("Chernobyl Accident" , 2009) .
This accident , especially , had caused many to oppose the nuclear power system as they feel that the extent of damage incurred by such systems would be massive and unacceptable .
However , future thorough research and development towards the safe operation of nuclear plants may prove to be worthwhile .
For example , the accident which occurred on the Three Mile Island did not involve any deaths or injuries as the radioactive particles were successfully contained within the reactor itself (Yousefzadeh , 2007) .
This simply shows that with advanced technology , even if an accident-free nuclear plant may never be achieved , at least the technology incorporated into the reactor system would be able to ensure that radiation is contained in times of accidents .
In addition , LFRs are relatively safer as compared to other generation IV reactors due to the inertness of the lead coolant .
Lead is chemically inactive with air and water , ruling out the possibility of accidental fires and explosions (Wider et al . , 2005) .
Hence , with more funding directed towards the research and development of the LFR , it may one day become one of the safest forms of energy generator .
Critics also claim that nuclear power plants and nuclear waste can be potential terrorist targets as a great extent of damage can be done when the plants are attacked or exploited .
Therefore , a strict set of security procedures have to be put in place and the use of advanced technology should be incorporated into the security system .
Another factor to be considered is the sustainability of the LFR .
Critics of nuclear energy claim that nuclear energy generation produces a large amount of radioactive waste products and eventually , storage spaces will run out , making nuclear energy unsustainable .
However , a characteristic of LFRs is that they are fast breeder reactors that carry out nuclear reprocessing of nuclear waste .
With this reprocessing feature in LFRs , uranium and plutonium , which make up 96% of the nuclear waste , can be extricated and reused in the reactor (Butler , 2004) .
As a result , the final amount of waste product would be reduced to a very large extent .
In addition , nuclear reprocessing also increases the efficiency of the usage of uranium and hence makes nuclear power a sustainable source of energy .
Moreover , lead is abundant (The Lead-cooled Fast Reactor , n .d .) , and uranium resources can last us for the next 250 years or so (Wider et al . , 2005) , making the LFR an excellent reactor in terms of sustainability .
In conclusion , the LFR has much to offer to mankind especially in terms of safety , security , sustainability as well as environmental effects .
The LFR is a nuclear energy reactor that is environmentally friendly with zero greenhouse gas emission .
Furthermore , the resources required in an LFR are in abundance , making it a sustainable source of energy .
Most importantly , humans can benefit from the LFR in the future if thorough research and more developments are to be made on it so as to make it safer and more secure from accidents or terrorist attacks .
The public has been concerned about the danger of radiation leaks from nuclear plants , especially after the Chernobyl incident in 1986 when the massive radiation exposure directly caused approximately 250 deaths (WHO , 2005) .
The incident raised security concerns about nuclear plants becoming a terrorist target , where an induced meltdown in terms of present-day operating scale will have catastrophic consequences .
The US administration , though , has recognized the potential of nuclear energy and has committed US$40 million to support research and development (R&D) for Next Generation Nuclear Plants (NGNPs) (DOE , 2009) .
The very-high-temperature-reactor (VHTR) , with  and the extensive R&D conducted on it , has been selected over other reactor concepts such as the supercritical-water-cooled-reactor (SCWR) as the reactor choice for the US' next generation nuclear power plants (DOE , 2008) .
Federal funding should be channeled for the R & D of the VHTR concept as it promises enhanced safety and inherent security designs , in addition to a highly efficient production process .
An estimated 4000 cases of thyroid cancer cases in children were attributed to the radiation leak from the Chernobyl incident , with the long term effect of the radiation exposure expected to continue over the years (UNSCEAR , N .D .) .
The slow but fatal effects of radiation have made radiation leaks from nuclear reactors a major safety concern among the public .
The VHTR addresses this concern by using helium gas as the choice of coolant for the reactor .
The inert nature of helium means it will not react with the radioactive materials of the VHTR to become radioactive , eliminating a source of radiation in the event of a coolant leak (CHM333 , 2007) .
Another safety feature of the VHTR is the use of uranium fuel pellets multi-coated with graphite .
These reinforced pellets are extremely heat resistant and do not crack easily , so even in the case of a meltdown , the uranium pellets will be able to retain the radiation and fission products within its core with minimal release to the surroundings (CHM333 , 2007) .
Questions have been raised by opponents of nuclear power technology regarding the security of the fuel pellets , which are rich sources of uranium .
When extracted and processed , enriched uranium can become a key material for the manufacture of nuclear weapons .
However , the multi-coated uranium fuel pellets used in the VHTR require a temperature of more than 1600oC before the fission products within its core can be removed and this arduous extraction condition deters potential weapon proliferation using its radioactive core (GIF , 2008) .
In addition , unlike traditional reactors , the VHTR is designed to minimize fissionable material in its spent fuel by running the fuel pellets through the reactors for consecutive cycles until its fissionable material is exhausted .
The spent fuel pellets will then be safe for disposal and not pose a security risk should there be any intention from terrorists to extract fissionable products from it (CHM333 , 2007) .
Detractors of nuclear power technology also have doubts on whether nuclear power plants can match the cost effectiveness of existing coal and gas power plants .
However , NGNPs are not only capable of generating electricity like coal and gas power plants , they can also simultaneously produce hydrogen (GIF , 2008) .
This co-generation of electricity and hydrogen is made possible by the high operating temperature of up to 1000oC for the VHTR which allows for the efficient production of hydrogen by thermo-chemical processes .
Hydrogen fuel cells have been identified as the energy source of the future , so the capability to produce hydrogen gives NGNPs an edge over existing coal and gas plants .
By future proofing its technology , NGNPs can ensure their relevance to the power industry in the future .
Moreover , the high operating temperature of the VHTR also results in higher fuel burn-up ratio of the fissionable materials in the uranium pellets (DOE , 2008) .
With its highly efficient fuel burn-up , NGNPs will have a lower carbon footprint than coal and gas technology and at the same time , havingless radioactive material remaining in the spent pellets reduces the amount of radioactive waste to be treated , improving the overall process economy .
R&D work done on nuclear power technology to date has shown promising prospects to justify the US$40 million financial support from the US administration .
However , additional funding for the VHTR will only be available if both the US government and the public can be convinced about the viability of NGNPs replacing coal and gas power plants as the main supplier of US electricity .
To achieve this , the VHTR has to stay on track through sustained R&D work in the coming years so that it can meet its expected delivery deadline in 2020 (Butler , 2004) .
The world is encountering an unprecedented challenge which requires urgent global action to prevent the risks of climate change (Stern , 2008) .
To do so , the global greenhouse gas emissions have to be reduced by half relative to 1990 by 2050 , which means to reduce to less than 10 Gigatonnes of emissions (Stern , 2008) .
Many countries rely on fossil fuels as their source of energy and fossil fuel is known to be the major contributor of  greenhouse gases .
In the United States alone , greenhouse gas emissions mainly come from the burning of fossil fuels for energy use .
Energy- related carbon dioxide emissions from the combustion of petroleum , coal , and natural gas contributed to eighty-two percent of total U .S . anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions in 2006 (Energy Information Administration , 2008) .
By using the very high temperature reactor (VHTR) , hydrogen can be used as the fuel of the future to replace  fossil fuels .
In addition , more electricity will be produced with the help of the VHTR .
Therefore , for a better environment to live in , countries should support further research and provide large funding for the development of the VHTR even though the public is concerned with the cost and security of the VHTR .
VHTR plants are able to produce hydrogen for fuel using high-temperature steam electrolysis , which breaks apart the bonds of water molecules; this process is 50 percent more energy-efficient as compared to  existing hydrogen production methods (Svoboda , 2009) .
Thus , hydrogen can replace fossil fuels as a source of fuel .
However , until now , there is still no material that can withstand the high temperatures and pressures required for the VHTR to operate , and even if such materials are found , they might add millions of dollars to the still- unknown cost of constructing a VHTR power plant (Svoboda , 2009) .
The public is then concerned about the huge funding needed for development of the VHTR and thus feel that developing countries should first handle poverty and unemployment .
However , the developing countries will account for around eight billion out of a world population of nine billion by 2050 (Stern , 2008) .
and so they need to be involved in achieving global emission reductions .
In addition , poor people around the world also need abundant , affordable and modern energy .
1 .6 billion people in the developing countries do not have excess to electricity so they have to end their day earlier than those in richer countries due to lack of proper lighting (Bradley , 2009) .
With the VHTR , developing countries will be able to meet their energy demand and will thus lift millions of people out of poverty .
Therefore , similar to those rich countries , developing countries should also provide funding for the development of the VHTR .
The the VHTR is able to produce fifty percent more electricity from the same amount of fuel as compared with conventional plants (Butler , 2004) and is also able to produce electricity about forty percent more efficiently than most reactors in the United States (Svoboda , 2009) .
In addition , INL researchers also believe that nuclear energy will be important in maintaining the nation's electricity supply as  (Svoboda , 2009) .
However , given memories of the partial reactor meltdown in 1979 at Three Mile Island , Pennsylvania and of the 1986 accident at Chernobyl in Ukraine , during which the reactor core exploded , killing some 31 people instantly and spreading radioactive debris across Europe (Butler , 2004) , the public is concerned about the safety of the VHTR .
Furthermore , the Department of Energy and the National Nuclear Security Agency found that reprocessing increases nuclear waste and the dangers of proliferation and terrorism (Lieberman , 2009) .
However , in actual fact , VHTR is able to function without having to rely on the reprocessing of plutonium waste (Butler , 2004) .
Nuclear reactors would then become less of a terrorist target .
The VHTR also has safety features to prevent core overheating and the release of radioactive material , in hope that these new approaches will eventually erase the memory of Three Mile Island and Chernobyl (Svoboda , 2009) .
Therefore , countries should provide funding for research and development of the VHTR .
Building of the VHTR means that countries will no longer need to depend on fossil fuels as a source of energy and the emission of greenhouse gases will also be greatly reduced .
In addition , the controversial reprocessing of nuclear waste will be solved .
Generating sufficient hydrogen to totally replace gasoline for  transport purposes would mean building more than four hundred nuclear power plants ,  (Butler , 2004) .
However , there are only 441 nuclear plants in the world today (Butler , 2004) .
It is evident that  countries should proceed with the research and development of the VHTR .
Developing countries should also invest in the development of the VHTR as satisfying their energy demand is essential for their economic growth .
Nuclear power has been a source of energy since the 1960s .
Nevertheless , the world has always been concerned about the safety and security issues of  nuclear reactors .
Thus , researchers have come up with generation four reactor concepts , hoping to ease the public's worries .
I personally support the molten salt reactor concept for further research and development based on the following factors: safe operation of the plant , global security and  cost efficiency .
The safety issue of nuclear reactors is directly linked to the risk of radioactive emissions .
Radioactive emissions can come from nuclear explosions or nuclear wastes .
An explosion of a nuclear reactor not only affects the people on site but also millions of others kilometres away .
A good example will be the Chernobyl disaster .
An explosion of the nuclear reactor  occurs due to either excessively high temperature or excessively high pressure .
According to Ghetta , Gorse , Mazi re and Pontikis (2008) , the molten salt reactor functions under very low vapour pressure but very high temperature .
Nevertheless , Forsberg (2006)statesd that the MSR has a strong negative temperature coefficient .Thus ,s when there is an increase intemperatures , the fuel-salt density will reduce and push fuel out of the reactor core into critically safe , passively cooled tanks .
This will prevent overheating which leads toexplosionsn .
As for the waste of molten salt reactors , due to reprocessing , the nuclear wastes are minimal .
According to Forsberg (2006) , the final nuclear waste from the molten salt reactor can be solidified to a stableform ,m thus ensuring that it does not emit radioactivity .
He also added that MSRs operate ata steady-state conditionn , with minimum excess nuclear reactivity .
This greatly reduces the radioactive emissions around the reactor .
Besides safety issues , the security of the nuclear reactors is another point brought up by critics .
The location of a nuclear reactor is to  terrorists an ideal bombing target .
In addition , in molten salt reactors , plutonium , a key ingredient of advanced nuclear weapons , is actually created during the process before it is reprocessed .
Critics fear that the plutonium might be stolen by terrorists to make nuclear weapons .
However , Idaho National Laboratory (2005) claims that the plutonium  remains in the salt and has high critical mass that makes it less desirable for use in weapons .
According to Butler (2004) , supporters are also positive that the plutonium obtained can be spiked with other chemicals or elements to make it  to steal .
This further supports the need for research and development on molten salt reactors .
As for  , the World Nuclear Association (2008) states that the basis of the design of the reactors assumes these threats .
There are sensors in the reactors that will shut down the entire reactor when there is any abnormality .
Having to incorporate all the safety and security measures makes the cost efficiency of the nuclear power plant  another concern .
The World Nuclear Association (2009) states that the cost of nuclear power generation has declined since the 1990s .
They also show statistics proving that although the construction cost of nuclear reactors is significantly higher , once the reactors are built , the nuclear generation cost is comparable to other energy sources .
In addition , Thornley (2009) claims that as compared to other energy sources ,   nuclear energy has the highest average capacity factor .
This means that nuclear power is the most efficient energy source .
Efficiency means lower costs .
Taking the MSR as an example , previous designs for the MSR used steam cycles for electrical production .
The current proposal uses the Brayton cycle which has advantages such as lower cost and improved efficiency .
According to Forsberg (2006) , there is a 4 percent increase in efficiency .
However , the MSR uses fluoride salt , which is more corrosive at high temperatures .
Thus , there are doubts about whether the MSR is a good choice .
Nevertheless , there is currently the carbon-based material which , according to Forsberg (2006) , is compatible with molten salt at high temperatures .
In other words , the corrosion will not be an issue .
In conclusion , I have to agree that the molten salt reactor is not perfect , but the benefits of the molten salt reactor outweigh the cons and supporters are optimistic about finding solutions to the problems , showing their potential .
This is proven from its low excess reactivity to decreasing maintenance costs .
Thus , I support the further research and development of the molten salt reactor .
A serious train calamity took place in Eschede on 3 June 1998 and claimed the lives of 101 innocent people while 88 were left severely injured (Sckhman , 1998) .
It was proclaimed to be the world's deadliest train accident .
Investigations proved that the derailment of the train was due to a single fatigue fissure in the wheel .
The steel tire had gotten loose from the wheel and was wedged in the rail carriages .
As the train passed two rail switches , the loosened tire knocked against a switch lever and pulled the train off the railway track , causing one of its carriages to crash into a bridge .
It is unimaginable that this minor fault is the main cause for this catastrophe .
At hindsight , it seems that this whole accident could have been prevented if more precautionary measures had been taken into consideration .
The numerous controversies over the actual cause of this accident revolve around the unsuitable design of the wheel , the inability and misconception of the conductor , the inadequate train repairs and the company guidelines for investigating the accident before addressing an issue .
After reviewing this accident , some experts have felt that incorporating a psychologist into the developmental process could have aided in preventing it .
This writer feels that the introduction of a psychologist in a team of design engineers would not have prevented the accident .
Nevertheless , the psychologist could have contributed to the design process by reducing the rate of accidents  .
A point to argue about is regarding the wheel design .
The train company , InterCity Expss (ICE) , had received complaints regarding the original train wheels causing serious resonance and tremors whilst travelling at high velocity .
Engineers resolved this problem by inserting a rubber damping ring between the wheel and the tire .
However , this design had never been used on high-speed trains before and thus failed to adhere to safety standards .
It is evident that had the engineers waited for the approval of the new wheels before  , this accident might not have happened .
A psychologist roped in to help the engineers may have been able to foresee this impending structural failure of the wheel and intervened before it was too late .
Another point lies with the company and the conductor .
Company policy stated that thorough examinations had to be done before taking any necessary action .
This led to the conductor refusing to stop the train even after a passenger raised concern regarding a damaged coach .
In addition , even after the conductor had verified the problem , he still  refused to stop the train and insisted on adhering to company regulations .
It is shocking to realize that this unique policy that ICE complies with differs from the traditional 'stop and examine' one .
This accident could perhaps have been averted if the conductor had used his personal judgment and halted the train when an unexpected problem was discovered .
It must have been pressure from the organizational management that made the conductor follow ICE orders and refuse to do what was right i .e .
stall the train .
In part , it can be said that the cause of the accident was ICE for forming this rule and the conductor's erroneous judgment .
After conducting a root cause analysis on the accident , a psychologist could perhaps have aided the company by vetting the flawed regulations to grant train conductors the power to make an assessment to stop the train should they receive any complaints from passengers .
Yet another point is  a simple fault found in the train's wheel .
This brought forth attention to the frequency of maintenance checks carried out by the train company .
ICE had claimed that they had conducted checks on the train on a regular basis using conventional flash lights .
This proves that checks were only conducted on the external structure of the train and not on the internal hardware and sustainability of the wheels to support the train's weight .
It is evident that ICE was too complacent and did not use more advanced technology to maintain their trains .
The aid from a psychologist in this aspect would have been limited as it deals with technical equipment and the views of psychological design would not have been implemented in this field .
After various considerations , this writer concludes that only one factor cannot be blamed as the sole cause of the accident .
Instead , it was various factors working together to create a chain reaction which led to the dire consequences .
In this train accident , the problems began from the preliminary wheel design that design engineers came up with , to the insufficient maintenance of trains and the operation mode ICE used .
The aid from a psychologist would have been inadequate in preventing the accident as the majority of the causes for this accident dealt with technical  aspects that psychologists do not have experience in .
However , the psychologist could have contributed to the intangible aspects of the company's routine like spotting the mistakes engineers sometimes overlook .
Hence , with the help of psychology design , the rates of accidents may reduce drastically .
Public opposition regarding the issue of nuclear technology has been evident ever since the Chernobyl and Three Mile accidents .
People are mostly concerned about public health and safety caused by radioactive exposures .
In the case of Shoreham , the nuclear plant faced strong opposition from both the people and the government .
Although Shoreham had a license for nuclear power testing , the plant was fully decommissioned in the end in 1998 .
Light Water Reactors (LWRs) make up the majority of nuclear plants in the United States .
Uranium is the primary fuel source in these nuclear plants .
Unfortunately ,  .
In addition , nuclear waste repositories require geological isolation  .
On the other hand , the concept of fourth generation nuclear power addresses the issue of  .
They are capable of combusting nuclear waste and leaving a minimal volume of waste with insignificant half-lives , thus addressing the nuclear waste problem .
The Molten Salt Reactor (MSR) is a type of fourth generation nuclear reactor .
The coolant comprises  a molten salt .
The concept of the MSR involves nuclear fuel dissolved in the molten fluoride salt as uranium tetra fluoride .
As such , the fluid would be able to rely on fuel that is dispersed in a graphite matrix with the molten salt providing low pressure and high temperature cooling , unlike in today's LWR's .
Thus , the MSR has the ability to work at high temperatures , at low pressures and at high power densities .
At higher temperatures , most of the reactor heat can then be transformed into electricity which ensures complete combustion of the uranium fuel .
Operating at lower pressures reduces accident risk  and  in the event of an accident .
The MSR can be air-cooled , making it capable of using waste heat for water desalination .
The turbines have also excellent thermodynamic efficiency due to the relatively high temperature it functions at .
Secondly , unlike traditional LWRs , refueling of the MSR can be done while the system is still in operation .
Fission products are removed and new fuel is added to portions of the fuel at a time , drastically reducing the cost operating the MSR .
The Obama administration was initially opposed to the idea of the Yucca Mountain nuclear repository .
The amount of money needed to build a nuclear repository isolated away from civilization cost up to $25billion .
There are better methods of using this sum of money collected from taxes from its people to solve the waste disposal problem .
The government should exploit the funds available to develop MSRs .
These reactors are capable of consuming existing nuclear waste in the production of electricity , and prevent nuclear waste from accumulating .
Accelerated development of MSRs will result in the US  successfully managing the nuclear waste problem and revolutionizing an entire new level of carbon-free energy that can last longer than just centuries .
Furthermore , MSRs are up to 300 times more fuel-efficient compared to  LWRs .
They actually provide a bit more than what most scientists expect from fusion as an MSR can be built in small 1 .2MW electric units .
A 7 .4 MW thermal reactor was built in the 1960s and operated for years ,  .
MSRs are also much more efficient than  helium-cooled Very High Temperature Reactors (VHTRs) operating at similar conditions , in terms of electricity conversion .
Apart from that , MSRs are capable of operating for several centuries with only uranium that is already present .
Thus , the claim of nuclear fuel mining using up fossil fuels and adding to the greenhouse effect is unjustified .
However , the high temperature and corrosive operating conditions of the MSR require materials that exceed the limitations of current nuclear reactors .
Materials used for these reactors require high dimensional stability and most importantly corrosion-resistance , due to the molten salt of MSRs being corrosive itself .
Some materials that are suitable include nickel-base super alloys , silicon carbide , specific grades of graphite and refractory alloys , which are expensive in nature .
Hence , the cost of operation will not be as price-friendly as claimed .
Nevertheless , the introduction of MSRs still deserves strong support as they are likely to prove to be the best solution for improving energy efficiency and developing renewable energies .
Prompt development of MSRs is especially required for  countries such as China and India .
These countries are unable to satisfy their energy needs  solely  based on the current available avenues for energy sources  .
In conclusion , nuclear energy from fourth generation nuclear reactors is the best substitution for coal and natural gas .
Current emissions of carbon dioxide from automobiles and industries are furiously contributing to global warming .
We have already crossed the threshold of acceptable greenhouse gas emission levels .
Thus , preventing accelerated climate change beyond human control is of the greatest priority .
According to a study done by the Sunssex Energy Group based in the University of Sussex , the world's fossil fuel supply is currently dwindling and will be running out within the next 20 years (Walker , 2009) .
Moreover , the increasing emission of carbon dioxide from the burning of fossil fuel has been proven to be one of the factors  causing climate change (Jager , n .d .) .
These two major issues will lead to more people accepting the use of nuclear energy .
However , there remains doubt of the safety of nuclear reactors' operation and hence , the public might not fully  .
In order to make the nuclear reactor safer , cleaner and cheaper , the Generation IV International Forum (GIF) was established in mid 2001 to further research  the III generation nuclear reactors .
In late 2002 the GIF announced the six best reactor technologies which they believe  will become the future nuclear reactors .
The six technologies are the Very High Temperature Reactor (VTHR) , the Super-Critical Water-Cooled Reactor (SCWR) , the Molten Salt Reactor (MSR) , the Gas-Cooled Fast Reactor (GFR) , the Sodium-Cooled Fast Reactor (SFR) , and the Lead-Cooled Fast Reactor (LFR) .
The few paragraphs below explain why you should support further research and development on the super-critical water-cooled reactor (SCRW) in terms of safety , security and performance .
The first reason is the safety of the super-critical water-cooled reactor (SCWR) .
The SCWR is basically a pressurized water reactor operating above the thermodynamic critical point of water .
The working temperature is about 510-550K and the pressure is 25MPa (Butler , 2004) .
many people may feel shocked at the high operating temperature and pressure of this reactor .
They will argue that the pressure vessel wall cannot withstand such a high pressure and the high working temperature will melt the core .
They worry that the will replay the accidents on the Three Mile Island on March 28 , 1979 and at Chernobyl on April 26 , 1986 ("Nuclear Disasters and Accidents") .
However , with the growth of modern technology , the SCWR has been designed with the pressure-tube design .
The success of this design eliminates the need for a thick wall vessel and minimizes the risks of explosion of nuclear reactors .
Furthermore , in this design the separation of coolant and moderator is introduced as part of a passive heat-removal system to minimize the consequences of accident scenarios where active cooling may not be available .
Decay heat will be removed through radiation and convection from distributed channels during accidents , and consequently fuel melting in the core will be prevented .
As a result , this design improves the safety of the SCWR .
The second reason are  security issues such as nuclear proliferation .
Nuclear power leads to potential security risks , as plutonium has to be separated out during the reprocessing of nuclear energy production .
Plutonium is a key ingredient of advance nuclear weapons .
Although the U .S .A . has decided to dump all the plutonium waste at  Yucca Mountain , the government never mentioned the level of safety that can be achieved .
Consequently , the public claims that nuclear power wastes create a high degree of proliferation risks and until today there is no solution for it .
Among the six generation IV nuclear technologies , only the SCWR and the VHTR do not require waste recycling .
In the super-critical water-cooled reactor (SCWR) system the waste recycling is optional , which means that the SCWR can operate without having to depend on the contentious reprocessing of plutonium waste (Butler , 2004) .
In conclusion , this technology is free of  proliferation risks .
Last but not least is the performance of the super-critical water-cooled reactor (SCWR) .
The SCWR is considered one of the most promising future nuclear reactors because of its high thermal efficiency .
The use of the multi-pass flows system in the SCWR allows the production of process heat on demand and improves the thermal efficiency .
The thermal efficiency of SCWR is about 45% , which is much higher than the generation III light water reactor of 33% of thermal efficiency (Supercritical-Water-Cooled Reactor (SCWR)) .
Moreover , the distributed fuel channels in the SCWR allow the system to optimize fuel bundles into each channel .
Thus , an appropriate fuel cycle , flow , cladding temperature and independent power distribution can be achieved , which ensures the stable and predictable performance of the reactors .
In conclusion , the super-critical water-cooled reactor (SCWR) has been proven to be cleaner , safer and better performing as compared with the generation III nuclear reactors .
In addition , to reduce the emission of carbon dioxide from  burning fossil fuel , we should now support further research and development for the super-critical water reactor (SCWR) .
The super-critical water-cooled reactor is the best future reactor to generate sufficient energy to fulfill the energy needs of the public .
The atomic bombs dropped on the island of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in Japan during the Second World War and Chernobyl Nuclear plant that caused two explosions in 1986 have raised eyebrows about thevastating effects of nuclear energy .
The Chernobyl disaster , especially , exposefission reactionsons of people to radioactive chemicals and has been linked to many for them torms of cancer in Eastern Europe and Russia , as well as destroying animals and plants .
These two incidents have highlighted the power of nuclear energy , which has caused so much controversy as to whether it has become a liability or a source of energy to the world .
Electric utility reactors heat water to produce steam , which is then used to generate electric energy .
In the Chernobyl nuclearworld's electricity came from nuclear power , despite concerns about safety and radioactive waste management .
More than 150 of such plants were built .
In this way , nuclear power has become an independent source of energy to meet the rising demand of a country and an increasingly growindestroyedopulation .
These reactors can also be used to split hydrogen from water thermochemically .
Many countries around the world that largely dependisd fossil fuels for their energy needs are betting on hydrogen as the fuel of the future , using fuel cells to convert the gas into electricity for cars and homes .
Research has been done by many countries to improve on generations of reactors , some of which are in operation now .
The latest theoretical nuclear reactor design has been drafted up by a consortium of ten nations that are planning the nuclear reactors of tomorrow .
The Generation IV reactors are expected to be available by 2030 .
These new plants would operate at high temperatures to improve their efficiency and they would include simplified safety features that rely on non sophisticated back up systems to eradicate any problems .
One such reactor that we could see in the near future is the Very-High-Temperature-Reactor (VHTR) , which allows for more efficient conversion of heat to electricity , up to more than half of what could be produced previously .
The problem of high operating temperatures is eliminated by using coolants that use inert helium .
Another important point to consider is that nuclear energy is not a source of carbon dioxide emission , unlike the burning of fossil fuels .
With the "greenhouse" effect and the environmental issue of global warming , nuclear energy has come at the right time to slow down the melting of the ice caps and stop the rise of sea levels .
will includewill operateAs much as there are many positive reasons to use nuclear power , many people still have their doubts about this source of energy , mainly due to the fact that they remembered the infamous Chernobyl incident and the atomic bombs of World War Two .
Any accidents could lead to widespread damage and nobody can afford another radioactive leakage which could signal thenergy demandof nuclear energy .
Despite a generally high security standard , accidents will , nonetheless , happen .
Technically , it is almost impossible to build a plant which is totally safe .
There is always a chance of the plant failing .
The consequences of an accident would be absolutely devastating for both humans and nature , as in the past .
have been the caseIn addition , the power plants , together with the nuclear waste , could be targets for terrorist attacks .
No atomic energy plant in the world could withstand an attaremember to the infamous 9/11 .
Such a terrorist act would have catastrophic effects for the entire world .
Researchers have not solved the problem of radioactive waste produced by plants .
This waste from nuclear energy is extremely dangerous and can be used for the production of nuclear weapons .
The question now is: Is there a future for nuclear energy ?
The sustainability of nuclear power is questionable .
Nuclear energy uses Uranium as a form of energy , which is a scarcthe infamous 9/11 incidentetically , the supply of Uranium is expected to last for about 50-60 years .
We can say that nuclear energy is a non-renewable resource .
Nuclear power is not just an energy technology .
It is a unique blend of technical , economical , political and military interest .
In my opinion , there is no future for nuclear power because: chances of an accident which will release radioactive waste into the atmosphere is too high , there are still no safe solutions for the growing pile of deadly radioactive wastes , and reprocessing of this energy is dirty , dangerous and costly .
From the above discussion of the pros and cons of nuclear energy , it should be clear that nuclear power cannot be a solution to any problem that we are facing today .
In any case , it is a source of many other problems we could face in the near future .
Nowadays , the issue of nuclear power is being discussed frequently .
Nuclear power is a new energy source and has a lot of potential to be discovered and explored .
According to Declan Butler (2004) , nuclear power will not release the greenhouse gas carbon dioxide  , and global energy demands are predicted to double by 2050 .
Therefore , the nuclear option has now become a viable alternative to be considered .
However , there are many uncertainties regarding safety in the processes found in nuclear power plants .
Many accidents and tragedies have happened .
Studies (Recently in Nuclear Accidents Category , n .d .) state that in  2008 , there was a plutonium leak at the Austrian IAEA Facility and a uranium leak at France's Tricastin Nuclear Facility .
In  2009 , a fire broke out in Unit 1 of Ukraine's Rivne Nuclear Power Plant .
Although these accidents did not cause any people to die , it reminded people that  nuclear power is not as safe as people think .
One system-the Emergency Response Information System (ERIS)- has hence been developed to enhance the safety .
When  something happens , the system will function immediately to respond to the incident and therefore adequately save the nuclear workers and the general public .
However , in some aspects , this system still has many defects in terms of its feasibility and performance .
In carrying out the ERIS , many training courses and regular exercises are essential in order to make the nuclear worker able to deal with radiation leaks or other accidents .
These essential courses and exercises will cost a lot of money to carry out .
Besides the cost of training , money is also needed for introducing  advanced technology skillsas well as modern facilities and equipment into the nuclear power plants .
According to H .J .
Laue (1982) , a total number of 400 experts in more than 60 Member States as well as the advanced equipment cost US $10million .
This is a big amount and thus needs a consortium to raise .
However , there are many obstacles and contradictions in finding a big consortium to raise these funds .
Hence , the ERIS is not feasible enough to be carried out .
Furthermore , this Emergency Response Information System may not be reliable as well .
In order to provide quick and effective response to any nuclear emergency , this system requires a complete round-the-clock operation centre (Asculai & Collins , 1988) .
There must be a very close connection between each stage of the system's operations in order for the system to perform well when incidents happen .
Even at midnight , there must still be workers to monitor the system to ensure that the system is functional for 24 hours .
Furthermore , most of the public are ignorant and do not have much knowledge regarding this system .
They do not know what they should do if there is an accident .
In addition , the government should also have good coordination with the nuclear power plants regarding  safety issues and be very clear of what they should do with this system when an accident happens .
Although this system is efficient to protect people when incidents suddenly happen , nobody can give a 100% guarantee that this system will perform well as this system consists of many operation stages and requires a wide range of people to monitor it .
Thus , what is the most efficient design to enhance the safety of nuclear power plants ?
Many researchers are dealing with this issue now but no one can design  the most efficient system to enhance such safety .
Therefore , many proponents still support the Emergency Response Information System .
They claim that other than the problems of cost and performance , this system is still very important and functional when nuclear accidents happen .
This system is believed to be the best system so far to protect  nuclear workers and the public  rather than  other methods such as probabilistic safety assessment because the ERIS is more practical  protecting people directly after an incident happens .
To sum up , theEmergency Response Information System is a effective system that protectsthe public if an incident happens .
However , it has to be improved on and developed more in-depth to ensure its safety and enhance its feasibility .
The countries that are developing this nuclear power (only five countries-China , France , Russia , the United Kingdom and the United States) must make good use of the nuclear power as the energy source for people's daily use .
People will definitely not give up this nuclear power as it has a lot of potential as an energy source .
Therefore , developing a design to enhance the safety of nuclear power plants becomes a long-term project of the world .
Consequently , the nuclear power source will be extensively used by the public  .
Mankind has been exploring various methods of obtaining high energy output to sustain the usage of energy supply for our daily lives , resulting in the expansion of the energy supply industry .
In its early days , nuclear power was seen as offering a potentially limitless source of energy .
However , this promise is notably associated with the technologies , the costs and the precise features , which were not yet known with high precision then .
There are various reasons leading to why expansion of nuclear power has faced problems through the years , such as the public's objection (Butler , 2004) .
On top of that , there are other factors that contribute to why further research and development of nuclear power should not continue .
For instance , the Very-high- temperature reactors in the generation IV reactor concept (Butler , 2004) , which still requires further development in the aspect of safety at this stage , is rather  .
Firstly , all stages of the nuclear fuel cycle involve potentially harmful effects on the environment or mankind due to the high reactivity , the radiation emitted by nuclear wastes and the huge heat dissipation during nuclear processes .
Any flaws in the reactor design or processes could result in disastrous circumstances .
For instance , the Chernobyl accident is still causing deaths years after the accident , with victims mainly dying from cancer caused by exposure to radiation from the highly radioactive waste products released after the massive steam explosion , which occurred due to system flaws , and a second non-nuclear explosion (International Atomic Energy Agency , 2006) .
A 2005 report entitled The Chernobyl Forum , prepared by the International Atomic Energy Agency and World Health Organization , attributed 56 direct deaths and estimated over thousands more deaths among the most highly exposed people .
Another example is the Three Mile Island accident , which occurred due to a partial core meltdown in one of its units (Corey , n .d .) .
The above examples illustrate the potential dangers of nuclear power due to its explosive and radioactive characteristics .
The radiation coming from the nuclear wastes will not only produce  instant harm , but also a long-term effect on residents in affected areas , spreading across generations .
Keeping that in mind , the gas-cooled fast reactor , one of the generation IV reactor concepts , which requires research on irradiation- resistance material ,  .
Furthermore , the need for research on heat resistance material and security in the various generation IV reactor concepts is also worrying in terms of the possibilities of nuclear accidents in the future .
Secondly , arguments are that nuclear power is the best alternative because of the characteristic of not producing combustion-related air- pollutants that will lead to global warming , and because of the huge power supply it provides .
In addition , nuclear power uses uranium , which is a scarce resource that is only expected to last for another 30 to 60 years , as fuel .
Therefore , uranium will soon deplete and we will need to search for a new form of energy supply .
Thus , the huge amount of funds pumped into research and development on nuclear power , which will not support us for the long run , is not cost-effective .
Moreover , renewable energy technologies are now expanding faster than nuclear power technologies (Natural Resources Defense Council , 2007) .
They are equally environmentally-friendly and the depleting of resources for renewable energy is of no worry since the reactants are renewable .
Last of all , one of the most promising and nerve-racking reasons is the risk of development of nuclear weapons in an era of transnational terrorism (Gaukler , Barnett , & Rosinski , 2002) .
Terrorism is one of the most troubling global issues in recent years .
The improvement in technologies of the nuclear power would also provide  in handling nuclear weapons , so any leakage of details could result in development of nuclear weapons , which in the time of translational terrorism is almost inevitable .
It is also worrying that nuclear power plants may be the target of attack for terrorists due to their destructive nature .
Therefore , there will be a higher risk of  nuclear warfare .
The result will be disastrous .
In addition , the need for research on security in various reactor concepts of generation IV is also disturbing .
To summarize , nuclear power has various  that could affect the well-being of our environment and health that cannot be neglected despite its numerous benefits .
In addition , there are better alternatives such as  renewable energy that will be able to support our energy needs in the long run .
Hence , the funds pumped into the development of nuclear power should instead be used in the development of renewable resources that are more cost- effective .
In Singapore , according to the Ministry of Manpower (2009) ,  about a total  of 11000 cases of fatal and non fatal  occupational accidents occur in Singapore and 60 people die in these accidents per annum .
The accident of the Nicoll Highway Collapse in  2004 , which is one of the most catastrophic accidents in the construction sector of Singapore ,  took away 4 lives .
According to the accident investigation report (Ministry of Manpower , 2005) ,  found that the main cause of the collapse was due to under-designing of the retaining wall which could not handle the stress of holding up the tunnel .
Although some people might think that the effectiveness of psychology in preventing accidents from occurring is controversial ,  I believe that the use of psychology during the design process could have prevented this accident from occurring .
Many people think that not only the Nicoll Highway Collapse incident , but also most of the major occupational accidents were unexpected and  mainly caused by errors in human judgment .
They believe that psychology could have done nothing to prevent the accident from occurring (International Labour Organisation , 2000) .
However , in certain aspects , accidents can be prevented if psychology is introduced to  during the design stage .
According to the Heinrich Domino theory ,  an accident is caused by the chain reaction of a series of factors .
Moreover , "Heinrich proposes that the removal of unsafe acts and unsafe conditions will prevent accidents , as  his research it was found that these were the direct or immediate causes of most accidents" (Singapore Polytechnic , 2008) .
In the United Kingdom , the approach of understanding human behaviour was used in a practical set of Human Factors Analysis Tools (HFAT) which was developed by Mr Ronny Lardner & Mr Richard Scaife .
This made significant enhancement in the steel- making , chemical manufacture and construction industry in preventing accidents at work .
Besides that , with this Human Factors Analysis Tools (HFAT) , the originatorsalso won the Occupational Psychology Practitioner of the Year award in  2006 (Division of Occupational Psychology , United Kingdom , n .d .) .
Most people claim that accidents are unpreventable because a malfunction in a product is due to inadequate design that might cause accidents to occur , which is beyond the control of human capability (Wilpert , 2007) .
However , this kind of situation can be easily prevented for a well designed product , if psychology is put into consideration during the design process .
(Association of Independent Consultants , Inc , n .d .) .
These could assist the engineer to experience and discover the limitations and weaknesses of the design and improve on it .
They may take into consideration of the Fixed Guard design (Singapore Polytechnic , 2008) .
This design has no moving parts and prevents access to dangerous parts at all times by enclosing the hazardous operation completely .
The safety level is 100% even when there is a malfunction of the system during its operations , so no one will get injured  .
Moreover , many people in the construction industry think that accidents caused by natural disasters and unfavorable working environments is something beyond the human limit and  are unavoidable (Julian , 2007) .
For example , a landslide occurs on a work site due to soil erosion after a heavy downpour .
This may be out of our control , yet it is not 100% inevitable that accidents cannot be prevented from occurring in this kind of situation if approached with psychology during the design stage .
According to Michael F . O'Toole (2002) , assistant professor from Western Michigan University in industrial psychology , "Accident investigation is about finding fact not fault" .
It is used to identify the cause of the accident so that corrective measures can be taken to prevent such similar cases from occurring .
Carrying out research studies on related issues or consultation of expertise would help the engineers to understand and envisage the possible accidents that may occur due to the surrounding environment (Association of Independent Consultants , Inc , n .d .) .
Therefore , they may apply appropriate measures to eliminate or minimize the potential risk with respect to the unfavorable working environment , such as strengthening the slope with grout anchor tie back , and using an inclinometer to monitor the slope condition .
To summarize , the approach of applying psychology  throughout the design process of a project such as understanding  human behavior and knowledge on how accidents occur may help to prevent them from occurring .
Studies on related industrial accidents and accident investigations , the ability to envisage possible accidents that may occur , and working with a psychology practitioner could eventually help to minimize and prevent the occurrence of accidents due to errors in human judgment , malfunctioning of products , and working environment factors .
In conclusion , although accidents are unexpected , it is possible to minimize and preventthem from occurring  by using the psychology approach in design processes .
It has also been proven to be effective in accident prevention as the MOM has made an obligatory requirement that all work sites must employ a Work Site Safety and Health Officer before the commencement of a project (Singapore Polytechnic , 2008) .
According to a recent US poll , a significant 44 .7% of the respondents think that nuclear is somewhat dangerous or very dangerous .
And they are not wrong in thinking that , given However ,t the radioactive uranium used as fuel is inherently dangerous , being extremely lethal to human health and polluting to the environment .
To address the safety concerns of the public , this design envisioned many safeguard systems .
A NEA report stated that a 'three barrier pbringle' will be implemented , and there will be 'cladding at fuel levels; vessels and primary circuit' .
This means that the radioactslatedar fbecomel be well contained by three separate layers of shielding material , greatly reducing the chances of leakage .
Furthermore the report emphasized the employment of 2 separate and redundant heat removal systems .
One is a passive system that uses natural convection while the other is an active system that uses circulators to pass the gas through the reactor core .
The coolant will be helium , an inert gas that is much safer than the sodium liquid used in sodium-cooled fast reactors .
A major constraint of nuclear power is the tricky issue of waste disposal .
Nucleanuclear energy productions need to be stored in deep geological repositories for thousands of years .
Hence the treatment of nuclear waste will be a major public concern .
A key feature of the gas cooled fast reactor is that it is a fast neutron reactor that fully recycles actinides .
According to 'Nucthe designgas cooled fast reactorincludes published on Nature , '96An of spent fuels consist of uranium and plutonium' in other words more fuels can be generated if the wastes are to be reprocessed .
In the gas cooled fast reactor , radioactive byproducts are recycled and the waste eventually produced will only be a fraction of that produced by reactors with once through uranium fuel cycles .
In addition , as the design is a fast neutron reactor , it produces excess neutrons which can be used to transmute the nuclear waste to isotopes of shorter half-lives , reducing the toxicity of the waste .
This design also addresses a security concern of nuclear waste reprocessing .
Currently , in the logistics of reprocessing , nuclear wastes are transported to reprocesHence ,facilities which recovers the urisnd plutonium before sending them to another mixed oxide fuel (MOX) reactors to be burnt as fuels .
This involves frequent transportation of highly dangethe article , 'Nuclear Power's New Dawn' , over long instances .
This exposes a security risk as an accidentplutonium'; in other words ,dioactive materials or a hijack can send these ials into the hands of terrorists .
However a report by Hussein Khalil from the Argonne National Laboratories in USA envisioned 'an integrated , onsite spent fuel treatment and refabrication plant' .
This essentially obliterates the security risks involved in transporting radioactive wastes and allows security efforts to be focused on plantintotself .

This is achievable by running the reactor at 850 C , a temperature that is kept in check by the helium heat removal system .
