In the meantime , this is impossible but at the rate which environmental organizations are progressing , I envision the day where we have zero dependence on coal for energy and SCWR takes its place at full speed !
The soundtrack , My Heart Will Go On sung by Celine Dion , was the theme song for the Oscar winning mega blockbuster movie , Titanic .
The movie was based on a true story whereby the ship named Titanic collided  with an iceberg and sank on its maiden voyage .
Eventually , it became one the worst maritime accidents that occurred during peacetime .
Being the largest , most luxurious and technologically advanced liner of her time (FDS Development , n .d) , the Titanic clearly enjoyed the prestige .
However , her downfall was partly due to human error .
Since then , more attention had been given to the area of human psychology in relation to engineering design process .
In view of this , I believe that this is the appropriate direction we should adopt to prevent major accidents from happening .
Rather , we should focus on the psychology of engineers and scientists who invent and apply the technology to meet our worldly needs .
In the case of Titanic , the ship was equipped with high technology water compartment system that would shut special doors in the event of any emergency .
This led engineers to think that Titanic was the safest ship at that point of time .
The Titanic was equipped with only 20 lifeboats , so that bulky lifeboats would not take up precious deck space for the first class passengers .
There were 20 lifeboats having a total capacity of 1178 people which was only enough to hold half of the Titanic passengers (History On The Net , 2007) .
This illustrates the point that despite having improved technology , accidents can still happen due to over-confidence and reliance on technology .
Furthermore , the idea of the Titanic being "sinkable" supported the notion that people at that time were overly confident .
While we understand that technology can help to prevent accidents when applied appropriately , it ultimately falls to the management of people .
Therefore if the engineers of the Titanic were prudent in the engineering design process , they would have included a high margin of safety factor to anticipate possible failure during its construction  .
Needless to say , the fatalities of that collision would have been minimized .
Not surprisingly , many detractors suggest that the main reason why the Titanic sank was due to the fact that the terrain at which Titanic was sailing was poor .
During the night before the collision , the ocean was icy cold and was filled with icebergs .
This made navigation difficult .
There were more icebergs in the North Atlantic that year than it had been for fifty years (White Star Line , n .d) .
While it is true that we cannot control the climate to suit our needs , we can always suit the environment by taking a proactive stance in contingency planning .
By taking a proactive stance in planning , we can identify our main priority and set goals achieving it in view of a possible setback .
One of the reasons why the Titanic sank was  the fact that the safety was being compromised for aesthetics and convenience .
For instance , the telegraphers ignored warnings from other ships about the icebergs ahead .
Instead , they were so busy sending private messages for the passengers , so they did not think about those warnings that much (BBC , 2000) .
When the crew spotted an iceberg ahead , the ship was steering too fast and could not avoid it despite performing emergency procedures .
This showed that the telegrapher had a wrong mindset in the first place .
He gave priority for private messages over the safety of the ship .
This mindset was probably induced by the culture of the working environment of the Titanic .
As the Titanic was exclusive and luxurious , the culture of the staff working was to first please their occupants , then consider safety .
Such a mindset can also be seen even in today's service industry whereby "customer is always first" .
In addition , the Captain of the Titanic did not reduce the speed at which the ship was traveling in order to arrive at their destination earlier .
He had in fact been influenced to "speed up" not necessarily in order for the Titanic to set a crossing record , but to beat the Olympic's (Titanic's sister ship) crossing record (Titanic and Other White Star Line , n .d) .
These only go to show that the crew of the Titanic had set the wrong priorities .
Therefore , if we neglect the psychological aspect of any engineering application , we can be certain that more accidents will happen .
In the case of the Titanic , the accident could had been avoided if the Captain had adopted a 'safety first' culture in the workplace and had made contingency plans for any emergency .
In conclusion , we cannot deny  the fact that psychology had an impact on the way we process and manage technology .
So long as there is a human factor in the engineering process , the use of psychology is inevitable .
In fact as we rely more on technology , we place more responsibilities on the few individuals who manage it .
In addition , we need to pay more attention to the way we set our priorities .
When we set wrong priorities , we head in the wrong direction despite having the best technology available .
After all , technology only assists us in achieving our material goals but when it comes to psychology , it has no part to play .
The term sophistication has made quite an impact in the lives of people all over the globe .
Technical advancement and uplift in standards of living has resulted ultimately in the rapid consumption of natural resources .
So viewing the present situation in this ominous light , the ultimate solution we get to think of is to find new means to sustain the exploding population .
Electric power is as important to the people now as  food clothing and shelter are .
How do we meet the power needs of the growing world with this limited power sources we have ?
The solution is offered by the Generaton IV nuclear power plants .
The Generation IV concepts offer a promising solution to the power issue through their very high efficiency in conversion of thermal energy to electricity  compared to their Generation 3 counterparts .
They also offer security in the event of an onsite emergency which assures us of the non repeat of another Chernobyl incident and wins our support .
There are several Generation IV nuclear power plant concepts which can be incorporated .
What we must remember is that we do not have the luxury of time to sit and research each and every concept as time is critical .
Our resources are fast disappearing and  we have to take some radical steps now .
The safety features of SCWR are passive; they  do not need human instructions in case of an onsite emergency .
The main concept of the safety features is that when there is an emergency , depressurization of the plant takes place , i . e the pressure inside the plant decreases .
However , if there is a large break in the feed water lines , the heating of fuel will be rapid and this will result in an emergency .
Though the passive safety features will take over  ,the plant will be non operational .
The GFR has a similar passive safety feature .
It has a few elements added in it which shut down the system during an onsite emergency( Wilfred , University of Delft 2004) .Besides this , the plant is made up of materials which can withstand very high temperatures .
So there will not be any calamities possible .
And it also does not lead to problems of plutonium fuel as it serves as an incinerator which burns away the wastes .
( Wilfred , University of Delft 2004) .
Thus , on the whole , if we compare the two models on the basis of these three very important criteria , we find that very clearly the GFR  has an edge over that of the SCWR and hence it should be pursued for research and not SCWR .
The nuclear power models are chosen and approved by the IAEA (International Atomic Energy Agency) based on the aspects of their cost , security and performance .
Two popular models under debate are Gas Cooled Fast Reactor(GFR) and Super critical water reactor(SCWR) .
I prefer the GFR over SCWR for many reasons which we will discuss in this essay .
On the basis of performance the SCWR has a net thermal efficiency of 45% (Jacapo Buongiomo 2002) .
It is a simplified model of the light water reactor which is very efficient in providing electricity  .
It has both open and closed fuel cycle models which can be incorporated .
In addition to this , it can also be suited to provide hydrogen upon further modifications .
However , this thermal efficiency of SCWR is less  compared to the GFR .
A model evaluation was done by scientists Ning Dong , Yao Weida for the SCWR and it found the following problems  to which SCWR was susceptible: (i) loss of feedwater flow ,  , (ii) loss of feedwater heating and (iii) large break in the feedwater lines , which , if unmitigated , results in coolant stagnation in the core and rapid overheating ofthe fuel .
Thus as we see there seem to be many problems with it .
The GFR plant has a net thermal efficiency of 48% (Hussein Khalil , Kevan Weaver 2002) .
It uses helium as coolant which increases inertness .
And it uses closed fuel cycle , thus the used fuel can be reused  .
It can also be effectively used for manufacturing hydrogen as well as for actinide management .
Thus clearly GFR outshines SCWR in performance .
The cost of construction of SCWR plant is half a billion  .
(INEEL FY 03 ANNUAL BUDGET REPORT) Thus SCWR is regarded as a very cheap solution to the power crisis .
For this very low rate of construction and maintenance we get a good amount of electricity for a lot of people .
However , the point  I would like to make here is this .
Though the cost of installation of plant and maintenance might be less ,  the plant life is only 60 years .
In other words , every 60 years the plant has to once again be renewed .
This is a very expensive affair .
The core of the reactor has to be replaced every 34 years .
So when all factors are taken into consideration , it is an expensive reactor .
The cost of GFR plan is nearly a billion dollars (INEEL FY 03 ANNUAL BUDGET REPORT) .
However , though it might be higher than that of SCWR the plant life is longer .So we do not need to change the plant very often unlike the SCWR . .In addition to this it can produce hydrogen as well as manage actinides .
Thus the overall contribution to economy clearly justifies its cost .It is a healthy investment .
In recent years , there have been unremitting arguments on whether developing countries should proceed with building generation IV reactors .
For a developing country where the economy is rather unstable , people are facing poverty and high unemployment; thus ,  it is vital for the country to solve these problems before handling other issues like developing power reactors .
For example in Afghanistan , according to statistics , the unemployment rate is estimated to be as high as 40% in 2008 (CIA , 2009) .
Even though it is known that developing generation IV reactors will benefit the country significantly , we cannot neglect the destructive effects that come simultaneously .
Therefore , developing countries need to solve unemployment and poverty in rural areas first , before they provide huge funding to build generation IV reactors .
Opponents maintain that  developing power reactors would enable the public to benefit from low-priced electricity that can build more factories which will eventually help to create jobs for the people as well as alleviate poverty .
However , this claim only takes into consideration the operation cost in the long run and does not take into account  the high set up cost estimated in 2009 to be around 10 billion dollars for just one reactor (Travis , Johanna , & Emily , 2009) .
The maintenance cost , money required for storage of waste was investigated to be about 13 .
3 billion today (Nevada study , 2007) and money to conduct continuous research and development (R&D) is estimated around 1 .275 billion dollars (Nuclear Age Peace Foundation , 2009) .
This large sum of money would ultimately be the main reason that might lead to the termination of the development since developing countries with an unstable economy will find it too costly to provide such a huge fund in the long run (Reportlinker , 2009) .
This will then lead us back to our issue where poverty and unemployment remain unsolved and the huge sum that goes to developing the power reactor has also gone to waste .
Thus , developing countries should strengthen its economy by solving the problem for unemployment and poverty first before  developing  power reactors .
Apart from the above points , it is mentioned by the opponents that by developing power reactors , many job opportunities will be created for the people since they need a labour force  to run the plant .
However , it is important to know that the labour force that is required by plants is a highly skilled workforce (Michael , 2005) .
Examples of such positions are nuclear technicians , radiologic technicians , researchers , monitoring technicians and reactor operators .
These roles demand knowledge of physics , mathematics , chemistry , public safety and security .
In developing countries , there will not be sufficient skilledlabour to support the development since most of the people are not equipped with such skills (Travis et al . , 2009) .
In due course , developing countries will need to hire foreign talent to take up those positions .
In the end , the locals will still suffer from poverty and remain unemployed while foreign talent will have numerous jobs to choose from .
In addition , power reactor plants are dealing with very-high-temperature reactors; some  of the reactors like Gas-cooled fast reactors and Supercritical-water-cooled reactors even need high pressure to operate .
Furthermore , to prevent radioactive waste from being stolen for the creation of nuclear weapon , scientists are going to modify radioactive elements in such a way that they will be too hot for human beings to handle even with the use of gloves (Nature , 2004)  .
Under such conditions where the high temperature is not a suitable work environment , the plants must involve highly automated machineries in order for the operations to be carried out .
In order words , the plant only creates a handful of employment opportunities for the people given that the plant is functioning automatically .
Hence , by developing power reactors in developing countries , only limited jobs will be created for the local people .
In summary , if developing countries with unstable economy were to develop generation IV reactors , they would face difficulties in funding the enormous sum of money for set up and operation in the long run (Hore et al .
, 2008; Reportlinker , 2009) .
The development of nuclear generator IV requires much R&D and high  technology; thus ,  local workforce might not have enough talented labour to support the operation .
Moderately skilled and lowly skilled workers will still be unable to secure a job .
Moreover , with high technology generation IV reactors , plants are mostly computerized and automated and they require only a small labour force .
Therefore , by developing reactors it will not improve the unemployment and poverty situation in the country , hence it would be wiser to develop the country first .
Developing the country can provide funding to assist locals in setting up businesses and factories or encourage Multinational Corporation to set up plants in their country .
By doing so , many jobs will be created for the people .
This would be the most effective and direct method to resolve the unemployment issue .
After that , the poverty state will also improve gradually since the country's economy is boost up through time .
With a stronger work force and economy , the country will then be ready to support the developing of power reactors .
Nuclear power involves the energy generated from the splitting of atoms , also known as nuclear fission .
The reason why the public reject the idea of nuclear power could be due to the Chernobyl power plant meltdown , one of the most tragic nuclear-related disasters in human history .
The ramification of the Chernobyl incident is so severe to the extent that it reminds everyone of death when nuclear power is mentioned .
We cannot prevent the public from having their biased and negative perspective on nuclear power but we cannot deny the fact that the Chernobyl disaster is a result of poor management and design of the power plant (Case details: Chernobyl accident (n .d)) .
Although the public oppose nuclear power due to its dangerous drawbacks on the world and its environment , it is crucial to support and fund further research and development for Very High Temperature Reactors (VHTR) .
The public feel that nuclear proliferation is imminent and fear the danger of excessive nuclear waste .
In other words , every nuclear plant is like a potential nuclear bomb and terrorist attacks are inevitable .
However , such claims would be deemed invalid in the context of a VHTR .
Among the proposed Generation IV nuclear plants , VHTR is one of the few which does not reprocess the resultant nuclear waste .
Reprocessing involves the separation of uranium and weapon-grade plutonium from radioactive waste which sums up the fear of plutonium war .
Therefore , VHTR is proliferation-proof as it does not reprocess nuclear waste .
Furthermore , VHTR produces less radioactive waste compared to other proposed reactors .
Shropshire and Herring (2004) claim that the heavy metal radioactive waste produced in VHTR is significantly low with every unit of energy generated and this is due to the plant's high thermal efficiency and high fuel burn up .
It implies that the total plutonium generated is less per unit of energy produced .
Waste treatment plans are also in place to tackle the lingering problem of long-live radioactive waste .
For instance , in the liquid state treatment , the by-products are constantly evaporated to reduce its radioactivity (2004) .
As for the remaining nuclear waste , it is stored in an underground repository  where multilayers of anti-radiation materials are installed to shield them from the external environment .
It may be true that nuclear power , akin to fossil fuel , is a non-renewable resource .
Naturally , the public would argue that it is not worth the funding and time to develop something which does not offer a long term solution .
Although from a general point of view , it is possible to recycle nuclear fuel  it is not ideal as reprocessing is costly and generates the dreaded plutonium .
Langwith(2009) states that uranium in Canada can only last for 40 years .
The projected time span definitely does not appeal to what the public see as long term , however , it is shallow to predict the outcome to be the same as fossil fuel power plants .
Furthermore , Canada's participation in the Generation IV International Forum (GIF) to perform further research on nuclear power , particularly VHTR (Priority Area: Next Generation Nuclear Energy Technologies (n .d)) , shows that they do not share the public's myopic view on the potential of nuclear power .
In addition , VHTR offers an alternate clean fuel , hydrogen .
At 1100 degree Celsius , hydrogen production efficiency is at 50 percent compared to electrical generation efficiency at 56 percent VHTR (2002) .
There is much radioactive material on earth to run nuclear power for a long time just like how we operate coal power plants .
The difference is that it extends the time needed to find more sources of electricity , probably nuclear fusion .
Opponents may claim that nuclear power plants are incapable of making significant changes to the climate and will even appear as an environmental risk .
Nonetheless , VHTR are almost emission free as nuclear power contributes the biggest portion of the world's electricity from non-greenhouse gas emitting sources (n .d) .
Consequently , the alternate fuel source generated is also emission free .
30 percent of the world primary fuel use is to generate electricity and 17 percent of electricity uses nuclear power (2002) .
In other words , VHTR reduces the general demand for fossil fuels .
Robinson (1987) also mentioned that the amount of electricity generated by one ton of uranium is similar to that produced by 16 ,000 tons of coal or 80 ,000 barrels of oil .
The amount of waste produced by fossil fuel plants is significantly higher than that of VHTR .
that the dominant VHTR has a better plant efficiency which indirectly implies that it requires 20 percent fewer tunnels to store its waste .
Hence , the resultant land pollution caused by VHTR will be milder in contrast with that of coal power
The public opinions on nuclear power are inconclusive .
The advantages of VHTR clearly outweigh the disadvantages of nuclear power .
They directly negate the fears of nuclear proliferation due to its once-through uranium fuel cycle .
Moreover , it offers non-electrical fuel source , hydrogen , which prolongs the time needed to develop another source .
As for the environment aspect , VHTR is ultimately emission free and it causes milder land pollution compared to coal power plants .
Therefore , in my opinion , it is justified to support further research and development funding for VHTR .
Many people consider nuclear power industry is highly dangerous since the radioactive fuels can be very harmful environment and environment .
According to a survey conducted in Australia in 2009 on the public opinions of building nuclear power plants in Australia , there were 43 percsafe the public opposing the plan because of the safety and security issues with nuclear power plants .
(Munro & Strong , 2009) However , nuclear power reactors are much safer and securer than most of people can image even when the reactive temperature is very high .
Firstly , in VHTR , the fuel used is uranium dioxide in a TRISO configuration , where TRISO is the type of fuel that small amount of uranium dioxide is in the center and coated with four layers of three isotropic materials (Olander , 2009) .
The TRISO particles are either dispersed in a pebble for the pebble bed design or molded into opponentsal graphite blocks .
Such designs are able to slow down neutrons to control the nuclear chain reaction , thus the reactivity can be controlled in a reasonable range and explosions can be prevented .
Secondly , because helium is used as coolant of VHTR , unexpected reactions can be prevented .
One reason is that helium is an inert gas , which is hardly reacts with any material .
Additionally , exposing helium to radiation does not make it radioactive , unlike most other possible coolants , for example light water , therefore it is a safer choice of coolant .
Moreover , since the reactor can only operate under a high temperature , in case of destructions by terrorism or other outside forces , the system will cool down and automatically stop the reaction .
This function ensures VHTR is very safe under attacks .
Therefore , VHTR is a very safe and secure prototype of the generation IV reactor .
water; thereforereaction; thusOther than the safety issue , the efficiency as VHTR is also a concern for those who want to invest in the project .
A Molten salt reactor can burn 99% of initial fuel , while VHTR can burn 65% of its initial fuelopinionionless than that of a molten salt reactor .
However , VHTR is very efficient comparing with the conventional light-water reactor , which can only burn-up 5% of the initial amount (n .f .
2008) .
VHTR is not only able to produce electrical power but also produce hydrog via electroimagine of water at high temperature .
Besides generating energy , the energy generated from nuclear reaction can also be used in crude oil refining or metal production (Ogawa , & VonLensa , 2002 .) .
In this sense , VHTR is efficient in using of energy .
Comparing to a molten salt reactor , VHTR has a simpler design and this leads to another advantage which is its high feasibility .
One more factor that affects the funding of a project is the feasibility of the project in terms of techniques and cost .
VHTR seems to be the most feasible design in the IV generation reactor .
Firstly , similar prototypes such as HTR-10 have already been operated in China and Japan .
VHTR is juscomparedte of High-Temperature Reactor; therefore it is easier to bburn upsystem with the foundation of similar technology .
Secondly , there is no reprocessing in VHTR .
Although some people argue that this causes energy waste and produces radioactive waste , the lack of reprocessing reduces the cost of the power plant and makes it more affordable since the reprocessing is very expensive .
The elimination of reprocessing will notusee any probleComparedis due to the burning of fuel in VHTR is very sufficient thus the amount of waste is very little .
In addition , the radioactive waste can be stored underground .
Lastly , even though the initiation of a nuclear power plant requires about 1 billion US dollars , for the long term profit , this project is practicable .
This is because the need of electricity of humans and the relatively low maintaining fees for VHTR .
Thus , in terms of feasibility , the VHTR is a better choice for further development .
because of the needsufficient; thusefficientbecauseIn conclusion , VHTR should be chosen to proceed on for further research and development .
This is because of its relative high efficiency , high safety and practicability .
There are many researches undergoing in U .S . , China and Japan to improve the Very-High-Temperature Reactors .
Optimistically , by about 2020 , the first commercial VHTR would be in operation .
Generation IV nuclear reactorshave drawn many controversies since they were introduced in the Generation IV International Forum in 2000 .
This raises public concern , due to the previous nuclear accidents which happened at Three Mile Island and Chernobyl , in 1979 and 1986 separately .
(Nuclear Disasters and Accidents) In theory , Generation IV reactors are a set of theoretical reactors which are still being under research to replace Generation III reactors , which are in use for power generation currently .
In comparison with current nuclear plant technology , Generation IV nuclear technology brings us more benefits , according to the researchers .
To point out a few of them , the claimed benefits include minimised nuclear waste and improved safety .
(Generation IV reactor , para .
1) With this , we can reduce nuclear waste as it accumulates when we generate nuclear electricity .
In addition to that , the experts from laboratory also claimed that Generation IV reactors are able to consume nuclear waste to generate more electricity .
However , they are just theories with no solid evidence to support them .
To focus the research on Generation IV technology , we have narrowed down to two reactors , which are lead-cooled fast reactor and sodium cooled fast reactor .
According to the data I have collected , I think sodium-cooled reactor would be a better choice than lead-cooled fast reactor .
Fromsafety perspective , lead-cooled reactor has low likelihood of damage .
(Lead-Cooled Fast Reactor , Advantages and Challenges section) This is due to the characteristic of lead as a good heat transfer medium with high specific heat and thermal expansion coefficient .
Moreover , lead makes the operation reliable as it possesses good fuel compatibility and fission product retention .
This is a vital safety feature together with the ability of lead to retain released fission products that enables us to avoid offsite emergency .
On the other hand , the sodium-cooled reactor  strengthens its safety with long thermal response time and large margin to coolant boiling .
(Sodium-Cooled Fast Reactor , para .
1) Sodium-cooled reactor focuses its safety in its primary system and intermediate system which operate near atmospheric pressure .
Given the fact that the two reactors focus on different aspects of safety , where the latter focuses on system operation rather than coolant , it is difficult to gauge the effectiveness of their practice based on theories .
Thus , it is inconsistent to compare when we are talking about the safety issue .
However , lead has a tendency for material corrosion at high temperature .
(Lead-Cooled Fast Reactor , Advantages and Challenges section) Thus , sodium-cooled reactor is a better choice as it has less dependence on the coolant itself .
In terms of performance , lead-cooled reactor has high sustainability .
The mentioned reactor has high sustainability due to its coolant , lead which is a low moderating medium as well as a medium with low absorption cross section that enables a core with fast neutron spectrum even with a large coolant fraction .
(Lead-Cooled Fast Reactor , Advantages and Challenges section) To compare the performance of the two clearly , we will have a look at the burn-up performance .
For sodium fast reactor , it has a tight pin structure , which in turn offers better neutron economy than lead-cooled reactor .
(Tucek K . , & Carlsson J . , & Wider H . , Neutronic and Burn-up Performance section , para .
2) As a result , when both reactors operate to acquire criticality , the average plutonium fraction in the lead-cooled reactor core is slightly higher than sodium-cooled reactor .
This can clearly show the better performer .
After safety and performance issue , production cost of the reactor plays an equally important role in deciding which reactor to put in use .
From the researchers of lead-cooled reactor , we can clearly see the economic side of the reactor .
As  claimed , the life cycle cost of the lead-cooled reactor  is relatively cheaper than any other reactor .
This claim is based on the fact that lead is not reactive with water and air .
As an additional point , lead is inexpensive , in theory .
As a matter of fact , sodium ranked as the sixth most abundant material on earth .
(Microsoft Encarta Online Encyclopedia , 2009) .
If we take in the consideration of the supply and demand theories , lead will be more costly as the demand soars , just like what happened to  crude oil .
In contrast , sodium which is more abundant will experience less effect on its price when the demand soars .
Furthermore , sodium-cooled reactor benefits from the research which was done  earlier .
So there can be a big difference in research cost when compared to lead-cooled reactor .
Moreover , the earliest delivery of the sodium-cooled reactor  is 10 years earlier than the lead-cooled reactor .
(Butler , D .  ,2004) .
Thus , the sodium-cooled reactor is better from economic aspect .
From the evidence I have collected , I have come to the  conclusion that the sodium-cooled reactor  is a better choice than the lead-cooled reactor as it outperforms the latter in three aspects , which are safety , performance and cost .
Have you ever imagined that communication is possible with a virtual character from your television screen ?
Microsoft is now spearing the project Natal , which  involves a controller-free gaming interface , Microsoft Xbox (2009) .
The current game consoles require users to use controllers as their interface to the virtual world .
User's expressions and desires are somewhat restricted by the buttons on the controller .
Thus , the enjoyment factor is somehow limited by the controller .
If project Natal succeeds , gamers will be able to fully indulge in their will and emotions and send this information via the motion detector and video camera into the game console .
This is a concept that is still in research and has yet to be be seen in the market .
A similar product , Wii , is currently in the market .
Although it is less tech-savvy than Natal ,  the safety issues it faces might be quite similar in nature .
Let us evaluate some of the safety issues below .
As playing a game with Natal will seem so real , we could expect more serious injuries occurring compared to injuries resulting from playing Wii .
Some gamers involved in a combat with a virtual opponent might accidentally throw his punches into the television screen , resulting in his fist being trapped within .
This injury is more serious than one arising from playing Wii .
The designers could make it safer by adding a barrier between the screen and the player .
The player could also be demanded by the system to wear safety boxing gloves , and limb guards .
However , some game activists might argue that it results in Natal losing its true entertainment value that it is first set to achieve .
Wearing such cumbersome equipment makes playing games using Natal a turn off .
In addition , it will add a substantial amount of cost to the already expensive-to-manufacture console , as the equipment might have to scan for motion further a distance away due to its exaggerated setup .
As reprted by Oli Welsh (2009) ,  it is "quite expensive to begin with ."
Hence , this idea of improving safety might not be feasible as it is going to be costly and its entertainment value will be affected .
Natal gamers might also suffer similar cases of "Nintendonitis" , muscle injuries owing to excessive playing hours  spent on Sony's Nintendo Wii(Thaindian News , 2009) .
Gamers might have to jump , kick , dance , or perform some repetitive movement during the course of the game .
Injuries as stated above might arise when their muscles gets overused .
Furthermore , the player might be prone to more injuries , such as falling and twisting his ankle , when he starts to feel lethargic .
To enhance safety , Natal could use its motion detection system to analyse whether the movement of the player is alright or he should take a rest , and then send out the respective warning to the player .
This could also help to help gamers who are glued to the game to realise that they have played too much .
It has happened before that gamers die after several hours of continuous gaming .
There are reports showing teenagers' death from  stroke after hours of continuous gaming .
One such example is elaborated in a report by Pravda .R (2009) , where a teenager in the Russian city of Ekaterinburg died after 12 hours of playing computer games .
Thus by using such gizmo , such occurrence of death could be reduced .
We can conclude that Natal is actually a double-edged sword .
It may allow us to have reality in the virtual paradise , increasing our degree of satisfaction when we can fully indulge in the playing of our favourite games , but when we get too carried away , it might cause injuries or death .
Safety can be slightly improved through software tweaking , advising the user to take a rest or stop the activity when he seems unfit by the analysis of the console .
However , large scale setup of barriers and tuxedos lookalike safety suit might not be feasible as they increase the cost significantly and limit its actual functionality .
Therefore the bottom line is safety only can be slightly enhanced by an improved design and itt depends more on the self discipline of the gamers .
Perhaps safety can be enhanced by making it mandatory for gamers to attend a safety course .
Nuclear power is not a new technology to the human race .
It has been around since the 1960s , but it is not the main choice for producing energy because society has rejected it for its low security and high cost .
Although public opposition still exists , with the new generation IV reactors , public support for further research and development of higher security and lower cost plants is increasing .
Some upcoming plants are the lead-cooled fast reactor for example , which produces both electricity and hydrogen as its products .
Opponents of nuclear power claim that the meltdown of the plant is one major reason why it should not exist .
Their concern would be the safety of the public in case of a nuclear meltdown .
This is an issue especially for small countries like Singapore , which stretches about 40 km from east to west , as international safety standards require a 30km buffer zone around the plant (Lee , 2004) .
However , this does not present a very good argument as looking at statistics over the years , the number of people affected by past major nuclear disasters , only number about an estimated 600 ,000 people (Louvat , 2006) .
Compared to an estimate of 1 .2 million deaths yearly due to traffic accidents (World Health Organization , 2007) , the nuclear casualties are relatively minor .
Besides this , with technological advancement , nuclear plants now enforce multiple fail-safe systems coupled with simplistic designs so fewer things could go wrong (Butler , 2004) .
Hence , with a more efficient safety system , there is no need to be afraid of disasters from happening .
Oppositions also claim that there is an ever present threat of terrorism .
For example , terrorists could steal nuclear material out of nuclear plants as easily as in the case when a thief broke into a shipyard in Russia and stole a container of nuclear submarine fuel (Digges , 2002) .
With this nuclear material , terrorists can create what are known as "Dirty" bombs , and threaten the public .
However , this argument disregards the fact that terrorism will be around regardless of whether nuclear plants are built or not .
Even without nuclear materials , terrorists have enough technology and materials to create their own "Dirty" bombs .
Also , this emphasizes the need for a better security system and therefore supports the fact that more funds should be used for this development .
With multiple security features to prevent thefts ,  there is no need to be afraid of radioactive materials being stolen .
Terrorists can only take advantage of our complacency , as in the case of the September 11 attacks .
With a well implemented security system , terrorists have no chance of infiltrating the plant .
The final argument that opponents claim is that the cost to society is very huge .
Building one nuclear plant would cost around US $ 2 .6 billion (Capps , 2005) .
This high cost would be a heavy burden on society and might affect the budgeting for other sectors like the health care system as well .
However , this is a short term view of the situation .
Uranium has more than 10 ,000 times the energy potential than fossil fuels and thus it is cheaper to use uranium for the production of energy (Magnumuranium , n .d .) .
In the long run , the high start up cost is covered by the savings made from the reduced cost of energy .
Many countries that depend on oil are also placing hopes on hydrogen as the new generation fuel for cars and perhaps home use (Butler , 2004) .
With hydrogen produced as the secondary product for the lead-cooled fast reactor , one can only expect energy prices to drop further as there is now an abundance of energy sources .
Hence , we would save more than what we would have initially spent on the building of the nuclear plant over time .
Looking at all the arguments that opponents have made against nuclear power , it can be seen that most are trivial and short termed .
With better technology , one can only expect the research and development to increase in cost .
In the long term view , society will benefit from the research and development of nuclear power .
The advancement in technology will allow nuclear energy to be harnessed with increased safety and efficiently .
Also , more jobs would be created which in turn would aid the country's economy .
Terrorism , safety or high costs are the factors we should base our research on and not be the reasons why we should not further develop nuclear power .
So in my opinion , funds should be injected into further research and development of nuclear power , to create a new generation of cleaner , safer and cheaper power to solve the looming energy crisis .
The world today depends heavily on fossil fuel to generate energy .
However , the burning of fossil fuels produces greenhouse gases which contribute to the effect of global warming .
In addition , experts have estimated that the remaining fuel reserve can only last a maximum of another 120 years (McLamb , 2008) .
With energy demand worldwide projected to increase by 44% in 2030 (International , 2009) and the worsening effect of global warming , researchers have proposed the concept of nuclear power .
Despite the benefits promised by Generation IV nuclear reactors , it still requires much effort to convince the public to accept this technology .
This is partly due to the negative memories from the 1986 reactor core explosion at Chernobyl in Ukraine , which resulted in the instant death of 31 people and radioactive debris spewed across Europe (Bulter , 2004) .
Yet , further research and development funding for the Generation IV nuclear prototypes , in particular the very-high-temperature reactor (VHTR) which is safer and can output greater electricity , should be supported .
Opponents of nuclear energy argued that nuclear power plants increase the health risk of workers and residents living in the vicinity of the reactor .
The long-term effects , they claimed , include potential for increased risk in cancer .
However , a survey conducted by the National Cancer Institute in the United States revealed no strong relationship between nuclear power and the risk of cancer (Excess , 1996) .
While there have been occurrences of leaks and safety incidents , including several in Japan , none of them resulted in severe death tolls (Critical , 2009) .
Similar to the Chernobyl and Three Mile Island accident , most nuclear accidents are consequences of human errors .
In modern nuclear reactors , passive safety systems which seek to eliminate the possibility of human errors have been installed .
This is a feature that will activate the safety measures by laws of physics in the event of an emergency , even without the aid of electronics and operators (Life , 2008) .
With VHTR , it should be even safer as helium gas , which will not react with other substances even at high temperature , is used as the coolant .
Hence , safety should not be an issue with modern nuclear technology .
Furthermore , economic viability and stability of nuclear power generation is challenged by the adversary .
They maintained that compared to coal or oil generators , building and operating nuclear facilities are more expensive and worried that the cost might be passed down to consumers eventually .
The construction and operation cost might be high , but this is so in order not to compromise the quality and safety of the plants .
With countries planning to impose carbon taxes on carbon dioxide emissions , producing electricity from coal or oil combustion might not remain cheap forever .
The depletion of oil supply and increasing difficulty in finding new oil reserves will also further increase the cost of electricity generated from coal or oil .
In contrast , nuclear energy might prove to be more reliable as uranium , the raw material for nuclear fuel , can be supplied by politically stable countries like Australia (Critical , 2009) and can last for more than 2500 years when used with more efficient reactors (Nuclear , n .d .) .
Indeed , experts have concluded that the nuclear energy will be competitive enough when the price of oil rises above USS60 per barrel (Limits , 2008) .
Finally , an argument advanced by anti-nuclear advocates is that although nuclear reaction does not produce greenhouse gases , harmful radioactive waste that must be stored for as long as a thousand years are generated instead .
Despite that , proponents argue that with proper storage and appropriate protection measures , the nuclear waste should not pose any health risk to the public .
In addition , most nuclear wastes are only hazardous for a few tens of years .
High-level waste , the most dangerous of all nuclear waste , is secured tightly in glass or ceramic before being isolated in storage facilities .
The structure of the glass and ceramic is so rigid that the dispersion of radioactive waste by terrorist will be difficult (Radioactive , 2009) .
The fact that there is no solution  for disposal of nuclear waste also suggests that there is a need to continue funding further research in nuclear technologies .
In conclusion , it is undeniable that nuclear power is costly .
However , it might be economically viable with the cost of fossil fuel expected to increase .
The safety concerns of nuclear plants are also addressed in the design of new nuclear reactors .
The radioactive wastes produced might not necessarily incur health hazard if they are properly stored .
Therefore , nuclear power is a trustworthy technology whose further research and development funding should be supported .
As technology continues to advance at an ever increasing rate , energy is also being consumed at a rapid pace .
Oil is still the main source of energy that drives the economy despite its ill effects on the environment .
Furthermore , it is projected to be depleted in fifty years' time .
Therefore , the global issue of today has to do with clean and sustainable energy .
The six Generation IV nuclear reactors that are currently being researched under the supervision of the Generation IV International Forum (GIF) are the answers to this very problem .
As of now , the Lead-Cooled Fast Reactor (LFR) and the Sodium-Cooled Fast Reactor (SFR) appear very promising and will likely be the main choice of nuclear power plant in the near future .
However , further comparison of both the reactors based on cost , performance and safety actually revealed (LFR) as the better option .
Advocates for the (SFR) often claim that the cost of running the (SFR) is low due to the fact that it uses hybrid loop-pool design that allows for use of a smaller Intermediate Heat Exchanger .
This will reduce the cost of building it (Zhao , 2009) .
1 However , the savings only amount to  about 10-15% of the final cost  of construction .
Instead , (LFR) can ultimately have the lowest cost among all  kinds of reactor because intermediate coolant loop is redundant for it .
Besides that , low refueling cycles of up to 15 years can bring down the total cost of constructing and running the (LFR) (Tucek , 2005) .2 Builders of the nuclear power plant should not just focus on the one-time cost of construction; rather , they should be looking at the long term running cost of the plant .
Therefore , Lead-Cooled Fast Reactor is clearly the better candidate here .
Regarding performance aspect of the reactors , studies often argued that SFR with multiple reheat and inter-cooling can allow the operating temperature to reach  650 degree Celsius while having thermal efficiencies of between 39% and 47% (Peterson , 2008) .3 However , as a result of the higher operating temperature  of (LFR) , it is definitely able to convert electricity more efficiently as compared to the former (Butler , 2004) .4
Furthermore , (LFR) produces hydrogen as part of its processes which (SFR) does not .
If fact hydrogen is also an alternate form of clean and efficient energy .
Ultimately , if we are talking about performance based on the total power output of the plant , (LFR) definitely has an edge over (SFR) , which operates at lower temperature and does not produce hydrogen as part of its process .
Safety plays an important role in deciding whether a reactor will be chosen over of its rival .
(SFR) in this sense has vast amount of operation experience under its belt .
In fact , Sodium as a coolant in a nuclear reactor has actually been around for quite some time .
This is the reason why many believe that (SFR) should be considerably safe and measures must have been in place to prevent any accident .
However , in terms of chemical property , sodium itself is  very reactive and any leakage during an accident will put the plant operators at risk .
Lead on the other hand has a lower burn-up (Tucek , 2005) .
In the event of an accident , the damage to the whole plant will be considerably lesser .
Furthermore , lead's superior neutronic properties and its small coolant temperature reactivity coefficient means that it could be easily controlled when there is an accident (Hejzlar , 2009) .5 For example , in the event of an accident , the natural circulation in (LFR) is enough to take away the nominal power of the system .
However in the case for (SFR) , the lack of natural circulation means that the reactivity of the coolant will increase , leading to a possible meltdown of the reactor (Tucek , 2005) .
In conclusion , based on the three most important considerations of a Generation IV reactor , it is clear that Lead-Cooled Fast Reactor is far  superior to the Sodium-Cooled Fast Reactor .
Despite the fact that (SFR) is slated to be delivered earliest by the year 2015 , more research needs to be done to proof that (SFR) is indeed better than (LFR) .
However , it would be more logical to channel more resources to the research of (LFR) so that it could be delivered earlier .
In addition , the production of hydrogen as a by-product is indeed very attractive for tomorrow's energy market .
The original lead-bismuth proposed for use in the (LFR) will also be replaced by lead , further decreasing the cost of the coolant by 10 times (Tucek , 2005) .
Therefore , Lead-Cooled Fast reactor is the obvious choice .
Global warming and energy shortage are two of the most discussed topics nowadays .
We are earnestly looking for solutions to these problems , and nuclear energy , has been proposed as a solution to solve these two problems at once .
The production of nuclear energy does not have carbon dioxide as a by-product; thus  it can reduce the effect of global warming , which is the reason for many other problems , like rising of sea levels .
Nuclear energy can also satisfy the increasing demand of energy , thus solving the problem of energy shortage .
However , choosing nuclear energy as an alternative here has many drawbacks in the areas of cleanliness , safety and cost , this can also be reflected in the very-high-temperature reactors (VHTR) .
Hence , I do not support the building of new nuclear plants and use of nuclear energy .
Some people argue that nuclear energy should be used as it is a cleaner source of energy compared to coal and fossil fuels .
It is true to some extent as no carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases are produced during the production of energy through nuclear power .
Nevertheless , we should not neglect the unique wastes which can be produced by nuclear power plants alone during its energy production process .
This refers to nuclear wastes .
The unique thing about nuclear wastes is that it is radioactive , like naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) , which is not only radioactive itself , but will also produce highly dangerous radioactive radon gas .
(What is nuclear waste , n .d .) It is very hard to recycle or dispose of those wastes due to their unique nature , like the wastes produced by VHTR .
The radioactive wastes will affect the health of man-kind , animals and plants when they are exposed to it .
The consequences are hazardous .
Even if it is buried underground , it will take hundreds of years for its effect to go off due to its long half-life .
The land used by nuclear power plants cannot be used for other purposes after the plants are decommissioned , as excessive radioactivity is present in the area .
There have been suggestions to solve this problem by using helium , which is not radioactive , and abundant helium can be found on the moon .
However , there are a few things we should address: the practicality  of mining on the moon and the cost of mining on the moon .
There is no doubt that it is extremely expensive to fly to the moon and do the mining there .
At the same time , the technology to dig on the moon , and even use helium as a fuel is still not available yet .
Thus , nuclear energy is not a good alternative .
There are also some other people who argue that nuclear energy is safer .
However , looking at the incident of partial reactor meltdown in 1979 , which took place at Three Mile Island , Pennsylvania , and the notorious nuclear accident at Chernobyl in Ukraine in 1986(Butler ,2004) , people may rethink  the statements they have made .
The result of Chernobyl accident is disastrous as the radioactive debris spread across Europe and affected many people in different countries .
Some infected people later developed all kinds of diseases , and some new born children are deformed as well .
Generally , they die at a very young age .
Nuclear power plants also pose safety problems as they are always targeted by terrorists .
( Carl B . and Mark H .  ,2005) .
Some people argue that the deaths per year in nuclear plants are much fewer than that in coal mines .
Nevertheless , once a main accident in nuclear plants occurs , the impact will be enormous , long term and wide spread  , while the impact of a coal mine accident is immediate , which takes place in limited areas only .
Hence , nuclear energy should not be accepted .
One more argument for nuclear energy is that it is cheap .
However , the nuclear power plants are all operating at low temperatures now , rendering them inefficient , due to limitations of technologies .
The cost advantage of nuclear energy is not so obvious here .
However , if we take into account  the set up cost of the nuclear plants , which are more high-tech than coal plants , they are definitely much more expensive .
The equally expensive maintenance cost covered will in the end together contribute to the average cost of producing nuclear energy , which is now much higher than that of coal and other sources .
Optimists say that the cost will be greatly reduced when generation IV reactors are developed as they will work with much higher efficiency .
Nevertheless , the technology required is not readily attainable and it will take a long time to be realised .
Thus , nuclear energy should not be accepted .
In conclusion , nuclear energy may have some seeming advantages; however , the problems associated with it are not negligible , specifically the high cost , radioactive wastes and the safety concerns .
Therefore , nuclear energy may not be a desirable  alternative .
We should put more of our focus on better energy sources like solar power .
Many accidents happened over the past decades , some related to design flaws while others to human errors .
Reasons for human errors range from emotional wellbeing , to the inability in handling the pre-accident situation (Charles , 1999) .
These accidents may have been prevented should psychology be encompassed into the design process .
The Chernobyl nuclear accident in 1986 illustrates this notion .
On the 25th of April 1986 , reactor 4 was scheduled for a shut down , and an experiment was planned to test a safety feature during this process .
delayed the test past midnight resulting in it being conducted by a less proficient night team .
Before the test , an unexpected drop in power resulted in operators retracting control rods in an attempt to restore power .
The reactor however , appeared stable after the retraction although it displayed abnormal readings .
The operators ignored this abnormality and proceeded with the test .
Subsequently two explosions occurred resulting in massive losses (CHERNOBYL ACCIDENT , 2009) .
Supporters related the accident to a lack of understanding in human psychology during the design phase (Reason , 1988) .
The test was approved only by the director of the plant , without the coordination of the reactor's chief designer or scientific manager (Nuclear Energy , 2009) .
Opponents claimed that approval was appropriate as the reactor was muffled at the start of the experiment and should not have devastating effects on its safety (Reason , 1988) .
Proponents however , argued that the plant director had insufficient specialised knowledge .
The use of psychology would enable designers to acknowledge that operators may encounter faults beyond their abilities and thus gear the design towards user friendliness .
Moreover , a psychologist should be able to relate a high competency requirement to the test and thus limit its handling to upper management .
In this manner , there is a high chance that the accident would not have occurred since the most qualified personnel would have been managing the test .
In addition , these reactors require highly skilled professionals (Reason , 1988) .
Opponents were firm that should the test be conducted by the more proficient day team , the accident was unlikely to occur (CHERNOBYL ACCIDENT , 2009) .
On the contrary , proponents refute this , stating that psychology encompasses the understanding of human reaction during panic stages (Wilpert , 2007) .
The design of the reactor could thus include simple idiot-proof automated safety mechanisms without relying on operators' competency .
This way , the operators would not have retracted the control rods during the pre test stage since the system would have been automated .
Therefore , the accident may not have occurred .
Opponents countered the use of psychology as they felt it stifles creativity in the design process (Wilpert , 2007) .
They believed that feedback may end up counterproductive and deter engineers from verbalizing their creations in fear of evaluation .
Moreover , they stood firm that the psychologist' lack of relevant knowledge may divert the focus of engineers and lead them away from designing a relevant product .
Proponents agreed to the possibility of limiting creativity should psychology be used in the entire design process .
As such , they suggest the intermittent intervention of psychology or simply the introduction of psychology only after the main design outline is formed (Wilpert , 2007) .
This way , the main focus of the product would not be altered and the critical design phases could be assessed through the use of simulation or operators .
This would possibly uproot errors during the entire design sequence thereby preventing the Chernobyl accident .
A Germany's Inter-City Express (ICE) train derailed and slammed into an overpass , killed 101 people and injured 200 people in June of 1998 , (Castellano , 2007) .
The causes of the accident were traced back to a damaged wheel that disintegrated just before the train passed over a switch track .
Upon further investigation , people discovered the evidence of poor wheel design , poor bridge construction , insufficient failure detection system , ineffective emergency procedures and insufficient design verification testing .
As a result , safety improvements and major engineering changes were implemented in order to prevent such disaster from happening again , which include the studies of psychology in design process .
Hence , the use of psychology in design process could have prevented the accident .
First of all , the use of psychology in the design process could have prevented the accident by revealing the need of adding several failure detection systems on the train .
According to the research that has been done by the German national railway company , Deutsche Bahn (1998) , the ICE train did not have a system installed to detect wheel failure and bring the train to an emergency stop .
According to Wilpert (2007) ,  inherent safety which links the design process to safety concerns must be taken into account .
However , in this situation , the engineers did not identify the inherently safer options (as cited in Wilpert , 2007) which led to a lack of failure detection systems that were installed in the train .
One example that highlighted this situation is the bullet trains from Japan .
The Japanese bullet trains are equipped with a detection system that can alert the train operator about wheel deformation and failure during the operation so that the operator may manually activate the emergency brake .
If the train had been installed with this system , the accident might not have happened .
Secondly , the use of psychology in the design process could have prevented the accident through activating the emergency brake despite the company's policy that did not allow the train manager to do so .
During the journey on the train , a large piece of metal came up through the floor and was witnessed by a passenger .
The passenger tried to warn the crew but was refused by the train manager due to the reason that he needed to investigate the problem  himself first .
As a result , valuable time was lost and the accident happened .
In this situation , the problem of psychopathology of design was revealed .
According to Wilpert (2007) ,  the designer 's and the user's conceptual model of a system or a device must be matched in order to reduce the problems that might occur during the time of using it , in this case , the train .
If the company policy was made with reference to a common sense that was agreed by everyone , such as , the train services in Singapore and the United Kingdom that made the control of emergency brakes available to the travelling passengers , the chain of failure would have been broken .
It is unlikely that the subsequent events could have occurred had the train been stopped immediately .
The third and most important thing to use psychology in the design process in this accident is that , it could have revealed the poor design of the wheel that caused the accident .
The ICE trains were equipped with single-cast wheels; after the accident , the engineers realized that the design of the wheels could make the metal to fatigue and cause out-of-round conditions that vibrate at cruising speeds .
According to Norman (as cited in Wilpert , 2007) , the appropriate system image must be ensured by the designer and this is one of the problems of psychopathology of design .
According to the research by Deutsche Bahn (1988) , the design of the wheels that were used did not reveal the actual durability and reliability of the wheels .
Hacker (as cited in Wilpert , 2007) points out that the quality of co-operative performance depends on the nature of the task at hand .
He says that a design task cannot be solved individually since each person has his own limitation in knowledge .
In this situation , if there were more designers involved in the design of the wheels , the poor design of the wheels could have been spotted and the accident would not have happened .
To sum up , with the use of psychology in the design process , the problems such as lack of failure detection systems that were installed in the train , company's policy that did not allow the train manager to stop the train , and the poor design of the train wheels would not have occurred .
To conclude , the train accident that happened  in Germany could have been prevented with the use of psychology in the design process .
A major accident does not usually happen with merely one error and the accumulation of all the errors will be catastrophic .
For instance the Nicoll Highway incident which occurred on Tuesday 20 April 2004 is the result of this which in turn caused four deaths .
The collapse was due to the retaining wall not being able  to handle the stress of supporting the tunnel and it gave way (Andrew , 2005) .
Hence , the opposing party argues that this failure is largely due to the technical aspect rather than the human errors .
Nevertheless , there are substantial points to suggest that psychology  can prevent the accident from happening if it has been implemented in the design stage .
As stated , the opponents claim that the collapse was due to the design of the structure .
The design of the structure itself was not well-built and the use of the weaker materials further exacerbated the failure (IES , 2005) .
Moreover , the opponents insist that the design was in fact approved by the Land Transportation Authority (LTA) .
Though the design was approved , the blueprint was in fact designed by engineers .
According to Wilpert .B (2007) , engineers do make design mistakes and this is known as an erroneous individual action .
The Nicolle Highway incident clearly illustrates this action when the contractor's engineers of Nishimatsu-Lum Chang (NLC) use the inappropriate soil simulation model for the design calculations (Andrew , 2005) .
As a result , the structure failed the safety criteria .
In addition , the use of the weak materials is due to the wrong mindset of the NLC wanting to earn more profits by cutting input materials cost , which is seriously a wrong attitude and perception .
Besides , the problem of psychopathology of design also arises when the NLC's engineers overestimated the basic technical ability of the LTA's personnel (Wilpert .B , 2007) .
Therefore , the lack in engineering knowledge of the LTA's personnel resulted in the approval of the blueprint which in turn resulted in the collapse .
Nonetheless , the supporters still argue another fact about the structure being used merely for a short period of time .
Thus there is no strict law imposed by the government about how a temporary structure should be built .
Furthermore , the supporters insist that the higher management within LTA and NLC had stringent control of the design phase despite the fact that the structure was used temporarily .
The wrong attitude about temporary structure causes them to let down their guard and become ignorant of the risk that the weak structure might pose .
Besides that , the NLC's design engineers ignored its failed risk assessment and continued to proceed with the blueprint without revealing the actual data to LTA (IES , 2005) .
This behavior is considered dishonest and immoral .
This is because NLC would want to complete their job within schedule  to avoid paying penalties to LTA (IES , 2005) .
Thus the over-eagerness and the time pressure exerted on them often lead to short-cuts and worsened the failure further (Wilpert .B , 2007) .
Lastly , the opposing party argues that all workers involved in this project had a strong sense of safety culture since it is compulsory to attend the Construction Safety Orientation Course (CSOC) before commencement of any construction work (MOM .Compulsory , 2007) .
Therefore the opponents emphasize that the failure was not due to the inadequate knowledge about the safety aspect but the failure of the technical aspect .
Although they had attended the CSOC , there were dysfunctional relations within the organization (Wilpert .B , 2007) .
The incapable the project management team failed to address the warning signs present in the early stage and implement corrective measures .
Thus , the failure was further aggravated .
Hence , the negligence and breaching of the project management team statutory duties indeed caused the collapse (MOM .Committe , 2007) .
In conclusion , one would realize the collapse of the Nicoll Highway is mainly due to human errors rather than the technical aspects .
Nevertheless , one would also recognize that failure of the technical aspect is due to the presence of human errors .
which is important in all human endeavors .
Thus , having certain knowledge about it will definitely aid in the understanding of human behavior and the reasons  why human makes mistakes .
As a result , it is vital to implement psychology in the design stage so to prevent the occurrence of any catastrophic accident .
